title: A Few Visit Steinbrenners Grave, but No Sign of Yankees
description: TRINITY, Fla.  The Bosss final resting place looked as neat and pressed as Yankee pinstripes. No flower bouquets, no gaudy makeshift shrines. Only a lone Rawlings baseball resting at the entrance to his mausoleum.

title: Town Elbows Its Way Into Clinton Wedding
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y.  Bill and Hillary Clinton have tried to shield their daughter, Chelsea, from the gaze of the public for most of her life.

title: Families Fear Phone Call From Mexicos Cartels
description: T was lucky he heard his cellphone ring over the racket of his construction equipment as he worked outside in the suburbs last September. We have your father, said a man in a voice T recalled as eerily calm. Try to get the money together as soon as you can so that your dad can be freed.

title: Mrquez Is Closer to Joining Red Bulls
description: The Red Bulls second designated player, Thierry Henry, was scheduled to make his debut in Major League Soccer on Saturday night in Houston while the man who is expected to soon become the clubs third high-priced import, Rafael Mrquez, was released from his contract with Barcelona earlier in the day.

title: To Help Democrats in the Fall, Obama May Stay Away
description: WASHINGTON  As lunch was served in the Roosevelt Room of the White House one day last week, President Obama assured the nine Democratic members of Congress sitting around the table that he would do anything he could to help them survive their fall elections.

title: Charging Station
description: Electric cars are not clogging local streets yet, but auto industry analysts expect California to be the largest market for electric vehicles in the United States. An infrastructure for charging the vehicles is being built in places like the parking lot of the Amtrak station in Martinez.

title: Whatever the Verdicts, Blagojevich Trial Hasnt Answered All the Questions
description: As Rod Blagojevichs lawyer declared to the jury in his closing argument last week, Think about it. He wanted jurors to consider what he thinks is self-evident about his clients innocence.

title: Age and the Demands of Managing
description: Lou Piniella turns 67 next month. Last week he decided that 23 years managing five big-league teams was enough, and he told the Cubs he would be stepping down and heading home to Tampa after the season.

title: After Development Plan Fails, the Accusations Fly
description: Alameda, an island long resistant to growth, threw a warm embrace around an unlikely suitor last year. The Southern California developer SunCal Companies proposed to build thousands of homes, sports fields, offices and a ferry terminal on 770 acres of a decommissioned naval base.

title: In Series of Trades, Yanks Take Another Shot at Firming Up Weak Spots
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  As Manager Joe Girardi was walking toward the Yankees clubhouse after Thursdays game in Cleveland, he spotted a former teammate.

title: Mets Remain the Same, but That Could Change
description: For many teams, Saturday was a time to evaluate the deals at the nonwaiver trading deadline and to look ahead with optimism to the final third of the season, which could include pennant races and the playoffs.

title: Family Is Selling Huntington Hotel, Nob Hill Fixture, but Allure Is Faded
description: John J. Copes father may have been known as the high-living nabob of Nob Hill, but Mr. Cope, who runs his familys Huntington Hotel, is clearly eager to move on.

title: Alabama Shrimping Opens Late and Starts Slow
description: For the Skinner family, the official opening to the shrimping season was as slow as expected. Gary Skinner had to purchase shrimp from Florida and his sons, who do the fishing for the store, hope the season turns around later this month.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 1
description: Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, appears on CBSs Face the Nation and NBCs Meet the Press this Sunday, one week after the release of thousands of leaked documents detailing the war in Afghanistan.

title: Far Away From Cellar, Padres Top the Buyers
description: Before the season, conventional wisdom said the San Diego Padres would be active leading to the nonwaiver trading deadline. The wisdom was correct, but in a way few people expected.

title: For Roethlisberger, Feelings of Anxiety Fade With the Sound of Cheers
description: LATROBE, Pa.  By the end of the day, Ben Roethlisberger stood in his stocking feet, still signing autographs long after he had given away his shoes to fans. Saturdays practice had been a success  the fans cheered, his passes were caught, his escape into his comfort zone complete. But hours earlier, when he stood behind the smoked-glass doors, waiting to take what might have been a very long walk to practice past a gantlet of those fans, Roethlisberger felt the familiar first-day-of-camp butterflies for very unfamiliar reasons.

title: Oh, Please. Its the Tour! A Grueling Event for All Involved
description: Sitting on the high-speed train from Bordeaux to Paris last Sunday, the final day of the Tour de France, I never saw the sharp-edged and evidently heavy suitcase perched precariously above me.

title: Robert C. Tucker, a Scholar of Marx, Stalin and Soviet Affairs, Dies at 92
description: Robert C. Tucker, a distinguished Sovietologist whose frustrations in persuading the authorities in Stalins Russia to let his new Russian wife accompany him home to the United States gave him crucial and influential insights into the Soviet leader, died Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 92.

title: Erich Steidtmann, Ex-Nazi Officer in Inquiry, Dies at 95
description: Three months after German prosecutors reopened an investigation into whether he had participated in massacres of thousands of Polish Jews  an investigation he inadvertently instigated  Erich Steidtmann, a former Nazi officer, died last Sunday in Hanover, Germany. He was 95.

title: Reader Comments on Medical Abortion
description: My Sunday column is about pharmaceutical breakthroughs  particularly misoprostol  in the provision of safe abortion. In the United States and Europe, abortion is safe, but five-sixths of abortions take place in the developing world where the procedure is often highly unsafe. As I write in the column, misoprostol may change that, and itll be very difficult for governments to prevent this revolution.

title: For Pocono, Solar Power and Safety Improvements
description: LONG POND, Pa.  Doc Mattioli is 85 and does not get around his racetrack in the mountains quite as well as he used to. Even 10 years ago, he would hop into a bulldozer to take care of a rough spot. Now he must use a wheelchair, and his once-booming voice seems several decibels softer.

title: John R. Branca, Advocate for Boxers, Dies at 86
description: John R. Branca, a former legislator who worked to enhance the safety of fighters in the boxing ring as the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, died July 17 in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 86 and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Alex Rodriguez was onto something Saturday night when he said its probably going to take a while for him to hit his 600th career homer. It seemed unlikely to happen on Sunday, when Rodriguez was held out of the lineup for the Yankees series finale with the Rays. He had played the last 13 games, and Manager Joe Girardi felt Rodriguez could use a break from the Tropicana Field turf.

title: Miss Daisy Gets a Son: Boyd Gaines
description: Boyd Gaines (The Grand Manner, Gypsy) will round out the three-member cast of the coming Broadway production of Alfred Uhrys play Driving Miss Daisy, joining Vanessa Redgrave and James Earl Jones. Mr. Gaines will play Boolie Werthan, who hires Hoke (Mr. Jones) as a chauffeur for his mother, Daisy (Ms. Redgrave). (Dan Aykroyd played Boolie in the film version of Driving Miss Daisy.) Mr. Gaines is the recipient of four Tony Awards for acting, most recently for the latest revival of Gypsy (starring Patti LuPone); he also earned Tonys for Contact, She Loves Me and The Heidi Chronicles. The Broadway production of Mr. Uhrys play  its first, having had its premiere Off Broadway in 1987  is scheduled to begin 16 weeks of performances on Oct. 7. David Esbjornson will direct.

title: Inception Continues Its Juggernaut
description: In the spring Hollywood was snickering that Inception was nothing more than an expensive vanity project, a movie that Warner Brothers allowed the director Christopher Nolan to make because The Dark Knight was so successful. But whos laughing now? Inception, starring Leonardo DiCaprio (above left, with Joseph Gordon-Levitt), was No. 1 at North American theaters for the third week in a row with an estimated $27.5 million in ticket sales, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. It has sold a cumulative $193.4 million in North America, making it one of the biggest nonanimated hits of the year. Dinner for Schmucks, a comedy from Paramount Pictures and DreamWorks Studios, was a soft second with about $23.3 million. That film, which stars Steve Carell, must now hope to replicate the pattern of Date Night, Mr. Carells last comedy, which opened with a so-so $25 million but managed to take in about $100 million before its run was over. Angelina Jolies Salt (Columbia Pictures) was third with about $19.3 million, for a new domestic total of $70.8 million. Despicable Me, the animated blockbuster from Universal Studios, sold another $15.5 million for fourth place and a new total of $190.3 million. A whimsical marketing campaign for Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (Warner Brothers) couldnt overcome deadly reviews, and it opened in fifth place with $12.5 million. Also disappointing was Zac Efron and Universals Charlie St. Cloud, which was sixth in its first weekend with $12.1 million, proving that young actor does not yet have the ability to anchor a major release.

description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees will not return to Tropicana Field for six weeks, so the Tampa Bay Rays gave them a parting gift Sunday to tide them over. It came in the form of a 3-0 victory that further reminded the Yankees, as if they needed it, that the standings in the American League East do not figure to change much before their next visit, in mid-September.

title: Another Star for New Law & Order
description: Though the original Law & Order television series ended in May, another spinoff, Law & Order: Los Angeles, is breathing new life into the franchise. On top of the already announced casting of Alfred Molina, the Oscar-nominated actor Terrence Howard, left, has been cast as a deputy district attorney, the shows creator Dick Wolf told the Television Critics Association on Friday, The Associated Press reported. Corey Stoll (Salt) also joins the cast as partner to the detective played by Skeet Ulrich, best known for his work in the Scream movie franchise. Further casting and details on the new characters have yet to be announced. The show is set to have its premiere in the fall.

description: President Obama soaked up some WNBA action Sunday at the Verizon Center in Washington, where the Washington Mystics took on the Tulsa Shock.

title: Entertaining the Troops With Touring Writers
description: Remember the old U.S.O. days of Marilyn Monroe and Bob Hope? Well, todays U.S.O. is turning to literature to entertain the troops. Representatives of the U.S.O., a nonprofit group that provides morale and recreational services to members of the military, have announced the start of Operation Thriller, a weeklong tour in the Persian Gulf this fall by five professional thriller writers. The authors scheduled to participate are Steve Berry (The Paris Vendetta), David Morrell (First Blood), Douglas Preston (Relic), James Rollins (Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull) and Andy Harp (A Northern Thunder). The tour begins in Washington, where the writers will visit troops at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center and National Naval Medical Center. Exact dates and locations will not be released because of security concerns.

title: Cosmos: Twice in a Lifetime?
description: The title of the film about the worlds most famous defunct soccer team was Once in a Lifetime.

title: Nacho Duato Joins Mikhailovsky Ballet
description: After the Spanish choreographer Nacho Duato announced in April that he was retiring as artistic director of the Compaa Nacional de Danza in Madrid, it seemed he would be without a dance home. Now Agence France-Presse reports that Mr. Duato will lead the Mikhailovsky Ballet of St. Petersburg, beginning Jan. 1, 2011. I will start working in St. Petersburg with energy and enthusiasm, Mr. Duato was quoted as saying. It is a challenge for me. He has said that after 20 years at the Madrid company, he and administrators had a falling out over the troupes direction.

title: Philosophy and Faith
description: One of my jobs as a teacher of bright, mostly Catholic undergraduates is to get them thinking about why they hold their religious beliefs. Its easy enough to spark discussion about the problem of evil (Can you really read the newspaper every day and continue to believe in an all-perfect God?) or about the diversity of religious beliefs (If youd been born in Saudi Arabia, dont you think youd be a Muslim?). Inevitably, however, the discussion starts to fizzle when someone raises a hand and says (sometimes ardently, sometimes smugly) But arent you forgetting about faith?

title: Double Dostoevsky at Baryshnikov Center
description: Two productions based on works by Dostoevsky will help to round out the Baryshnikov Arts Centers new season of dance, music and theater, the center announced. The Theater Art Studio in Moscow brings The Boys, a reworking of The Brothers Karamazov, to the center for its United States premiere, Oct. 6 to 10. In association with Theater for a New Audience, the center will present Yale Repertory Theaters Notes From Underground, the director Robert Woodruffs adaptation of Dostoevskys first-person novella, Nov. 7 to 20. Other season highlights will include performances by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and the Australian dancer and choreographer Russell Dumas, as well as a collaboration between the pianist Eteri Andjaparidze and the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton, exploring the connections between chords and colors in their piece Spectral Scriabin. The centers chamber music series, the Movado Hour, continues with performances throughout the season, which begins Sept. 9. Tickets for all events go on sale Aug. 30; (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com.

title: Aileys New Season: Revelations at 50
description: A celebration of the 50th anniversary of the seminal Revelations (above, with Antonio Douthit and Akua Parker) will be among the highlights of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters 2010 season at City Center, the company announced. The season, which runs from Dec. 1 through Jan. 2, will feature special performances of this piece, choreographed by Ailey and first performed in 1960. The season, which will be Judith Jamisons last as artistic director, includes nine premieres, including a world premiere by Christopher Huggins, a former company member, and company premieres by Camille A. Brown and by Robert Battle, who will be taking over as artistic director. The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra with Wynton Marsalis will join the company for one week during the season for a program titled, Ailey/Jazz, which will include the first full production in over 30 years of Three Black Kings, a collaboration between Ailey and Duke Ellington. The season will conclude with a tribute to Ms. Jamison on Jan. 2 featuring guest artists.

Dr. Ransom has now chased heroically through three of Mr. Reichs feverish espionage novels, working medical miracles while thwarting terrorist attacks. He is capable of brooking no retort while holding up his end of a conversation.

title: A Nietzschean Plunge Into Sensual Labyrinths

The operas that hooked him as a child were concoctions like Mozarts Zauberflte, with its ladies from the beyond, ghostly queen, mysterious guards and magic bells. That is opera, he said in an interview for the program book of this summers Salzburg Festival.

title: Blog Meta
description: One thing readers may not realize is that although this blog is located at the New York Times, its essentially a personal not-for-pay venture. Three answers based on the straightforward phrases THE SPEED OF LIGHT, THE SOUND OF MUSIC and THE COLOR OF MONEY would be bland. Simply by spinning the dial on the last words so they dont match up properly, a new constructor, Diane Baker van Hoff, ups the ante with unexpected interconnectedness.

One was the crisp, enterprising gospel-turned-pop that found its biggest audience on Motown Records. The other was a cantankerous streak that runs from Detroit blues through the citys proto-punk and garage-rock, and arguably into the combative hip-hop of Eminem. Through afternoon and evening shows, craftsmanship and commotion kept recombining.

title: Sympathy For Mira Sorvino
description: Heres an exercise: Read Sam Andersons profile of James Franco for New York Magazine. Then go back and read Andrew Corsellos 1996 profile of Mira Sorvino for GQ. Both are essays about highly-cerebral, possibly-overeducated celebrity actors whose peculiar personae are more interesting than any of the movies theyve made. Both are the work of extremely skillful and engaging writers. But Andersons profile is an exercise in rueful wonderment, whereas Corsellos profile is a brutal takedown. Francos intellectual pretentions are celebrated and his eccentricities are smiled upon; Sorvinos intellectual ambitions are used against her and her eccentricities mercilessly mocked. Anderson goes out of his way to insist that Francos academic work is legitimate; Corsello makes fun of Sorvino for talking about her honors thesis. Anderson takes a rueful attitude toward the gulf between Francos ambitions and his actual body of work; Corsello has a good time making fun of Romy and Michelles High School Reunion. And so forth.

title: Film Company to Appeal Rating of Holocaust Documentary
description: Oscilloscope Laboratories said it planned to appeal an R rating assigned by the Classification and Rating Administration to the Holocaust documentary A Film Unfinished. The documentary, which screened at the Sundance Film Festival this year, dissects a Nazi propaganda film that was shot in the Warsaw Ghetto in 1942. In assigning an R rating, which requires viewers under the age of 17 to be accompanied by an adult, the ratings board cited disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities including graphic nudity. Adam Yauch, an owner of Oscilloscope and its Oscilloscope Pictures operation, said the proposed rating would block use of the film as an educational tool. This is too important of a historical document to ban from classrooms, Mr. Yauch said in a statement on Monday. A Film Unfinished is to open in New York on Aug. 18, and two days later in Los Angeles, before a planned national release.

description: Five years after Islamic charities with ties to militant groups aided victims of a deadly earthquake in Pakistan, earning good will as the countrys government struggled to respond, reports suggest that the same scenario may be unfolding again.

title: Taking Over a Tree to Save Community Gardens
description: A woman dressed as a sunflower climbed more than 20 feet into a tree in City Hall Park on Monday morning and said she would not come down unless the city agreed to make all community gardens permanent. After a short period of time, however, she descended and was taken into custody by the police.

title: Pakistanis Anger Grows as Flood Damage Mounts
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The damage from Pakistans worst floods in generations mounted on Monday as rescue operations continued and public fury rose in the countrys most volatile province.

title: Feeding Dementia Patients With Dignity
description: First Alzheimers disease stole Rosemary DeFelices speech, mobility and independence. Then, at 75, she lost the ability to eat.

title: Screening: Cholesterol Checks for Young Adults
description: Young adults tend to be notoriously lax about preventive health care, and cholesterol screening is no exception. Barely half of all young men and women are screened for high LDL, the so-called bad cholesterol, a new study has found.

title: Be Sure Exercise Is All You Get at the Gym
description: When you go to the gym, do you wash your hands before and after using the equipment? Bring your own regularly cleaned mat for floor exercises? Shower with antibacterial soap and put on clean clothes immediately after your workout? Use only your own towels, razors, bar soap, water bottles?

title: Avoiding Germs at the Gym
description: In the latest Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores the dermatological perils lurking on exercise equipment, and in health club showers and locker rooms.

title: Patients Want Patent Broken on Genzyme Drug
description: Updated: Three patients with a rare genetic disease are asking the federal government to abrogate the exclusive patent rights held by the biotechnology company Genzyme on the only drug now approved to treat the illness.

title: Childbirth: Respiratory Distress in Premature Infants
description: Babies born six weeks prematurely are 40 times as likely as full-term infants to suffer respiratory distress syndrome, a new study reports.

title: Justice Is Blind, but Its Nose Rules for the Plaintiff
description: Nineteen pages into a ruling on an insurance case, a federal judge did not actually declare that the defendants claim  that odors from a restaurant should be considered pollution  stank. The way Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald put it was, that argument was malodorous to this court.

title: Justin Bieber, 16, 2 Write Memoir
description: If anything can turn young people on to reading, it might be a memoir by the teenage pop superstar Justin Bieber, below. In October HarperCollins will release Justin Bieber: First Step 2 Forever: My Story, the publisher announced on Monday. Between the behind-the-scenes pictures and the story, I think this is going to be something they can all enjoy, Mr. Bieber, 16, said in a statement. This is just another way for me to say thank you to my fans. HarperCollins described the book as an illustrated memoir that will detail Mr. Biebers rise to stardom, complemented by exclusive photos  a must-have for fans afflicted with Bieber-fever. All kidding aside, predicted Publishers Weekly, its going to sell a million-billion copies.

title: Lindsay Lohan Out of Jail, Into Rehab
description: On her previous trip to the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif., in 2007, Lindsay Lohan was incarcerated for just under 90 minutes after arrests for drunken driving and cocaine possession. On a return visit, she was there only slightly longer: The Associated Press reported that Ms. Lohan, the 24-year-old Mean Girls and Freaky Friday star, was released from the jail on Monday at 1:35 a.m. Pacific time, having been jailed for less than two weeks of a 90-day sentence for violating the terms of her probation. The A.P. said Ms. Lohan would have to fulfill the rest of her sentence at a rehabilitation center. On July 20 she surrendered herself in the Beverly Hills courtroom of Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court, having missed a May parole hearing stemming from the 2007 arrests and after a court-ordered monitoring device detected the presence of alcohol.

title: Want Instant Replay in Baseball? Try the Little League World Series
description: Little League World Series officials announced Monday that their instant replay system  in place for the past two years to cover mostly home runs or other close outfield-fence calls  would be expanded this year and managers would be allowed to challenge calls on forceouts, tags, missed bases and hit batsmen.

title: Boon for Broad Museum: Millions From Developers
description: The Los Angeles financier Eli Broad may get millions of dollars back on the $100 million museum he is planning to build as part of the Grand Avenue Project, a development of condos, cultural sites, stores, offices and a hotel in downtown Los Angeles. According to The Los Angeles Times, a deal approved last month by the Community Redevelopment Agency of Los Angeles calls for Mr. Broads museum to receive millions of dollars as the Grand Avenue Project moves forward. The redevelopment agency requires developers  in this case Related Companies  to pay 1 percent of their projects design and construction costs to create public artworks or support cultural sites in the neighborhood where they build. The deal, which was approved on July 15, includes the Broad Collection at Grand Avenue and Second Street as the cultural site that will fulfill a large part of Related Companies percent-for-art obligation. If the Grand Avenue Project costs its estimated $3 billion, the 1 percent requirement would generate $30 million for arts and culture, and Mr. Broads museum would receive about a third of that under the plan approved last month.

title: From Allies to Rivals to Allies in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  It is the political relationship that has long mystified Indonesias chattering classes, one whose ups and downs regularly send tremors throughout the capital, and one whose future is intricately tied to this countrys.

title: Oscilloscope Appealing Film Unfinished Rating
description: Oscilloscope Laboratories said it planned to appeal an R rating assigned by the Classification and Rating Administration to the Holocaust documentary A Film Unfinished (a scene, above). The documentary, which screened at the Sundance Film Festival this year, dissects a Nazi propaganda film that was shot in the Warsaw Ghetto in 1942. In assigning an R rating, which requires viewers under the age of 17 to be accompanied by an adult, the ratings board cited disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities, including graphic nudity. Adam Yauch, an owner of Oscilloscope and its Oscilloscope Pictures operation, said the proposed rating would block use of the film as an educational tool. This is too important of a historical document to ban from classrooms, Mr. Yauch said in a statement on Monday. A Film Unfinished is to open in New York on Aug. 18, and two days later in Los Angeles, before a planned national release.

title: Bush to Promote Book in NBC Interviews
description: Former President George W. Bushs first one-on-one television interview in nearly two years will take place on NBC in early November, the network said on Monday. Matt Lauer will interview Mr. Bush on a prime-time broadcast on Nov. 8, one day before Mr. Bushs book, Decision Points, is to be released by Crown Publishers. Mr. Lauer will also interview Mr. Bush live on the Today show, the countrys highest-rated morning show, on Nov. 10. The meetings will probably garner wide attention, given that Mr. Bush has largely stayed out of the public eye since leaving office in January 2009. He has a family connection to the Today show: his daughter Jenna Bush Hager has been a contributing correspondent since last year.

title: 60 Minutes Supreme
description: Big Brother helped lift CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday night, while the CBS newsmagazine 60 Minutes delivered the largest audience in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates, 7.8 million viewers tuned in at 7 for CBSs 60 Minutes. Big Brother finished close behind at 8, with 7.1 million viewers, while reruns of Undercover Boss (6 million) and The Good Wife (4.1 million) helped CBS maintain a strong enough average for the night, outperforming new episodes of ABCs Scoundrels at 9 (3.2 million) and The Gates at 10 (2.8 million). ABC was second, boosted by solid ratings for a repeat of Americas Funniest Home Videos at 7 (6.2 million). NBC was third, and Fox ranked fourth with reruns of its comedy lineup.

title: Royal Shakespeare Companys New York Slate
description: King Lear and Antony and Cleopatra, two Shakespeare plays not frequently produced in New York City, will be among the five productions that the Royal Shakespeare Company will mount at the Lincoln Center Festival next summer, the organizers announced on Monday. The other plays will be As You Like It, Romeo and Juliet and The Winters Tale. Actors in the companys 44-member ensemble will play various roles in the productions, with 7 to 10 performances scheduled for each piece. The entire run, July 6 to Aug. 14, will be at the Park Avenue Armory on a thrust stage (with seats on three sides) that the Royal Shakespeare Company is building now to the specifications of its Courtyard Theater in Stratford-upon-Avon. All five plays are currently running at the companys home base in England. Among the lead actors will be the veteran company member Greg Hicks  playing two mad kings, Lear and Leontes in The Winters Tale  and Kathryn Hunter, who will play Cleopatra and the Fool in Lear. (Above, Mr. Hicks and Ms. Hunter in Lear.) The timing for ticket sales to the public is to be announced in the fall.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: The struggle against time and nature continues in northwest Pakistan, where the worst monsoon rains in the countrys history have left soldiers and emergency workers fighting to reach those threatened by rising waters.

title: A Snapshot of a Generation May Come Out Blurry
description: Trying to pin down the character of a generation is a controversial and, some say, presumptuous exercise. Whos to say whether 50 million Americans should be called the Me Generation, or the Greatest? Whos to decide exactly when Gen X ends and Gen Y begins?

title: Is Every Generation Self-Absorbed?
description: The latest Mind column by Benedict Carey explores a fascinating debate about the psychological traits of Generation Y, the current crop of 20- and 30-year-olds who are often described as self-absorbed and narcissistic.

title: Not on the Doctors Checklist, but Touch Matters
description: A new patient comes to my office, a healthy middle-aged woman. The medical assistant has already documented her normal blood pressure. Of our allotted 15 minutes, I spend more than two-thirds talking with her.

title: Africa: In a Meningitis Hotbed, a New Vaccine at a Price Governments Can Afford
description: In Africas meningitis belt  25 countries along the bottom edge of the Sahara from Senegal to Ethiopia  epidemics arrive with the dry harmattan winds in March. In the worst years, meningitis has killed more than 25,000 people and left thousands more deaf or retarded.

title: Mahler and Strauss Keep Conductors (but Not Levine) Busy
description: LENOX, Mass.  This was to have been another weekend of hectic triumph for James Levine here at the Tanglewood Festival, in what increasingly emerges as a ridiculously overcrowded schedule for someone in dubious health.

description: URUMQI, China  For a street whose name suggests throwing off shackles, South Liberation Road doesnt look like a very free place these days.

Its as if American Ballet Theaters two-month Metropolitan Opera House season were compressed into three weeks.

description: A large part of human milk cannot be digested by babies and seems to have a purpose quite different from infant nutrition  that of influencing the composition of the bacteria in the infants gut.

They came from Soldier, by Ingrid Michaelson, the soundtrack-friendly folkie from Staten Island, and they encapsulated the Lilith worldview established during the tours initial run from 1997 to 1999: direct, empowered, emotive, a little sullen.

description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  Facing eviction from her Tennessee apartment after several months of unpaid rent, Alexandra Jarrin packed up whatever she could fit into her two-door coupe recently and drove out of town.

title: World War II Still Shapes Atolls Ecosystem
description: I often wonder what life was like for military personnel who served on Palmyra Atoll during World War II. We see ghosts of their activities  whether abandoned buildings and ancient, odd-shaped light bulbs or structural changes to the islets and the lagoon.The military occupation there was brief, but the effects, like causeways built across the waterways, are long lasting. Some of the modifications cut off the flow of water and turned the lagoons into warm, silty bathwater, which influences what can grow and live there.

title: King Tuts Chariot Arrives in Times Square
description: As 18th-Dynasty pharaohs chariots go, the one that arrived in Times Square on Friday night was not a Mercedes or a Bentley. There was no gold leaf or fine animal-fur interior or richly appointed cartouche-ing. It was more like a teenagers dragster stripped down for speed, just a lightweight frame of tamarisk, elm and birch, missing only its two-horsepower engine.

description: Although July fell just short of being the hottest month in New York City history, it did set a record for energy consumption.

title: A Different Side of Barber, in Songs and Piano Work

This year Chopin and Schumann, both born 200 years ago, have attracted widespread attention; among the worthy figures overshadowed is the American composer Samuel Barber, born in 1910.

title: A Footnote Gets His Spotlight at Last
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  Among worldly Europeans during the early decades of the 20th century, the Austrian composer Franz Schreker was a heroic figure, a worthy successor to Wagner and Strauss. To the Nazis, Schreker, the son of a Jewish father, was a degenerate pornographer to be censured and shunned. For Americans he became an obscure footnote, a formidable artist whose works never reached the New World.

The Unisphere is a Queens landmark; Im embarrassed to admit that this was my first view of it.

title: Critics Picks Video: Foreign Correspondent
description: Is the person best suited to deal with a crisis someone who knows very little about it and cares even less? A. O. Scott seeks the answer to this question in this weeks pick, Foreign Correspondent. Alfred Hitchcocks 1940 film centers on an American reporter Joel McCrea sent to Europe on the brink of World War II. For a movie about characters caught up in a global catastrophe, Mr. Scott says it is a lot of fun. But its never simply escapist. Have you seen Foreign Correspondent? Please share your thoughts.

title: Connecting Brains to the Outside World
description: About four years ago, John Donoghues son, Jacob, then 18, took his father aside and declared, Dad, I now understand what you do  youre The Matrix! Dr. Donoghue, 61, is a professor of engineering and neuroscience at Brown University, studying how human brain signals could combine with modern electronics to help paralyzed people gain greater control over their environments. Hes designed a machine, the BrainGate, that uses thought to move objects. We spoke for two hours in his Brown University offices in Providence, R.I., and then again by telephone. description: Thats the subject taken up in an American Spectator symposium, which is divided, roughly speaking, between writers who think the Republicans have become serious about limited government again and writers who think they havent. Not surprisingly, I incline toward the latter camp: There may be specific Republicans (a Paul Ryan, a Chris Christie, a Mitch Daniels) who are committed to spending restraint in practice as well as theory, but the party as a whole is still more eager to posture about earmarks than to wrestle with entitlements. Most Republicans talk a good game about Americas looming fiscal crisis, but then dance away when the subjects turns to what, specifically, they want to do about it.

But now that Dick Wolfs Law & Order has called it a day  or rather a 20-year run  it is time to notice what may be its most remarkable feature; not the brilliant formula that offers both the comfort of predictability and the promise of constant surprise (an episode almost never ends up where it seems to be going at the beginning), not the ability of the show to survive major cast changes without missing a beat, not the considerable accomplishment of making the arcane vocabulary of the law ( fruit of the poisonous tree, asked and answered, prejudicial, allocute, goes to relevance) as familiar to TV viewers as the jargon of sports, but the extraordinarily long list of professions, classes and category of persons it doesnt like.

title: Return Engagement | Camelot
description: In an extreme case of camel coat envy, a frustrated New York socialite who had long fetishized the trench coat Ali MacGraw wore in Love Story engaged a patternmaker last year to copy it in caramel cashmere, down to the patch pockets and double-wide lapel and collar (which, like MacGraws character, Jenny, you gotta wear popped). From Paris to New York, from Kate Moss to Blake Lively (who seem to be as attached to their fawn-colored coats as Grace Kelly and Katharine Hepburn were to theirs), camel is dans lair this fall. Clines Phoebe Philo jump-started the trend last spring with the ultimate boyfriend coat, a honey-toned Crombie. Jean Paul Gaultier  in his penultimate, fall collection for Herms  showed a three-quarter camel coat pinched from the guys, saving his most luxurious discursion for duffel coats like the ones once worn by the British Royal Navy. Michael Kors imagined a gender mix-up at the coat check, or maybe that blushingly erotic moment when a gentleman slips his camel coat over his dates chilly shoulders. If its all beginning to sound like a male conspiracy, well, a lot of womens outerwear in the buff register does lead back to the blokes. Think of the peacoat  and the polo coat. Around 1900, polo players began wrapping themselves in camel wait coats  patterned, essentially, on a dressing gown  to keep warm between chukkers. Later, women borrowed freely of the details: half belt, full cut, chest pocket. In 1949 the camel coat was the American coeds favorite. Kors made winking reference to all that history, pairing a great big muff of a fur skirt with a camel knit tee. Among the other camel offerings were satin blouses and high-waisted slacks (Chlo), even a strapless dress (Gianfranco Ferr). But in the end, it was the camel coat that scored, whether sable-trimmed at Carolina Herrera or sleeveless at Alexander Wang. A real love story.

title: When (and Why) Adoption Goes Awry
description: Visions of a loving family  two young children who lived in foster homes for years, given a new start with parents who were determined to give them a better life. It started out well  with newly painted rooms, closets full of new clothes, a new school, new toys and a big sister. Then came months of discipline problems, lack of attachment, violence, stealing, lying and fear.

title: That Cafeteria Cheese Steak Might Be Antibiotic-Free
description: When I went off to college, I didnt give much thought to the food. I had always been more interested in hot dogs and corn than any of the dishes my mom lovingly prepared each night for our family. So, college dining was hardly forefront on my list of concerns.

title: Cadillac Escalade Tops Theft List
description: Cadillac Escalade owners, watch out. Among vehicles bought between one and three years ago, Escalades are most preferred by thieves, according to new information released by the Highway Loss Data Institute.

title: Samurai Shopper | Bosom Buddies
description: In 1913, the provocateur Marcel Duchamp created a ruckus at the New York Armory Show with his Nude Descending a Staircase (No. 2). The painting didnt go down well; apparently nudes dont use staircases, theyre busy lolling on divans or dancing with seven veils. Looking at Nude today (in the Philadelphia Museum of Art), the Samurai Shopper sees nothing R-rated, just a fractured maze of lines and planes. Whats naked is Duchamps ambition to shock the stuffed shirts.

title: Most Carmakers Report Higher Sales
description: DETROIT  A year ago, Americans were dumping their pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles by the hundreds of thousands, enticed by government rebates to drive something more fuel-efficient.

title: Inception to Materialize in China
description: Having topped the United Space box office list, burned out brain cells and tied up Twitter feeds for the past three weeks, the Christopher Nolan mind caper Inception has earned another rare distinction: it will be one of only 20 foreign-made blockbusters that China will allow to be shown at its movie theaters this year, The Associated Press reported. The government-owned China Film Group told The A.P. that Inception will be one of the few non-domestically produced films that it annually imports and for which it shares ticket revenues with the studio that produced it. (The company also buys smaller foreign films for flat fees.)

title: A Place of Final Rest Changes Hands
description: Soon, grave sites at the Canarsie Cemetery will be for sale again.

title: At U. of Iowa, Recruitment Success Has Its Perils
description: IOWA CITY  Like an airline overselling a flight, the University of Iowa extended admission this year to several thousand more applicants than it could accommodate on campus in this falls freshman class.

title: Stuck on 599 Laughs
description: Todays challenge is trying to pick which occasion best signals that we have hit some sort of cosmic low for summer sports silliness. The first is trying to count where we are in Alex Rodriguezs tortured quest for home run No. 600 (officially, 11 games, 43 at-bats, 527 A-Rod face crinkles). The second is counting the number of cameras pointed at Jets Coach Rex Ryans stomach at training camp, which are trying to detect some sign that he actually had weight-loss surgery. And the third is the ridiculous standoff over the Redskins Albert Haynesworths inability to pull his ample midsection through a conditioning test.

title: An Alternative to the Feeding Tube
description: The Times reports today on a new option in palliative care called comfort feeding only.

description: Update | April 25, 2013  We now have an all-new version of this post, updated for the new movie with teaching ideas as well as both the resources below and many new ones. Find it here.

title: Video Stirs Debate on French Police Tactics Against Immigrant Protesters
description: Far from Arizona, the rights a government may owe to immigrants even as they resist the states authority are being debated in France, after the release of video showing French riot police dragging African mothers away from a protest on the outskirts of Paris last month.

title: A Crowded Freshman Class at Iowa
description: In a piece just posted on The Timess Web site, I look at the incoming freshman class at the University of Iowa, which has several hundred more students than the admissions office anticipated.

title: Me and the Bond Market
description: Whenever I point out that bond markets are not, in fact, demanding immediate fiscal austerity, I get comments along the lines of So now you believe markets are perfect? Thats missing the point. The starting point for the argument people like me make is that markets shouldnt be demanding immediate austerity, because the long-run fiscal effects of short-run deficits are relatively small; the burden of proof is therefore on the other side to show that markets will demand something they shouldnt.

title: In Senate, Vote Nears on Kagan Nomination
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday opened debate on Elena Kagans nomination to the Supreme Court, with Democrats praising her as a sagacious legal mind and a refreshing choice from outside the usual ranks of federal judges and Republicans denouncing her as a liberal partisan who would bend the law to her political views.

title: FIFA Fines Spain and the Netherlands for Foul-Marred Final
description: Each time the referee Howard Webb reached into his pocket during the World Cup final last month in Johannesburg, it cost Spain and the Netherlands about $2,000. At the time, you probably didnt hear the kah-ching of an imaginary cash register, just your teams chances for winning its first World Cup title slipping away.

title: Cond Nast to Move to Skyscraper at Ground Zero
description: Cond Nasts decision in 1996 to move its headquarters, chic magazines and black-clad editors to Times Square proved to be a transformative moment for a still rough-and-tumble district shunned by many New Yorkers.

description: A birthday party scene in "The Saddest Boy in the World."

title: Dynamic Duo | Cocteau & Cartier
description: Jean Cocteau, best known for his graphic line drawings and Surrealist cinema, had a longstanding association with the jeweler Cartier that was best signified by his famously wearing two of its signature Trinity rings stacked on his left pinkie. Created in 1924, the three intertwined bands of pink, yellow and white gold have long been held as a symbol of love and worn by many a Cartier fan as an actual wedding band.

title: Research In Motion Brings the Torch to AT&T
description: At a press conference in downtown Manhattan on Tuesday, executives from AT&T and Research In Motion, makers of the BlackBerry line of smartphones, introduced the BlackBerry Torch, the companys first phone with both a touch screen and a slide-out keyboard.

title: Drought Strains Russian Wheat Supplies
description: Wheat prices in Europe reached a two-year high this week after Russian officials announced that extreme heat and drought had decimated roughly 20 percent of the countrys winter crop. Prices retreated slightly after the countrys Agriculture Ministry said that Russia, the worlds third-largest wheat exporter, would use its stocks to maintain exports.

title: State Police Official Transferred Over Domestic Dispute Scandal
description: The commander of Gov. David A. Patersons State Police security detail will be reassigned following an independent counsels report last week that raised questions about the officers conduct in a domestic dispute case involving one of Mr. Patersons top aides.

title: What Were Reading: Welcome to the Recovery
BP Sales Continue With Colombian Deal
description: BP made more progress in its multibillion-dollar asset sales on Tuesday, announcing a deal to sell its Colombian oil and gas exploration and production business to Ecopetrol and Talisman Energy for $1.9 billion in cash.

title: TimesCast | August 3, 2010
description: In today's Timescast, the latest on BP's efforts to permanently cap the well, the significance of the Newsweek sale and too many incoming freshmen at the University of Iowa.

title: Obama Signs Law Narrowing Cocaine Sentencing Disparities
description: President Obama signed legislation on Tuesday reducing longstanding federal sentencing disparities between those caught with crack and those arrested with powder cocaine, finalizing a bipartisan consensus addressing a racially polarizing law enforcement debate.

title: New Wonderland, With Familiar Pedigree, Is Coming to Broadway
description: Frank Wildhorn is about to take another leap down the rabbit hole of Broadway. After his big-budget musicals  including Jekyll and Hyde, The Civil War and The Scarlet Pimpernel  lost nearly $20 million on Broadway by the end of 2000, and a 2004 production, Dracula: The Musical, shut down after five months, Mr. Wildhorn, the composer, is readying a new work inspired by Lewis Carrolls Alices Adventures in Wonderland.

title: Millennium-Plus: A Stieg Larsson Boxed Set
description: Forget about that unpublished, almost-finished fourth manuscript. The next Stieg Larsson volume is a collection that includes essays about Mr. Larsson and e-mails between Mr. Larsson and his publisher, Eva Gedin. The volume, called On Stieg Larsson, will be released by Knopf as part of a boxed set including the best-selling Millennium trilogy, which began with The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, then was followed by The Girl Who Played With Fire and The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets Nest. According to Knopf, the new book will include an essay by John-Henri Holmberg, a member of the Swedish Crime Fiction Academy, placing Stieg Larsson in the context of the resurgence of Scandinavian crime writing, and an essay by Svante Weyler, the publishing director from Mr. Larssons publisher in Sweden, about the phenomenon surrounding Mr. Larsson. The boxed set, priced at $99, will go on sale the day after Thanksgiving  also known as the start of the holiday shopping season.

title: Fire and Water on a Hot, Turbulent Planet
description: The Earth Observatory Web site of NASA is a vital portal, not only providing data that help scientists clarify global conditions and trends but also reminding people, once in awhile, of the special nature of this pale blue (and green) dot.

title: BP Begins Static Kill, to Seal Well Permanently
description: HOUSTON  Engineers began pumping heavy drilling mud into BPs stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday with the hope of sealing the well permanently or at least revealing critical clues on how to kill it before the end of the month.

title: Robert F. Boyle, Film Designer for Hitchcock, Dies at 100
description: Robert F. Boyle, the eminent Hollywood production designer who created some of the most memorable scenes and images in cinematic history  Cary Grant clinging to Mount Rushmore in North by Northwest, the birds-eye view of the seagull attack in The Birds, the colorfully ramshackle shtetl for Fiddler on the Roof  died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 100.

title: Between Queens and Brooklyn, an Oil Spills Legacy
description: The salt marshes are long gone from Newtown Creek, and so are most of the birds and fish. Now, this waterway straddling Brooklyn and Queens is dotted by bulkheads and containment booms meant to keep oil away from the shoreline while underground pumps work around the clock removing petroleum from adjacent land.

title: Im With the Bland | Montreals Backstage Feast
description: One might think that rock bands are fed like kings backstage, but the reality is more like a tuna wrap and a bowl of M&Ms. This weekend at the Osheaga Festival in Montreal, however, the National, Arcade Fire, Beach House, Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros et al. were treated to a feast: the artists area was catered by Chuck Hughes, the chef at the citys Garde Manger restaurant and host of the Cooking Channels Chucks Day Off. Highlights on the menu  which I sampled as the guest of my husband, the Walkmens Walter Martin  included pulled-pork tacos, jerk crab, smoked chicken (cooked in a 50-foot smoker) and a poutine bar where guests could customize the classic Qubcois dish. Salads were made to order, with options including pea shoots snipped from the plant, golden beets, prosciutto and poached asparagus. Bands took advantage of the full raw bar with oysters shucked on the spot and scallops on the half shell. Beach House dug the smoothie station, and fried Mars bars were a hit as Arcade Fire was getting ready to play Saturday night. Meals are usually a to-be-avoided part of backstage life, but these bands lingered at picnic tables under twinkling lanterns. The vote was unanimous that this was the best catering ever.

title: Russian Billionaire Stands Firm on Norilsk Nickel
description: Oleg V. Deripaska, the chief executive of the big aluminum producer Rusal, said on Tuesday that his companys 25 percent stake in Norilsk Nickel was not for sale and denied reports that the Russian government was trying to push him to sell it to resolve a dispute with a fellow Russian billionaire.

title: Being There, Without Leaving Home
description: At the Selfhelp Benjamin Rosenthal Senior Center in Queens, a social worker, Rachel Itzkowitz, is leading the weekly current events class, guiding participants through a series of discussions. What did they think about that shooting at the Mexican border? About higher compensation for first responders injured on Sept. 11? And what about the controversy over building a Muslim community center near the World Trade Center site?

title: Stew Leonards Halts 14-Year Battle to Open Store in Connecticut Town
description: ORANGE, Conn.  The cornfield just off Interstate 95 in this town of 13,000 looks like any other in rural Connecticut. But hidden behind the rows of stalks are piles of steel girders. They were going to be the new store, said Stew Leonard Jr., whose father founded the Stew Leonards supermarket chain in Norwalk in 1969.

title: Kenya Stakes Reinvention on Constitution Vote
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Ever since independence in 1963, Kenya has been ruled by a winner-take-all political system that has exacerbated ethnic divisions and steadily turned the country into one of the most corrupt on the continent.

title: Afghan War Is Being Lost, Pakistani President Says

title: Mentor
description: The sun set at 4:30 p.m., frost glazed our lawn each morning, and while pumpkins still rested on our neighborhood's front porches I completed "Book One" of my novel. Instinctively, I knew I'd reached its midpoint. Its scope could no longer be enlarged, no characters added. Conflicts would now be resolved, not developed. As always, I'd tracked how much time I'd written, and how many words I'd produced daily in a small, gray-covered assignment pad. In seventy-two days I'd written one hundred and fifty-three pages. Of them, Frank had read only the chapter I'd put up in workshop. One night at the Mill, where we now regularly shared a table, I told him I was burning out. "So, take a break," he said. "Slow down." I received no other advice from him. But in a literary sense, I didn't need it. His presence was all that mattered.

title: A Writers Prayer, Halfway Answered
description: Every serious fiction writer, published or unpublished, has a pile of horror stories about trying to get his or her work out into the world. The funny ones are told in bars. The ones that arent funny  the ones that may never be funny  are told only to therapists or to the insides of medicine cabinets.

title: London Theater Journal: Pomp and Circumstance
description: I wasnt around for the coronation of Elizabeth II, and it seems unlikely Ill be invited to the crowning of her successor, should that day ever arrive. So I was delighted to be able to attend the ceremonies celebrating the ascension of one Anne Boleyn as the Queen of England. Such pomp, such circumstance. The gold canopy, the procession of ecclesiastics, the charming boys choir. And as for young Anne herself, well, that ultimate royal fashion plate Diana, Princess of Wales, might have envied the sumptuous, megatrain-bearing dress with which the second wife of King Henry VIII has been outfitted.

title: As Iraq Drawdown Nears, a Soldier Shares Hopes and Fears

Operation Iraqi Freedom will become Operation New Dawn. The change is meant to be symbolic of the new, more tacit role the United States will play in Iraqs evolving internal affairs.

title: Birdcalls and Other Sounds for Piano
description: Visions de lAmen (1943), Messiaens work for two pianos, is as prismatic and astounding in its way as his Quartet for the End of Time (1941), a glimpse of the apocalypse crystallized as a work for clarinet, violin, cello and piano. That the scoring of Visions is more monochromatic scarcely matters: Messiaen approached the piano not only with an organists sense of sonority but also with an imagination that drew on birdcalls, Asian music (and tuning systems) and recent innovations in Western harmony, as well as his own ideas about Roman Catholic mysticism.

But he also wants stiffer penalties for companies that violate the rules and a pack of FBI agents to investigate lawbreaking in offshore drilling  including any misdeeds inside his own agency.

title: Barnes & Noble Considers Selling Itself
description: 1:30 a.m. | Updated The New York Timess Julie Bosman has more:

title: Scholar Emerges From Doghouse
description: NEW HAVEN  On this hot summer day, Michael A. Bellesiles is sitting outside the abandoned red brick armory here. It is, he said, a much friendlier building than the one that occupied this spot in 1877. In the middle of what was then a working-class neighborhood northwest of Yale, the old Gothic armory, made of stone with no windows on the first floor, was meant to withstand the American precursor of a Molotov cocktail, he explained: It was a testament to middle-class fears.

title: Gibbs: Mosque by Ground Zero a Local Matter
description: President Obama, who made outreach to Muslims a central theme of his first year in office, has decided to sit out the national debate now raging over the plan to build a mosque near the site of Ground Zero in Lower Manhattan.

title: Irans Account of Womans Crime Shifting From Adultery to Murder
description: TEHRAN  Iran appears to be answering international criticism of its handling of the case of a woman sentenced to death by stoning by suggesting that she is guilty not only of adultery, but also of murder.

title: Senator Defends New Yorks New Short-Term Rental Ban
description: First Paris began cracking down on short-term vacation rentals. Now, travelers who use apartment-rental Web sites to find lodging in New York may have fewer places to choose from.

title: Singing Along With Mitch (and Johnny)
description: After I wrote a Big City column about Mitch Miller, the music impresario and television personality who died Saturday at age 99, dozens of people wrote to share their personal memories of the man and his recordings.

title: Charlie Sheen Sentenced
description: The actor Charlie Sheen, below, avoided jail time and was instead given a sentence on Monday by a Colorado judge that included 30 days in a rehabilitation center after pleading guilty to a misdemeanor third-degree assault on his wife, Brooke Mueller Sheen, The Associated Press reported. The charges faced by Mr. Sheen, a star of the CBS comedy Two and a Half Men, stemmed from a Christmas Day altercation in Aspen, Colo. Mr. Sheen was also sentenced to 30 days of probation and 36 hours of anger management counseling, and may not have to serve the 30 days in rehab, having already spent 93 days this year at a treatment center.

title: Millennium Plus: A Larsson Boxed Set
description: Forget about that unpublished, almost-finished fourth manuscript. The next Stieg Larsson volume is a collection that includes essays about Mr. Larsson, below, who died in 2004, and e-mails between him and his publisher, Eva Gedin. The volume, called On Stieg Larsson, will be released by Alfred A. Knopf as part of a boxed set including the best-selling Millennium trilogy, which began with The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo and was followed by The Girl Who Played With Fire and The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets Nest. According to Knopf, the new book will include, among other essays, one by John-Henri Holmberg, a member of the Swedish Crime Fiction Academy, that places Stieg Larsson in the context of the resurgence of Scandinavian crime writing. The set, priced at $99, will go on sale the day after Thanksgiving.

title: Glee Making Room for McCartney and Boyle
description: The second season of Glee will feature one of the most popular singing sensations to emerge from Britain  and the music of Paul McCartney, too. Ryan Murphy, a creator of the Fox musical comedy series, said at the Television Critics Association press tour on Monday that Susan Boyle, below, would appear in a coming episode of Glee and that Mr. McCartneys music would also be featured, Reuters reported. Mr. Murphy said that Ms. Boyle, the best-selling pop singer who was discovered on the reality series Britains Got Talent, would appear in a Christmas-theme episode of Glee; Reuters said she would play the (not-at-all-typecast) role of a high school lunch lady. The episode featuring Mr. McCartneys songs wasnt specified, but Mr. Murphy said he had been won over by a set of mix CDs Mr. McCartney sent to him. It came out of blue in a package, handwritten, and it had two CDs, and it said, Hi Ryan, I hope you will consider some of these songs for Glee, Mr. Murphy said, according to Reuters.

title: Broadway Wonderland
description: Frank Wildhorn is about to take another leap down the rabbit hole of Broadway. After his big-budget musicals  including Jekyll and Hyde, The Civil War and The Scarlet Pimpernel  had lost nearly $20 million on Broadway by the end of 2000, and a 2004 production, Dracula: The Musical, shut down after five months, Mr. Wildhorn, the composer, is readying a new work inspired by Lewis Carrolls Alices Adventures in Wonderland. On Tuesday the producers of Wonderland: A New Alice. A New Musical Adventure, said they would bring the updated take on the classic childrens story to Broadway in the spring, presenting it at a Nederlander theater to be determined. The musical, which focuses on a new, grown-up Alice, features a book by Gregory Boyd and Jack Murphy, as well as lyrics by Mr. Murphy and music by Mr. Wildhorn. It will be directed by Mr. Boyd and choreographed by Marguerite Derricks. Previews are scheduled to begin on March 21, with an opening night of April 17.

title: Commence Squealing: 3-D Movie for Bieber
description: Justin Bieber, the 16-year-old pop phenomenon who is simply too big to be contained in two dimensions, will star in an autobiographical film in which every floppy hair on his adorable head will leap off the screen in 3-D, Paramount Pictures said on Tuesday. The movie, which does not yet have a title or a director, will feature footage from Mr. Biebers current tour and is planned for release over Valentines Day weekend next year. Mr. Bieber, who also struck a deal this week to write his memoirs, said in a statement that the film was a chance to give something very special back to all the fans who have been a huge source of inspiration and support throughout my entire career thus far.

title: Climate Policy Is Paralyzed, but the Climate Isnt
description: While American energy and climate policy remain paralyzed, physics isnt standing still. And the science pointing to big, long-lasting consequences for the world from the buildup of greenhouse gases continues to accumulate.

title: Lady Gaga Leads MTV Award Nominees
description: Lady Gaga, who was shut out of the big categories at the Grammy Awards this year, might get another chance to deliver an acceptance speech through stretched red lace at the MTV Video Music Awards next month. She leads this years contenders with 13 nominations, MTV said on Tuesday. Lady Gagas songs Bad Romance and Telephone are both up for video of the year, the top prize, in which she will compete against B.o.Bs Airplanes, Florence + the Machines Dog Days Are Over, 30 Seconds to Marss Kings and Queens and Not Afraid by Eminem, whose eight nominations this year are the second-most. B.o.B has five nominations, and Kesha has three, including best new artist: her competition is Jason Derulo, Justin Bieber, Nicki Minaj and Broken Bells. The Video Music Awards will be held at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on Sept. 12.

title: Horton Says Home Sales Gained 60%
description: D.R. Horton, the American home builder, reported its third consecutive quarterly profit on Tuesday after sales climbed and the company cut costs.

title: Strong Bachelorette End
description: Closing its highest-rated season since 2004, The Bachelorette attracted 11.6 million viewers with the two-hour finale of its sixth season on Monday, according to Nielsens estimates, helping ABC dominate the night. CBS placed second, averaging 6.6 million viewers from 8 to 10 for reruns of its comedies and 6 million at 10 for a repeat of CSI: Miami. Fox and NBC finished in a virtual tie for third.

title: Aretha Franklin Cancels Free Concerts In Brooklyn
description: Aretha Franklin has canceled two free concerts in Brooklyn next week because of an injury suffered on Sunday. The shows  at Wingate Field in East Flatbush on Monday, and Asser Levy Park in Brighton Beach on Aug. 12  were part of two series presented by Marty Markowitz, the borough president, and were to be the first concerts by Ms. Franklin, above, in Brooklyn. There was no immediate word on the nature of her injury, and the office of Debra Garcia, who organizes the concerts for Mr. Markowitz, said it did not know if her appearances would be rescheduled for this season.

title: Wringing Art Out of the Rubble in Detroit
description: DETROIT  The latest must-go event in this gritty, left-behind city  where D.J.s flourish among ruins, trespassing in tumbledown buildings is part of a night out, and even garage rock is bare-bones  centers on soup.

title: Artists Making It in Detroit
description: Photographs of D.I.Y. artists in Detroit and at the Maker Faire, held for the first time in nearby Dearborn, Mich.

title: Stop and Go: Reinventing the Car Pedal
description: Masuyuki Naruse, a Japanese inventor, combined the accelerator and brake pedal. He believes the contraption will reduce the number of car accidents by limiting driver confusion over the two pedals.

title: On-Demand Options for Hard-to-Find Films
description: The Hong Kong director Johnnie To, one of the great virtuosos of the gangster film, makes movies worth rushing out to see.

title: Gas-and-Brake Pedal Gets New Look After Recalls
description: TAMANA, Japan  Two pedals, inches apart, one for gas and the other for brakes. For years, a Japanese inventor has argued that this most basic of car designs is dangerously flawed.

title: Pay Scandal Roils Two California Cities
description: For the first few weeks, things seemed to be going fine in Maywood, the California city that gave up the fiscal ghost in June, when it fired almost all of its employees and signed a contract with a neighboring town to run its affairs.

title: An Angry Soul From a Hard Island
description: When we first meet Rita Mancuso, the purposeful heroine of The Sicilian Girl, shes a bratty 11-year-old (played by Miriana Faja) slapping tomato sauce onto her mothers freshly laundered sheets. Later we see her mouthing off to a prosecutor from Palermo (Grard Jugnot) who has come to Ritas village to question her adored father  an old-school Mafioso who defends his neighbors from less gentlemanly wiseguys  about the murder of a local rapist. The year is 1985, and Rita, her authority-flouting credentials firmly established, is poised to mouth off on a much grander scale.

title: Revis-Jets Stalemate Was Year in Making
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  The backdrop behind the Darrelle Revis contract stalemate centers on Leon Washington, a former Jets running back now playing in Seattle. His experience last season still resonates, quite strongly, throughout the locker room.

title: Airline Fees Test Travelers Limits
description: AFTER a United flight hit severe turbulence over Kansas on July 20, injuring dozens of people on board, Jay Leno joked that flight attendants administered first aid only to passengers who paid a $7.50 triage fee. It was a bit of morbid humor reflecting the view that airline fees are out of control.

title: Schumanns Troubled Spirit Is Fertile Ground for Players
description: Even highly competent orchestral concerts can sound like just another day at the office for jaded musicians. But when the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen appeared at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening in the Mostly Mozart Festival, it seemed that work was certainly play for these fiery performers.

title: In Europe, Chess Is King, but Not in the U.S.
Target Touches Up Manhattans Makeup
description: NOW that Target has come to Manhattan, savvy beauty shoppers no longer have to brave the weekend crowds at the chains Atlantic Terminal outpost in Brooklyn to score exclusive products, like the Boots No. 7 skin-care line. They can just take the No. 6 train to Harlem.

title: Another Anise Spirit Worth Knowing
description: In the Middle Eastern lands along the Mediterranean, arak has long been the drink of choice to accompany meze. But Lebanese wineries are paying more attention to the finesse with which they produce this ancient anise-flavored spirit. At Massaya, for example, the fermented juice of native white grapes is triple-distilled in a traditional pot still. On the third still run, the spirit is infused with fresh, organic green anise seeds from Mount Hermon. The arak (106 proof) is aged in clay amphorae for 18 months, making a smooth, deeply flavorful spirit. Like pastis (although less sweet), arak is meant to be diluted: one part spirit to two of water, before adding ice.

description: La Guardia Airport is mostly for domestic flights, the stingiest when it comes to feeding passengers aloft. At Delta Airlines Terminal D, at least, the food options for those who have time before boarding are about to become much more alluring.

description: Time: 20 minutes, plus churning and chilling

description: Openings

title: A Glove to Exfoliate Potatoes, Carrots and More
description: Slip on these textured elastic nylon gloves from Skruba in Denmark and you make short work of scrubbing vegetables without removing too much skin (and the nutrients just beneath it). The company makes black gloves labeled potato and orange ones for carrots, but you do not need a wardrobe: except for the color, theyre interchangeable. Nevertheless, there could be one labeled clams because I found them effective for scrubbing littlenecks. They also provide about enough cushioning for opening clams and oysters.

title: Tigerlily
description: 299 Greene Avenue (Classon Avenue), Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, (917) 652-4648; tigerlilybrooklyn.com

title: Robust Garlic, Fresh and Juicy
description: In addition to yarn from merino rams, the Catskill Merino Sheep Farm in Goshen, N.Y., grows and sells organic garlic. The harvest is in and dried bulbs are now available: hard-neck garlic with tight, fat, fairly uniform cloves often tinged with purple. It is strong, pungent and juicy because it is so fresh. The cloves are easy to peel, slice, sliver or chop.

description: 355 West 116th Street (between Manhattan and Morningside Avenues), (212) 222-1127.

description: Time: 30 minutes, plus churning and chilling

title: Conservatism Beyond Deficit Cutting
description: Ezra Klein and David Frum both have posts touching on the issue I raised here yesterday  the deeper socioeconomic forces that helped midwife the current Democratic majority, and that will pose an ongoing dilemma for leaders of both parties once the current economic debacle is behind us. Heres Klein, pointing out that while right now were dreaming about getting back to the growth of early 2007, we need to recognize that by historical standards early 2007 was terrible.

title: When the Trifle Turns Serious, Experience Counts
description: LENOX, Mass.  When a new team of conductors was announced to fill the many vacancies in the Tanglewood Festival season left by the withdrawal of James Levine, who is still recovering from back surgery, some may have been surprised to see Christoph von Dohnanyi assigned to an opera: the Tanglewood Music Center production of Strausss Ariadne auf Naxos. Mr. Dohnanyi is known in the United States chiefly as an orchestral conductor, especially for his two decades with the Cleveland Orchestra. He was, in fact, already scheduled to conduct concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra here at Tanglewood this weekend.

title: John Aylesworth, a Hee-Haw Creator, Dies at 81
description: John Aylesworth, co-creator of the long-running television hit Hee Haw, a blend of cornball humor and country music, died July 28 in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Palm Desert, Calif.

title: Beauty Spots
description: IN this summers heat, putting your best face forward often means mopping up shine and fighting unruly hair. Heres some advice to help you get ahead of the heat.

title: Bristol and Levis Engagement Is Off Again
description: The roller coaster continues.

title: Dollar Thrifty Finds Avis Bid Is Problematic
description: The Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group told the Avis Budget Group late Tuesday that its $1.3 billion takeover offer was problematic because Avis did not prove that its proposed merger could get antitrust clearance and it did not provide for a break-up fee if the deal fell through.

title: Egg-Free Ice Cream Lets Flavors Bloom
description: ALTHOUGH Id spent most of my childhood licking wan soft-serve vanilla and shockingly green mint-chocolate chip, I never looked back after my first taste of premium custard-based ice cream. Exceedingly creamy and as smooth as a stick of softened butter, it blew those crystallized supermarket cartons away with an icy blast.

title: Homes for $350,000
description: A one-bedroom condo in Chicago, a three-bedroom cape in Vermont and a two-bedroom house in California.

description: President Obama on Tuesday ordered federal agencies to temporarily cut out bonuses and other non-salary payments for federal political appointees in light of the economys lackluster performance.

description: CHICAGO

title: Suso Cecchi DAmico, Writer of Literate Screenplays, Dies at 96
description: Suso Cecchi DAmico, whose spare, literate screenplays made her a favored collaborator for directors including Vittorio De Sica, Michelangelo Antonioni, Luchino Visconti and Mario Monicelli, died on Saturday in Rome. She was 96.

title: Assassination Sets Off Wave of Killings in Pakistani City
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A wave of violence after the assassination of a senior politician on Monday has left at least 47 people dead in Pakistans largest city, the southern port of Karachi.

title: Second Quarter G.D.P. Was Probably Worse Than Reported
description: The economy most likely grew much less in the second quarter of 2010 than initially estimated.

title: Infighting at Russian Mining Company Threatens Markets
description: MOSCOW  A struggle for control has erupted on the board of Norilsk Nickel, one of Russias most valuable mining companies and the worlds largest producer of nickel and platinum group metals, which currently have new uses in fuel cells for electric cars.

title: Muscle Tear Sends Youkilis to D.L.
description: BOSTON  The Red Sox season of woe took another dark turn on Tuesday when the team placed Kevin Youkilis on the disabled list with a torn adductor muscle in his right thumb. Mike Lowell was activated and started for Youkilis at first base.

title: Energy Bill a No-Go in the Senate
description: Senate Democrats on Tuesday abandoned all hopes of passing even a slimmed-down energy bill before they adjourn for the summer recess, saying that they did not have sufficient votes even for legislation tailored narrowly to respond to the Gulf oil spill.

title: In Italy, Perched in the Alps
description: A house ringed by tall pines, with breathtaking unobstructed views of the mountains.

title: Obesity Rates Keep Rising, Troubling Health Officials
description: Americans are continuing to get fatter and fatter, with obesity rates reaching 30 percent or more in nine states last year, as opposed to only three states in 2007, health officials reported on Tuesday.

title: In Italy, Framing (and Preserving) the View
description: TIROL, Italy  About three years ago, Michael Pirpamer, 51, finally moved out of his mothers house.

title: BlackBerry Maker Resists Governments Pressure
description: A top executive of Research In Motion, the Canadian company that makes BlackBerry smartphones, said on Tuesday that his company would not give in to pressure from foreign governments to provide access to its customers messages.

title: House Hunting in ... Ireland
description: A THREE-BEDROOM COUNTRY HOUSE WITH A GUEST COTTAGE AND TURKISH BATH IN COUNTY WICKLOW, IRELAND

title: A Country House in Ireland
description: A three-bedroom house, with a guest house and Turkish baths, is on the market for 2 million euros ($2.6 million) in County Wicklow, Ireland.

title: Fair Director Misapplied State Funds, Report Says
description: A former director of the New York State Fair used state resources to help put on weddings for his two daughters, and also gave away more than $700,000 worth of free fair and concert tickets to politicians, employees and other officials, an investigation by the New York State inspector general found.

title: Building a New History by Exhuming Bolvar
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The clock had just struck midnight. Most of the country was asleep. But that did not stop President Hugo Chvez from announcing in the early hours of July 16 that the latest phase of his Bolivarian Revolution had been stirred into motion.

title: Improving Train Service
description: To the Editor:
