description: To the Editor:

title: Rage and Floods in Pakistan
description: The worst floods in a generation in northwestern Pakistan have killed more than 1,400 people, left as many as 1.3 million others homeless and destroyed as much as 70 percent of the regions livestock. Responding to the needs of the region and its desperately vulnerable people is not something the Pakistani government or the United States can afford to get wrong.

title: Commercials in Mad Men Style, Created for the Series
description: THE fact that Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, the new agency on Mad Men, has landed the Ponds cold cream account is not the only advertising news to come out of the television series this week. AMC, the cable channel that presents the show about the ad industry  and America  in the 1960s has made a deal with a giant marketer, Unilever, for a season-long sponsorship agreement.

title: After Afghan War Leaks, Revisions in a Shield Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic senators who have been working on legislation providing greater protections to reporters who refuse to identify confidential sources are backpedaling from WikiLeaks, the Web site that recently disclosed more than 75,000 classified documents related to the Afghanistan war.

title: Putting Investors First
description: In large part, the success of financial reform will depend on regulators writing tough rules and enforcing them, which they have failed to do in the past. An early and important test of such willpower will come soon as the Securities and Exchange Commission finalizes new rules for nominating directors to corporate boards.

title: South Africa: Ex-police Chief Is Sentenced to 15 Years
description: Jackie Selebi, the former national police chief, was sentenced to 15 years in prison on Tuesday after his conviction last month for accepting bribes from a drug kingpin. In issuing the sentence, Judge Meyer Joffe chastised Mr. Selebi, the former president of Interpol, the international police group, for fabricating evidence. Mr. Selebi is free on bond during the two weeks he has to file an appeal.

title: Mexico: Death Toll From Drug-Related Violence Is Thousands Higher Than Was Reported Earlier
description: The number of deaths from drug-related violence is higher than previous acknowledged, the director of Mexicos intelligence agency said Tuesday. Guillermo Valds Castellanos, director of the National Security and Investigation Center, or Cisen, put the new toll at a little more than 28,000 murders since President Felipe Caldern took office in December 2006. Last month the attorney generals office reported that 24,826 lives had been lost nationwide.

title: Giants Happy to Let Others (Like the Jets) Make the Headlines
description: ALBANY  At Giants training camp, the only thing to disturb the silence has been the screaming of the boisterous new defensive coordinator, Perry Fewell.

title: The Hunt for American Decency in the Arizona Quicksand
description: The federal judge who struck down most of Arizonas new immigration law last week wasnt trying to strike a blow for immigrants rights, about which her ruling said little. She wasnt dictating what immigration laws should look like or how strict they should be. She was making a much more fundamental argument, one that has regularly emerged in Americas long and often ugly history in dealing with noncitizens and other vulnerable minorities.

title: Taste Testing Strawberry Ice Cream
description: A PACKAGED pint of ice cream now costs more than $10 in some New York City markets, making the older premium brands like Hagen-Dazs and Ben & Jerrys seem relatively cheap.

title: Notes From the Ice Cream Taste Test
description: The Dining section conducted a blind taste test of 11 kinds of strawberry ice cream.

title: You Scream, I Scream ... at the Price of Ice Cream
description: EMILY EISENBERG, who lives in the Eagle Rock neighborhood of Los Angeles, said she let her young sons talk her into trying a new scoop shop, Gelato Bar, in nearby Los Feliz in June. It is the kind of place that describes its ice cream as premium and handmade, the mix-ins are from local artisans and farmers, and the prices are accordingly high. For two small servings, she paid more than $10, and walked out vowing never to return.

title: Amare Stoudemires Quest to Israel
description: TEL AVIV  Amare Stoudemire loped into the lobby of his Tel Aviv seaside hotel, bouncing an orange basketball, wearing a gray T-shirt with the legend Jerusalem-Israel and side-by-side flags of Israel and the United States, a two-flag pin he said he was given as a gift, and a large black crocheted skullcap on his head.

title: Future of Big East Is in Hands of Others
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  For Big East Commissioner John Marinatto, the conferences off-season of uncertainty may best be described by the dirty looks he received in church.

title: Slicing Away Some Mystique From a Once-Rare PGA Score
description: AKRON, Ohio  Such is the ubiquity of the once-rare score of 59 on the PGA Tour these days that the United States Open champion Graeme McDowell  after first dismissing the notion that anyone could shoot a 59 this week at the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational and duplicate the magic number shot twice in less than a month  began a debate with himself.

title: Why I Was Angry
description: LAST week I got angry on the floor of the House. In this age of cable and YouTube, millions of people evidently saw the one-minute-plus clip. But there has been relatively little focus on why the substantive debate that sparked it matters.

title: Conflicting Reports Add to Speculation on Favre
description: The Favre Follies are starting to sound familiar.

description: Washington

title: Giants Relieved OHaras Injury Not More Serious
description: ALBANY  The Giants were able to breathe a little easier Tuesday night after learning that Shaun OHaras swollen left ankle was a result of a chronic condition in the joint, not a new injury.

description: The pop-up restaurant in Los Angeles serves vaguely Asian, deeply French and fairly Californian experiments that are both simple in flavor and amazingly complex in execution.

description: Washington

title: Red Eye
description: A visual diary documenting a flight from New York to Berlin (with a layover in London).

title: New Jersey Is Sued Over the Forced Medication of Patients at Psychiatric Hospitals
description: Patient advocates filed a federal lawsuit on Tuesday charging that New Jersey psychiatric hospitals routinely medicate patients against their will without a review by an outside arbiter, a practice that is banned in most other states.

title: At Company, a Culture of Family and Charity
description: Even as it expanded into one of Connecticuts largest wholesalers of beer and wine, and even as its employee count swelled past 100, Hartford Distributors remained a close-knit company, owned and operated by the same family for decades. It was the type of multigenerational business where workers might stay for 20, even 30 years.

title: Mosque Plan Clears Hurdle in New York
description: As New York City removed the final hurdle for a controversial mosque near ground zero, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg forcefully defended the project on Tuesday as a symbol of Americas religious tolerance and sought to reframe a fiery national debate over the project.

title: 125 Days Late, a State Budget With New Taxes
description: ALBANY  Lawmakers completed one of the latest budgets in New York State history on Tuesday night, passing a last piece of legislation that will raise an additional $1 billion  in part by increasing taxes on the sale of clothing and on a variety of businesses.

title: As Space Priorities Shift, Orbiting Station Takes On a Central Role
description: When a cooling-system pump on the International Space Station broke down over the weekend, NASA and the six astronauts on board responded with typical cool self-assurance. The space agency scheduled two spacewalks to repair the damage and said the astronauts, three Americans and three Russians, were in no danger.

title: After Haiti Quake, the Chaos of U.S. Adoptions
description: BAXTER, Minn.  Beechestore and Rosecarline, two Haitian teenagers in the throes of puberty, were not supposed to be adopted.

description: The furloughs that popped up during the recession are being replaced by a highly unusual tactic: actual cuts in pay.

title: Art Dealer Is Sentenced for $120 Million Scheme
description: He cultivated their trust with his longstanding reputation as a prominent art dealer and endeared them with a smile, backslapping charm and firm reassurances. But he used it all to steal  not only money and valuable artwork, but also family heirlooms, memories of loved ones and connections to the past.

title: Lottery Numbers
More on Work and Parenthood
description: The notion that more mothers of young children have dropped out of the labor force in recent years has been a hotly debated topic. But I think the facts are clear  more mothers are not working, compared with the mid- and late 1990s  even if the causes and implications are open to debate. This Bureau of Labor Statistics report from 2007, which I mentioned in my column this week, offers a good overview.

title: Francoeurs Homer in the Ninth Means a Lot to Him, and to the Mets
description: ATLANTA  The list of reasons that Jeff Francoeur felt Tuesdays home run was the biggest hit in his brief career as a member of the Mets is not a short one.

description: He was bankrupt by age 24, when, court filings show, his only worldly possessions were $250 worth of clothing and $600 in a checking account. Debt collectors hounded him for years.

title: Coles Is Back. For Now at Least.
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  On Monday afternoon, Laveranues Coles turned the question on the questioner. A reporter asked Coles, who has returned to the Jets this season for the third time, if he was comfortable knowing that his career could end after four weeks, eight weeks or even after this season.

description: WATERBURY, Vt.  Green Mountain Coffee Roasters has built a reputation as an eco-friendly company since it was founded nearly 30 years ago.

description: Maj. Charles Day, who the State Police said Tuesday was being transferred from Gov. David A. Patersons security detail, is under scrutiny by the state ethics commission for his conduct in a domestic dispute case involving one of the governors top aides.

title: Injuries Are Slowing Down Nicks and Manningham
description: ALBANY  The results of a magnetic resonance imaging exam on Hakeem Nickss hyperextended right knee could be telling for the development of the Giants wide receivers.

title: Rodriguez Stays at No. 599 as Yankees Fall Out of First
description: It is no secret that Alex Rodriguez is not hitting home runs. But the obsession over his quest for his 600th home run has perhaps begun to overshadow another more significant trend: the Yankees are not winning games, either.

title: Archer Daniels Gets a Boost From Asia

title: Phys Ed: How Much Does Knee Surgery Really Help?
description: A study published late last month in The New England Journal of Medicine is raising provocative questions about how best to treat a torn anterior cruciate ligament. For the study, researchers from Lund University in Sweden recruited 121 young adults who had injured their A.C.L.s. The volunteers, between 18 and 35, were physically active, and many were competitive athletes. They agreed, rather bravely, to be randomly assigned to one of two groups and accept radically different treatments for their torn A.C.L.s. The first group began physical therapy and then underwent surgical reconstruction of the ligament, considered by many people to be the best option for injured athletes. The second group received only physical therapy, with the option to have the operation later. Twenty-three subjects of that group did eventually have the operation. (For those fortunate enough not to be personally familiar with A.C.L. surgery, reconstruction involves replacing the injured ligament with tissue from elsewhere in your own leg or from a cadaver.)

Under the old law, a person caught with five grams of crack received a mandatory five years in prison, while a person caught with powder cocaine had to have 500 grams to merit the same term. The new law reduces the 100-to-1 disparity to 18-to-1.

title: My Life in Therapy
description: All those years, all that money, all that unrequited love. It began way back when I was a child, an anxiety-riddled 10-year-old who didnt want to go to school in the morning and had difficulty falling asleep at night. Even in a family like mine, where there were many siblings (six in all) and little attention paid to dispositional differences, I stood out as a neurotic specimen. And so I was sent to what would prove to be the first of many psychiatrists in the four and a half decades to follow  indeed, I could be said to be a one-person boon to the therapeutic establishment  and was initiated into the curious and slippery business of self-disclosure. I learned, that is, to construct an ongoing narrative of the self, composed of what the psychoanalyst Robert Stoller calls microdots (the consciously experienced moments selected from the whole and arranged to present a point of view), one that might have been more or less cohesive than my actual self but that at any rate was supposed to illuminate puzzling behavior and onerous symptoms  my behavior and my symptoms.

title: A Shoe In
description: Massimiliano Giornetti planned to spend his summer vacation in Puglia, a popular Italian getaway several hours from his home in Florence. Im not entirely a free spirit on holiday, says the 38-year-old designer, who was recently named Ferragamos creative director. I like some structure, with a little room to be adventurous. A perfect metaphor for his design mantra at Ferragamo, where he has helmed the mens-wear divison for the last decade. Any question as to whether Giornetti could translate his masculine sensibilities to the more mercurial closets of women was answered in his much lauded fall collection. He managed to channel the independent spirit of Salvatore Ferragamos devoted customer, Greta Garbo, while creating sharp, assertive glamour: fur-lined capes, cuffed leather shorts, thick cable knits and a three-piece pinstriped suit that seemed like a 21st-century version of Annie Hall.

But a lot of it is just plain likable. Its as if Stravinsky, for once, had found an earlier form that he wanted to emulate rather than parody, extend rather than distend.

description: Catching up with the technologies offered by browsers including Mozillas Firefox and Googles Chrome, Apple this week began offering a version 5.01 update to its Safari Web browser that includes the option to create lite Web extensions.

title: Bookmarks, From A to Z
description: Bookmarks

title: Fairies, Goblins and a Thumb-Sucking Hero in Battery Park City
description: There are fairies in Battery Park City (faeries, according to the publicity), with flapping wings and floral headdresses. There is also a young man, possibly answering to the name of Garbhglas, if only you could pronounce that properly, who  though bare-chested  wears a pixie hat, long pointed booties and a kilt, all in one of the more subdued shades of rustic green. And there are three mud-colored bestial creatures whom I will call goblins, who have udders all over their bodies, even their high-pointed heads.

title: Into the Breach, Clad in Adolfo
description: NO one really remembers. Actually, that is not altogether true. There are those who do recall, the ones who survived the terrifying place that New York became in the 1980s, when a disease with no fixed medical designation  beyond an acronym that made it seem as though those most affected were somehow its cause  was killing people in droves.

title: Bridging Jazz Generations Without Nostalgia
description: Greg Osby has a keen, focused tone on alto saxophone and a hummingbirds phrasing, an equilibrium of hover and flutter. His style hasnt changed drastically since the mid-1980s, when he was among the more important new arrivals on the New York scene. What has changed is his stature, and the context around his work. Mr. Osby is now a mentor and a pacesetter, one of the sturdier bridges between jazz generations. His music, for all its coiled intricacies, has gradually been absorbed by the modern mainstream.

title: For Fannie Stock, Even Betting Pennies Is a Risk
description: It is flotsam of the housing wreck, a stock no longer worthy of the Big Board. But penny by penny, the mortgage giant Fannie Mae is being salvaged in the stock market.

title: How Much Debt Should Households Have?
description: One of the biggest question marks for the economic recovery going forward is how consumer behavior  usually one of the drivers of growth  has changed in this post-housing-bust world.

title: Meeting Force With Force: A Police Units Beat Is Behind Bars
description: Is there any outlet on television that comes close to A&E in showing us just what it takes to clean up the broad mess of American life? Whenever current events threaten to sever faith in our institutions, there is A&E reminding us that federal marshals are capturing killers on the lam (Manhunters: Fugitive Task Force); that mental-health professionals are rehabilitating drunks, germophobes and hoarders (Intervention, Obsessed, Hoarders); that transit officials are nailing parking rogues (Parking Wars); that annihilators are whacking household pests (Billy the Exterminator); that the patriarchy is being upheld however unconventionally (Gene Simmons Family Jewels).

title: Antismoking Forces Revive Ads With a Jagged Edge
description: Weeks ago, a popular commercial that fought smoking among teenagers and young adults as part of the Truth campaign returned after a six-year absence.

title: City Barred From Hiring New Firefighters
description: The federal judge overseeing a discrimination lawsuit against the citys Fire Department ruled on Wednesday that the hiring test being used by the department was unfair to minority applicants and issued an injunction that will prevent the city from offering positions to 300 applicants who had already taken the exam.

title: Aggressive, Delicate and Enduring
description: There is no shame in the singing of Ann Wilson of Heart. Feet planted squarely, hand on microphone, she anticipates the bigness of notes to come, then still sings them in such an overwhelming fashion that they appear to knock her off her center. Many times at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday night she took a pause, howled a few lines in a manner that would have impressed even Meat Loaf, then took another pause, needing to refocus.

title: Grilled Fish, a Smartphone and Dinner
description: I had an hour to pull dinner together.

title: Digging Deep, and Riding High (at Last)
description: ANDY gave me a shove and the 10-foot longboard took off like a shark on the hunt. I felt a sense of lightness as the roll of water caught up with me, tilting down the foam plank on which I lay. I paddled hard to stay ahead of the wave.

title: Motion Picture Academy Re-elects Its President
description: Tom Sherak, below, a longtime film-distribution executive, was re-elected on Tuesday night as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the academy said. Sidney Ganis, a previous academy president, was elected first vice president, while James L. Brooks and Phil Robinson were elected as vice presidents, Hawk Koch was elected treasurer, and Annette Bening was elected secretary. Officers of the Academy, whose 6,000 members present the Oscars each year, are elected to one-year terms by the groups board of governors.

title: An Argentine Gem Hidden No More
description: EVERY August, the people of Jujuy pay tribute to the earth goddess Pachamama. Families prepare elaborate dishes  tamales, stews, llama or lamb  and then bury the food in a backyard or field, along with abundant hard liquor, coca leaves and even cigarettes. They believe that these offerings will satisfy the deitys appetites and thus bring them good fortune and an abundant harvest. Its an ancient Andean tradition that remains strong in this province in the northwestern corner of Argentina.

title: Man Dies at Kansas Stop of Vans Warped Tour
description: The Vans Warped Tour expressed its condolences to the family of a man who died at a concert stop in Bonner Springs, Kan., on Monday. In a statement publicists for the tour said they were awaiting a complete report from the Bonner Springs law enforcement and medical examiner, adding: Tour organizers are working closely with Capitol Federal Park @ Sandstone staff and local officials to determine the actual facts surrounding this tragic incident and will make further details known as they become available. The Web page of the concert site, sandstoneamp.com, identified the man as Curtis Alan DeForest, 26, of Wichita. A statement on the site said that he had been taken to a nearby medical center where he died, and that a cause of death had not been determined.

title: Nightmare for Eminem: He Loses Top Album Spot
description: It took a metal band to knock Eminem from his five-week perch atop the Billboard album chart. Avenged Sevenfold, from Huntington Beach, Calif., sold 163,000 copies of its new album, Nightmare (Warner Brothers), above, while Eminems Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope) was close behind with 159,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In a week with no major new releases Rick Rosss Teflon Don (Maybach Music/Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam) fell one spot to No. 3 with 63,000 in sales, Justin Biebers My World 2.0 (Island) rose two to No. 4 with 38,000, and Drakes Thank Me Later (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) had 34,000, enough for No. 5. Total album sales for the year are at 174.9 million, down 12 percent from the same period last year.

title: Chevron Cites Documentary Outtakes in Legal Papers
description: The Chevron Corporation says in federal court filings in Manhattan that footage it was provided from the Joe Berlinger documentary Crude demonstrated pervasive corruption and fraud by lawyers representing Ecuadorians who are suing the company, an accusation those lawyers vigorously dispute. In July a federal appeals court ruled that Mr. Berlinger had to provide the oil company with some footage from his 2009 film, which chronicles Ecuadorians who say that an oil field established by Texaco (now owned by Chevron) polluted their water. Chevron said in a statement that interactions between lawyers for the Ecuadorian plaintiffs and a court-appointed expert showed the parties engaged in an illegal scheme to corrupt the proceedings in Ecuador. Ilann M. Maazel, a lawyer whose firm represents the Ecuadorean plaintiffs, said that neither Chevron nor Mr. Berlinger had provided his team with the film outtakes, and that lawyers for Chevron had similar access to court experts. They cherrypick a couple of minutes and share it with the court, but theyre not willing to release all the tapes, Mr. Maazel said in a telephone interview. He said that neither Chevron nor Mr. Berlinger would provide the outtakes to him.

title: Roundabout Theater Writing Assignments
description: The playwright Theresa Rebeck, below, (The Understudy, Mauritius) has become the first dramatist to be named as associate artist of Roundabout Theater Company, the not-for-profit theater said on Wednesday, as part of its effort to develop more new work for its stages. In addition to having a home at Roundabout to develop work, associate artists consult with the artistic director, Todd Haimes, on projects that Roundabout is considering for readings, workshops and productions. Other associate artists include the directors Scott Elliott, Joe Mantello and Kathleen Marshall. Mr. Haimes announced 10 playwriting commissions for new works that are in development, including playwrights like Julia Cho (The Language Archive) and Lydia Diamond (The Bluest Eye). Roundabout also said that a new play by David West Read, The Dream of the Burning Boy, will be the first spring 2011 production at its 62-seat black-box theater. The play, about the fallout from the death of a high school overachiever, will be directed by Evan Cabnet (Oliver Parker!) and is scheduled to begin performances on Feb. 25 and open on March 20.

title: Another Cast Signing for Women on the Verge
description: If playing a woman who was driven to a life of striptease by the most overbearing stage mother in show business history did not leave Laura Benanti, right, in a state of mental collapse, her next role just might: Ms. Benanti will reunite with her Gypsy co-star Patti LuPone in Lincoln Center Theaters coming musical version of Pedro Almodvars Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, the theater company said on Wednesday. Ms. Benanti, who won a Tony Award for her portrayal of Louise in the recent Gypsy revival, is joining the musical as Candela, a fashion model whose lover turns out to be a terrorist. Previously announced cast members include Sherie Rene Scott as Pepa, the television actress at the center of the farce; Brian Stokes Mitchell as her boyfriend, Ivn; Ms. LuPone as Luca, Ivns wife; deAdre Aziza as Paulina, Lucas lawyer; and Nikka Graff Lanzarone as Marisa, the fiance of the son of Ivn and Luca. (Got all that?) The Women on the Verge musical is directed by Bartlett Sher with a book by Jeffrey Lane and music and lyrics by David Yazbek. Previews are to begin at the Belasco Theater on Oct. 2 with an opening night set for Nov. 4.

title: Talent Takes Tuesday
description: The last group of 12 quarterfinalists competed on Tuesday nights episode of Americas Got Talent as that NBC reality show topped the ratings with 10.2 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The network drew meager ratings earlier in the night for the second installment of Breakthrough With Tony Robbins (2.8 million). CBS ranked second over all with a lineup of crime-show repeats. In third place Fox edged ahead of ABC with the cooking-themed reality shows Hells Kitchen (7.1 million) and MasterChef (5.9 million). ABC drew its best ratings with Wipeout (8.8 million) but lagged with the second-season premiere of Shaq Vs. (5.4 million) and Primetime (4.7 million).

description: One day last week, the novelist Peter Quinn (Im actually a lapsed historian) was walking west on 45th Street, beyond Eighth Avenue, when he stopped outside the old home of a vanished Broadway restaurant called Billy Haass Chophouse.

title: Still Wild for Animal Prints
description: THE animal print frenzy shows no sign of abating. Starting today, Alexander Wang is having a sample sale from its resort and spring 2010 collection.

title: Seeking the Eye for Art
description: NEW HAVEN  A dozen years ago the art dealer Richard L. Feigen attended an auction of European paintings at Sothebys in London and found a picture he liked: a richly colored scene of a religious vision, with a hovering saint and four angels, all topped by shimmering gold halos, that was attributed to a minor Italian painter.

title: For Fannie Stock, Even Betting Pennies Is a Risk
description: It is flotsam of the housing wreck, a stock no longer worthy of the Big Board. But penny by penny, the mortgage giant Fannie Mae is being salvaged in the stock market, The New York Timess David Gillen reports.

description: The front-runner for the Republican nomination in the Colorado governors race is causing a stir with claims that his likely Democratic opponent, Mayor John Hickenlooper of Denver, is bringing the city under United Nations control by promoting bike riding and other sustainability measures.

description: A commercial, called "Recall," is part of a new campaign for the Truth anti-smoking effort that revives a fake product, Shards O'Glass.

description: SILHOUETTED against a dying sun on a late July evening, more than a dozen Hamptons regulars eased into the warm darkness of Sagaponack Pond.

title: Avant-Garde Director Gathers Rats Into a Wagnerian Maze
description: BAYREUTH, Germany  It has become practically a part of the tradition at the Bayreuth Festival for the director of an avant-garde Wagner production to be vociferously booed on opening night. So it was on July 25, when the festival opened with the new Hans Neuenfels production of Lohengrin, which I saw here on Tuesday, the second performance.

title: Google Acquires Slide, Maker of Social Apps
description: Google has acquired Slide, the start-up that makes apps for social networking Web sites, according to two sources briefed on the deal.

title: Fox To Make Nigel Lythgoes Idol Return Official
description: Fox and the production companies behind American Idol are expected to announce Wednesday that Nigel Lythgoe will return to the show as an executive producer, a person with knowledge of his hiring said.

title: Turkey and Israel Do a Brisk Business
description: ISTANBUL  Israeli business executives here like to point out that most of the angry Turks who protested Israels deadly raid on a Turkish-led flotilla to Gaza this past spring do not know that their cellphones, personal computers and plasma televisions were made using parts and technology from Tel Aviv.

title: Laptop and Piano, Dispelling Traditions
description: Tune in to any pop radio station today, and the ubiquity of electronic music is evident in the Auto-Tune vocals and programmed beats of even the most banal hit single. Listen closely, and you realize that gifted pop producers routinely turn out sophisticated orchestrations that surpass the reckonings of avant-garde prophets like Busoni, Varse and Stockhausen.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Vacuuming Robots
description: In this weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast we ask: How smart can a vacuum robot be? J.D. Biersdorfer and Sam Grobart, deputy editor of the Times Home section, get on the ground with the Neato XV-11.

title: NCAPS
description: How I Saved My Company | Reaching out directly to the client base

title: Ravi Coltrane Signs With Blue Note
description: Ravi Coltrane, the highly regarded tenor and soprano saxophonist, is the newest addition to the roster of Blue Note Records, with an album due out next spring. His signing unites the most storied label in jazz, one of the last majors standing, with a saxophonist-bandleader from an imposing lineage: Mr. Coltranes father was John Coltrane, who similarly played tenor and soprano, reshaping the language of jazz improvisation from the mid-1950s up to his death in 1967.

title: A Sly Lead Succeeds in the Heat Down South
description: When youre hot, youre hot  especially in New Orleans at the just completed Summer North American Championships, where the thermometer flirted with 100 degrees most days.

title: The Mystery and Majesty of the Number 600
description: Six hundred: a six followed by two zeroes. Just a number, and not even a prime number or anything like that. But in baseball, it is a milestone  though for a while, as one of the Yankees YES Network commentators said on Wednesday, it seemed to be a millstone around Alex Rodriguezs neck. And then he passed it. On to 700.

title: A Texas Address Migrates
description: KATHY and Scott Formby, a husband-and-wife design team in New York, have started a new line of womens clothing and accessories called no.1808. The name is taken from the address of an elegant, eccentric Texas home that has been in Mr. Formbys family for years.

title: Old and New
description: DAVID ZWIRNER, the blue-chip gallery with three locations in Chelsea, is opening a pop-up bookstore next week, from Aug. 9 to 13, that will feature rare and out-of-print books and new artist catalogs.

title: Think Green and Young
description: LORETTA GENDVILLE is a mini-mogul. Her first Area Kids store opened in 2005 in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. She now has nine stores, including a new one (above) in Manhattan, at 55 West 14th Street, (212) 229-1700. She offers eco-friendly and locally made toys and clothing.

title: Delta to Move at Kennedy as End Nears for Old Home
description: Delta Air Lines is set to decamp from its squat, crowded and much-maligned terminal at Kennedy International Airport and take up residence in an adjacent space that will undergo a $1.2 billion renovation and expansion.

title: Happy Birthday, Mr. President
description: With President Obama turning 49 today, both parties national committees are seizing on his birthday to cash in.

description: The shake-up of the magazine industrys corner offices will continue next week as Time Warner is expected to announce that Jack Griffin, the former Meredith Corporation executive, will become chief executive at Time Inc., succeeding Ann S. Moore.

title: Google Kills Wave, Its Collaboration Tool
description: Google Wave was one of Googles most prominent new services. Now it is one of its most prominent flops.

title: In Battle Over Mosque, a Defender of Architecture
description: In the tsunami of hubbub over the Landmarks Preservation Commissions decision Tuesday not to grant landmark status a building near ground zero that is now to be demolished to make way for an Islamic community center and mosque, little attention has been paid to the actual landmark-worthiness of the building under consideration.

title: W.N.B.A. Signs Jamba Juice as New Sponsor
description: The smoothie retailer Jamba Juice has made its first investment in a national sports league by signing a multi-year deal to sponsor the W.N.B.A.

title: More Evidence That Group Tied to Mumbai Attacks Provides Aid in Pakistan
description: As Pakistans government struggles to provide aid to about three million Pakistanis displaced by flooding, foreign correspondents continue to find evidence that the aid vacuum is being filled by militant Islamist groups, including one that is run by the founder of a banned militant group held responsible for the Mumbai terror attacks in 2008.

title: Giulianis Daughter, 20, Is Arrested
description: Rudolph W. Giulianis 20-year-old daughter was arrested on Wednesday after workers in an Upper East Side cosmetics store caught her stuffing makeup worth more than $100 into her coat pocket, law enforcement officials said.

title: Methods Single-Handed Soap Dispenser
description: The cleaning-products company Method is updating its range, aiming to keep every corner of the home spotless  and equipped with sculptural bottles. The new line of dishwashing soap ($3) is notable. We had been trying to crack dish soap for years, said Eric Ryan, one of the companys founders.

title: Sales at Jonathan Adler, M2L and Design Within Reach
description: During Jonathan Adlers first rug sale, through Aug. 15, all rugs including custom orders are 20 percent off (the 8-by-10-foot Greek Key, regularly $2,200, is $1,760; the 4-by-6 Lollipop, regularly $650, is $520; and the 8-by-10 Pat Nixon, regularly $2,200, is $1,760); for information and locations: (800) 963-0891 or jonathanadler.com.

title: An Area Store in the East Village
description: Anki Spets, who 20 years ago founded a line called Area known mainly for its bed linens, has finally opened a store of her own. A lot of my retail outlets closed in the past couple years, Ms. Spets said. Which meant the time was right for me to open a retail store. Areas 2,000 square feet, complete with a mezzanine that doubles as Ms. Spetss design studio, showcases the full range of the companys bed linens  sheets, blankets and quilts (for adults and babies), as well as throw pillows, beds and bedside tables. Theres also a small selection of kitchen items in simple, modern shapes by the industrial designer Magnus Lundstrom, her husband. They include cutting boards of walnut, oak or maple; peppermills of porcelain and walnut; and mortar and pestle sets. Prices range from $10 for a kitchen towel to $4,300 for a king bed. Area, 58 East 11th Street (Broadway), (212) 924-7084 or areahome.com.

title: Christophe Pillets Unintrusive Outdoor Umbrella
description: Those who need a break from the summer sun, but dislike the ungainly look of many patio umbrellas, may prefer the minimalist Shade, created by the Paris-based designer Christophe Pillet for the Italian outdoor furniture company Emu. It is a study in simplicity. The detailing is elegant, as opposed to clunky and chunky, said Tom Dilillo, a spokesman for the furniture company Coalesse, which recently introduced the umbrella in the United States. The pared down aluminum frame, he said, is designed to withstand years of use.

title: Architect Carlos Ott on Playa Vik in Uruguay
description: The architect Carlos Ott, above, is known for sweeping structures of steel and glass designed for wealthy corporate clients in places like Dubai. But this month he completed a rare residential project, Playa Vik, in his native Uruguay. It is a beachside retreat on the Jos Ignacio peninsula, with a center structure surrounded by six casitas. It was built for a family, but can be rented as a private retreat.

title: Sandy Chilewichs RayTray
description: Sandy Chilewichs RayTray was originally released in 1997; it was discontinued in 2000. Ten years later, it is about to make its return. Ms. Chilewich is known for her innovative use of textiles in everyday items; true to that, the 19-inch-tall RayTrays sloping stainless-steel frame holds three separate trays, made of a flexible nylon-Lycra blend. The tiered trays, which are removable and machine-washable, allow fruit and vegetables (or whatever other food theyre holding) to breathe. I was inspired by the idea of making a container entirely out of fabric, Ms. Chilewich said, because I love stretching the limits of what material can do. Available in black/smoke/off-white, green and off-white, the RayTray ($125) goes on sale Sept. 8 on chilewich.com; orders will be taken on the site starting Aug. 16.

title: Pressed-Glass Chandeliers by Elizabeth Lyons
description: Elizabeth Lyonss new pressed-glass chandeliers, which she makes by hand, are a result of an unlikely inspiration: her collection of vintage kitchen objects like pizzelle presses, drain grates and cast-iron hot plates.

title: Making Arrangements
description: Scenes from the Little Flower Schools wildflower-arranging class in Brooklyn.

title: Flower Arranging Finds a Younger Audience
description: THE first time I bought flowers for myself was about five years ago at the Greenmarket in Union Square, in the midst of the hottest, dullest days of summer. Feeling very alone that afternoon for a reason now forgotten, I stood admiring some tulips. For $8 they could be mine. I was in my mid-20s and it seemed like such a luxury to buy myself flowers for no reason, no occasion. But that day I had the money in my wallet, and soon I was carrying the tulips home. I stuck them in a glass pitcher and watched them bloom, until their stems bowed and swept the tabletop and the petals all dropped off.

description: Cond Nast continued its retooling on Wednesday with the appointment of Joe Simon as chief technology officer. Mr. Simon, 48, was previously chief technology officer for Viacom.

title: Conserving Creativity, Cow Bones Included
description: As a conservator specializing in sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art since 1984, Lynda A. Zycherman, 61, has applied a preservationists touch to sculpture composed of every conceivable material: marble, bronze, steel, textiles, chocolate and  once was enough  three tons of cow bones imported from Italy. Ms. Zycherman deemed the bones unsanitary and sent them to Oklahoma to be pickled before allowing a Marina Abramovic sculpture to go on display recently. Widowed with two grown children, she lives on the Upper West Side.

description: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  Two years ago, as the election season roared toward November, people here in northern Colorado feared the economy was headed for a cliff. They sought refuge in voting for Democrats in numbers not seen in generations.

description: CHICAGO  Lets face it, turning 49 is no fun. Especially when your wife and children are not around to celebrate. But to have the birthday cake scratched by the Secret Service?

description: Vicente Wolf, a designer known for his pale interiors, turned a plain room in a Manhattan apartment into a fuchsia-saturated space on a budget of $5,000.

title: Tips From Europe on I.P.O. for G.M.
description: The Obama administration should brush up on recent European financial history. That could help it pitch the coming initial public offering of General Motors. If the I.P.O. is priced too high and flops, it will be much harder for the government to offload the rest of its shares without losing money in future sales. But if G.M.s stock market debut is priced too low and shares surge, the White House would risk accusations of favoring Wall Street at the expense of taxpayers.

title: Oil Spill Cleanup Workers Include Many Very, Very Small Ones
description: Among the hidden stars of the gulf cleanup is an oil-hungry bacterium that Dr. Seuss could have named  Alcanivorax. It and fellow microbes are breaking down a significant amount of the oil that gushed into the environment from BPs runaway well, scientists say. The microbial feasting is known as biodegradation.

title: Promising Results Reported for Cholesterol and Hepatitis C Drugs
description: New drugs for hepatitis C and superhigh cholesterol succeeded in late-stage clinical trials, the developers of the products announced on Wednesday. But both drugs have side effects that could dampen sales, analysts said.

title: Vicente Wolf Creates an Indian Sanctuary in Kips Bay
description: FOUR years ago, after selling her weekend home in Amagansett, Harrice Miller, a dealer in and historian of costume jewelry, began reexamining her life.

title: Toyota Recovers From a Slump to Report a $2.2 Billion Profit
description: TOKYO  Despite a strong yen and the lingering fallout from recalls, the automaker Toyota said Wednesday that it had returned to a profit in the April-to-June quarter because of strong sales in emerging markets and aggressive cost-cutting.

description: You fall asleep on a summer night bound for the minds winter pantry, a memory to be opened in some dark, cold day as an anti-depressant. Windless. Warm. The lake in glassy repose. The mountains in silvery silhouette lit by the moon. Sleep is deep. You control your fate.

title: Framing the Afghan Debate With a Magazine Cover
description: Not only has President Obama found flagging support among Democrats on the U.S. troop buildup in Afghanistan, the recent disclosure by WikiLeaks of military documents which paint a bleak picture of the war has added to skepticism about the buildup of forces, the progress made so far, and whether the goals of U.S. policy are realistic or achievable.

title: Woods, Still Winless, Returns to the Right Place for a Victory
description: AKRON, Ohio  Wearing a goatee and his game face, Tiger Woods was all business when he showed up Wednesday at Firestone Country Club. In his first meeting with the news media since he tied for 23rd in the British Open at St. Andrews, Woods looked both rested and ready and left no doubt about the confidence he is bringing to his latest title defense, a W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational event that he has won seven times.

title: Ryan and Mark Cuban Start Texas Showdown in the Rangers Auction

The judges rejected the motion on Wednesday, saying that Ms. Campbell, a hostile witness, had been uncooperative and that prosecutors could not be expected to provide such a statement from her. Ms. Campbell was subpoenaed to testify whether Mr. Taylor had sent her a gift of rough diamonds after they met at a charity dinner in 1997 in South Africa. Prosecutors hope to show that Mr. Taylor lied under oath when he said that he never had any diamonds and did not trade any for weapons to support the bloody rampage by rebels in Sierra Leone during the countrys civil war.

description: In a recent bloggingheads conversation with Matt Yglesias, I tried to make the point that were unlikely to get sweeping procedural reform in Congress anytime soon despite liberal optimism on that front because nobody who isnt immersed in the angst of movement liberalism sees the first two years of the Obama administration as a period of gridlock and inaction. That conversation took place before George Packer came out with his epic New Yorker story on the dysfunctions of the Senate, which makes the strongest possible case that the institution is incapable of governing the country. I recommend reading the whole thing  but Id also associate myself with this comment, from David Frum:

title: Mary Hart to Leave Entertainment Tonight
description: After almost three decades of imbuing Entertainment Tonight with one of the perkiest dispositions and some of the shiniest teeth in television, Mary Hart said on Thursday she will leave that syndicated pop-culture program at the end of its coming 30th season.

title: Why No Villains Have Emerged From the Crisis
description: Its been almost two years since the collapse of Lehman Brothers, and so far no villain has emerged who can be brought to account.

description: Even when he isnt winning, the son of the late Dale Earnhardt Sr. remains the most popular driver in Nascar.

title: In the Name of the Father
description: He is very, very introverted, a publicist says. He lives alone. He plays video games by himself eight hours at a clip. Hes a multimillionaire, yet he lived alone for months in a 20-by-20 garage loft. The publicist makes him out to be the Howard Hughes of Nascar.

title: A Chance to Re-examine Hank Aaron
description: Alex Rodriguez was hailed as the golden one, the natural, the five-tool template almost certain to wind up with baseballs most cherished cherry on top.

description: The Senate today is likely to confirm Solicitor General Elena Kagan as the 112th Supreme Court justice and the fourth woman to sit on the court.

title: BP Done Pumping Cement Into Well
description: HOUSTON  For more than three months, an oil-weary nation has waited for the moment when engineers would begin pumping cement into BPs runaway well, in hopes of plugging its flow for good.

title: Seeing Things | Cathy of California
description: If you put Martha Stewart and Rhoda Morgenstern together, you might just get Cathy Callahan. As Cathy of California, Callahan creates whimsical shop windows and styles merchandise for Los Angeles shops like Heath Ceramics; the fashion boutique Market; Stripes, an upscale shoe store in Bel Air; and Yolk, a purveyor of groovy gifts and housewares in Silver Lake. The garland of bright yellow marshmallow Peeps that graced Yolks window around Easter time was Cathy of Californias handiwork. Callahans displays blend elegance, whimsy and humor; her windows often include cheeky one-liners. Her current window for Market, which features hanging embroidery hoops festooned with paper price tags, declares, Tag, youre it! Shes also an avid crafter and often makes the props for her displays. When a client wanted to buy the props from a display that was coming down, Callahan added a handmade craft business to her repertory. Her colorful vintage-inspired creations  like plump toadstool pincushions and bright butterfly brooches  sell out quickly at West Coast indie craft fairs like Renegade and Felt Club. Callahan once appeared on Martha Stewarts TV show, kindly but firmly demonstrating to the design maven herself how to make straw flowers from a vintage kit.

title: What Were Reading: Borders Matter
I.B.M.s Strategy in Electronic Health Records
description: I.B.M. has been quietly saying for months that it planned to enter the market for electronic health records, a business being primed with hefty government subsidies.

title: New York Send-Off | Closer to Heaven
description: Jan Benzel is an editor at The Times who is being reassigned to Paris. Before she leaves, she is attempting to do all the things in the city that every New Yorker should do, at least once.

title: Sketching a Future for Brooklyn Museum
description: THOUGH it resides in a prime example of traditional museum architecture  a Beaux-Arts building designed in 1893 by McKim, Mead & White  there is little stale or stodgy about the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Childrens Programming at Bayreuth: Wagner, of Course, and They Love It
description: BAYREUTH, Germany  There is a general and mostly well-founded perception of the Bayreuth Festival as an elitist stronghold for opera, as much a shrine to Wagner as a festival of his works. And there is no ticket harder to come by. Wagner-lovers wait an average of 10 years to get a coveted ticket to the Festspielhaus, which seats only about 2,000.

title: Russia, Crippled by Drought, Bans Grain Exports
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday banned all exports of grain after millions of acres of Russian wheat withered in a severe drought, driving up prices around the world and pushing them to their highest level in two years in the United States.

description: Wine bars and restaurants mentioned in this article:

title: Greens Debating Tactics Instead of Ideas
description: In Politco, Darren Samuelsohn has a solid roundup of reflections by environmental campaigners on why, despite spending tens of millions of dollars, they failed to gain the votes for any climate action in the Senate. But the entire discussion is about tactics, not ideas. There are scant signs, yet, that anyone within the Beltway is willing to shift toward attacking the entwined energy and climate challenges as less a 20th-century-style pollution problem and more a 21st-century-style technology and innovation opportunity.

title: Tipsy Diaries: Riesling Restraint
description: Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, quarrels with a Riesling aficionado over the flexibility of the sugary drink.

title: How I Spent My Summer of Riesling, by Terroir
description: On June 21 the sommelier and restaurateur Paul Grieco did something mischievous, idealistic, provocative, ornery and, in its way, rather sweet. Which is to say he summed up, in one sweeping gesture, what makes him such an indelible character in the New York dining and drinking scene.

title: New York Tackles Brownfields Cleanup
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Pete Grannis, the commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, announced an agreement Thursday morning that paved the way for the city to start cleaning up brownfields, or light-to-moderately contaminated areas that are not toxic enough to qualify for federal or state Superfund cleanup programs. About 7,000 vacant or underused acres around the city could be readied for new development under the program, city officials said.

title: C.I.C. Said to Deny Ties to Liverpool Bid
description: A spokesman for the sovereign wealth fund the China Investment Corporation told The Financial Times on Thursday that the fund had no plans to help Kenneth Huang, a Hong Kong businessman, buy the Liverpool soccer team, despite reports to the contrary.

title: Politician Apologizes to Don Henley for Song Parodies
description: Usually in situations like these, wed begin with a tongue-in-cheek gloss on one of Don Henleys songs  Dirty Laundry, maybe?  but under the circumstances, well just play it straight: Mr. Henley, the once and future Eagle and solo singer-songwriter, has reached a settlement with and received an apology from Chuck DeVore, the California politician, and Justin Hart, a worker for Mr. DeVores 2010 United States Senate campaign, who were found to have violated the copyrights to two of Mr. Henleys best-known tracks.

title: Sale of Troubled Buildings May Not Mean Rescue
description: Bronx portfolio, the Web posting read. These distressed properties fetches prices that are much below its market value.

title: Education Department Deals Out Big Awards
description: Teach for America, the nonprofit group that recruits elite college students to teach in public schools, and the KIPP Foundation, which runs a nationwide network of charter schools, were big winners in a $650 million federal grant competition known as Investing in Innovation, the Department of Education said Wednesday.

title: A Weekend in Boston
description: The city is starting to take on a glossier, more modern sheen.

title: Q&A: Savannah for Parents in Their 70s
description: My parents, who are in their 70s, are coming to visit Savannah this summer. They are from New York, and Savannah is on their list of possible places to retire to. Do you have any sights youd recommend?

title: Bar + Food | Portlands Happiest Hours
description: Add this to the growing list of reasons to visit (or relocate to) Portland, Ore.: the citys food-focused happy hour tradition. While other towns  notably Seattle, Los Angeles, Atlanta and Charleston, S.C.  also serve cheap eats in the late afternoon, Portland has been doing it since the last recession. If you ask restaurant owners, theyll tell you the back story: a state liquor law forbids businesses from promoting discounted alcohol, so it made sense to lure in diners with at-cost food. (Though this law has recently changed, $5 plates are more ubiquitous than ever.) And this being Portland, youre more likely to find charcuterie plates or pig heart with quince jam on the menu than sliders and fries.

title: A Lightning Rod for Debate
description: Say what you will about Alex Rodriguez  and judging from our Bats blog comments after he hit his 600th questionably legitimate home run Wednesday, a lot of you are moved to do that  he sure knows how to get people talking about him. They are rarely saying the things he would want them saying, but thats part of Rodriguezs talent, too. He is a publicity train wreck.

title: Popcast: Arcade Fires New Album
description: This week on Popcast, The Timess music podcast, Jon Pareles discusses The Suburbs by Arcade Fire, the indie-rock band from Montreal that went gold with whoa-oh-oh choruses and meditations on death and family.

title: White House Party for Africa Leaves Out Leaders
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Many of Africas leaders have spent part of their summer shuttling between capitals, congratulating one another on 50 years of independence. One capital they will not be visiting together is Washington.

title: 36 Hours in Boston
description: BOSTON is known for its bricks and brownstones, but the city is starting to take on a glossier, more modern sheen. With the completion of the $15 billion Big Dig, downtown now stretches unimpeded to the harbor, making Boston feel like a whole new city. History abounds, of course  Faneuil Hall still stands, Paul Revere is still buried at the Granary Burying Ground  but it is now joined by a high-tech exuberance, modern parks and a reclaimed harbor. Revere would not recognize it.

title: Law Will Extend Medicare Fund, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Medicare will remain financially solvent for 12 years longer than projected a year ago  until 2029  because of the cost-cutting measures in President Obamas recently enacted health care legislation, the programs trustees reported on Thursday.

title: Delgado Becoming an Option for Some Teams
description: The former Mets first baseman Carlos Delgado, recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his right hip, seems to be on the verge of a major league return.

title: A Patient Is Rescued, Quietly
description: From watching television we tend to think we know what a hospital emergency looks like: violent, dramatic and optimally bloody. Someone calls the alarm, a team that includes at least one handsome doctor surges into the room, and people yell out STAT! as needed. The patient always survives.

title: Let the Chevrolet Volt Buyer Beware, as Some Dealers Mark Up Price
description: After Chevrolets announcement last week that its 2011 Volt plug-in hybrid would sell for $41,000, it seemed that only President Obama could muster an unequivocal assessment of the car. Pretty smooth, he said, grinning, after a brief test drive on the Volts factory floor in Hamtramck, Mich. Others criticized Chevrolets parent company, General Motors, for pricing the car beyond the reach of many taxpayers who buoyed the corporation before its June 2009 bankruptcy filing.

title: Further Scrutiny of For-Profit Colleges
description: Readers of The Choice enrolled at for-profit colleges, or considering doing so, would do well to read two articles by my colleague Tamar Lewin in The Times on Thursday and Wednesday.

title: Visiting Frances Cte Fleurie
description: Former fishing villages in northern France know how to keep both visitors from Paris and local residents entertained.

title: Trying Triggerfish, Unusual in New York
description: Im not the man to write about climate change, but I can say that I was a little surprised last week to see triggerfish at our local farmers market, caught off the Hamptons. Members of this pretty large family are not unheard of around here, but Ive always thought of them as warmer-water fish. I look to readers to set me straight on this, especially if theyre anglers by profession or avocation. Anyway, never having tasted triggerfish, my wife, Jackie, and I bought a couple of five-ounce fillets to slot into the previously designed template for dinner that night.

title: Broadway Joe Pulls Up Just Short of a Guarantee
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  The Hall of Fame quarterback Joe Namath met with reporters Thursday morning in the media room of the Jets training facility. He labeled the Jets Super Bowl aspirations justified, claimed he was not concerned with the stalled contract negotiations for Darrelle Revis and repeatedly expressed concern about the teams opening at left guard.

title: Normandys Quiet Glamour
description: THE anticipation was palpable as French paparazzi and gawkers crowded the red carpet outside the beachfront Grand Htel and awaited the arrival of the film festival stars.

title: Killer of Opposition Leader in a Russian Republic Is Slain
description: MOSCOW  Gunmen strode into the Eastern Fairy Tale Cafe in the southern Russian city of Nazran on Wednesday afternoon and opened fire with automatic weapons on two police officials, Russias Investigative Committee announced. Dead on the spot was Ibragim D. Yevloyev, a police official who was involved in a notorious killing two years ago.

title: Are Your Children Really Hungry?
description: Our children are overweight. Experts blame everything from high fructose corn syrup and too much computer time to too little sleep and insidious advertising.

title: Are You Calling Me Alaa?
description: Oh, the trials of being a supermodel. Naomi Campbell testified in the war crimes trial against former Liberian President Charles Taylor this morning in The Hague. La Campbell, who had been subpoenaed about whether Taylor had gifted her blood diamonds, was asked why she didnt find being given a small pouch of dirty-looking stones by two men in the middle of the night strange. Her reply? She responded, Its not abnormal for me to get gifts, I get gifts all the time. She also claimed she didnt even know the stones, which she subsequently donated to charity, were diamonds: Im used to seeing diamonds shiny and in a box, thats the kind of diamonds Im used to seeing. At least she had the common sense not to wear diamonds with her Azzedine Alaa knit dress and matching cardigan.

title: Yogas Newest Fans
description: The 18 men and women slowly climbing the steps to their yoga class at RAIN Inwood Senior Center the other day hardly resembled the young, lithe exemplars of Americas yoga boom. You wont find the likes of Sylvia Guzman, 81, on the covers of yoga magazines or Francisco Batista, 88, on the proliferating Web sites hawking trendy yoga clothing.

title: Alignment Is Crucial, Even When Youre Great
description: Stuart Appleby had just birdied the last three holes. It was the final round of the Greenbrier Classic, and he had birdied nine holes and eagled another to shoot a historic 59. He had bogeyed only one of 72 holes during the tournament. He was on fire, playing almost as precisely - 22-under par for the four days - as any golfer could reasonably expect.

description: In today's Timescast, political repercussions from the ruling on same sex marriage in California, a Ground Zero update and Frank Bruni on the virtues of Riesling wine.

description: Bummer, man: a planned biographical film about Jerry Garcia will have to keep on truckin without any of the original music of the Grateful Dead or the involvement of Mr. Garcias family, Variety reported [registration required].

But the financial picture for both Medicare and Social Security has improved because of changes mandated by the new health care law, according to a new article by The Timess Jackie Calmes.

title: Alternatives to Overdraft Protection
description: Because of the new overdraft law fully going into effect on Aug. 15, new and existing bank customers will be able to withdraw more than is in their checking accounts only if they opt in to pay for overdraft protection from their banks. Previously, banks had automatically signed up consumers for the service and then charged customers hefty fees whenever they covered an overdraft.

title: Do Dispersants Pose a Risk in Seafood?
description: In an article on Wednesday and a followup on Thursday, my colleague Leslie Kaufman and I wrote about a new government report that says that about three-quarters of the oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill has effectively been dealt with through capture, skimming, burning, dispersion or dissolution. The implication is that the oil poses little additional risk to shorelines or at the oceans surface.

title: Brown to Vote No on Kagan Nomination
description: Senator Scott Brown, the Massachusetts Republican, said on Thursday that he would not support Solicitor General Elena Kagans nomination to the Supreme Court, denying her a Republican vote that many had expected to be in her corner.

description: Earlier this year, we asked students and teachers to name the books they love to read and teach. Books like The Catcher in the Rye and To Kill a Mockingbird were favorites among teachers and students alike.

title: Marriage Rulings Unpredictable Unions
description: From the start, postures in the lawsuit challenging Californias same-sex marriage ban have been unpredictable. There was the David Boies-Ted Olson alliance arguing for the plaintiffs. The defendant in the case, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, a Republican, said, essentially, that he was glad he lost.

title: Hot Dog Champ Cleared in Stage-Storming Incident

title: We Three Things | Jiggledy-Jig
description: Jellies and jelly molds seem to be wiggling into the picture. Their structured yet bosomy shapes provide a flourish of Victoriana, and their wobbly weirdness seems to prefigure molecular cuisine. I store my hair elastics in upended enamel molds, and turned out my third summer pudding in a rabbit-shaped one from a tag sale. Theyre remarkably pretty, and they satisfy the current food-geist of homemade and arcane.

title: Hipster Replacement
description: At a recent Chanel party, a little-known D.J. took the stage to a remix of Carmina Burana and spun the crowd  which included Tim Burton, Vanessa Paradis and Johnny Depp  into a frenzy. This mix master wasnt a model or a downtown doyenne: it was Ruth Flowers, aka Mamy Rock, a grandmother well into her 70s who has put in appearances at Cannes, Glastonbury and Paris, where her factotum is based. I thought, What are they going to think of this old biddy who gets up there to play records? she says from her home in southwest England. Inspired to become a D.J. when she attended her grandsons birthday party, Flowers has worked with a French producer on mixing, as well as on her stage persona, which includes a hairstyle that looks as if Ive been plugged into an electricity cord. Spinning has eclipsed some of her other hobbies, like giving historical talks about Henry VIII, but shes happy to be busy. When you get to 60, thats when you just go to bingo, I suppose, she says, adding unnecessarily, Thats not my scene.

One of the best things about the package is that most of the content is freely accessible, as was the case with an important paper on feeding the world in the competing journal Science in February.

description: LONDON  Geert Wilders, the anti-Muslim politician who has campaigned for a tax on head scarves and a ban on the Koran, seemed poised Thursday to emerge as a prominent player in a new minority government in the Netherlands.

title: Charles Guislain | Like Tavi, Only French, Male and Blogless
description: Charles Guislain was just 15 when he crashed his first Paris runway show, Gareth Pugh in 2008. For a petit colier, he cuts an unusual image, clad in an apocalyptic Rad Hourani chain mail sheath or a princely Martin Margiela cape with hooflike Rick Owens wedge boots. The fashion commentariat thinks of him as the goth counterpoint to the kooky, hat-loving Tavi, but Guislain is no blogger. He was discovered by the raspy-voiced cult fashion journalist Diane Pernet and became something of a flaxen-haired YouTube curiosity, and he was recently the subject of a spread in Italian Vogue. description: Though it feels like a cultural violation to talk about any television shown in contest with Mad Men, our national homage to past depravities, it is merely one of two series about a good-looking divorced white man in conflict with his virility that is offered on Sunday nights at 10. The other series is Hung, a comedy that, although it has not given birth to a single trend, expression or style of tie, has distinguished itself as the most topical fictional programming on television. As its moved into its second season on HBO, Hung has become an even more finely drawn satire of the Great Recession.
