title: A Man, a Woman and the Pyramids
description: You might say that there is, in the literal, plot-summary sense, a romantic triangle at the heart of Ruba Naddas Cairo Time. An American woman waiting to meet her husband in the Egyptian capital is drawn toward a dalliance with a former colleague of his, a local resident who drives her from the airport to her hotel and graciously offers his services as tour guide and companion. But what gives this delicate, decorous movie its distinctive throb of melancholy sensuality is less the humdrum possibility of adultery than the intimation of a three-way entanglement involving the man, the woman and Cairo. The city is also clearly the principal object of Ms. Naddas ardor.

title: The Jets All-Weather Team
description: CORTLAND, N.Y. - When Rex Ryan became the Jets coach before last season, he promised an all-weather football team. On Thursday morning, extreme conditions tested that theory out at training camp.

title: Bending The Curve
description: The new Medicare Trustees Report is out. Comparing Table IIIA-2 in this years report and last years report, we get this:

title: Lobbyist Charged With Hiding Political Donations
description: WASHINGTON  In one of the biggest pay to play investigations in recent years, a protg of the late Representative John P. Murtha was indicted Thursday on charges that as a lobbyist he made hundreds of thousands of dollars in laundered campaign contributions to lawmakers, using straw donors and other illicit means to disguise the source of the money.

title: Investors Are Still Behaving Badly
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital.

title: Resurrecting Laurelton Hall
Cult Director Courts the Mass, Keeps the Crazy
description: AS he prepared to board another in a series of Virgin Atlantic flights from London to Los Angeles that have lately defined his life, Edgar Wright was presented with a quandary: Should he spend the 11 -hour trip getting some much-needed shut-eye or playing Super Mario Bros. on an in-flight video-game system?

title: Grass Fed | Korean in Massachusetts
description: The Pioneer Valley, home to a whole mess of Western Massachusettss finest higher-education operations, is not a bad place to eat per se. But I know from friends who live or have lived there that the options can feel limited. So I was stoked, when passing through last week, to be taken to a restaurant that I hadnt heard of and actually liked: Gohyang Korean Restaurant, a shoebox of a place on Route 9. Theres no reason why there shouldnt, couldnt or wouldnt be a good Korean restaurant there, but I was quietly thrilled about it.

title: Fighting Good Fight, the Swashbuckler Becomes a Hero
description: IF Errol Flynn hadnt existed, Raoul Walsh might have invented him.

title: Fungus on Track to Extinguish Bats in Northeast
description: .A research team organized by Thomas Kunz of Boston University has concluded in a new paper that a common, beneficial bat species is likely to be completely wiped out across much of the Northeastern United States within 20 years due to a spreading fungal infection. The basics are laid out in the news section of the journal Science, which is also publishing the research paper. The news report mentions that bat biologists suggest landowners can boost bats prospects by erecting bat houses.

title: Goldman vs. Morgan Stanley: A Duel of 2 Economists
description: When the latest unemployment figures are announced on Friday, all of Wall Street will be watching. But for Richard Berner of Morgan Stanley and Jan Hatzius of Goldman Sachs, the results will be more than just another marker in an avalanche of data.

title: Letter: A Cheaper Phone Choice
description: To the Editor: Regarding Staying in Touch, for Less (Aug. 1): If you are a truly global traveler, the simplest solution by far is to buy a cheap, unlocked SIM-ready phone ($50 or less) and buy SIM cards in each country you travel to. SIMs generally cost $5 or less. With a local number you can very cheaply call hotels, restaurants, etc., in that country to book a spot, and you can call or text home much more cheaply than you can while roaming on your home-based plan.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: This isnt the first time we have highlighted the work of Mohammad Sajjad, who captured a heart-rending image of a child on a roadside near Peshawar, Pakistan, on Thursday (Slide 5). Of the estimated three million people the United Nations said have been uprooted by recent flooding, nearly half are children.

title: Big 12 Defections Force Kansas to Sing a New Tune
description: Conference realignment has upended rivalries, schedules and perhaps the balance of power in college football, but it has also caused some musical consternation at Kansas. The Kansas fight song, Im a Jayhawk, contains multiple references to Nebraska and Colorado, who left the Big 12 this summer for the Big Ten and Pac-10:

title: For Love and Money
description: Not everyone who has a child is cut out to be a parent, and not every kid is cut out for a carefree childhood. Theres no clean connection between these two accidents of character and fate. Hot-housed children can end up with blighted lives, while neglected kids can succeed and thrive as adults. Nonetheless, when Claire, one of the two women at the center of Mona Simpsons new novel, My Hollywood, has a baby in her late 30s, she convinces herself not only that shes an unfit mother but that her 17-week-old son, Will (who seemed more furious than other babies, more bereft) is aware of her shortcomings: Will and I both felt astonished that he was stuck with me. Is an infant capable of such nuanced misgiving? Or could Claire be projecting? Taking no chances, she hires a nanny, Lola  a mother of five from the Philippines and the novels other central character  to take care of Will and to lighten her psychic load. But eventually she starts to worry: What if the nanny isnt up to the job either? How can she know?

title: Measures to Legalize Pot May Lure Young to Polls
description: A coalition of liberals, police officers, and a former Reagan administration lawyer say weed could be the secret to high voter turnout this November.

title: A Dictator Is No Match for a Tough School Board
description: When Cassius declares, I ... have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone, what the audience sees is that noble Romans open blouse with a black bra underneath.

title: Letter: Holiday on Campus
description: To the Editor: In Britain, Dorms Have Summer Jobs (Aug. 1): What a delightful article. Before I read the piece, I noticed the gorgeous photo of the dining hall at Oxford Universitys Keble College. It reminded me of a Harry Potter production, as it did your writer.

title: G.M. Pushes for U.S. to Sell Entire Stake at I.P.O.
description: 7:33 p.m. | Updated Eager to shed his companys stigma of being government-owned, the chief executive of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., said Thursday that G.M. wanted Washington to sell its entire stake during an initial public offering, The New York Timess Nick Bunkley reports from Traverse City, Mich.

title: As Darkness Falls
description: For busy, harried or distractible readers who have the time and energy only to skim the opening paragraph of a review, Ill say this as quickly and clearly as possible: The Death of the Adversary and Comedy in a Minor Key are masterpieces, and Hans Keilson is a genius.

title: Devil Wears Prada Author Buys Condo
description: IN Lauren Weisbergers new novel, Last Night at Chateau Marmont, a musician shoots from modest Manhattan nightclubs to big-time name-in-lights stardom after a performance on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno. The book follows his wife as she deals with the difficulties of their new life, fame and the media.

title: Theater Listings: Aug. 6  12
description: Theater

title: Senate Approves $26 Billion in Teacher Aid
description: The Senate on Thursday approved $26 billion in aid to states and school districts, a decision that Democrats said would prevent the layoffs of tens of thousands of teachers and public employees.

title: An Art Experiment in Flashy Las Vegas
description: Las Vegas may be known for gambling and gaudiness, but when it comes to art, the exhibitions on view there have been surprisingly highbrow. Over the years its galleries have displayed canvases by Rembrandt and Picasso, Monet and van Gogh.

title: New Editor Named for Architectural Digest
description: Margaret Russell will succeed Paige Rense as editor in chief of Architectural Digest, Cond Nast announced on Thursday. Ms. Russell was previously vice president and editor in chief of brand contentat Elle Decor. She will step into her newdigs in early September. Ms. Rense joined Architectural Digest in 1970 as an associate editor and was named editor in chief shortly thereafter.

title: Goldmans Trading Plan: Shades of Volcker
description: With Goldman Sachs planning a move of its proprietary trading desk to its asset management arm, according to press reports, another bank is planning a big response to the just-passed financial regulatory overhaul

title: The Global War on Small People
description: In Graham Greenes 1940 novel, The Power and the Glory, the unnamed protagonist, a whisky priest, utters the books most resonant line. Hate, the priest says, was just a failure of imagination.

title: A Foreigner Carrying in the Crook of His Arm a Tiny Bomb
description: Prologue: A Missile in the Living Room

title: Continental Tries Out Self-Boarding
description: First they took away the complimentary travel kits. Then the meals. The inexorable transition of the experience of flying into something more akin to public transportation may be taking a major step forward. Continental Airlines has begun testing out self-boarding at George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston, it said recently, becoming the first airline in the United States to do so. Passengers who have checked in can swipe their boarding passes at gates reminiscent of turnstiles and then proceed to their departing flight.

title: Mapquest, Nicaraguan Style
description: Nicaragua is infamous for being a land of few street signs and fewer house numbers, a place where three blocks north of where the market used to be is a legitimate address. (Like, even on business cards.)

title: A Not-So-Macho Cops Moment of Truth
description: Is it possible to run a bait-and-switch scam in reverse? I cant think of another way to describe the odd trick pulled off by The Other Guys, a new goofballs-and-fireballs comedy directed by Adam McKay. The closing credit sequence is, in effect, a tease for a movie quite different from the one that has just concluded.

title: Lookbooks
description: Three books due out this fall find fashion in a retrospective mood. Yohji Yamamoto: My Dear Bomb (Ludion), the first-ever biography of the designer, fittingly ditches an orthodox chronology for a series of short fictions written by Yamamoto interspersed with vivid reminiscences. (For those looking for something a little more linear, the book concludes with a timeline featuring never-before-seen personal images.) Anna Suis eponymous biography (Chronicle Books), on the other hand, is a more visual feast. Written by Andrew Bolton, a curator at the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this book will showcase 400 photographs from the Sui archives and include text by the White Stripes frontman Jack White and her longtime collaborator Steven Meisel. Finally, two photographers put the art in Rodarte in a new book from JRP Ringier. Rodarte, Catherine Opie, Alec Soth (above) is an off-the-cuff collaboration with Kate and Laura Mulleavy that delves into the design duos myriad obsessions.

title: Despite Appeal, Holocaust Documentary Will Retain R-Rating
description: The R-rating for the Holocaust documentary A Film Unfinished will stand, an appeals board ruled on Thursday, according to Oscilloscope Laboratories, which is releasing the movie. Oscilloscope had appealed the rating by the Classification and Rating Administration, which cited disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities including graphic nudity. The film, directed by Yael Hersonski, dissects a Nazi propaganda film that purported to depict life among Jews in the Warsaw ghetto during World War II but actually manipulated its portrayal to reinforce anti-Jewish policies. The rating bars those under 17 from seeing the film without an accompanying parent or guardian. Oscilloscope argued that a similar film, The Last Days, on which Steven Spielberg was an executive producer, had been rated PG-13. Spokesmen for the ratings administration did not immediately respond to a query. Oscilloscope said the board ruled 12 to 3 against changing the rating. A Film Unfinished won a film editing award at the Sundance Film Festival earlier this year.

title: Beyond the Blockbusters at the Met
description: Wall Street may be fattening up, but New Yorks art institutions arent. Theres a conspicuous recessionary logic behind the Metropolitan Museum of Arts two marquee spring-summer exhibitions, one devoted to Picasso, the other to American fashion. Both were homegrown, low-overhead productions, pulled entirely from the permanent collection.

title: Five and Five: No. 34, Texas A&M
description: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Pauls top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Todays team, No. 34, is Texas A&M. You can find a larger Texas A&M preview at Pre-Snap Read.

title: Staying Ashore, or Wading In
description: Cover the Waterfront week on City Room is drawing to an end. Thank you for all your waterfront photos  were no longer accepting submissions. Tomorrow, we will publish a slideshow of several hundred of them. Heres the last installment in our series of riparian adventures.

title: The Hard Part of Tennis in New York? Finding an Open Court
description: THE pleas are routinely posted in online forums like one devoted to sports on Yelp.com: Is there a way to play tennis on the cheap in N.Y.C.? asked Abel M., who couldnt help recalling growing up where tennis was free. Laura A. had waited three hours at Riverside Park and wanted to know where there were less crowded courts. Another Yelp poster, Jim R., captured their frustration: I wish I could play more tennis, but its such a hassle to play living in N.Y.

title: Varieties of Abstraction
description: Happy birthday, abstract painting! One of the prides and joys of Western modernism is in the vicinity of its first centennial. Its hard to be much more exact, since its invention was a scattered effort extending over years if not decades. Fans of Frantisek Kupka should have celebrated last year; Kandinskys crowd can uncork the Champagne in 2012. Devotees of Mondrian or Malevich will have to wait a year or two longer.

title: Beach-Blanket Lingo
description: When Jake Tapper of ABCs This Week asked Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey last month for his opinion of the MTV reality series Jersey Shore, the contempt in the governors voice was obvious. What it does is it takes a bunch of New Yorkers  most of the people on Jersey Shore are New Yorkers  drops them at the Jersey Shore and tries to make America feel like this is New Jersey, Christie said. In other words, in the parlance of the Jersey Shore, the show is about a bunch of bennies  disagreeable tourists from the metropolitan New York region who crowd the beaches every summer.

title: What Fridays Jobs Report May Hold
description: Is it a pause, or are we spluttering?

title: Still Upbeat About the Recovery
description: I know I raised some eyebrows a few months ago when I wrote that the economy was turning around (Here Comes the Recovery!). While lots of folks commented that they, too, were experiencing a resurgence in their business over the past few quarters, there seemed to be just as many naysayers who saw only dark clouds ahead. With the recent news that gross domestic product grew at a less-than-expected 2.4 percent in the second quarter (down from a revised 3.7 percent in the first quarter), the naysayers (including economists) who are predicting a double-dip recession are getting louder than ever.

title: Letters: The End of Forgetting
description: Jeffrey Rosens article overlooks the simplest tactic for managing your reputation online: Dont post. No one is forcing you to upload embarrassing photos, reveal personal information or make ill-informed comments on Web sites. Life will continue, even if its not broadcast in its entirety.

title: The Mystery of the Lost City
description: WHEN it was built in 1833 Colonnade Row was the biggest thing in New York since the British occupation, a 200-foot-long sweep of glistening white marble in the form of a Corinthian colonnade, nine houses combined into one great Greek revival statement on what is now Lafayette Street, opposite the Public Theater.

title: House Tour: New Hope, Pa.
description: WHAT House with two bedrooms, one and a half baths.

title: Letter: Mad Men-Ese
description: Ben Zimmer quotes the creator of Mad Men, Matthew Weiner, as regretting that he allowed the character Joan on the show to use the phrase the medium is the message in 1960, four years before Weiner believes Marshall McLuhan introduced it in print.

title: Industry Group Backs Goldman on Bayou Suit
description: Goldman Sachs, which is suing to overturn a $20.5 million arbitration award to creditors of the failed hedge fund firm Bayou Group, received support from the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association on Thursday, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Abstraction in Manhattan
description: Abstract art is unusually visible in galleries around town this summer.

title: Small Gems
description: Small shows at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are worth a good, long look.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: Movies

title: Lonely Hearts Club Ban
description: My husband and I moved next door to a beautiful park. I enjoy walking there for exercise and quiet time to think. But a woman who is often there approaches random strangers and asks if they would like company. Shes with someone different every day. Shes done this to me a couple of times, then proceeds to divulge extremely intimate details about her life. Ive tried switching the times I walk, but shes always there. I find her off-putting, and I bet my neighbors do, too. What should be done?

title: Despite Industry Skepticism, South Korea and China Are Said to Plan Trade Talks
description: BEIJING  South Korea and China are likely to open free-trade talks next year, South Koreas ambassador to China said in an interview published on Thursday.

title: The View From the Lens of an Israeli Tanks Scope
description: A scene early in Lebanon dramatizes the moral confusion of combat with unusual clarity and force. Shmulik (Yoav Donat), a nervous young Israeli soldier who operates the main gun in a tank, has orders to shoot a fast-approaching car. Through his viewfinder he can see the faces of the driver and passengers, and the fact of their humanity paralyzes his hand, preventing him from firing.

title: In 911 Call, Gunman in Connecticut Says He Wishes He Had Gotten More
description: After Omar S. Thornton had gone on a shooting rampage, killing eight people at the Hartford Distributors warehouse on Tuesday morning, he called 911 from inside the buildings offices in Manchester, Conn., saying he wanted to leave a permanent record of his deadly acts.

title: Giants and Moss Both Hope He Can Contribute
description: ALBANY  By the time Sinorice Moss reached the N.F.L., in 2006, his older brother, Santana, had two seasons with more than 1,000 receiving yards. There was hope the younger Moss would follow.

title: F.C.C. Chief Opposes Fees for Internet Priority
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said Thursday that he believed it was unacceptable for Internet service providers to offer faster Internet transmission to content providers willing to pay higher fees.

title: Still Paying for Lehmans Demise
description: Nearly two years ago, in the middle of a financial crisis of historic proportions, a federal bankruptcy judge, James M. Peck, made the gutsy decision to approve the sale of the bulk of Lehman Brothers domestic investment-banking business to Barclays for between $1.3 and $1.7 billion, including Lehmans Seventh Avenue headquarters, which was worth nearly $1 billion. Judge Pecks decision came four days after a deal to sell all of Lehman to Barclays fell apart at the 11th hour and Lehman filed the largest bankruptcy case ever.

title: August: Time for an Unexamined Life
description: August in New York City is predictable: Theres a surplus of heat and a dearth of therapists, many of whom take the month off, following a tradition of Sigmund Freuds. At McNally Jackson Books in SoHo on Wednesday evening, four authors read selections of their work, under the loose theme of having a nervous breakdown, at an annual event, The Shrinks Are Away!

title: Van Hollen: Rangel, Waters Cases Show Ethics Progress
description: A high-ranking House Democrat argued on Thursday that the ethics charges against Representatives Charles B. Rangel and Maxine Waters signal something of an achievement for Democrats.

title: A Band of Neo-Nazis, Navigating Sexuality
description: Nicolo Donatos melodrama Brotherhood digs into the collective psyche of a Danish neo-Nazi group whose brightest recruit and biggest potential star, Lars (Thure Lindhardt), is a semi-closeted gay man with masculinity issues. An up-and-coming army officer, Lars abruptly abandons the military when his expected promotion to master sergeant is denied because of rumors that he has made drunken passes at fellow soldiers. While he bides his time considering a course of action, his well-connected middle-class parents arrange behind his back for him to take an army post in New Zealand; he angrily rejects their interference.

title: Dear FloFab: Do I Need Furniture to Have a Party?
description: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Life, That Continuing Mystery, Should Be Lived, Not Worried Over
description: In Eccentricities of a Blond Hair Girl, the Portuguese filmmaker Manoel de Oliveiras exquisite but peculiar screen adaptation of a short story by Ea de Queiros, everything changes yet remains the same. All is illusion and beyond human understanding, and memory is not to be trusted in a film that takes a long view that encompasses generations. An excerpt from The Keeper of Sheep, a 1914 poem by the Portuguese writer Fernando Pessoa that is recited in the movie, distills the perspective of Mr. de Oliveira, who at the age of 101 should know something about farsightedness.

title: Holocaust-Denying Cartoonist Finds a Home Online
description: On Thursday, a brief report on the Web site of Irans semiofficial Fars news agency announced the launch of a new Web site, Holocartoons.com, devoted to the work of Maziar Bijani, a Holocaust-denying Iranian cartoonist.

title: A Purveyor of Prurience in a Family-Man Guise
description: Apparently there is quite a bit of pornography on the Internet. If you have also heard something about this, and wondered how exactly it came to be, then you might be curious about Middle Men, a new movie about the discreet online use of credit cards, directed by George Gallo.

title: G.M. Pushes for U.S. to Sell Entire Stake at I.P.O.
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich.  Eager to rid his company of the stigma of being government owned, the chief executive of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., said Thursday that G.M. wanted Washington to sell its entire stake during an initial public offering.

title: In a One-Horse Stable, a Forlorn Filly Has Come From Nowhere
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  A few days after he bought a modestly bred horse from a friend named Don Hunt, Tim Snyder took a moment to reflect. He had no money, no horse trailer to get his new acquisition to where he needed to go and a filly that had been rejected by nearly everyone else who had come in contact with her. The horse had a clubfoot, a bad shoulder, a reputation for being slow and was blind in one eye, reason enough for Snyder to second-guess what he had just done.

title: Revolving-Door Romances for Modern-Day Chinese
description: Drunken nights without hope, like this one: I spend them wandering outside until the sky grows pale. Those words, written in 1923 by the Chinese author Yu Dafu, serve as the epigraph for Lou Yes rambling, unstrung soap opera Spring Fever. As a voice-over murmurs the epigraph, the camera surveys the murky skyline of Nanjing, the Chinese city through which its restless young characters drift in a state of sullen heat. The tableau is one of the few reflective moments in an otherwise chaotic, distracted melodrama.

title: Mexican Guest Workers, Laid Off, Want BPs Help
description: NEW ORLEANS  Soon after the oil from the Deepwater Horizon began gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, business at the Ramada Plaza Beach Resort in Fort Walton Beach, Fla., dried up  and so did the jobs of five Mexican housekeepers who were guest workers at the hotel under contracts guaranteeing them work until Nov. 1.

title: Keeping Score: An Ace, and Some Hope, Return for Red Sox
description: On Friday, the Boston Red Sox will arrive at Yankee Stadium for a four-game series. When Boston came to New York last August, they were only two and a half games out of first place. In 2008, they were four and a half out of first when they made the August trip. And in 2007, the Red Sox were in first place, by seven and a half games, when they traveled to Yankee Stadium in August.

title: Happy Feet Waging Hip-Hop Battles
description: Partway through Step Up 3D theres a number unlike anything else in the movie. Set to a remix of Fred Astaires version of I Wont Dance, blaring from an ice cream trucks loudspeaker, its the films most conspicuous attempt to ride  Astaires coattails and is its only memorable dance. Thats not because of the choreography, which is ho-hum, but because for a few moments the dancing helps tell the story, taking the tentative romance of Moose (Adam G. Sevani) and Camille (Alyson Stoner) a few steps further.

title: U.S. Tells WikiLeaks to Return Afghan War Logs
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon demanded on Thursday that WikiLeaks do the right thing and remove from its Web site tens of thousands of classified documents about the war in Afghanistan, and return to the military thousands of others that it had not yet made public.

title: A Whirlwind Moves Into G.M.s Marketing Office
description: NEVER mind the globe-trotting rou whom Dos Equis beer describes as the most interesting man in the world. On Madison Avenue, at least, that sobriquet belongs these days to Joel Ewanick.

title: Senate Passes Child Nutrition Act
description: The Senate on Thursday approved a long-awaited child nutrition act that intends to feed more hungry kids and make school food more nutritious, and it provides for $4.5 billion over the next decade to make that happen.

title: A New Drug Is King in Manhattan
description: Twelve, the Joel Schumacher-directed screen adaptation of Nick McDonells controversial best-selling novel, to quote the films production notes, sinks under the weight of its pretensions, beginning with the first words uttered by its omniscient narrator, Kiefer Sutherland. Introducing the main character, White Mike (Chace Crawford of Gossip Girl, painfully miscast), a drug dealer to rich and disaffected youth living on Manhattans Upper East Side, Mr. Sutherland affects the insinuating, too-cool-to-be-ruffled tone of a latter-day Humphrey Bogart, minus the vocal gravel.

title: A Legal Victory for Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Avon Calling!
description: At first I didnt notice the Avon truck parked on Fifth Avenue in front of the General Motors Building this morning, and I thought the line of people was for the Apple store. On second glance I noted that people inside the Avon truck had their heads in washbowls and were getting a public shampoo. What had they done to deserve that? No, no, Avon was just promoting a new anti-frizz product on a steamy summer day, and a lot of folks were giving it a whirl.

title: A Discouraged Moviegoer, and a Cause for Optimism
description: To the Editor:

title: Abuse of Painkillers
description: To the Editor:

title: Old-Fashioned Farming
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Indicts 14 Accused of Supporting Terrorist Group in Somalia
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Thursday announced the indictment of 14 people  many of them United States citizens  accused of funneling money, personnel and services to the Shabab, the Islamist terrorist group fighting an insurgency in Somalia.

title: Survival and a Cancer Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Frim Fram Sauce
description: Why, you ask? To go with tomorrows column.

title: Ryan Group Wins Rights to Rangers at Auction
description: FORT WORTH  When the bankruptcy auction of the Texas Rangers ended early Thursday morning after a nearly 16-hour slog, the team was in the hands of Nolan Ryan and Chuck Greenberg, who all along were Major League Baseballs preferred buyers.

title: Dursts Make Deal for Stake In New Trade Center Tower
description: The Durst real estate family, which has 10 office towers in Midtown Manhattan, will soon own a piece of what will be New York Citys tallest building  the 1,776-foot skyscraper known as 1 World Trade Center.

title: Blagojevich Deliberations Lead to Speculation
description: CHICAGO  Speculation over how long it will take jurors to decide the fate of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, has reached the point where one blogger here wondered publicly what a jurors new choice of casual attire (khaki shorts) might signal about how much longer they would deliberate.

title: McConnell Not Amused as Franken Fidgets
description: Senator Al Franken, the Minnesota Democrat and former comedian, has kept his irrepressible side pretty well repressed since entering Congress last year. But he failed Thursday.

title: $16.6 Million in Fines After Fatal Blast at a Connecticut Plant
description: Federal safety officials on Thursday issued $16.6 million in proposed fines in connection with a huge explosion at a power plant that killed six workers in Middletown, Conn., determining that construction companies had blatantly disregarded industry procedures designed to safeguard workers.

title: Hiroshima and the Art of Outrage
description: Tokyo

title: Wildfires Spread in Russia
description: Russias worst heat wave since record-keeping began here more than 130 years ago has exacerbated a severe drought and wildfires, which have been spreading across the countrys central and western regions.

title: Romer Leaves as Head of Council of Economic Advisers
description: Christina D. Romer, the chairwoman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, will step down from the post next month, the White House announced Thursday night.

title: Senate Votes $26 Billion for States and Schools
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday approved $26 billion in aid to states and school districts to prevent the layoffs of tens of thousands of teachers and government workers while allocating $600 million to strengthen border security as senators headed toward an August recess.

title: Nascar Schedule Shuffle Begins as a Sprint Race Leaves Atlanta
description: Atlanta Motor Speedway, which has played host to at least two races per year in Nascars top series since 1960, announced Thursday that it would have only one Sprint Cup race in 2011  the first tweak in what may become a substantial alteration to the season schedule.

title: Inventing Our Way Out of Joblessness
description: AS President Obama and Congress search for ways to jump-start job creation in our stalled economy, their best strategy may be right under their noses  in the voluminous backlogged files of the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

title: Creepiness and Twists in a Hostage Thriller
description: The British actor Eddie Marsan ("The New World," "Happy-Go-Lucky") does clenched rage and disappointment better than anyone right now, and he provides the creeps in the creepy, twisty Disappearance of Alice Creed, a hostage thriller written and directed by J Blakeson in his feature debut.

title: Despite Mets Struggles, Wilpon Hints at Minayas Return
description: Fred Wilpon, principal owner of the Mets, made a comment at a news conference Thursday that indicated Omar Minaya would still be the general manager next year.

title: In Indonesia, Many Eyes Follow Money for Hajj
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  As the nation with the worlds largest number of Muslims, Indonesia every year sends the most pilgrims to Mecca by far. About one out of 10 believers who performed the hajj last year were Indonesian.

title: Its Jeters Turn to Chase a Milestone
description: Derek Jeter has an uncluttered mind. It frees him to concentrate on the everyday grind of baseball, not the hypothetical or theoretical. Winning is all that seems to matter to Jeter, who once again is on the cusp of a milestone, even if he would be one of the last to talk about it.

title: Corporate Funds Aid Centers Tied to Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly a dozen current or former lawmakers have been honored by university endowments financed in part by corporations with business before Congress, posing some potential conflicts like that attributed to Representative Charles B. Rangel in an House ethics complaint.

title: Jeter Foundation Honors Graduates
description: On the eve of a four-game series against the Boston Red Sox and in the middle of a tight division race, Derek Jeter still found an opportunity Thursday night to have dinner with a few friends.

title: The Flimflam Man
description: One depressing aspect of American politics is the susceptibility of the political and media establishment to charlatans. You might have thought, given past experience, that D.C. insiders would be on their guard against conservatives with grandiose plans. But no: as long as someone on the right claims to have bold new proposals, hes hailed as an innovative thinker. And nobody checks his arithmetic.

title: Guest List for Rangels Birthday Celebration Shrinks
description: One New York representative said he could not make it because he had to march in a local firefighters parade. Another said that, as much as she wanted to go, she had to visit family out of town. Yet another just sent his regrets, saying he would be traveling that day  in Connecticut.

title: Ragbrai
description: Bike enthusiasts and amateurs -- numbering near 20,000 this year -- meander across Iowa's highways every July for Ragbrai, a bike event centered more around camaraderie than competition.

title: A War Story Continued
description: If you saw Ari Taubs World War II drama The Fallen when it was released in New York in 2006, then you know how his new World War II drama, Last Letters From Monte Rosa, ends. You also have a pretty good idea of how it begins, and what comes in between. Thats because theyre essentially the same movie.

title: Home for Life
description: My husband and I spent a year looking for our first home. Every Sunday, wed jump in the car with driving directions and hope, the latter often dashed before we even got out of the car. The open houses were often short stories unto themselves: what exactly  or who  was behind that padlocked door in the hall? Who thought to put the kitchen next to the master bedroom? What sort of people suspend a suit of armor over their bed?

title: Martinez Going to Disney World, Then Maybe to Contender
description: Last July, Pedro Martinez signed with Philadelphia as a free agent and helped the defending champion Phillies make a second straight run to the World Series. That run ended in the Bronx, where Martinez was the starting pitcher in the Game 6 finale, won by the Yankees, 7-3.

title: Xenophobia: Casting Out the Un-French
description: France has no equivalent to the 14th Amendment, but the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, who likes to be known as Sarko the American, also is fanning dangerous anti-immigrant passions for short-term political gain.

title: An Unusual Concert Tour
description: Len Gieco, the well-known Argentine folk singer, is so determined to put the spotlight on others in Mundo Alas (World Wings), an admirable documentary about an unusual concert tour he led, that you end up wanting to wrestle him into a chair and make him talk.

title: Xenophobia: Fear-Mongering for American Votes
description: Leading Republicans have gotten chilly toward the Constitutions 14th Amendment, which guarantees citizenship to people born in the United States. Senators Mitch McConnell, John McCain, Lindsey Graham, Jeff Sessions and Jon Kyl have been suggesting that the country should take a look at it, re-examine it, think it over, hold hearings. They seem worried that maybe we got something wrong nearly 150 years ago, after fighting the Civil War, freeing enslaved Africans and declaring that they and their descendants were not property or partial persons, but free and full Americans.

title: Exotic Deals Put Denver Schools Deeper in Debt
description: In the spring of 2008, the Denver public school system needed to plug a $400 million hole in its pension fund. Bankers at JPMorgan Chase offered what seemed to be a perfect solution.

title: In 911 Call, Killer of 8 Spoke of Wanting to Kill More
description: The 911 call lasted just more than four minutes, the rare recorded words of a killer moments after he had slain eight people and was about to end his own life.

title: Gay Marriage Ruling a Challenge for Both Parties
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judges decision on Wednesday overturning Proposition 8  Californias ban on same-sex marriage  has tossed a largely unwanted issue into the middle of the November midterm elections.

title: Caveat Emptor, Continued
description: A few years ago, the securities markets financed hundreds of billions of dollars in mortgages without any government guarantee. Now, those markets are virtually closed to such financing.

title: Wall St. Faces Specter of Lost Trading Units
description: They are the elite among the elite at Goldman Sachs, highfliers who are the envy of Wall Street.

title: A Mountain View
description: You may not believe its possible to bore people to death with a film about risking your life, but The Wildest Dream comes shockingly close. Positing that George Mallory, the renowned British climber who vanished on Mount Everest in 1924, might have actually reached the summit, this stodgy documentary from National Geographic Entertainment feels as antiquated as Mallorys hobnailed boots.

title: Turning a Crisis Into an Opportunity
description: CHICAGO  At a political fund-raiser on Thursday for a close friend running for his old Senate seat, President Obama brought up the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico to make his case to voters.

title: The Broadband Gap
description: Since it started measuring in 1999, the Federal Communications Commission invariably concluded that the spread of broadband service was progressing just fine. In 2008, it said more than 99 percent of Americans lived in areas that had access to high-speed Internet networks.

title: A Campaign Vow Come Due
description: As the nation veers toward an era of laissez-faire campaign spending by corporations and unions, it is urgent that President Obama deliver on his promise to repair the system of publicly subsidized campaign financing.

title: Two New Paths to the Dream: Regeneration
description: Two research reports published Friday offer novel approaches to the age-old dream of regenerating the body from its own cells.

title: Revenue at Viacom Remains the Same, but Cost-Cutting Helps Lift Profit
description: Viacom, which is controlled by Sumner M. Redstone, reported roughly the same amount of revenue for the quarter ending in June  $3.3 billion  as it did in the quarter a year earlier, yet its profit rose almost 52 percent, to $420 million, from $277 million last year, largely because of cost cutting.

title: Imperfect Attendants
description: Watching The Parking Lot Movie, a quirky documentary about, yes, a parking lot, is probably not unlike working at such a lot: there are long stretches when not much happens, but every once in a while theres a burst of activity that is kind of enthralling.

title: Knoxville Mayor Wins Tennessee G.O.P. Primary
description: Knoxvilles mayor, Bill Haslam, won the Republican primary for governor of Tennessee, beating four opponents in a hotly contested race.

title: Top Obama Adviser on Economics to Step Down
description: WASHINGTON  Christina D. Romer is resigning as the chairwoman of President Obamas Council of Economic Advisers, the White House announced on Thursday night. She will be the second member this summer to leave an economic team that has steered the administration through the worst recession since the Depression.

title: Barclays Reports 29% Rise in Profit, Highlighting European Gains
description: The British banking giant Barclays said Thursday that its profit rose 29 percent in the first half as provisions for credit losses declined, especially at its investment banking unit.

title: Two Men and Not Quite a Baby
description: Tanya Tucker belting on the soundtrack of a Swedish romantic comedy is not something you hear every day, but she fits right in with the general eccentricity of Patrik, Age 1.5.

title: Conservative Jurist, With Independent Streak
description: Judge Vaughn R. Walker has ruled on cases involving newspaper mergers, high-tech corporate battles and the Bush administrations use of wiretaps without warrants. But nothing has earned him as much attention  and ire  as Wednesdays decision declaring Californias Proposition 8 ban on same-sex marriage unconstitutional.

title: Five and Five: No. 33, Missouri
description: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Pauls top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Todays team, No. 33, is Missouri. You can find a larger Missouri preview at Pre-Snap Read.

title: Chancellor Declares Emergency to Sidestep State Ruling and Expand Charter School
description: It took almost six months for David M. Steiner, the state education commissioner, to decide that New York City had broken the law when it decided to take space from a program for autistic children on the Lower East Side and give it to an expanding charter school.

title: Bloggingheads: Did Obama Save Us?
description: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Rich Lowry of National Review debate whether President Obama prevented economic catastrophe.

title: Body of Missing Boy Is Found in Desert About a Mile From Home
description: PHOENIX  It was not a needle in a haystack but a toddler in the desert, both of which are extremely challenging to find.

title: Snurfer
description: I feel the earth  move  under my feetI feel the sky tum-b-ling down  tum-b-ling down

title: A Busy Love Life
description: There are moments during the slog through Lucky Days, a dreary vanity project by Angelica Torn, that you think the whole thing could be a very, very deadpan parody. But eventually you have to acknowledge that this unpleasant drama set on Coney Island isnt deadpan; its just dead.

title: Medicare Stronger, Social Security Worse in Short Run, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Medicare will remain financially solvent for 12 additional years, until 2029, because of the cost-cutting measures in President Obamas recently enacted health care legislation, the programs trustees projected on Thursday.

title: Boxing Dreams
description: In The Kid: Chamaco, a gauche but likable first feature from Miguel Necoechea, a Mexican boy dreams of becoming a famous boxer. In his way are poverty, an abusive father, a corrupt cop and a bad case of asthma; in his corner are a washed-up Olympian and a kindly American doctor. Since the doctor is played by none other than Martin Sheen, we know the cinema gods, at least, are on the kids side.

title: Judge Orders Protection for Wolves in 2 States
description: A federal judge ruled Thursday that gray wolves in Montana and Idaho must be given the same protections under the federal Endangered Species Act as their cousins in Wyoming.

title: Lottery Numbers
Excerpt From New York Education: Powers and Duties of Chancellor
description: From Article 52-A - 2590-h (2-a) (f):Powers and Duties of Chancellor

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Top Time of Year in Breaststroke
description: IRVINE, Calif.  Rebecca Soni clocked the fastest time in the world this year in the 100-meter breaststroke Thursday at the USA Swimming national championships, easily beating a star-studded field that included the sentimental favorite, Amanda Beard.

title: After Marriage Ruling, Uncertainty Still Lingers
description: Hours after a federal judge declared Californias ban on same-sex marriage unconstitutional on Wednesday, Phil Ting, San Franciscos assessor-recorder, stood on the steps of City Hall and addressed a cheering crowd.

title: Zhao Retakes Lead at Womens Chess Grand Prix
Schumer Bill Seeks to Protect Fashion Design
description: The American fashion industry has been pushing hard over the last four years for copyright protection for its designs. An earlier bill in the House was deemed too broad; clothing makers argued that protection against knock-offs would only encourage frivolous lawsuits from people claiming they had the idea first. Today, after a year of negotiations, Senator Charles E. Schumer introduced a bill that seemed to satisfy the different sides of the fashion industry  and may provide some protection, too.

title: South Korea: Naval Exercises Start
description: South Korea on Thursday began one of its largest naval exercises ever in waters near a disputed border with North Korea, despite the Norths threat to retaliate. The exercises took place near where a South Korean Navy ship sank in March, torpedoed, according to South Korean investigators, by North Korea. Military officials said that South Korean marines spent the first day running drills aimed at searching for and destroying enemy submarines.

title: Mexico: Marriage Law Upheld
description: The Supreme Court upheld Mexico Citys same-sex marriage law on Thursday in an 8-to-2 decision, but postponed deciding related issues, like the adoption of children by same-sex couples, until next week. Rejecting a challenge by the attorney general, the court based its decision on the principle of equal rights and the responsibility of state governments, including the federal district that includes Mexico City, for writing their own marriage laws. The federal government had argued that the law, the first in Latin America allowing same-sex couples to marry, violates a constitutional clause protecting the family. The justices in the majority said the Constitution did not define what constituted a family.

title: Pakistan: U.S. Flood Aid Arrives
description: American helicopters began evacuating people and delivering aid to flood-ravaged northwestern Pakistan on Thursday in an effort to aid Pakistani rescue efforts and sway hearts and minds. Six Army helicopters evacuated more than 800 people from the Swat Valley and ferried 66,000 pounds of relief supplies, the United States Embassy said. The United States also said that it would provide $25 million in relief aid, in addition to the $10 million already committed. The floods, which began last week, have claimed at least 1,400 lives and uprooted more than three million people.

title: In Violent Oakland, a Rap Producer Is Changing His Tune
description: John Davis is one of the most popular rap producers in Oakland, even though he is no longer allowed to live there under the conditions of his parole.

title: Rosie ODonnell to Be Host of OWN Channel Talk Show
description: Rosie ODonnell, no longer determined to fill the time slots soon to be left by Oprah Winfrey on broadcast television, said Thursday that she was joining Ms. Winfreys forthcoming cable channel, OWN.

title: Belongings of Russian Agents Reveal Their Everyday Lives
description: Mini-recorders and notebooks. A publication on a Lockheed military aircraft. A pocket watch containing Russian writing. Sheet music. And a whoopee cushion.

title: Tofu Maker Is Idled After Recall of Products
description: Outside a padlocked warehouse on Airport Boulevard in South San Francisco, a row of parked trucks bearing the slogan Quong Hop & Co. quality soy foods since 1906 sit idle.

title: Dreams and Schemes Explode Into Global Trouble
description: A comedy with you-know-whos name in the title may not be a natural sell in America, but its hard to imagine the likable, gently satiric Bollywood film Tere Bin Laden (Without Bin Laden) ruffling too many feathers.

title: With an Assist From Craigslist, a Sex Worker Plies His Trade
description: James sat at the Sweet Inspiration cafe on Market Street in San Francisco, sipped ginger ginseng tea and talked about his job. He was once a barista in a place like this, but today he works in the oldest profession.

title: U.S. Changes Plan for Capturing Emissions From Coal
description: WASHINGTON  The Energy Department abruptly shifted course on Thursday on a flagship federal effort to capture and sequester carbon dioxide from coal-fired power plants, saying it would not finance construction of a new plant in Mattoon, Ill.

title: The Uncertainties of the Volcker Rule
description: Goldman Sachs may be rushing to reorganize or spin off its private equity and proprietary trading units to comply with the newly enacted Volcker Rule. But the directive, intended to prevent banks from making big bets for their own accounts, remains vague enough for Goldman and its Wall Street rivals to put plenty of money at risk.

title: New Editor of the Stylish at Cond Nast
description: Margaret Russell will succeed Paige Rense  once known as the archduchess of decorating  as editor in chief of Architectural Digest, Cond Nast announced on Thursday.

title: Israel: Turkish Boat Heads Home
description: The Mavi Marmara, the Turkish passenger boat at the center of a deadly raid by Israeli naval commandos as it tried to breach the blockade of Gaza in late May, was towed out of Haifa on Thursday on its way back to Turkey. Israels Defense Ministry said it would release two more Turkish vessels that were part of the flotilla.

title: Judge Sentences Ex-Officer to 5 Years for Sexual Abuse
description: A former New York City police officer who was convicted in separate trials of sexually abusing two women and trying to coerce a third to give him oral sex was sentenced on Thursday to five years in prison.

title: Marilyn Buck, Imprisoned for Brinks Holdup, Dies at 62
description: Marilyn Buck, who served more than two decades in prison for her role in the 1981 Brinks armored-car robbery in Rockland County, N.Y., in which three people were killed, died on Tuesday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 62.

title: Snagged by an N.C.A.A. Rule on Transfers
description: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: After Broadway, Obamas Turn to Washington Theater
description: Having shined a White House spotlight on Broadway over the last year, President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama are turning their attentions to theater closer to home. Arena Stage, the 60-year-old theatrical company in Washington, announced Thursday that the Obamas would be the honorary chairpeople for its inaugural 2010-11 season at its new home, the Mead Center for American Theater, in Southwest Washington. The Obamas will also serve as honorary chairs for an Oct. 25 black-tie dinner to celebrate Arenas move into the Mead Center.

title: Pressure Building on Future of 2 Coal-Burning Power Plants
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley has repeatedly billed himself as a green mayor and recently vowed to use every available tool to reduce the citys carbon footprint, but critics say City Hall has failed to grapple with Chicagos two most significant sources of greenhouse-gas pollution.

title: Settling Scores and Looking Out for No. 1, Hendon-Style
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: A City Deal Doesnt End Overtime
description: Even though most of Chicagos unionized workers agreed to forgo overtime pay and take unpaid furlough days to help reduce the citys staggering budget deficit, many city workers continue to enjoy some of the most lucrative blue-collar work available: overtime.

title: Learning in Summer, Gladly
description: There Theodore C. Sorensen was the other day, passing the torch to a new generation of Americans.

title: Word of the Day | forswear
description: forswear \for-swer\ verb

description: From Carl Richards at Bucks:

title: Space Walkers Will Sit It Out Another Day
description: A spacewalk to replace a broken coolant pump on the International Space Station has been delayed another day to Saturday morning. NASA officials said the additional day was needed to finish details and gave the space walkers a day to review the plans. A second spacewalk, to finish hooking up the replacement pump has also been pushed back, to Wednesday. The pump, which broke last Saturday, moves ammonia coolant through a loop on the outside of the space station, one of two such cooling loops. Until the pump repairs are complete, the station is operating with reduced power to avoid overheating, and scientific research has been curtailed.

title: Exotic Deals Put Denver Schools Deeper in Debt
description: In the spring of 2008, the Denver public school system needed to plug a $400 million hole in its pension fund. Bankers at JPMorgan Chase offered what seemed to be a perfect solution, Gretchen Morgenson reports in The New York Times.

title: News Quiz | August 6, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Wall St. Faces Specter of Lost Trading Units
description: They are the elite among the elite at Goldman Sachs, highfliers who are the envy of Wall Street.

title: Biopic About Jerry Garcia Wont Include His Songs
description: Bummer, man: a planned biographical film about Jerry Garcia will have to keep on truckin without any of the original music of the Grateful Dead or the involvement of Mr. Garcias family, Variety reported. Last month it was announced that Amir Bar-Lev, a filmmaker whose features include the documentaries The Tillman Story and My Kid Could Paint That, would direct a biographical film about Mr. Garcia, above, the Grateful Dead co-founder, lead guitarist and vocalist, who died on Aug. 9, 1995. Mr. Bar-Levs film, written by Topper Lilien, is adapted from the Robert Greenfield book Dark Star: An Oral Biography of Jerry Garcia, which includes interviews with Mr. Garcias band mates and relatives, and focuses on his frequent drug use, among other problems he faced in his life. In a statement reported by Variety, Mr. Garcias estate and the bands production company said: We want to make clear that neither Grateful Dead Productions nor the Jerry Garcia Family LLC are in any way working with  or are in any other way affiliated with  the supposed upcoming Amir Bar-Lev-directed biopic about Jerry Garcia. We will not be licensing any recordings from Grateful Dead or Jerry Garcias music library for this production, nor will we provide the producer-director with access to any Garcia family members. Variety said the film would probably use other peoples songs covered by Mr. Garcia earlier in his career.

title: Greece Gets Good Progress Report
description: Greeces international lenders cleared the way Thursday for Athens to receive the next installment of its bailout package, in the latest sign that the crisis surrounding European finances was starting to ebb, Suzanne Daley and Matthew Saltmarsh report in The New York Times.

title: Mary Hart to Leave entertainment Tonight
description: After almost three decades of imbuing Entertainment Tonight with one of the perkiest dispositions and some of the shiniest teeth on television, Mary Hart said on Thursday that she would leave that syndicated pop-culture show at the end of its coming 30th season. Ms. Hart, right, a Miss South Dakota turned television broadcaster, joined the fast-paced Entertainment Tonight in 1982. In a statement she said: Ive reached a point when I clearly realize its time for a change. There are many things I want to do in my life, and Id better get on with them. It will certainly be with mixed sentiments that I say goodbye at the end of the season, but it will definitely be with a sense of celebration. The coming season of Entertainment Tonight is to have its premiere on Sept. 13. CBS Television Distribution, which produces the series, said no decision had been made on Ms. Harts replacement.

title: Politician Settles Case Over Don Henley Songs
description: Don Henley, the once and future Eagle and solo singer-songwriter, has reached a settlement with, and received an apology from, Chuck DeVore, the California politician, and Justin Hart, a worker for Mr. DeVores 2010 United States Senate campaign, who were found to have violated the copyrights to two Henley hits. Mr. Henley, above, and his fellow musicians Mike Campbell and Danny Kortchmar filed suit against Mr. DeVore, a Republican member of the California State Assembly, and Mr. Hart, saying that parodies of The Boys of Summer (originally written by Mr. Henley and Mr. Campbell) and All She Wants to Do Is Dance (Mr. Kortchmar) that Mr. DeVore used in his campaign ads were made without permission. In June Judge James V. Selna of United States District Court in Santa Ana, Calif., sided with Mr. Henley on his claim. In a statement Mr. DeVore and Mr. Hart apologized to the musicians, saying: The courts ruling in this case confirms that political candidates, regardless of affiliation, should seek appropriate license authority before they use copyrighted works. Further, we regret all inaccurate, derogatory or disparaging remarks made about Mr. Henley during the course of this dispute.

title: Ravi Coltrane Signs With Blue Note
description: Ravi Coltrane, the highly regarded tenor and soprano saxophonist, is the newest addition to the roster of Blue Note Records, with an album due out next spring. His signing unites the most storied label in jazz, one of the last majors standing, with a saxophonist-bandleader from an imposing lineage: Mr. Coltranes father was John Coltrane, who similarly played tenor and soprano, reshaping the language of jazz improvisation from the mid-1950s up to his death in 1967. Mr. Coltrane, above, who turns 45 on Friday, comes to Blue Note with an established track record, having made albums for RCA Victor and Savoy Jazz. Ravis a guy weve been watching for a long time, said Bruce Lundvall, the chairman emeritus of Blue Note. The decision to sign Mr. Coltrane was made last year, he said, in the midst of festivities around the labels 70th anniversary. John Coltrane was never signed to Blue Note, but he did make one important album for the label, the 1957 hard-bop classic Blue Train. And in 2005 Blue Note released Thelonious Monk Quartet With John Coltrane at Carnegie Hall, a newly discovered recording of a 1957 concert.

title: Major-Network Choices: Reality or Reruns?
description: Wednesday nights edition of Americas Got Talent lifted NBC to another victory in the ratings, as 10 million viewers tuned in to the reality competition, according to Nielsens estimates. NBC drew somewhat lower ratings the rest of the night with Minute to Win It (6.8 million) and a repeat of Law & Order: SVU (5.9 million). CBS ranked second with a new Big Brother (6.9 million) and a repeat of Criminal Minds (7.1 million). Fox was third as So You Think You Can Dance averaged 6.1 million viewers. ABC finished fourth with comedy reruns.

title: An Early idol Producer Returns to the Fold
description: The makeover of American Idol marched forward on Thursday when Fox confirmed that Nigel Lythgoe would return to the show as one of the executive producers. The creator of Idol, Simon Fuller, said in a statement that Mr. Lythgoe would help redefine the nine-year-old singing competition. His return to the show, which he helped get off the ground, was first reported as likely last week. Mr. Lythgoe signaled in an interview this week that he wanted the show to renew its focus on the contestants. Where are these kids? he told Variety. That has got to be the priority, more than anything. More than the judges panel. That said, the changes to the panel are a priority at the moment. Last week the judge Ellen DeGeneres confirmed she was quitting the program, and another judge, Kara DioGuardi, is also expected to leave. The leading candidates to join the judges panel are Jennifer Lopez and Steven Tyler of the band Aerosmith, though Fox said on Monday that no deals had been signed. Separately, The Los Angeles Times said on Wednesday that the music producer Jimmy Iovine was joining Idol as a mentor of sorts for the contestants.

title: Trichet Sees Reasons for Optimism in Europe
description: The president of the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, offered a somewhat more optimistic assessment of the euro zone economy Thursday and said that bank stress tests in July were an important step forward in restoring market confidence.

title: Temasek Puts $35 Million Into Tudou
description: Temasek Holdings, Singapores state investment company, invested $35 million in the Chinese video Web site, Tudou.com, according to an e-mail from the Shanghai-based start-up, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Wildfires Ravaging Swaths of Russia
description: MOSCOW  Wildfires that have overwhelmed Russias firefighting services and burned freely through large areas of the heat-seared countryside have claimed 52 lives, clouded Moscow in smoke and on Friday forced the military to transfer rockets away from a garrison near the capital.

title: Canadian Finance Chiefs So-Called Problem
description: In a world of deepening fiscal deficits, Finance Minister Jim Flaherty of Canada has a rare problem: His countrys strong economy is pushing up the currency. And even that doesnt really worry him.

title: Winning Funds Wary of Slowdown
description: Winning hedge fund managers expect the American and European economies to slow, according to Bloomberg Businessweek. With some saying they plan to bet against industries that do poorly when the economy loses steam and others betting against consumer-related stocks, hedge fund managers are taking less risk, using less debt and making fewer trades.

title: C2Call Raises $2 Million to Spread Calls on Web
description: C2Call, a German start-up that offers an array of Web-calling applications, said Thursday that it had raised $2 million in its first institutional financing, VentureBeat reported.

title: E.C.B. Backs Temporary Bans on Naked Short-Selling
description: The European Central Bank supports temporary bans on naked short selling of European credit default swaps and shares in extreme market conditions, but has warned against permanent action to stop shorting, Retuers reported.

title: Axiom Eyes Overlooked Southeast Asia
description: Axiom Asia Private Capital, run by former managers of the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, plans to allocate more money to Vietnam and other private-equity markets that are shunned by most investors, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Barclays Defends Universal Model Against Breakup
description: Barclays delivered a thinly veiled threat to the British government on Thursday, warning that a break-up could force it to move abroad. The Financial Times reported that the warning came as the bank defended its approach of combining retail and investment banking under one roof.

title: Carlyle Enlists Food-Safety Experts Ahead of Potential Yashili I.P.O.
description: Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, has enlisted safety experts to help Yashili Group increase consumer confidence following Chinas recent food safety scandals. The Wall Street Journal reported that the Chinese baby-formula maker, in which Carlyle has a stake, is also preparing for an initial public offering, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: 3i to Sell Two Companies Valued at $1.3 Billion
description: 3i, the oldest private equity firm in Britain, has enlisted Rothschild and Credit Suisse to sell the two biggest companies in its German portfolio, The Financial Times reported. The companies, Norma Group and MWM, have a combined value of 1 billion euros ($1.3 billion).

title: R.B.S. Posts First Quarterly Profit in Three Years
description: Royal Bank of Scotland said Friday that it had broken even for the first half of the year after earning its first quarterly profit since 2007.

title: Old Mutual Sells U.S. Life Insurance Unit to Harbinger
description: Shares of Old Mutual, Africas biggest insurer, reached a two-year high in London trading after the company announced a return to profit and the sale of its American life insurance unit, Bloomberg News reports.

description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.On a recent episode of the television talk show Raw Nerve, the host William Shatner, of Star Trek fame, had this exchange with Rush Limbaugh:

title: Blending Jazz and Religion in Istanbul
description: A series of eight concerts will be held at two open-air venues: a courtyard of Topkapi Palace and the garden of the Istanbul Archaeology Museum, both in the Sultanahmet neighborhood. But the most interesting element linking the shows is that they are taking place during the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, as part of a series called  what else?  Jazz in Ramadan.

title: What an N.F.L. Training Camp Is Really Like
description: Nate Jackson was a tight end and wide receiver with the Denver Broncos from 2003-08. In April, he wrote about the draft from a players perspective.

title: BofA Wants Out of Secret U.S. Sanction
description: Bank of America is angling to be released from a confidential memorandum of understanding that was imposed by American regulators during the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: At Hiroshima Ceremony, a First for a U.S. Envoy
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan  With the mournful gong of a Buddhist temple bell and the release of a flock of doves, a crowd of 55,000 on Friday solemnly marked the moment 65 years ago when the worlds first atomic attack incinerated this city under a towering mushroom cloud.

title: The Trouble With Weddings
description: Todays idea: Modern weddings are celebrations of the ego  the biggest enemy of the subsequent marriage, a columnist says.

title: Coal Producers I.P.O. Price Slashed in Australia
description: Aston Resources has seen the price of its initial public offer slashed 27 percent in order to attract more investors, a person familiar with the matter told The Wall Street Journal.

title: Model Testifies at War Crimes Trial
description: THE HAGUE  The supermodel Naomi Campbell appeared Thursday at the war crimes trial of Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, and testified that she had been given a pouch containing very small, dirty-looking stones after she met Mr. Taylor at a dinner with Nelson Mandela in South Africa 13 years ago.

title: Tip of the Week: Navigating Microsoft Office 2010
description: Microsoft Office 2010 came out this summer, and users who made the leap from Office 2003 or earlier may find the ribbon that replaces the on-screen toolbars to be confusing. To help newcomers get used to the ribbon, Microsoft has made a game of it. Ribbon Hero, released this year, is a tool that combines casual gaming with interactive software training to teach users how to find commands in the ribbon for Word, Excel, PowerPoint and OneNote. While the experimental game may not be for everyone (or for those who wish the ribbon were more intuitive in the first place), it may help ease some frustration for others. Ribbon Hero is free to download.

title: Stray Questions for: Mona Simpson
description: Mona Simpsons new novel, My Hollywood, is reviewed in this Sundays Book Review.

title: Samsung Adds Pop-Out U.S.B. to Camera
description: Its an idea so elementary that you have to wonder why no one thought of it before: Samsung has added a pop-out U.S.B. connector to a digital camera, enabling you to plug it into any computer and transfer photos and video  without having to scramble for cables or a memory card adapter.

title: Americas Venture Capitalist in Chief
description: Obscured by political battles over health care and financial regulation, President Barack Obama has turned the government into the chief financier of a manufacturing base for clean-energy technology, Bloomberg Businessweek wrote. The comment by Businessweek was published Thursday, the same day the Obama administration made a $1 billion pledge to fund the capture of carbon emissions from a coal-fired Ameren Corporation power plant in Illinois.

title: The Rabbi
description: Newsweek just published a list, The 50 Most Influential Rabbis in America, and placed you at No. 1. As a Hasidic rabbi and a leader of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement, do you think you can rank rabbis or any other religious leaders as if they were athletes?  I am of the opinion that you cant rank human beings. Every person has something to contribute to the welfare of the next human being. No two people think alike or look alike, and everyone has something that another person does not have. Whos to say who is higher and whos lower? In terms of the essence of human beings, I dont feel its proper to rank them because we dont really know what their mission in life is.

title: Accounting Charge Aside, A.I.G.s Profits Rise

title: The Classroom Showroom
description: My husband donated time and money to computerize a public-middle-school-teachers successful remedial math program. It is up and running in that teachers classroom. A number of people, including the schools principal, have come to see it in action and are interested in using it in their private- and public-school classrooms. This teacher would be pleased to sell it to them and other math teachers. May this public-school classroom ethically be a showroom for interested visitors? NAME WITHHELD, NEW MEXICO

title: Amazons Prime Suspect
description: Im a member of Amazon Prime, and I cant help congratulating myself. Though I should know better, I persist in believing that Amazon Prime, a program that for an annual fee gets me free two-day shipping on purchases from Amazon, is something Ive been tapped for  like Skull and Bones. Sure, I know that Amazon flogs Amazon Prime on every Web street corner, and if you shop even once at the nations largest online retailer you practically have to fight not to join up, which is to say, to pay the 79 bucks that make you a member. But on most days Im so delighted by the warm welcome the site gives me, the exciting word free  it never gets old  and Amazon Primes many right-this-way-madams that I let myself believe Im just better and wiser than other Amazon shoppers. With the double-consciousness of the recreational shopper, who knows the clerks are on commission but still craves their solicitousness, I refuse to even entertain the idea Im being suckered.

title: Creative New Uses for Books
description: In July, Amazon.com announced that, during the previous three months, it sold more e-books than hardback books. This may or may not portend something about the future of the form in which long chunks of text are published. But what about the future of the long chunks of text that have already been published as physical objects with paper pages bound between covers? There are, after all, many such things around. Set aside any emotional attachment you may feel toward the reading of physical books; the truth is that creative uses for books that do not involve engaging with words on a page already abound.

title: Terry Gilliam Takes Total Control of Arcade Fire

title: What the Great Recession Has Done to Family Life
description: Economists may assert that were in the early stages of a recovery, but surveys continue to show that the impact of the Great Recession on American families is deep, widespread and grim. A Pew Research poll published last month indicated that more than half of all adults in the U.S. labor force had experienced some work-related hardship  a period of unemployment, a pay cut, a reduction in work hours or an involuntary move to part-time employment  since the recession began in December 2007. A report in March from the Population Reference Bureau showed that more than 70 percent of Americans age 40 and over felt they had been affected by the economic crisis. Government data indicate that the net worth of the average American household has shrunk by about 20 percent  the greatest such decline since the end of World War II. Long-term unemployment  joblessness lasting six months or more  is also at its highest level since the mid-1940s. According to recent data from the Rockefeller Institute, 20 percent of Americans have seen their available household income decline by 25 percent or more.

title: Marienbad Revisited
description: Movies haunt culture like starlit ghosts, circling our collective unconscious. Some insinuate themselves because they are comforting and friendly, which is not the case with Last Year at Marienbad, a famously impenetrable monument to the avant-garde directed by Alain Resnais. But the discovery of six reels of behind-the-scenes footage from 1960 forever fractures the movies cool, calculated surface. With a Super-8 camera, Franoise Spira, a young cast member with a bit part, produced what seems like an amateur version of the film itself, her relationship to its protagonist, played by Delphine Seyrig, as intimate as Resnaiss. Spira committed suicide a few years later, and her celluloid diary languished until 2008. The movies second assistant director, Volker Schlndorff, later turned it into the documentary The Making of Last Year at Marienbad, which Diane von Furstenberg toasted at her studio in June after a screening at New York University. Schlndorff was there, as well as Jean-Luc Godards biographer Richard Brody, the photographer Steven Klein, Ahn Duong, Daphne Guinness and the documentarys principal promoter, Bernard-Henri Lvy.

description: Anyone who thinks astronauts ply a glamorous trade would do well to read Mary Roachs Packing for Mars. The book is an often hilarious, sometimes queasy-making catalog of the strange stuff devised to permit people to survive in an environment for which their bodies are stupendously unsuited. Roach eases us into the story, with an anecdote that reveals the cultural differences among spacefaring nations. In Japan, psychologists evaluate astronaut candidates by, among other things, their ability to fold origami cranes swiftly under stress.

Shteyngarts characters never give in to reality all at once. They have immigrant skills and immigrant illusions, and they come from countries that are themselves in the process of migrating: in one novel a Russia that wants to be America, in another an America that imagines it is not Russia.

title: When the Screen Goes Blank
description: Its become gauche, lately, to criticize television. In the age of The Sopranos, The Wire, Lost and Mad Men, TV has achieved a measure of cultural respectability that would flummox longtime naysayers. The guy who constantly mentions he doesnt own a television is an Onion joke. If you really believe that TV is a wasteland, youre either a crank, a pedant or unfortunate enough to have missed that one episode of Battlestar Galactica in which we find out about the Cylons.

title: Going Digital
description: It sounds odd, but a comic novel need not be particularly funny. Of course it doesnt hurt if it is. Whenever I read Don Quixote I am laughing to myself in the first page or two, and I have involuntary bursts of laughter probably every 10 minutes. But other great comic novels  Dawn Powells Time to Be Born, John Barths Giles Goat-Boy, Gilbert Sorrentinos Mulligan Stew  make me laugh less often than many other novels that arent in the genre. What distinguishes the comic novel is that it takes the spiritual rather than the tragic view of life. It tries to reconcile us to existence as it really is, rather than suggesting that we try to change things or chuck the whole mess. This is why Miguel de Unamuno once remarked that, given the choice between Christ and Don Quixote, the Spanish take sides with the knight of the doleful countenance. Christ makes us weep for this world, while Quixote makes us glad to be here. Were not eager for the next life because this one is very entertaining.

title: State and Local Government Jobs Take a Beating
description: Most of the net payroll loss in July can be attributed to the end of temporary federal Census jobs. But state and local government payrolls also took a beating last month.

title: They Got the Beat

The goofy New Wave number was a shot across the bow, the perfect mission statement for the upstart network, which will celebrate its 30th anniversary this summer. O.K., then, smart guy, what was broadcast next  what was MTVs first regular video?

title: Sorrow in Her Voice
description: In 1970, after the Vietnam War and a host of heated causes had turned the country into a mass of raw nerve endings, a young duo emerged on AM radio. Singing of white lace and promises and so much of life ahead, they offered America hope, and became sudden superstars. The Carpenters were a sister and brother who lived with their parents in a West Coast suburb. Karen sang lead; Richard played keyboards, multitracked his voice into an electronic choral blur and arranged with an obsessive ear for perfection. Every rough edge was buffed away and bathed in Southern California sunlight.

title: Your Tired, Your Poor and Their Food
description: One of the first sights that greeted immigrants in New York, right after the Statue of Liberty, was a prune sandwich. The offending object appeared on the menu in the vast dining hall at Ellis Island, and it served as a warning that food was going to be a cultural struggle in this strange land. Keeping faith with their native cuisines, the newcomers made a series of counteroffers  sauerkraut, spaghetti, borscht  that changed the national palate forever. Jane Ziegelman tells this story exuberantly in 97 Orchard: An Edible History of Five Immigrant Families in One New York Tenement. Highly entertaining and deceptively ambitious, the book resurrects the juicy details of breakfast, lunch and dinner (recipes included) consumed by poor and working-class New Yorkers a century and more ago. It could well have been subtitled How the Other Half Ate.
