The album, which will be produced and arranged by Joel McNeely (whose credits include Mr. MacFarlanes series American Dad) will include standards by Rodgers and Hammerstein, and Lerner and Loewe, as well as a song called Shes Wonderful, Too that Mr. McNeely wrote for the television show The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles. This ferociously reported, darkly humorous and spellbinding book, as our reviewer, Doug Stanton, described it, tells what it felt like and gives unforgettable voice to those whose voices we otherwise might not have heard. It was one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2009.

What fate will befall our heroine, Katniss Everdeen? My fellow book club members and I are desperate to know. When will the Capitol fall? And how can Collins possibly top the first two installments, The Hunger Games and Catching Fire?

title: The Next-to-Last Tycoon
description: Jay Gatsby is one of the most memorable characters in American fiction. But so is Tom Buchanan, his adversary and foil. Cruel, avaricious, thick as two planks, Tom is the apotheosis of the Ivy League slob, Jazz Age edition. Tom, as F. Scott Fitzgerald conceives him, has no redeeming virtues. Hes a lecher, a racist and a dope. He reads books like The Rise of the Colored Empires and then declares: If we dont look out the white race will be  will be utterly submerged. Its all scientific stuff, its been proved. He never says anything original or interesting; hes too stupid to realize his wife despises him. He went to Yale in an era when Yale was still turning out battalions of well-connected dopes, an era thats not as far in the past as some would like to believe. Buchanan, in the words of Nick Carraway, the narrator of Gatsby, is a man of hard malice with a peculiar quality of oppressiveness.

title: Presumed Indecent
description: No one likes having her husband murdered, but its just plain mortifying when he turns up dead in the apartment of an unattractive prostitute. Objectively speaking, says Susie Gersten, wife of the victim, I swear to God, she looked like a ewe in a blond wig. Susie is certain that her husband, Jonah, would never have visited Dorinda Dillon (formerly Cristal Rousseau) for any unsavory reason. Objectively speaking, Susie (formerly Susan B. Anthony Rabinowitz) knows that she herself is gorgeous. Besides, Jonah, a Park Avenue plastic surgeon, had a moral code so strict that he never even tried to get out of jury duty. Most important, he adored Susie and their triplet sons, Dashiell, Evan and Mason.

title: Mad to Talk
description: Tonight while walking on the waterfront in the angelic streets I suddenly wanted to tell you how wonderful I think you are, Jack Kerouac began a typical letter to his friend Allen Ginsberg in 1950. Gods angels are ravishing and fooling me. I saw a whore and an old man in a lunch cart, and God  their faces! I wondered what God was up to. Gods purpose would remain opaque to Kerouac  try as he might to impart some glimpse of it in his work  and a decade later he was pretty much a burnt-out case. Poring over his old correspondence with Ginsberg and others in 1961, he sadly wondered at the enthusiasms of younger men. Someday The Letters of Allen Ginsberg to Jack Kerouac will make America cry, he wrote.

title: Wanderlust | Tel Avivs New Un-Mall

Constructed in 1892 as the terminus for the Jaffa-Jerusalem railway, its become an instant hit with locals who, like Manhattanites, never say no to a piece of the sky or a new hipster nook. HaTachana offers both, and the location couldnt be better: between the beach and Neve Tzedek, the citys first Jewish settlement outside Jaffa and now a lively district of renovated pastel houses and designer boutiques, especially along Shabazi Street, which ends where the HaTachana complex begins.

title: Youth Indicted in Staten Island Hate-Crime Assault

The assault was the latest in a series of attacks on Mexican immigrants in the Port Richmond neighborhood.

title: Opposites Attract, Even Joy and Melancholy
description: Its startling to see a work of genius composed largely from movements as basic as walking, running, hopping, skipping, lying down and the like. When it was new in 1988, LAllegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato, Mark Morriss full-evening Handel-oratorio dance, made me quote Schumanns line about Chopin: Hats off, gentlemen, a genius. I do so again with pleasure now. Even after 22 years I find no end to the intricacies of Mr. Morriss construction, and the meanings that continually pour from them. It fills the soul with wonder; it fascinates the mind with suggestion.

title: First Time Together Leads to a National Title
description: When two experts play together for the first time, they usually do well. And that again proved to be the case when Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., and Gary Cohler of Miami paired up with the husband-and-wife players JoAnna and Lew Stansby of Dublin, Calif., for the Richard Freeman Mixed Board-a-Match Teams in New Orleans last week. They cruised to the national title, finishing nearly five and a half boards ahead of two married couples: Gloria and Les Bart of Bradenton, Fla., and Sally and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif.

title: From Family Guy to Music Man
description: You give a nerd a record deal, and this is the record you get: Seth MacFarlane, below, the pop-cultural polymath who created and provides many of the voices on the Fox animated comedy Family Guy, will be lending his pipes to an album of 1940s and 50s-era show tunes for Universal Republic Records, the label said on Friday. The album, which will be produced and arranged by Joel McNeely (whose credits include Mr. MacFarlanes series American Dad) will include standards by Rodgers and Hammerstein, and Lerner and Loewe, as well as a song called Shes Wonderful, Too that Mr. McNeely wrote for the television show The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles. Universal Republic said in a news release that Mr. MacFarlane would sing to the accompaniment of a live orchestra and a big band, using vintage equipment and analog tape to replicate the sound of classic records by artists like Frank Sinatra, Nat King Cole and Rosemary Clooney.

title: Show Gets Ratings When Contestants Are Cut
description: The live elimination episode of Big Brother on Thursday attracted seven million viewers for CBS, helping the network lead the nights ratings over all, according to Nielsens estimates. CBS earned relatively solid ratings the rest of the night as well with crime show repeats. ABC ranked a strong second, garnering its best ratings with Rookie Blue (6.8 million), which came in between a rerun of Wipeout (6.5 million) and the second-to-last installment of ABCs documentary miniseries Boston Med (4.9 million). Fox placed third and NBC was fourth.

title: Holocaust Documentary Will Retain R Rating
description: The R rating for the Holocaust documentary A Film Unfinished will stand, an appeals board ruled on Thursday, despite arguments by the pictures director and distributor that young people would needlessly be closed off from its historical lessons. In a 12-to-3 vote, the appeals board of the Classification and Rating Administration, which rates films released in the United States, upheld an earlier R rating that cited the movies disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities including graphic nudity. Directed by Yael Hersonski, A Film Unfinished dissects a Nazi propaganda film that purported to depict life among Jews in the Warsaw Ghetto during World War II, but was later discovered to have manipulated situations to help reinforce negative images of Jews. David Fenkel, who with Adam Yauch founded Oscilloscope Laboratories, the movies distributor, said that the rating makes it much harder for libraries to accept it and that some wont. The film is set to open in New York on Aug. 18, and is expected to play later across the United States according to Oscilloscope. Howard Gantman, a spokesman for the Motion Picture Association of America, which helps to oversee the ratings board, declined to comment on the rating, which the association confirmed in a brief statement.

title: Obamas, After Broadway, Turn to Washington Theater
description: Having shined a White House spotlight on Broadway over the last year, President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, above, are turning their attentions to theater closer to home. Arena Stage, the 60-year-old theatrical company in Washington, announced that the Obamas would be the honorary chairman and chairwoman for its inaugural 2010-11 season at its new home, the Mead Center for American Theater, in Southwest Washington. The Obamas will also serve as honorary chairman and chairwoman for a black-tie fund-raising dinner on Oct. 25  with table sponsorships and tickets ranging from $1,500 to $50,000  to celebrate Arenas move to the center. A spokesman for Arena said it was not known whether the Obamas would attend the dinner, nor was it clear what, if anything, their honorary designation involved beyond the title itself. The dinner is to feature a performance by the Tony Award-winning actor Brian Stokes Mitchell (Kiss Me, Kate) on his Monday night off from his new Broadway musical this fall, Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown. The evening will raise money for Arenas work at the center, which includes the renovated 683-seat Fichandler Stage and the 514-seat Kreeger Theater, as well as a new third stage, the 200-seat Kogod Cradle.

title: Wyclef Jean Cant Count on Fugees Vote
description: The people of Haiti will not officially make their presidential preference known at the polls until the election scheduled for Nov. 28. But Wyclef Jean, the hip-hop artist who declared this week that he would run as a potential successor to President Ren Prval, has already lost one-third of the crucial Fugees vote. Pras, a cousin of Mr. Jean and a fellow Haitian-American performer who worked with him in that influential rap group, told The Daily News of New York that he backed one of his former bandmates rivals. In a statement, Pras, whose name is Prakazrel Michel, told The Daily News that he supported Michel Martelly as the next president of Haiti because he is the most competent candidate for the job, and wrote on his Twitter feed, I support and believe in my heart that Michel Martelly is prez for Haiti! Like Pras and Mr. Jean, Mr. Martelly is also a Haitian musician, and performs under the stage name Sweet Micky.

title: Youtube Day Project Will Consume Many
description: For his Life in a Day documentary project (poster, above), Ridley Scott asked people around the world to film a snippet of what they were doing on July 24 and upload the videos onto a special YouTube channel. Be careful what you ask for: Mr. Scott said on Thursday that submissions totaled 80,000  or about 4,600 hours of footage. He was expecting about 300 hours worth. To power forward  the goal is to make a feature documentary by splicing together the best moments  Mr. Scott and his partner on the project, the director Kevin Macdonald (The Last King of Scotland), have assembled 20 editors and researchers to log and vet the footage. Its a mountain, but were eager to climb it, Mr. Macdonald said. The team will winnow the videos, which came from 197 countries, down to 100 hours and begin sharing some results at youtube.com/lifeinaday, in September. The final film will have its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival and on YouTube in January.

title: Lollapalooza and Its Promoters Rise on the Stage of Chicago

Offering a little bit of everything  from Alsatian pizza to lamb Milanese to jalapeo cheddar grits  the restaurant packs in diners who might venture downstairs to snap pictures in the old-fashioned photo booth or watch a bit of vintage porn through a peephole. On Wednesday night, the crowd included reunited friends laughing over a recent birthday celebration.

State Trooper William Taylor was among the first police officers on the scene. He immediately closed off access to the highway and coordinated communications with other police agencies, all while keeping the suicidal male calm while speaking with him on the phone, read the citation for the Meritorious Service Award he later received.

But once shes settled in, a local black woman named Rosa Parks refuses to give up her seat to a white person on a city bus and starts a yearlong bus boycott that costs Ruby her job.

title: Kaplan Suspends Enrollment at 2 Campuses
description: The Washington Post Companys Kaplan Inc. unit suspended enrollment on Friday at its campuses in Pembroke Pines, Fla., and Riverside, Calif., where undercover investigators for the Government Accountability Office found deceptive practices by admissions officials.

title: What Does It Mean? Artists Will Explain
description: EVER stand in a museum or gallery looking at a work of art and wonder: Gee, what were they thinking? Some artists are willing to answer that question in person, and dozens, including the photographer Tom Steele, the multimedia artist Avital Oz and the painter Roseline Koener, will meet participants in a self-guided tour of artists studios in the greater Westhampton area next weekend. The tour is being presented for the second year by Family Counseling Services in Westhampton.

title: A Career Reprieve for the Red Sox Lowell

title: Pettitte, on Schedule, Pitches Off the Rubber
description: Andy Pettittes recovery from a left groin strain has progressed according to schedule, if not ahead of it. He threw off a half mound Sunday and Tuesday, then off the pitching rubber Friday afternoon. Originally told he would miss up to five weeks, Pettitte, almost three weeks into his convalescence, said a return is not far off.

title: Watergate Becomes Sore Point at Nixon Library

But on Friday, the exhibit was nearly empty, dominated by a 30-foot blank slate of a wall that is testimony to a new battle set off by this still-polarizing former president: how to mark the scandal that forced him from office 36 years ago.

The Senate approved two important measures this week  the $26 billion state-aid bill and the $4.5 billion school nutrition program  in part by shaving food stamp funds as a target of least resistance.

title: Victory for Wolves
description: Donald Molloy, a Federal District Court judge in Montana, ruled Thursday that gray wolves in Montana and Idaho must be provided federal protection under the Endangered Species Act. This is a welcome decision. The immediate effect will be to spare the animals from hunts planned for this fall that are now illegal. The larger hope is that Washington will devise a protection plan ensuring the wolves survival not only in Montana and Idaho but across the northern Rocky Mountains.

This summer he is living in a recreational vehicle on Coney Island with his wife and stage assistant, Jamieleigh, 23, and their black cat, Ninja. Sent off as the 3-2 favorite, she came from off the pace under Kent Desormeaux to win going away for her owner and trainer, Tim Snyder, who bought her last winter. He said he had declined offers of as much as $500,000 for the filly, who is undefeated in four starts. This story hasnt ended yet, he told reporters.

Last year, Pecks Muscle Hill set a record for the one-mile distance, and his winning margin of six lengths was a fraction short of the record. It was a superb performance in what is known as the Kentucky Derby of harness racing.

title: The Economy Needs a Bit of Ingenuity
description: THE steps being taken by government officials to help the economy are based on a faulty premise. The diagnosis is that the economy is constrained by a deficiency of aggregate demand, the total demand for American goods and services. The officials prescription is to stimulate that demand, for as long as it takes, to facilitate the recovery of an otherwise undamaged economy  as if the task were to help an uninjured skater get up after a bad fall.

description: The people who spend their nights at 639 Exchange Street in a rural slice of upstate New York have long officially been counted as residents of Wyoming County.

title: China: Crackdown on Vulgarity and Indecency Is Expected
description: Chinese officials are expected to start a crackdown soon on vulgarity and indecency in the media, including television dating shows, according to a report Friday in the English-language edition of the official newspaper Global Times. The report referred to a commentary by Xinhua, the official news agency, saying that the mass media are profit-driven, commercialism leads to vulgarity and officials must impose a long-term ban on indecency. In late May, officials issued a directive that called dating shows vulgar and moved to cancel or censor them. The Global Times article also pointed to criticism of a cross-dressing comedian, Xiao Shenyang.

title: Mexico: 14 Die in Prison Fighting
description: A fight between two groups of inmates at the Santa Adelaida prison in the border city of Matamoros on Friday killed at least 14 prisoners, who attacked one another with homemade knives and sharpened objects, Tamaulipas state officials said. In March, 40 inmates  many with ties to drug cartels  escaped from the same prison with the help of guards. Mexicos prisons are overflowing with suspects arrested in the countrys crackdown on drug cartels and organized crime, and riots occur regularly as the cartels exploit gangs to gain recruits and carry out illicit business from behind bars, said a security expert, Pedro Isnardo de la Cruz of the National Autonomous University of Mexico.

title: Former Mandela Fund Official Says Model Gave Him Diamonds
description: A former director of the Nelson Mandela Childrens Fund charity, Jeremy Ractliffe, confirmed on Friday that he received three small uncut diamonds from the supermodel Naomi Campbell the day after she attended a 1997 dinner given by Mr. Mandela and attended by Charles Taylor, then the president of Liberia. Ms. Campbell testified at Mr. Taylors war crimes trial in The Hague on Thursday that after the dinner, two unidentified men gave her a pouch containing very small, dirty-looking stones, which she passed to Mr. Ractliffe in the hope that they might be used to help the charity. The prosecution has accused Mr. Taylor of trading in so-called blood diamonds, which are used to foment civil conflict  a charge he denies. In a statement, Mr. Ractliffe said he worried that the gift would damage reputations and that it might be illegal, so he kept the diamonds and did not tell anyone until he recently turned them over to South African authorities. Mr. Ractliffe is no longer the charitys chief executive, but he is listed on its Web site as a trustee.

title: With Yanks Help, Red Sox Edge Closer
description: A quick glance at the American League East standings reveals that no team has clinched the title  not the Yankees, not the Tampa Bay Rays and not the Boston Red Sox, who do not care about the injuries that have ravaged their infield, outfield, catching depth and rotation. The Yankees fully expect Boston to loiter in the division race, and they made it easy on the Red Sox on Friday night with a sloppy performance that undercut any plans of using this four-game series to pull away.

The Royal Bank could receive a further 200 million if the buyers returns hit certain targets, the bank said. The Royal Bank will keep a 20 percent stake. The Royal Bank is being forced to dispose of the unit to comply with the European Unions state-aid rules after taking 45.5 billion ($72 billion) in a rescue packaged financed by taxpayers during the financial crisis.

title: Summer Holiday Notes in Grand Prix Racing
description: The summer holiday period has existed for a few years now in Formula One. It used to be there was no break, but as teams took more and more mechanics and crew to races and there were more and more races in the season, the series decided to create a three week break in August to give everyone a rest. That three-week break is sometimes four weeks, as it is this year, but even a four-week break for F1 people is a three week break, since they usually leave a day or two after the preceding race and they arrive at the next race several days in advance.

title: Will Ferrell Gets a Boost From The Other Guys
description: Will Ferrell, right, badly needed a hit  his last outing in theaters was the disastrous Land of the Lost  and he got one over the weekend with The Other Guys, a buddy comedy that took in about $35.6 million at the North American box office. The Other Guys, which cost Columbia Pictures about $90 million to make, was easily No. 1 for the weekend and represented one of the strongest openings of Mr. Ferrells career. It continued a winning streak at Columbia, owned by Sony, which was behind the hit remake of The Karate Kid and also scored with Grown Ups and Salt. In second place for the weekend was Christopher Nolans Inception with about $18.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. This Warner Brothers film has shown remarkable holding power over the last month, selling a total of $227.7 million in North America. Step Up 3D, the third in a series from Walt Disney Studios and Summit Entertainment, was a weak third, selling $15.5 million and marking a low point for the franchise, despite having the benefit of premium-price 3-D tickets for the first time. One reason may have been marketing: Step Up 3-D was backed by dark, difficult-to-decipher images that baffled many Hollywood veterans. Salt, the Angelina Jolie spy caper, was fourth with about $11.1 million, for a new domestic total of $92 million. The comedy Dinner for Schmucks, from Paramount Pictures and DreamWorks Studios, was fifth with $10.5 million ($46.7 million total.)

The show will feature Francesca Faridany (The 39 Steps), Annika Boras, Gibson Frazier, David Greenspan, Tom Nelis (Enron) and Howard W. Overshown (Julius Caesar) in a limited run at the East Village theater, from Sept. 8 to Oct. 17 (classicstage.org). ... The creators of the musical [title of show] are in the process of developing a new work at the Vineyard Theater. And Now This Is Happening, created by Hunter Bell, Michael Berresse, Susan Blackwell, Heidi Blickenstaff, Jeff Bowen and Larry Pressgrove, will have a run at the Vineyard next spring, with direction by Mr. Berresse and musical direction and arrangements by Mr. Pressgrove (vineyardtheatre.org).

title: 1st Irish Festival Plans 3rd Edition Here
description: Sixteen Irish playwrights will have their work featured in the 1st Irish 2010 theater festival in New York, beginning Sept. 7 across the city. The plays will include Owen ONeills drama Absolution (about sexual abuse among the clergy) at 59E59 Theaters and Deirdre Kinahans dark comedy Hue and Cry (about two cousins reconnecting at a funeral) at the Irish Repertory Theater. The third edition of the festival, scheduled to run through Oct. 4, will also include a symposium on contemporary Irish theater on Sept. 25, with the Tony Award-winning director Garry Hynes (The Beauty Queen of Leenane) among the speakers and a staged reading on Sept. 27 of the poet Seamus Heaneys translation of Beowulf into modern English. Details about the festival can be found at 1stIrish.org.

title: Springsteen Documentary to Be Shown on HBO
description: HBO has announced plans to show The Promise: The Making of Darkness on the Edge of Town, a documentary that follows the making of Bruce Springsteens fourth album, Variety reported. Directed by Thom Zimny, who has made several films about Mr. Springsteen and his band, including the Emmy-nominated Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band: Live in New York City, the film chronicles Mr. Springsteens work on Darkness from 1975, after the release of his pivotal album Born to Run, until 1978, a time when he was prohibited from recording any music because of a pending lawsuit with Mike Appel, his former manager. The film mixes footage from rehearsals during that time with recent commentary from Mr. Springsteen and the band. (Above, Mr. Springsteen, right, with Southside Johnny.) The fact that this footage has been sitting in a vault, and no one has seen it for more than 30 years is just extraordinary, Richard L. Plepler, a co-president of HBO, said at a Television Critics Association meeting on Saturday. Mr. Plepler and Michael Lombardo, programming president for HBO, said the documentary would be shown on the network in October, after a premiere on Sept. 14, at the Toronto International Film Festival.

title: Dance Companies Plan Tours and Premieres

The premieres include Petrichor, to music by Villa-Lobos, in October in Boston, and a second work, as yet untitled, in March at the companys Brooklyn home, the Mark Morris Dance Center. The troupe has already announced another New York engagement, The Hard Nut, Mr. Morriss take on The Nutcracker, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in December. ... The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company will begin a new tour at the Biennale de la Danse, in Lyon, France, in September, with the international premiere of Fondly Do We Hope ... Fervently Do We Pray, the companys dance-theater work celebrating the bicentennial of Lincolns birth. (Above, Antonio Brown, in Fondly Do We Hope.) The tour continues with performances of Fondly Do We Hope in Creteil, France, and at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, around Presidents Day, as well as with other recent works, through April.

But sometimes they turn to a plastic barrel that is wending its way toward her, from her cousins two-family house in Queens to a ship moving down the Atlantic coast to  someday soon  a truck rumbling up the road to her brothers cinderblock bungalow, where she moved when the cataclysm wrecked her home.

Credited with holding back the Nazi invasion and changing the course of the war, the plane has come to symbolize the bravery of the Royal Air Force.

title: Numberplay: Hanging Over the Edge
description: You are on the Grand Canyon Skywalk, shown above, standing on the glass-bottomed structure that projects out 70 feet over the edge. You look down through the glass below your feet at the sheer fall into the Colorado River 4,000 feet below. Click here, to get a sense of the experience. You know you are safe, but suddenly you are stricken with fear: the perfectly normal feeling of mild acrophobia. It almost overcomes you  that tingling in your feet, that vague dread in the pit of your stomach, that imp in your mind insistently asking What if I fell? You brush away the feeling, trusting your rationality, trusting in the safety of physics and engineering. Today well look at over-the-precipice engineering, and then Im going to do my best to give you some acrophobia again.

title: Shape Shifters
description: Before there was HGTV, there was Gaetano Pesce, the legendary Italian architect and designer who once espoused the joys of D.I.Y. in a column for French Elle and actually made good on it. His 1972 Golgotha chair, part of the permanent collection at MoMA, was the first of his many forays into the world of mass customization: its Dacron-filled seat assumed different shapes depending on who sat on it. Now, another clever bit of personalization: Pesces new shoe for the Brazilian company Melissa  an ankle bootie composed of interconnected PVC circles, whose form can change at the whim of its owner with a swift slice of the scissors. Cut once, and the boot becomes a bootie; cut again, and its a ballet flat, a peep toe, a sandal or even a flip-flop. This is the future of mass production, Pesce says. With the technology we have today, we can give people something that is half done and ask them to finish it. Go to melissashoes.com.

title: New Name for Hilton Theater
description: The Hilton Theater on 42nd Street, originally the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, has a new name  Foxwoods Theater. Live Nation, the concert and theater presenting company that operates the theater, and the Foxwoods Resort Casino, the Connecticut gambling and show center owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, announced the multiyear agreement on Monday but did not disclose financial arrangements. The agreement for exclusive naming rights means that the Foxwoods name will appear not only on the theaters marquee and tickets but also in advertising to promote the troubled multimillion-dollar musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, which is bound for the theater. The show, which has as its lead producer Michael Cohl, a former chairman of Live Nation, begins rehearsals next week. The theater, which has been empty since January 2009 waiting for the much-delayed Spider-Man musical, was last home to The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein.

title: Aid Groups in Afghanistan Vow to Stay
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Aid groups who have stayed in Afghanistan through years of incessant fighting vowed Monday to continue their work, even after the slaying of 10 foreign relief workers renewed concerns about their safety in the face of a revived Taliban insurgency.

title: Amid Heat and Smoke, Deaths Double in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  The daily mortality rate here has nearly doubled in recent days, the citys chief health official said Monday, singling out the heat as the primary factor and not the culprit most people here suspected: the choking cloud of wildfire smoke.

title: Coalitionspeak
description: Policy terms preferred by Britains new coalition government.In a BBC radio clip titled The new world of coalitionspeak,' Dr Nicholas Ostler and Alistair Beaton discussed the alternative terms Britains Con-Lib coalition has adopted to differentiate it from the previous administration.

title: Cuomo Offers 150 Pages of Views on Energy
description: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos campaign released its second policy book last week, this time focusing on energy.

title: N.B.A. to Play 2 Regular-Season Games in London
description: The N.B.A. said Monday that the Nets and the Toronto Raptors would play two games in London in March, the first regular-season contests to be held in Europe.

title: Burnett Expected to Start Tuesday
description: A.J. Burnett played catch with the pitching coach Dave Eiland before Mondays game, and Manager Joe Girardi said he expected him to make his start Tuesday against the Texas Rangers.

title: How I Bargain on Hotel Rates
description: Last weeks column provoked a number of comments about my practice of seeking discounts on hotel rooms. I thought it would be helpful to explain my strategy a bit further, since it clearly didnt come across as I intended.

title: The Claim: Smoking Relieves Stress
description: THE FACTS

title: The Insider | Sang Yoon
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

title: A Different Take on Lehmans Executive Fees
description: On the Opinionator blog of The New York Times, William D. Cohan writes that he finds it distasteful that former Lehman Brothers executives are asking to have some of their legal fees paid for by the fallen banks estate.

title: MTV Names Its First T.J.
description: From those wonderful people who brought you the V.J. comes the T.J., with a little help from a sponsor.

title: Revis Makes a New Pitch to Jets
description: There was news on the Darrelle Revis contract negotiations front on Monday afternoon. Whether that constitutes actual progress remains to be seen.

title: Statistics: Who Visits the Emergency Room? 20 Percent of Americans, Insured or Not
description: Americans, insured and not, make ample use of hospital emergency rooms: One out of every five visited an E.R. at least once in 2007, the latest year for which the National Center for Health Statistics has data.

title: Pettitte Encouraged by Throwing Sessions
description: Andy Pettitte threw 20 pitches in a bullpen session Monday as he continued to recover from a left groin muscle strain he sustained on July 18.

title: Breakthrough Award for New Novelist
description: With the publication this week of his first novel, Bill Warringtons Last Chance, James P. King, 55, is living the dream of every hopeful writer who persists at his work despite rejection slips from publishing houses and agents. After Mr. King, who lives in Wilton, Conn., won the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award, in which more than 6,500 writers from 22 countries competed, his novel, a road story in which an elderly veteran who is developing Alzheimers disease travels across the country with his rebellious 14-year-old granddaughter, was acquired by Viking. This is what reading is about, and what a good book is supposed to do, the mystery writer Sue Grafton writes in a blurb for the novel, Mr. Kings fourth attempt at fiction.

title: My Phone Is Shouting at Me
description: My new smartphone is very smart indeed. And, frankly, a little insecure. It knows its own name, and it keeps shouting it at me to get my attention.

title: Tech Savvy Moms, Setting Rules
description: Much has been said about the downside of technology. It isolates family members from each other emotionally and physically. It keeps kids glued to chairs instead of running around in the fresh air. It shortens attention spans. It puts kids at risk for danger online.

title: Behavior: Internet Use Tied to Depression in Youths
description: A large Chinese study suggests that otherwise healthy teenagers are much more vulnerable to depression if they spend too much time on the Internet.

title: 'Fast, Cheap and Out of Control'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Errol Morris's innovative 1997 documentary.

title: Bennett Street, Staten Island, 12:17 P.M.
description: State Senator Rubn Daz led a group, including the New York Hispanic Clergy Organization, in prayer during a protest march against a recent rash of hate crimes against immigrants in the Port Richmond neighborhood. The sign behind him reads: From Jehovah come the earth, its plenty the world and all those who live in it.

title: A Record Number of Children Are Dying in Hot Cars
description: Despite awareness campaigns from child safety advocates and substantial media coverage, the number of children dying in hot vehicles has continued to rise.

title: Hazards: Salmonella Is Traced to Dry Pet Food
description: Dozens of salmonella infections in toddlers have been traced to dry pet food, the first time human infections have been linked to dry dog and cat food, health officials say.

title: Added Fees Make It Hard to Compare Old Air Fares With New
description: If you thought airline tickets have been getting more expensive, you are right. But how much more expensive is difficult to say.

title: Arizona Prison Escapee Is Captured
description: MAMMOTH, Wyo.  It was the biggest news for the tiny town of Meeteetse since the black-footed ferret, once thought to be extinct, showed up there back in 1981. On Monday, one of two Arizona prison escapees was captured after a resident spotted him at a church the previous day and notified the police.

title: The Rise of the Permabears
description: The central question dividing economists these days is whether Western governments should spend more to ward off a potential second recession or retrench to hold down their ballooning debts in a bid to restore confidence among investors, The New York Timess Landon Thomas Jr. reports from London.

title: Pentagon Plans Steps to Reduce Budget and Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Monday that he would close a military command, restrict the use of outside contractors and reduce the number of generals and admirals across the armed forces as part of a broad effort to rein in Pentagon spending.

title: Allman Brothers to Return to the Stage
description: Less than two months after getting a new liver, Gregg Allman is ready to work again.

title: News Corp. Sells Stakes in TV Units in China
description: SHANGHAI  The News Corporation said Monday that it would sell a controlling stake in three Chinese television stations and a movie library to a private equity fund that was formed with the backing of the Chinese government.

title: Washington National Opera and Kennedy Center Discussing Future
description: The Washington National Opera and officials of the Kennedy Center, where it performs, are discussing their long-term relationship, the company said Monday in response to news reports that it might be merged into the performing arts center. The opera said the talks are part of regular negotiations over its contract with the center, which expires in 2013.

title: Anesthetic Said to Aid Depression
description: A new study suggests that a 50-year-old drug commonly used as an anesthetic for humans and animals  and abused, as the drug called Special K  may deliver almost instant relief in some of the most troublesome cases of bipolar depression.

title: Web Plan From Google and Verizon Is Criticized
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google and Verizon on Monday introduced a proposal for how Internet service should be regulated  and were immediately criticized by groups that favor keeping the network as open as possible.

title: Bullet That Killed Man in Harlem Was Probably Fired by Police
description: Updated, Tuesday, Aug. 10 | A full version of this story can be read here.

title: That Middle-of-the-Night Bellyache: Appendicitis?
description: Lets start with Madeline. In that classic childrens story by Ludwig Bemelmans, published in 1939, the little French girl of the title is awakened in the night by severe abdominal pain, and the doctor races to get her to the operating table.

title: Critics Picks Video: Fast, Cheap and Out of Control
description: In this weeks Critics Pick, A. O. Scott looks at the 1997 Errol Morris documentary Fast, Cheap and Out of Control. The film digs deep into uncommon jobs of four men: an animal trainer, a topiary gardener, a robot scientist and a mole-rat specialist. Mr. Scott praises Mr. Morriss unique filmmaking, saying that the director has turned the talking head documentary into a vehicle for artistic expression and philosophical inquiry. Have you seen Fast, Cheap and Out of Control or any of Mr. Morriss films? Please share your thoughts.

title: Arabian Nights | Dar al Mamlouka
description: Starting Aug. 15, visitors to Damascus, Syria, will have a new stylish hotel to check into after a long day of strolling the souks. Dar al Mamlouka, located in the historic Christian quarter of Old Damascus, is a 17th-century Ottoman-style palace that has been converted into a lush retreat by the owners of Beit al Mamlouka, the first Oriental-style boutique hotel in the area. Built around a tranquil central courtyard with wisterias, lemon trees and a fountain, it offers 10 luxuriously decorated rooms. Each room celebrates a particular figure from Arab history  from poets to warriors  in the ornate Damascene style, with plenty of inlaid mother-of-pearl woodwork, colorful mosaics and Persian rugs.

title: Ugly Animals
description: Examples of animals few would choose as wallpaper for a Web browser.

title: In Spinal-Fluid Test, an Early Warning on Alzheimers
description: Researchers report that a spinal fluid test can be 100 percent accurate in in identifying a signature level of abnormal proteins in patients with significant memory loss who went on to develop Alzheimers disease.

title: Battlegrounds in 6 States in Midwest
description: Who occupies the statehouse in a swath of states near the Great Lakes could prove crucial in the 2012 presidential campaign. A primer to some races to watch:

title: With 2012 in Mind, Parties Focus on Governorships
description: CHICAGO  For all the talk of midterm elections and control of Congress, the political parties are obsessing this year more than ever over the nations 37 races for governor.

title: Entourage to End Next Summer
description: The HBO series Entourage, that networks longest-running show, will end next summer after a shortened eighth season that will consist of six episodes. Addressing the Television Critics Association summer press tour, Michael Lombardo, HBOs president for programming, said he hoped a movie version follows the series, whose stars include, from left Jerry Ferrara, Jeremy Piven, Adrian Grenier, Kevin Connolly and Kevin Dillon, but acknowledged that that depends on whether Doug Ellin, the programs executive producer and head writer, thinks it makes sense for the story and characters. We have a long-term relationship with Doug Ellin, and Im sure youll soon see another series from him here, Mr. Lombardo told the critics. But next summer will definitely be the final season for Entourage.

title: Bolshoi Theater Names New Musical Director
description: The Bolshoi Theater, in flux since the end of the Soviet Union, has named a new musical director, according to the Interfax news agency. The composer Vassily Sinaisky, who has served as musical director and chief conductor of the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra and the Russian Symphony Orchestra, will replace Leonid Desyatnikov. Mr. Desyatnikov, who was appointed to the post last September, said from the beginning that he would spend only an interlude in the job, but had a contract that was to run through the end of next year. Mr. Sinaisky, 63, a graduate of the St. Petersburg Conservatory, has worked extensively as a guest conductor outside Russia, including for operas in San Francisco and Berlin and the BBC Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: Vampires Rule at Teen Choice Awards
description: To the surprise of no one, movies and television shows about vampires dominated the annual Teen Choice Awards on Sunday in Los Angeles. The Twilight Saga film series walked away with a dozen awards, including those for villain and fantasy movie, and CWs Vampire Diaries won seven in the television category. Voting online, youthful fans gave the actor Robert Pattinson, above, star of the Twilight films, four awards, one of which was for a non-Twilight performance, in the drama Remember Me. In the music categories, Taylor Swift and Justin Bieber also won four awards each.

title: Kazakh Director Plans Answer To Borat
description: Kazakhstan was furious when Sacha Baron Cohens mock documentary comedy Borat became a worldwide hit in 2006, but has apparently decided, somewhat belatedly, that if you cant beat em, join em. Erkin Rakishev, a Kazakh director, has announced that he will soon begin shooting My Brother, Borat, as part of an effort to counter negative stereotypes about that oil-rich Central Asian country. In the new story an American fan of Mr. Cohens movie, which is banned in Kazakhstan, travels there and finds a prosperous and modern state. We want to ride on the wave of success of Borat, to take advantage of this popular image in the West to show people the real Kazakhstan, Mr. Rakishev told Kazakhstanskaya Pravda.

title: Waist Size Linked With Longevity
description: Even if you dont need to watch your weight, you still need to watch your waist.

title: Breakthrough Award For New Novelist
description: With the publication this week of his first novel, Bill Warringtons Last Chance, James P. King, 55, is living the dream of every hopeful writer who persists at his work despite rejection slips from publishing houses and agents. After Mr. King, who lives in Wilton, Conn., won the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award, in which more than 6,500 writers from 22 countries competed, Viking acquired his novel, a road story in which an elderly veteran who is developing Alzheimers disease travels across the country with his rebellious 14-year-old granddaughter. This is what reading is about, and what a good book is supposed to do, the mystery writer Sue Grafton writes in a blurb for the novel, Mr. Kings fourth attempt at fiction.

title: Critics Blast Stricter Homeless Rules
description: Advocates for the homeless on Monday said they would seek to reverse an effort by the Bloomberg administration to make it harder for homeless families to qualify for a generous rent-subsidy program.

title: Repertorio Espaol Season Announced
description: An adaptation of the Julia Alvarez novel In the Time of the Butterfly heads the 2010-11 season that Repertorio Espaol, New Yorks main Spanish-language theater company, announced on Monday. The production will bring together the dramatist Caridad Svich and the director Jos Zayas, the same team that collaborated on a well-received version of Isabel Allendes House of the Spirits in 2009. In addition to the adaptation of the Alvarez novel, about real-life sisters who ran afoul of the Trujillo dictatorship in the Dominican Republic in the 1950s, the ensemble will also be adding to its permanent repertory Way to Heaven, a drama by Juan Mayorga, one of the most distinguished younger Spanish playwrights.

title: Football Fuels Victory For NBC
description: After a monthslong off-season, the return of football to Sunday night television helped lift NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on the night. According to Nielsens estimates, NBCs broadcast of the N.F.L.s annual Hall of Fame game delivered footballs best preliminary overnight ratings numbers in six years, finishing 30 percent better than last years first preseason game, which drew 7.9 million viewers when final ratings were released. CBS ranked second on the night, leading during the early part of prime time with 60 Minutes at 7 p.m. (9.3 million) and posting the largest audience of the summer for Big Brother at 8 (7.5 million). From 9 to 11, CBS broadcast lower-rated reruns of Undercover Boss (6.2 million) and The Good Wife (4 million). ABC was third, garnering few viewers for Scoundrels at 9 (3.3 million) and The Gates at 10 (2.6 million), while Fox finished in fourth place with reruns of its comedy lineup.

title: Hilton Theater Is Now Foxwoods Theater
description: The Hilton Theater on West 42nd Street, originally the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, has a new name  Foxwoods Theater. Live Nation, the concert and theater presenting company that operates the theater, and the Foxwoods Resort Casino, the Connecticut gambling and show center owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, announced a multiyear agreement on Monday but did not disclose financial arrangements. The agreement for exclusive naming rights means the Foxwoods name will appear not only on the theaters marquee and tickets but also in advertising to promote the troubled multimilliondollar musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, which is bound for the theater. The show, which has as its lead producer Michael Cohl, a former chairman of Live Nation, begins rehearsals next week. The theater, which has been empty since January 2009 waiting for the much-delayed Spider-Man musical, was last home to The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein.

title: Glimmerglass Recycles Its Sets, Not Its Ideas
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  Its hard not to think of the current Glimmerglass Opera season as something of a footnote, though that is patently unfair to the artists doing consistently solid and frequently inspired work here this summer. In February came the news that the general and artistic director, Michael MacLeod, would be leaving at the end of the current season. With the impending arrival of Francesca Zambello, the seasoned opera and musical theater director who will take over in September, comes the promise of fresh energy and change that extends even to the name of this venerable organization. Next year it becomes the Glimmerglass Festival.

title: Is That a Shoe on Your Head or Have You Been Styled?
description: Hair Battle Spectacular, a series beginning Tuesday on Oxygen, feels like the harbinger of something: if not the end of a thinking society and a decent pageboy, than at least the last stand of second-tier reality competition shows presided over by nobody hosts who make lame exit declamations. Hair Battle Spectacular is the coffin in which all similar ideas scheduled for future broadcast ought to be buried, no exhuming permitted.

title: Bush to Make Another Trip to Haiti
description: Former President George W. Bush is scheduled to travel to Haiti on Tuesday to assess the countrys recovery from the devastating earthquake in January that displaced 1.5 million people and left an estimated 300,000 dead.

title: A Masterpiece of Nature? Yuck!
description: A friend recently sent around an e-mail with the subject line lost cat bulletin. Open the message and  gack!  there was a head-on shot of a star-nosed mole, its Dawn of the Dead digging claws in full view and its hallmark nasal boutonniere of 22 highly sensitive feelers looking like fresh bits of sirloin being extruded through a meat grinder.

title: Merrills Risk Disclosure Dodges Are Unearthed
description: It was named after a faint constellation in the southern sky: Pyxis, the Mariners Compass. But it helped to steer the mighty Merrill Lynch toward disaster.

title: The Standby Star Who Stole Broadways Limelight
description: Iva Withers, 93, tapped her cane on the hardwood floor of her neat West 55th Street apartment with the ferocity of a dance instructor. She was about to describe a bit of Broadway musical history: the afternoon and night when she played the leads in what are now two classics.

title: Lady Gaga Has a Told-You-So Moment
description: CHICAGO  If youre Lady Gaga, you have lots of ways to quantify your success. Your two albums have sold nearly five million copies combined in an era of chronically low sales. MTV has nominated you for more Video Music Awards in one year than it has any other artist. You have more Facebook fans than any public figure except Michael Jackson.

title: A Bit of Broadway History
description: At home with the 93-year-old actress Iva Withers.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gansu Province and Elsewhere
description: A landslide buried and flooded hundreds of homes over the weekend in a remote mountainous region of Gansu Province in China, Michael Wines reported. Officials said Sunday evening that 127 bodies had been recovered and that nearly 2,000 people were missing. Torrential rains began to fall on Saturday, a local official said. Then there were landslides, and many people were trapped, he said. Now sludge has become the biggest hindrance to our operations. Its too thick to walk or drive through.

title: Oracle Chief Faults H.P. Board for Forcing Hurd Out
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle, denounced Hewlett-Packards directors on Monday for forcing the resignation of the H.P. chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, who is a friend of Mr. Ellisons.

title: Now Spinning | Victoria Aitkens Sunshine
description: Victoria Aitken, the New York and London-based socialite songstress, has teamed up with the Scumfrog, a New York-based D.J., on her recent single Sunshine, which is currently No. 7 on the British dance charts. The light-spirited house track was inspired by a Latin loffer she met on holiday in Spain. He was very charming, funny and interesting, she says. The only problem was that others thought so too, and they were girls who dressed up to the nines in diamonds and couture. According to Aitken, the song is also a hit with her father, Jonathan Aitken, the disgraced former Tory cabinet minister. (Dad wasnt a big fan of her last video, Ill Be Your Bitch, in which she danced suggestively while brandishing a whip and in preparation for which she took pole-dancing classes.) The jury is still out on whether Victoria is a card-carrying blue blood  Dutch newspaper reports earlier this year claimed that her grandmother, Lady Penelope Aitken, was the longtime girlfriend of Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands (husband of Queen Juliana)  but one thing is certain: The Scumfrogs kiss has turned this sassy singer into a bona fide dance-floor princess. Her latest song, Sexy Skirt, just entered the charts at No. 34. To listen to Sunshine and Sexy Skirt go to myspace.com/victoriaaitken.

title: K.K.R. Withdraws Stock Offering
description: 8:26 p.m. | Updated Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity giant now listed on the New York Stock Exchange, said that it was withdrawing a planned $500 million stock offering and reported a 29 percent drop in earnings for its second quarter.

title: Is This Rehab or an Exorcism?
description: HARTFORD  The horrors are stacked to the heavens in Matthew Lombardos play High at Hartford TheaterWorks. The grisly list of crimes described in this dark drama about addiction and victimization includes rape, murder, child molestation and child prostitution.

title: Stroke Patients Discontinue Medications
description: Within three months of being hospitalized for an acute stroke, nearly one-quarter of patients stop taking at least one of the drugs prescribed by their doctors to prevent further cardiovascular problems, according to a study published on Monday afternoon in the medical journal Archives of Neurology.

title: Inspired by Flying, and Inspiring Others
description: IVE loved airplanes ever since I was a child. In fact, my mom took me to my first air show when I was just a baby. She said I loved it.

title: Showcasing Durability in a Soft Economy
description: RIPPING up the merchandise is not typically the first approach a company uses to promote its brand. But Dickies, the longtime maker of work wear, does just that in a new advertising campaign in which two motorcyclists, revving their engines, strain to tear apart a pair of its Original 874 work pants that are suspended between them.

title: For Fighter, a Long Count Before Release
description: LOS ANGELES  Take a cast full of past Oscar nominees like Amy Adams and Melissa Leo, working for almost no pay in return for a piece of the future action. Throw in outside financing, a classic underdog story and a director with cachet, David O. Russell.

title: Cheney Released From Hospital
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney has been released from the hospital after doctors implanted a pump last month to help his heart.

title: Matthew Simmons, Noted Energy Banker, Dies at 67
description: The death of Matthew R. Simmons, the founder of Simmons & Company International, a boutique energy investment bank, has stunned the tight-knit energy banking community.

title: Now Screening | Quando, Quando Quando
description: Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce are the latest fashion designers to make the foray into filmmaking. The designing duos first feature length film, Quando, Quando, Quando comes out in September. The films preview shows a lace-clad, pump-wearing woman exploring the Trevi fountain in Rome as lecherous local men of all ages ogle her, gesticulating dramatically. The melodramatic soundtrack, R-rating and black and white cinematography could either add up to cinematic genius or fashion fluff. Tune in in September to find out which.

title: Treatments: Drug Schedule Improves Survival Rate of Those With AIDS and Tuberculosis
description: People who are near death from a combination of tuberculosis and AIDS are more likely to survive if they get immediate TB treatment, followed two weeks later by antiretroviral drugs for AIDS, doctors are reporting.

title: Red Sox Let Yankees Know Race Is Still On
description: It took until their last meeting of a four-game series, but the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox finally put together the sort of tense, postseason-worthy affair that they have made a regular summertime occurrence for the better part of the decade.

title: The Drawing Center to Stay in SoHo
description: 6:01 p.m. | Updated After years of looking for a new downtown home, the Drawing Center has decided to stay put in its SoHo neighborhood. The economy made us re-evaluate what scale of project we want, said Brett Littman, the Drawing Centers director, in an interview on Monday. Were like a nice small jazz club  the scale of what we do is intimate, drawings tend to be pretty small. The board leadership and myself have come to the conclusion that maybe the Drawing Center shouldnt be 30,000 square feet. Its not in the cards for us. The move was first reported by Crains NY Business.

title: Scoliosis Test Lets Children Avoid a Brace
description: For her 12th birthday in February, Marissa Levy of Oceanside, N.Y., received an unusual gift: a test that told her spine doctor she could give up her body brace.

title: In a Video Game, Tackling the Complexities of Protein Folding
description: Gamers 1, computer 0.

title: Where Millions Need Care, Starting With One
description: At dawn, an old woman in a bright but tattered dress picked her way along a muddy, trash-strewn path. She stopped at a pile of garbage and carefully removed the remains of a dirty onion. Then she sat and slowly began to eat it for breakfast.

title: Hands-On Reassembly in Stripped-Down Gallery
description: There is much for New York art institutions of all sizes to learn from the extreme makeover lately visited upon Artists Space, the small and venerable, if long-moribund, pioneer of the downtown alternative art scene. Basically the place has been literally and spiritually swept clean by the new broom of Stefan Kalmr, the German-born former director of the Munich Kunstverein, who took over as executive director and chief curator in June 2009.

title: Water Safety
description: Q. Ive been saving gallons of water in unopened plastic jugs since 9/11. Does the water go bad for drinking and cooking?

title: Merrills Downfall Provides a Disclosure Lesson
description: It was named after a faint constellation in the southern sky: Pyxis, the Mariners Compass. But it helped to steer the mighty Merrill Lynch toward disaster, The New York Timess Louise Story reports.

title: Where Anglers Rear Back and Let It Fly
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  If one is aiming to make the longest cast with a fly rod in American history, the best attempts to make the record book are usually the first two casts.

title: Share Your Last Straw Stories
description: Updated, 4:00 p.m., Aug. 13 | The fracas on Monday aboard a JetBlue plane at Kennedy International Airport has us thinking at City Room  and wanting to hear from you.

title: Water on Moon Unlikely, a New Study Indicates
description: In the long discussion of water on the Moon, a new study contradicts some recent reports that say the Moon had water at the time of its formation. A group of researchers reports in the journal Science that when the Moon was created, some 4.5 billion years ago, there was not much hydrogen on it, and therefore no water.

title: Building a Framework to Read Animal Emotion
description: Pet owners might like to think they can judge the moods of their cats or dogs with ease, but finding true scientific methods to evaluate animal emotion is difficult.

title: Crocodile Fossil Reveals Teeth of a Mammal
description: Modern crocodiles have conical teeth they use to grab at prey. Sometime the crocodiles rip off pieces of flesh from their prey, and sometimes they swallow their victims whole. They do not, however, chew their food, as humans and many other mammals do.

title: Hezbollah Says Israel Took Part in Assassination
description: BEIRUT  In a two-hour long television appearance, Hezbollahs leader, Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, offered Monday what he contended was evidence proving Israels involvement in the assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, in a 2005 bombing.

title: Oracle Chief Faults H.P. Board for Forcing Hurd Out
description: Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle, denounced Hewlett-Packards directors on Monday for forcing the resignation of the H.P. chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, who is a friend of Mr. Ellisons, The New York Timess Ashlee Vance reports from San Francisco.

title: Is It Really Appendicitis?
description: In todays 18 and Under column, pediatrician Dr. Perri Klass explores the murky world of appendicitis. As often as 20 percent of the time, an operation to remove an appendix turns out to be unnecessary. (Its called a negative appendectomy, she explains.) But while new CT scans can improve diagnostic ability, it also exposes a child to radiation. Dr. Klass writes:

title: For Travel Industry, Things Are Looking Up
description: HOUSTON

title: Lessons From a Wounded Star Pupil
description: It was hard to look at her bruised and lacerated legs, but she insisted on showing me how her own limbs had become the enemy. At age 22, Sue was paralyzed from the waist down, unable to feel any sensation in her legs.

title: Smokers Have More Stress
description: Smokers often reach for a cigarette to calm their nerves, but new research suggests that smoking is actually a source of a stress, according to todays Really? column.

title: New Jersey Halts Oyster Restoration Project
description: KEYPORT, N.J.  A decade of efforts to restore marine life to the polluted Raritan Bay suffered a serious setback on Monday when, under orders from the state, an environmental group pulled up the oysters it had cultivated there.

title: David F. Dixon, Force Behind Saints and Superdome, Dies at 87
description: David F. Dixon, a New Orleans businessman who played a leading role in the founding of the National Football Leagues Saints and the construction of the Louisiana Superdome, died Sunday at his home in New Orleans. He was 87.

title: Fed Will Meet With Concerns on Deflation Rising
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve will meet on Tuesday faced with a pivotal decision about whether to abandon its presumption that the economy is gradually picking up steam and begin to consider new steps to keep the recovery from sputtering out.

title: The Caucus With Reshma Saujani
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC interviewed Reshma Saujani, a Democratic candidate for New York's 14th Congressional District.

title: Diet: Low-Fat vs. Atkins: Parallel Results
description: One of the longest trials to pit low-fat diets against Atkins-style diets found that participants lost the same amount of weight after two years, regardless of which diet they were on, though the Atkins dieters had greater increases in HDL, or good cholesterol. Previous studies have shown mixed results.

title: Shea Gallante to Open Ciano This Fall
description: Shea Gallante, who has had a little trouble finding his niche since stepping down as chef of Cru about a year ago, has now found a place of his own. Teaming up with the restaurateur Stratis Morfogen, he will open Ciano this fall. The Italian restaurant, named for a Tuscan village, takes over the space at 45 East 22nd Street once occupied by Cesare Casellas Beppe. It already has a Tuscan look, which the owners intend to enhance. Mr. Gallante even plans to bake hearth breads in the fireplace.

title: DNA Test May Speed Colon Cancer Diagnosis
description: A new generation of DNA tests for colon cancer seems likely to improve the detection both of cancers and of the precancerous polyps that precede them. The tests, if validated, could reduce the burden of disease substantially by detecting tumors at an early stage, including those not picked up by a colonoscopy.

title: A Key for Opening Stunted Egg Cells to Fertilization
description: For years, reproductive biologists were stymied by a mystery of egg cell development: What are the signals that tell immature egg cells  primordial follicles  to develop into mature eggs that can be fertilized?

title: Via Listserv, Parents Clash in Harlem

title: Arkansas: Doctor Found Guilty in Bomb Attack
description: A federal jury on Monday convicted a physician of conspiring to detonate a car bomb that badly injured the state medical board chairman. Dr. Randeep Mann faces the possibility of life in prison in the February 2009 bombing in West Memphis, Ark., which left the board chairman, Dr. Trent P. Pierce, badly scarred and partly blind. Prosecutors said the bombing was in retaliation after the board twice sanctioned Dr. Mann for overprescribing pain medication. Dr. Manns wife, Sangeeta, was convicted of conspiring to conceal evidence. Prosecutors say that they do not believe the Manns planted the bomb, but that Dr. Mann ordered an unknown person to do so.

The pass was also low, but the receiver dropped to one knee, snagged the ball, and turned up the sideline for a long gain.

title: Paul Milstein, City Real Estate Titan, Dies at 88
description: Paul Milstein, who used profits from the family flooring business to build a real estate empire in New York City, distinguished by major projects begun in uncertain neighborhoods and totaling 50,000 apartments, 8,000 hotel rooms and 20 million square feet of office space, died on Monday at his Manhattan home. He was 88.

title: Mercury Limits Are Set for Cement Plants
description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday set the first limits for mercury emissions from cement factories. The rules will cut mercury emissions and particulate matter 92 percent a year starting in 2013, the agency said. Manufacture of Portland cement, the type most widely used, is the third-biggest source of mercury air pollution in the country, the agency. said. Mercury, which can harm childhood development of the brain and is linked to asthma, heart attacks and premature deaths, is released when cement components are heated in a kiln, according to agency documents. The E.P.A. estimated that the rules would yield $6.7 billion to $18 billion in environmental and health benefits and cost companies as much as $950 million a year.

Everyone, it seems, is in a bad mood.

description: Senator Tim Johnson, Democrat of South Dakota, is resting comfortably after surgery Tuesday morning to remove his gallbladder, according to a statement released by his office.

description: I HAD the route mapped out in my mind. I would bike from the Lower East Side of Manhattan, hit the taco trucks along the ball fields of Red Hook, Brooklyn, cruise through Prospect Park over to Brighton Beach for a quick dip, then hypotenuse it back to a bar in Williamsburg to watch the World Cup finals.

title: The Focal-Point Fed
description: The FOMC has spoken. Whats my reaction? The Feds current policy is grossly inadequate, logically bizarre, and slightly  but only slightly  encouraging.

title: The Insider | Jon Spencer
description: After a six-year hiatus, the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion  the stripped-down blues-rock outfit that put sweat on the brow of the Lower East Side in the 90s  is back in its leather-panted garage-stomp glory, reissuing key albums like Extra Width and releasing the compilation Dirty Shirt Rock (En Roll: The First Ten Years). At a recent performance at the Pitchfork Music Festival, Spencer, the guitarist Judah Bauer (who also plays with Cat Powers Dirty Delta Blues Band) and the drummer Russell Simins showed the skinny-jeans crowd where skinny pants came from as Spencer whipped up the audience wearing rubber-coated denim on a 95-degree day. Still hot after all these years. Here, Spencer shares his insider picks.

title: Disney Earnings Are Better Than Expected
description: LOS ANGELES  Profit soared 40 percent at the Walt Disney Company in its most recent quarter, propelled by three blockbuster movies, strong merchandise sales and deferred revenue at ESPN.

title: Early U.S. Tests Find No Toyota Flaw in Electronics
description: DETROIT  The governments investigation into complaints of sudden acceleration of Toyota vehicles has found no evidence of flawed electronics in 58 of the vehicles that crashed, federal regulators said Tuesday.

title: Societies May Fall, but Prices Do Not at Lanvin
description: WHENEVER the disparity between rich and poor becomes too obscene, as it did during the Victorian era or the Great Depression, a particular story line seems to reassert itself in literature and other media. A rich and cold-hearted magnate (e.g., Ebenezer Scrooge) is met by some lovely person or divine agency whose innate goodness forces the tycoon to realize that his life is miserable because it has been devoted to greed. The misers heart thaws, the weight of his priorities shifts. In the end, he places less value on the wealth part of his personal wealth and more value on the personal.

title: Staten Island Armory and Church Are Named Landmarks
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission granted landmark status on Tuesday to two venerable complexes on Staten Island: the Staten Island Armory on Manor Road in Castleton Corners, and the neo-Gothic Christ Church and its rectory and parish house in the northeast corner of the island.

title: The Fed Is Worried
description: It is clear that the Fed is much more worried than it has been about the strength of the economic recovery.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gansu Province and Elsewhere
description: The death toll from landslides early Sunday morning in western China has climbed to 702, with 1,042 people still missing and 42 seriously injured, the state news agency, Xinhua, reported Tuesday afternoon. Vice Premier Hui Liangyu ordered rescuers to step up efforts to find people trapped under the rubble in Zhouqu, in Gansu Province, and noted that these people had the best chance of survival if found within 72 hours of the disaster. The landslide obliterated a large section of the town and then poured into a river, damming the waterway and causing it to flood and submerge part of the devastated community. Soldiers have been using explosives to clear the blockage and drain the town.

title: New Federal Aid for School Districts, States
description: The House interrupted its summer recess on Tuesday to approve $26 billion in aid to school districts and states to prevent large-scale layoffs of teachers and public employees and to engage in another partisan fight over policy priorities.

title: Hurling Thunderbolts From the Floor
description: VAIL, Colo.  I dont much enjoy watching dance on YouTube, but the scale of tango suits it better than any other genre. There you can see two ravishing clips of the Argentine tango dancers Natalia Hills and Gabriel Miss at the Vail International Dance Festival last year. (Search for their names and the Vail festival.)

title: Barak Says Friction Was Expected in Flotilla Raid
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, said Tuesday that Israels leaders were aware of the possibility that the military interception of a flotilla bound for Gaza in late May could turn violent, although lower level military officials had said at the time that the commandos were expecting only passive resistance.

title: Homes for $500,000
description: Properties on the market in Pittsburgh, Seattle and Phoenix.

title: What You Get for ... $500,000
description: PITTSBURGH

title: Russian Fires Raise Fears of Radioactivity
description: MOSCOW  As if things in Russia were not looking sufficiently apocalyptic already, with 100-degree temperatures and noxious fumes rolling in from burning peat bogs and forests, there is growing alarm here that fires in regions coated with fallout from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster 24 years ago could now be emitting plumes of radioactive smoke.

title: 8,000 People? E.P.A. Defers Hearing on Fracking
description: After successfully holding hearings around the country on the impact of the natural gas drilling method known as hydraulic fracturing, officials with the federal Environmental Protection Agency ran into a hurdle this week in New York State: finding an acceptable site for a hearing and for the passionate crowds expected to show up for it.

title: Incumbent Backed by Obama Wins Colorado Primary
description: DENVER  The predictions of doom for incumbents and establishment candidates this campaign season are proving to be more complex in the real world. On Tuesday, Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado, a Democrat who had hitched his star to the fortunes of President Obama, survived a bitter primary challenge.

title: Scientists See Links From Asian Floods to Russian Heat
description: Two climatologists, Peter Stott at the British Met Office and Kevin Trenberth of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, have separately described atmospheric dynamics that appear to link the extreme rains and flooding in Asia with Russias unrelenting, extraordinary heat and resulting conflagrations.

title: Quote Unquote | Unzipped
description: Marc Jacobs explains his nude fragrance ad, shot by Juergen Teller, to Harpers Bazaar. As a frequent wearer of skirts and kilts, how could he find jeans and a shirt ridiculous?

title: A Tool for Activists Is Simplified for the Less Tech Savvy
description: Software that has been hailed as a powerful tool in response to crisis has become accessible for low-tech activists. Ushahidi, a technology which allows users to create maps from data drawn from messages from cellphones, news reports and the Web, is now available through a Web-based application called Crowdmap.

title: Video From an Embed With the Taliban
description: A video of Taliban fighters shot last October by a Norwegian journalist in eastern Afghanistan offers a rare glimpse of the war from the perspective of the Afghan insurgents.

title: Keep It With the Committee, Please
description: White House officials and other top Democrats, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California, were not happy with the decision by Representative Charles R. Rangel, Democrat of New York, to take over the House floor during Tuesdays emergency session to offer his personal defense against ethics charges.

description: A man accused of raping a Russian tourist last month was indicted on Tuesday, a Manhattan prosecutor said in court.

title: Beer Gardens Bloom Around the City
