description: Ice Cream and Beer

title: At the New Meadowlands Stadium, Grilling Stations
description: Fans who arrive by train at the New Meadowlands Stadium in New Jersey will be met by the aroma of steaks sizzling on gas grills inside the gate. Its a twist on tailgating that the folks who run the stadium are calling "railgating." Lobels, the Madison Avenue meat purveyor, and Weber-Stephen, a maker of charcoal and gas grills, are partners with the stadium in two grilling stations, which made their debut at the Brazil-U.S.A. soccer match on Aug. 10, and will be in business throughout the football season.

title: Pickle Chips With Hot Sauce
description: Demand for a spicy cucumber pickle led Rick Field to dump some sriracha Thai-style hot sauce into a batch of his straightforward pickle chips. Several trial runs later, Mr. Field believes he has nailed the balance of crisp, briny and hot  just what his fans had asked for. The pickles pack heat but not searingly so, and are a terrific accompaniment to sandwiches, charcuterie, cold noodle dishes and burgers. Chop them to start a tartar sauce for chilled or fried seafood.

title: Recyclables Become Spoons and Spatulas
description: Take two or three plastic water bottles, let a green alchemist touch them with a magic wand and you have kitchen utensils: two generous spoons and two spatulas, plain or with a leaf pattern. The tools are made by turning the plastic into flakes that are compressed and shaped. The work is done in an upstate New York plant that uses wind energy and trucks that run on bio-diesel.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: Traif
description: IN the valley of the shadow of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, where bearded Hasidim cross paths with mustachioed steam punks, stands the restaurant Traif.

title: Just Looking | Head Trip
description: The fashion tribes descending on Paris for couture week in July might have done well to leave behind the elegant boutiques of the rue Boissy dAnglas and the chic precincts of the Hotel Crillon and head instead toward La Bastille, where on a quay fringed with plumbing supply and carpet shops and overlooking the Canal Saint Martin, an extraordinary collection of accessories has taken up residence. There, the Maison Rouge, a nonprofit kunsthalle devoted to contemporary art, is showing more than 300 hats and headdresses from all over the globe, all of which belong to the institutions founder, Antoine de Galbert.De Galbert, a former gallery owner better known as a collector of both outsider and contemporary art, acquired the first hat in his collection about 15 years ago  a small headdress, intended as a sculptural ornament, and adorned with cassowary feathers from Papua New Guinea. He was hooked. His collection now numbers more than 400 pieces. It includes brilliantly beplumed Amazonian bonnets; sumptuously beaded, cone-shaped royal crowns worn by Yoruba chieftains, adorned with birds (symbols, according to the shows catalog, of the mystical power of women); a Burmese hunters horned headdress, designed to inspire terror, with a monkeys skull posed atop a bit of bear fur; as well as more modest garments, like a simple cap from India, made of felted yak hair, to protect against the rain. Theres a diadem once worn by an Uzbek bride on her wedding day, and a headband covered in cowry shells that announced the birth of a first child to a woman in Indonesia.

title: CBS Wins With Comedy
description: ABCs latest Bachelor spinoff, Bachelor Pad, attracted a modest showing in the ratings on Monday, earning 6.4 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates, enough to lift ABC to second place for the night. CBS led over all, garnering larger audiences with reruns of its comedy lineup, particularly Two and a Half Men (8.6 million) and The Big Bang Theory (8.4 million). NBC and Fox finished in a virtual tie for third with NBC edging ahead with an Americas Got Talent rerun at 8 (4.9 million). Fox broadcast the 2010 Teen Choice Awards, which averaged 4.1 million viewers from 8 to 10.

title: Arena Stage Lineup of Leading Ladies
description: Phylicia Rashad, below top, and Anna Deavere Smith, below bottom, will be the leading ladies in the inaugural productions at Arena Stage at the Mead Center for American Theater in Washington, Arena Stage officials announced on Tuesday. Ms. Rashad, whose Broadway credits include Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, will play Mother Sister/Sophia in the world premiere of Every Tongue Confess by Marcus Gardley (On the Levee). Directed by Kenny Leon, it will run Nov. 9 to Jan. 2. Ms. Smith, a stage, film and television actress, will begin a national tour of Let Me Down Easy, her one-woman show about health care and the body as a Second Stage production in the newly refurbished Kreeger Theater. That play, directed by Leonard Foglia (Moby Dick), runs Dec. 31 to Feb. 13. In addition, E. Faye Butler (Trouble in Mind) will play Aunt Eller in Rodgers and Hammersteins Oklahoma! Directed by Molly Smith, artistic director of Arena Stage, it runs Oct. 22 to Dec. 26.

title: New Yorks New Beer Gardens
description: Loreley in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and the Biergarten at the Standard Hotel in the meatpacking district in Manhattan are among the crop of new beer gardens opening around the city.

title: Storycorps Histories Become Animated Shorts
description: Some of the stirring oral histories recorded by StoryCorps are being transformed into animated television segments. The PBS program P.O.V. announced on Tuesday that the first of six animated shorts would be shown alongside its feature films starting on Tuesday. The shorts illustrate some of the most memorable stories captured by StoryCorps since its founding seven years ago. The nonprofit group has recorded the oral histories of more than 60,000 participants. One recording is featured each week on NPR. P.O.V. said examples of the animated shorts include a conversation between a 12-year-old boy with Aspergers syndrome and his mother; an infantrymans memories of the Battle of the Bulge; and an interview of the author and radio host Studs Terkel, who died in 2008.

title: Considering the Chute, in the Event of a Non-Emergency
description: As a veteran flight attendant for JetBlue, Steven Slater undoubtedly logged many hours in training how to evacuate a planeload of terrified fliers down the emergency chutes. On Monday, he put those skills to use  by quickly evacuating himself.

title: Opening Date Is Set For Spider-Man Musical
description: The much-anticipated, much-delayed Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, with music and lyrics by U2s Bono and the Edge, has been given a date for the start of preview performances  Nov. 14  at Broadways newly renamed Foxwoods Theater (formerly the Hilton Theater). The shows producers announced on Tuesday that they had also set an opening night, Dec. 21. The musical is estimated to have a $50 million budget, the largest in Broadway history. Directed by Julie Taymor, the Tony Award-winning creator of the long-running musical The Lion King, Spider-Man appears to have rebounded from a production delay that involved scuttling its original plan to start performances last February. According to executives involved with Spider-Man, the new producers have secured enough financing for the creative team to begin rehearsals next week and commit to performance dates and a box-office schedule. Tickets will go on sale in September; an exclusive presale to American Express cardholders begins on Saturday. People who previously bought tickets will be contacted by Ticketmaster and given priority access for tickets again.

title: Bruno Suit Is Dismissed
description: Sacha Baron Cohen, who was sued late last year for slander in connection with Bruno, his comedy-documentary about a gay fashion reporter, managed this week to get out of another sticky legal situation, Reuters reported. On Monday a federal judge dismissed a copyright claim brought by a writer who said that a scene in the 2009 film was very similar to his own original script, titled Himbos, Reuters reported. John Musero filed suit against Mr. Baron Cohen, in character above, the director Larry Charles, the producers Mosaic Media Group and MRC and others in March. Mr. Musero had claimed that a scene in which Bruno wrecks havoc at a fashion show because he is stuck in a Velcro suit came from a script that Mr. Musero had pitched to Mosaic, which later rejected it. The court ruled that the idea of a man in a Velcro suit was not subject to copyright and that the two works were not that similar. The protagonist in Himbos is chased by a rabbit and cats after rabbit food gets stuck to the back of his suit. Bruno shows its title character crashing into a rack of clothes and falling onto a runway.

title: The Drawing Center Will Stay In Soho
description: After years of seeking a new downtown home, the Drawing Center has decided to stay put in its SoHo neighborhood. The economy made us re-evaluate what scale of project we want, Brett Littman, the Drawing Centers director, said in an interview on Monday. Were like a nice small jazz club  the scale of what we do is intimate; drawings tend to be pretty small. The center has 2,500 square feet in its main gallery at 35 Wooster Street, which it owns, and about 500 square feet across the street at 40 Wooster Street, where it has a lease that must be renegotiated every two years. Mr. Littman said the center was looking at alternatives to its secondary space and considering ways to better utilize its main gallery with a possible redesign. Until recently, the Drawing Center had been exploring a wholesale move, a search that included ground zero and the South Street Seaport and Pier 18. But now SoHo has become even more of a cultural haven, fueled by an influx of commercial galleries and the opening of the New Museum on the Bowery. There is a kind of understanding that the circumstances have shifted and maybe this is a good moment for the Drawing Center to reinvest in the neighborhood it built its reputation in, Mr. Littman said.

title: Levi Johnston Pitches Reality Show For Cable
description: After a Playgirl shoot and a star turn on Kathy Griffins My Life on the D-List, one might think that Levi Johnstons 15 minutes are up. But he apparently wants a half-hour each week. Mr. Johnston, a bit player in the last presidential election, is pitching a reality television show to several cable channels. Producers are filming in Hollywood this week for the show, which would be called Loving Levi: The Road to the Mayors Office. That would be the mayors office in Wasilla, Alaska, where Sarah Palin got her start. According to the producers, the series would show Mr. Johnston campaigning to be the mayor of Wasilla, even though that job does not come up for election until 2012. Without a channel, though, the show is little more than an idea. Asked why Mr. Johnstons show was publicized even though it lacks a channel, Canaan Rubin, an executive producer, said in an e-mail that a pilot is in preproduction and several networks are interested. The interested parties have not been identified.

title: Bill to Halt Certain Sales of Artwork May Be Dead

description: Kem was scatting a bit Saturday night, even if he didnt quite mean to. It was the Budweiser Superfest, at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater, and he was about three minutes away from climbing atop the grand piano at center stage for a triumphant dance.

description: Two companies  Gallim Dance and Camille A. Brown & Dancers  shared Mondays bill at the Joyce Theater. On the recording Ms. Kole sings with 11 eminent jazz pianists: Monty Alexander, Kenny Barron, Alan Broadbent, Dave Brubeck, Freddy Cole, Benny Green, Steve Kuhn, Michel Legrand, Mike Renzi, Cedar Walton and Hank Jones (who died on May 16).

description: If ever there was a time for a group of former Hare Krishna adherents to come to New York to make their way as a band, it would be now. Thanks to groups like Animal Collective and its peers, the shamanic impulse is as alive as ever in indie rock. The embrace of Eastern spirituality is at an apex. Tie-dye is making a comeback.

title: Turkey: Adviser Could Face Polygamy Charges
description: Ali Yuksel, an adviser to the Turkish prime ministers office, could face up to two years in prison if he is charged with polygamy after describing his simultaneous relationship with three women in a recently published book. Mr. Yuksel cited Islamic law, which does not apply in secular Turkey, to defend the relationships. He is the father-in-law of Suat Kilic, a leading member of the governing Justice and Development Party whose attempt to pass a law legalizing polygamy a few years ago failed in the face of heavy secular opposition.

title: President Abbas and Peace Talks
description: Making peace between Israelis and Palestinians is somewhat like solving a Rubiks Cube. You get one colored square lined up but the next one just wont fall into place. So it is now. After three months of American-mediated proximity talks, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has agreed to direct negotiations on a two-state solution; the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, is stubbornly resisting. It is time for him to talk.

title: Early Detection of Alzheimers
description: Scientists are making steady gains toward developing tests that can predict whether patients with mild cognitive difficulties or even no symptoms at all are likely to progress to full-blown Alzheimers disease. title: The Phenomenology of Ugly

So Luigi took his scissors out and tried to fix me up. Except  and this is the point that occurred to me as I inspected the hair in the bathroom mirror the next morning  he didnt really take quite enough off. He had enhanced the style, true, but there was a big floppy fringe that was starting to annoy me. And it was hot out. So I opened up the clipper attachment on the razor and hacked away at it for a while. When I finally emerged there was a general consensus that I looked like a particularly disreputable scarecrow. In the end I went to another barbershop (I didnt dare show Luigi my handiwork) and had it all sheared off. Now I look like a cross between Britney Spears and Michel Foucault.

title: The F Word
description: Fashion, which has always been as much a narrative about the body as it is about clothes, has rarely taken kindly to the idea of flesh. Much as we may wax nostalgic about the Rubenesque ideal or the buxom, wide-hipped wenches of Restoration comedies, in its modern iteration fashion has steadily downsized the human scale. Flesh suggests messiness, privileging the indiscipline of life over the fierce control of art, the unaerobicized body spilling over the contours of an artificial silhouette, be it Christian Diors New Look in 1947 or Marc Jacobss New Look for Louis Vuitton this fall. Flesh also suggests the threateningly female, moistness and blood, the hothouse clutches of a heavy-breasted mother  off-putting images for male fashion designers, who are more often than not gay. (Think of Karl Lagerfelds withering disdain on hearing that a German magazine would now be using only regular-size women in its fashion spreads: No one wants to see curvy women. . . . Youve got fat mothers with their bags of chips sitting in front of the television and saying that thin models are ugly.)

title: Chernobyl, Fires and Radiation

title: On Dawkinss Atheism: A Response

It argued that faith should go hand-in-hand with rational reflection, even though such reflection might well require serious questioning of their faith. I very much appreciated the many and diverse comments and the honesty and passion with which so many expressed their views. Interestingly, many of the most passionate responses came from non-believers who objected to my claim that popular atheistic arguments (like popular theistic arguments) do not establish their conclusions. There was particular dismay over my passing comment that the atheistic arguments of Richard Dawkins are demonstrably faulty. This follow-up provides support for my negative assessment. I will focus on Dawkins arguments in his 2006 book, The God Delusion.

I put her in that special class of actresses  along with Meryl Streep, Marisa Tomei and Julianne Moore  who choose the work because the role seems right for them at the time, not necessarily for the money.

title: TwitPics Creator Has a New Project, Heello
description: Before Noah Everett started TwitPic, a photo sharing service for people who use Twitter, he had bigger plans in mind: he wanted to build tools that made the Web an easier place to work.

title: Letters: Plus-Size Wars
description: Thank you to Ginia Bellafante for giving this strange purgatory a name, for I have been on the bridge between regular and plus for most of my adult life. My choices are between too-tight pants and the dreaded droopy crotch; crossing the divide from womens to plus always seems to involve a humiliating trip through maternity. I hope Bellafantes article is being passed around the apparel industry as a message: make me a stylish, form-fitting outfit of natural fibers, and Ill give you my cold, hard cash.

title: Letters: Unnatural Science
description: In The Medium, the usually fair-minded Virginia Heffernan excoriates the science-blogging community in because of some offensive or silly posts. Science blogs serve a valuable educational function, but they are uneven and cacophonous  just like the mainstream media. If some bloggers sound desperate and strident, its possibly because even into the 21st century, only 39 percent of Americans believe in evolution and one out of five believes the Sun revolves around the Earth.

title: Letters: I Tweet, Therefore I Am
description: Connected? Or clamoring for attention? I fear as a parent, a therapist and a cranky 50-year-old that all this Twittering, texting, Facebooking and blogging neglects the No. 1 developmental task  to know thyself and not give much of a whit what others think.

title: Bullock To Remain In Oil-Spill Campaign
description: Sandra Bullock, an Academy Award winner for The Blind Side and a New Orleans resident, has agreed to remain part of a celebrity video to draw attention to the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Last month she threatened to withdraw amid questions about the corporate sponsorship of the group organizing the campaign. We are happy that Ms. Bullock has reviewed the facts of the RestoretheGulf.com campaign, Anne Milling, founder of Women of the Storm, which began the effort, said in a statement. She and the other celebrities have been instrumental in rallying national support for restoration of our beaches, wetlands and Gulf Coast environment. The campaigns first goal is to gather signatures demanding a fully financed, environmentally sustainable effort to restore the Gulf Coast; the group has collected more than 127,000 signatures. The video, called Be the One, in which performers who live in or are connected with the Gulf Coast, includes Wendell Pierce, Harry Shearer, Dr. John and Lenny Kravitz.

title: Global Youth Unemployment Reaches New High
description: PARIS  Youth unemployment across the world has climbed to a new high and is likely to climb further this year, a United Nations agency said Thursday, while warning of a lost generation as more young people give up the search for work.

title: Coalition to Challenge N.Y.U. Expansion
description: A coalition of Greenwich Village community, preservation and parent groups has formed to register concerns about New York Universitys expansion plans, after a previous task force was suspended by Scott Stringer, the Manhattan borough president. (Mr. Stringers office said he decided to suspend the task force and delegate the process to an existing community board as the project begins a formal public review this fall.) The new coalition  called the Community Action Alliance on N.Y.U. 2031  is pushing to ensure that the recommendations of the original task force are adopted by elected officials and the local community board, which have not yet taken a position on the plan. The plan, known as N.Y.U. 2031, calls for adding six million square feet of classrooms, dormitories and offices over the next 20 years on the core campus and other locations. In letter sent Friday the new alliance urged elected officials to have the university consider alternative locations, like the financial district, insisting that the proposal is too much and would inalterably destroy the quality of our community. Above, a protest at N.Y.U. in April.

title: Waiting in the Wings to Be Chief G.O.P. Dealmaker
description: WASHINGTON  As lawmakers head home this week for what remains of summer, one question transfixes Washington: Will Democrats lose control of the House and possibly even the Senate in November, or will they hang on to fragile majorities?

title: Designers Donate Their Archives
description: The designers Massimo and Lella Vignelli have donated their archives to the Rochester Institute of Technology, where the collection will be available to professional designers and scholars. The archive contains original source materials, along with examples of finished work  including their corporate identity programs, jewelry, silverware and furniture. The Vignelli Collection will be part of the Vignelli Center for Design Studies, a three-story complex on the campus. The center officially opens with a ceremony on Sept. 16. The university is already home to the archives of the American Modernist graphic design pioneers Lester Beall, Will Burtin, Cipe Pineles, Alvin Lustig and William Golden, among others.

title: Smackdown at P.G.A. as Gray and Pavin Trade Barbs
description: HAVEN, Wis.  A scene right out of a World Wrestling Entertainment event erupted at the staid P.G.A. Championship on Wednesday when Jim Gray of the Golf Channel called the United States Ryder Cup captain Corey Pavin a liar and told him, Youre going down.

title: New York Kicks
description: New Yorkers missed out on the basketball superstar LeBron James flaunting his Nikes for the Knicks or Nets when the signed with the Miami Heat last month. However, arm-chair athletes in Manhattan and Brooklyn (the future home of the Nets), the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island can flaunt their own moves in sneakers honoring the five boroughs. Nikes limited-edition Air Force 1 Borough Pack features different colors, logos and laces for each of the citys boroughs.

title: Social Security Madness
description: Has the Washington Post gone mad? asks Dean Baker, reading the Posts latest editorial on Social Security. The answer is no: it has been mad all along.

title: LED Bulb Edges Below $20
description: This week, Home Depot fired a new marketing salvo in what is expected to be a broader national effort to get home customers to adopt LED lighting.

title: Jan Maxwell to Star in Revival of Wings
description: Jan Maxwell will star in the revival of Arthur Kopits 1978 play Wings at Second Stage Theater, the theater announced on Wednesday. The play, directed by John Doyle (Sweeney Todd, Company), begins previews on Oct. 5 and opens on Oct. 24. Mr. Kopits Tony-nominated play follows the adventures of Emily Stilson, a 1920s wing walker. The cast also includes Teagle F. Bougere, Beth Dixon, January LaVoy, Anne L. Nathan and Michael Warner.

title: First in a Decade: Living Novelist on Cover
description: The issue of Time magazine on sale Friday will feature Jonathan Franzen on the cover, below, the first time that a living American novelist has garnered that honor since Stephen King, in 2000. The accompanying article, by Lev Grossman, is a profile of Mr. Franzen on the occasion of his fourth novel, Freedom, the story of an American family that is due to be published this month. In the past Time has featured Tom Wolfe, Toni Morrison, George Orwell, John Updike, John Le Carr, Norman Mailer and other writers.

title: Sunny Scenes, Direct From Pyongyang
description: VIENNA

title: NBC Wins Tuesday
description: NBC won the ratings race on Tuesday as the 10-year-old singer Jackie Evancho stunned audiences with a Susan Boyle moment on Americas Got Talent. According to Nielsens estimates, 10.4 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. to the two-hour talent show. CBS placed second on the night, outpacing NBCs repeat of Minute to Win It (5 million) in the 8 p.m. hour with a rerun of NCIS (8.6 million). Fox ranked third over all, earning 7.1 million viewers for the season finale of Hells Kitchen followed by 6.1 million for the third installment of MasterChef. Despite their modest audiences, the two culinary reality shows helped Fox win the night in the sought-after demographic of adults 18 to 49. ABC finished in fourth place with Wipeout at 8 (7.9 million), Shaq Vs. at 9 (3.9 million) and Primetime at 10 (4.2 million).

title: Wanda Sykes to Watch Orphans in Annie
description: The comedian Wanda Sykes, below, is no stranger to theatricality. Best known for her ribald stand-up comedy and appearances on TV shows including Curb Your Enthusiasm, and as host of her own late-night talk show, Ms. Sykes is to take on a new, unexpectedly theatrical role: that of the orphanage matron Miss Hannigan in a revival of the musical Annie, beginning this fall at the Media Theater near Philadelphia. Ms. Sykes is scheduled to appear in the production from Nov. 23 through Dec. 12, and again from Jan. 12 to 16, leaving the role over the holidays to fill other commitments, according to a spokesman for the theater. Having watched her with her stand-up, her timing and the inherent talent that she has with comedy, is something she can really use in the show, said Jesse Cline, the theaters artistic director. And if you have ever dreamed of performing onstage with Ms. Sykes  and who hasnt?  nows your chance. Auditions for the roles of the orphans will be held at the theater on Aug. 21. Auditions for the shows adult roles will be held on Aug. 23.

title: Details Emerge About Alaska Crash Rescue
description: Rescue workers, rain-soaked and mud-caked, had to hike through a dense Alaska forest to reach the four survivors of the small plane crash that killed the former Senator Ted Stevens and four other people Monday night, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said on Wednesday.

title: Happy Secular Pakistan Day
description: As Pakistans government continues to vie with Islamist charities to provide relief to millions of its citizens affected by catastrophic flooding, two posts on Lahores Pak Tea House blog are worth reading.

title: Producers Put a Theater in Their Own Backyard
description: FOURTEEN years ago, Barry and Fran Weissler took Chicago, a Broadway show that had done well at the box office but was received coolly by critics, and turned the revival into a hit that generated front-page reviews and drop-dead ticket sales.

title: Amazon Digital Discount Helps Arcade Fire Hit No. 1
description: The indie kids made it to No. 1, with a little help from Amazon.com.

title: The Mirthless Senate
description: The United States Senate, which still flatters itself with the misnomer the worlds greatest deliberative body, counts a former Major League Baseball player, an organic wheat farmer, far too many lawyers and a member who describes herself as a mom in tennis shoes among its select 100.

title: Blagojevich Jury Tells Judge Its Deadlocked
description: CHICAGO  Unable to reach a unanimous decision on several counts in the wide-ranging corruption trial of Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, jurors sent a note late Wednesday to the presiding judge asking for advice. It was the 11th day of deliberations, and the judge, James B. Zagel, told lawyers for the defense and prosecutors that he would advise the jury to keep working at reaching at least some consensus.

title: After Uproar, Knicks and Thomas Call Deal Off
description: Five days after the Knicks startled the basketball world by announcing that Isiah Thomas would return as a part-time consultant to the team with which he had a disastrous run as president and coach, the whole arrangement was called off.

description: Family legacies are passed down in stories and keepsakes and history books and genes.

description: Its Ann Liv Young versus P.S. 1, Round 2.

title: Phillips Collections New Bonsai Sculpture
description: All wood products, when you think about it, are made of dead wood. But few have the poignancy of Phillips Collections new end of life Bonsai Sculpture Collection: dead bonsai trees or branches from Thailand that have been bleached and mounted on iron bases, and, as shown, can be placed in a shapely polished aluminum and resin vase.

title: Tiffany Reinvents Vases From Its Archives
description: Tiffany & Company is introducing six small vases inspired by pieces made by Louis Comfort Tiffany and Tiffany Studios between 1906 and 1913. Four bone-china vases, above, were introduced last month; two sterling-silver ones will be available on Sept. 1.

title: Garden Guide: New York City
description: The revised edition of Nancy Berner and Susan Lowrys Garden Guide: New York City (W. W. Norton; $22.95) has the same number of gardens as the original 2002 edition (100) but 25 of them are new.

title: Sales at Fred Flare and Michele Varian
description: Fred Flare, a clothing, gift and accessories boutique in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is discounting a selection of electronics, in the store and online, through Aug. 31 (the Keepsake USB Turntable, above, originally $165, is $149; the Crosley USB tech turntable, above right, regularly $150, is $129; the Lego digital camera, originally $102, is $75); 131 Meserole Avenue (Leonard Street), Brooklyn, (718) 349-1257 or fredflare.com.

description: It has been 25 years since Paulo Mendes da Rocha, a Brazilian architect, designed the PMR outdoor chaise.

description: Boo Davis, a Seattle-based quilter, uses traditional techniques to create designs that feature skulls or a devil-horns hand sign.

title: A Purple Martin Birdhouse Tour
description: The swallows depend on humans for their housing, which is designed to attract.

title: Boo Davis, Alt-Quilter
description: Boo Davis likes to say that she makes quilts just like your metal-loving, half-blind grandma would. An Ozzy Osbourne, Metallica and all-around thrash-metal fan from way back, Ms. Davis, 36, became an alt-craft darling by using traditional quilting techniques to create head-banging designs featuring skulls or a devil horns hand sign, under the label Quiltsryche. After a flurry of press in Seattle, her hometown, and in magazines like ReadyMade and Bust, she got a book deal. Dare to Be Square Quilting, published this month by Potter Craft ($21.99), is the result. Eagerly rifling its pages for patterns like God Bless the Children of the Beast  the title of a Motley Crue classic that Ms. Davis built a quilt around  this reporter found instead a fairly tame handful of designs. Theres a fine skull, to be sure, but also an owl, a deer head and a clock face, among other patterns that skew more cute than evil, to borrow a phrase from Ms. Davis. Its a sound quilting book, and readers will learn from it, but they may miss her subversive side.

title: Birdhouses Designed for Repeat Visitors
description: AFTER a long day at work, Chuck Abare, 63, a computer designer, likes to sit on the porch of his two-story ranch house on the outskirts of Huntsville, Ala., drink a gin and tonic, and watch the antics of the purple martins winging around his backyard.

title: Down the Aisle With the Help of Pocket Wedding Planners
description: Wedding planners are great for couples who have the money to hire a professional.

title: A Home on a Slope, With Floors to Match
description: CERNIN, Czech Republic

title: This Teenage Girl Uses Botox. No, Shes Not Alone.
description: LAST month, Charice Pempengco, the petite Filipino teenager whose knockout voice has wowed Oprah and millions worldwide, caused a stir of another kind.

title: Beauty Spots
description: SHADOW ME, BABY American women love eye makeup: sales hit $1.08 billion in 2009, up 38 percent from 2004, versus an 11 percent increase in the overall color cosmetics market, to $2.52 billion, according to a new report from Mintel. Just in time for Este Lauder, which is releasing the new 48-shade Pure Color EyeShadow line this month.

title: Quick Change in Strategy for a Bookseller
description: In the movie Youve Got Mail, Tom Hanks played the aggressive big-box retailer Joe Fox driving the little bookshop owner played by Meg Ryan out of business.

title: Officer Sues to Block His Discharge Under Gay Ban
description: In early 2008, just eight days before he was to deploy in support of the war in Afghanistan, Lt. Col. Victor Fehrenbach, a decorated Air Force flight officer, was told he was under investigation on charges of sexually assaulting a civilian and of violating the militarys ban on homosexuality.

title: Missing Buttons in Outlook
description: Q. I just upgraded to Outlook 2007 and there is no Send button on my e-mail toolbar. What do I do?

title: Fantasy Football: The Flexible Draft Strategy
description: Jason and Justin Sablich, The Timess in-house fantasy football experts, are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season and are now on Twitter.

title: Its Hard to Figure Out the Coaching Pioneers
description: Baseball is a game of statistics based on years of meticulous record-keeping. But one area of the game that is often overlooked is information on coaches.

title: In State Primary, Few Clues About Voter Attitudes
description: NEW HAVEN  With each state primary being scrutinized for signs of what is to come nationally in November, Connecticut voters threw off few cues Tuesday night. Jobs? Yes, voters said. Anger? Yes. But throw out the status quo? Hardly.

title: Georgia Congressman No Fan of Palin Endorsements
description: It seems fair to say that Representative Jack Kingston, a Georgia Republican, didnt appreciate that Sarah Palin inserted herself into the G.O.P.s gubernatorial primary in his state.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. JetBlues Steven Slater flees job site via inflatable slide. Disgruntled postal worker meets Nanny McPhee.

title: The Caucus With Richard Blumenthal
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Democrat Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut's attorney general and a candidate for the open Senate seat.

title: The Caucus With Linda McMahon
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Linda McMahon, a Republican candidate for the open Senate in Connecticut.

title: Britain: Antiterror Commercial Banned
description: Britains advertising watchdog has banned an antiterrorism commercial that urged radio listeners to watch out for people who keep their curtains drawn, keep away from their neighbors and pay with cash instead of debit or credit cards, behavior that senior police officers said could potentially be linked to terrorist activities. The Advertising Standards Agency, an industry-appointed body, said it made the ruling after concluding that law-abiding people with similar habits could be offended. The advertisement, paid for by the Association of Chief Police Officers, featured a narrator saying: The man at the end of the street doesnt talk to his neighbors much because he likes to keep to himself. He pays with cash because he doesnt have a bank card, and he keeps his curtains closed because his house is on a bus route. The narrator concluded, If you suspect it, report it.

title: Fund Managers Face a Conflict
description: It stands to reason that the more money flowing to a particular investment strategy, the more likely returns will diminish. By logical extension, fund managers should therefore occasionally say no to new cash to keep from hurting performance. But in the money business, thats easier said than done, especially when considering the growing number of alternative asset managers that are publicly traded.

title: The Caucus With Joe Sestak
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Representative Joe Sestak, the Democrats' candidate for the open Senate seat in Pennsylvania.

title: Chinas Economy, While Still Surging, Begins Showing Signs of Moderation
description: HONG KONG  In the latest signs that the Chinese economy is beginning to cool after setting a torrid pace in the first half of this year, several government indicators slowed slightly last month, Beijing announced on Wednesday.

title: Lebanon: Tribunal Turns to Hezbollah
description: The international tribunal investigating the 2005 killing of a former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, requested Wednesday that Hezbollah turn over evidence that the militant group says implicates Israel in the assassination. On Monday, Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollahs leader, presented what he said were videotaped confessions, maps and previously unreleased Israeli spy videos that he said pointed to Israel as the culprit in Mr. Hariris killing. Mr. Nasrallah has said in earlier speeches that the tribunal was planning to indict Hezbollah members in the killing, and he has accused the tribunal of distorting its findings to suit a political agenda.

title: Is Shredding Over? Not So Fast
description: AT a glance there is not much glamour in a coat or T-shirt that seems to have been run through a Cuisinart. But to Joie Reinstein, that sort of diced and shredded look, which she first glimpsed two years ago in a Rodarte show, represented the tatty quintessence of chic. The collection featured those crazy clothes with holes in them, she recalled. When it was released on the runway, it felt different from everything else.

title: Antibiotic-Resistant Bacteria Moving From South Asia to U.S.
description: A dangerous new mutation that makes some bacteria resistant to almost all antibiotics has become increasingly common in India and Pakistan and is being found in patients in Britain and the United States who got medical care in those countries, according to new studies.

title: Celebrating Scandal
description: THE crisp invitation, edged in a striped border and lettered in Art Deco capitals, arrived on a sultry summer afternoon. Dawn Davis, an editor at HarperCollins, was beckoning literary hedonists to a Bolter party, to celebrate the scandalous life of Idina Sackville  the aristocrat who shocked Britain in 1919 with her divorce from the most eligible bachelor of her generation, and then decamped to Kenya, leaving her two toddler sons behind. She went on to marry and divorce four other men (earning her the nickname the Bolter), while cavorting with countless others.

title: Chinese Hospitals Are Battlegrounds of Discontent
description: SHENYANG, China  Forget the calls by many Chinese patients for more honest, better-qualified doctors. What this citys 27 public hospitals really needed, officials decided last month, was police officers.

title: First in a Decade: A Living Novelist on Times Cover
description: The new cover of Time Magazine, on sale Friday, will feature Jonathan Franzen on the cover, the first time in 10 years that a living American novelist has been on the cover since Stephen King, in 2000.

title: Northeast Heat: The Harwood Interviews
description: 9:48 p.m. | Updated John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC caught up with candidates in some of the regions most hotly contested Senate races. He asks Linda McMahon, the Republican nominee and former wrestling mogul, if her original support of the bailout would be a kick in the groin to Connecticut tax payers and draws out disagreements with President Obama of her Democratic opponent, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal. In Pennsylvania, Mr. Harwood grills Representative Joe Sestak, a Democrat, about whether Medicare and Social Security must face cuts, while his Republican opponent, former Representative Pat Toomey, discusses why he was against the bank bailouts during the financial crisis.

title: The Age of Austerity Challenges Stonehenge
description: STONEHENGE, England  The prehistoric monument of Stonehenge stands tall in the British countryside as one of the last remnants of the Neolithic Age. Recently it has also become the latest symbol of another era: the new fiscal austerity.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,207 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

description: THE marketers and image-makers of Madison Avenue are asking each other, What would you do if you were JetBlue?

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Net Neutrality
description: On this weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Brian Stelter, a Times media reporter, drops by to chat about Internet access regulation with J.D. Biersdorfer and Bettina Edelstein. The so-called net neutrality plan of Google and Verizon would exempt wireless and some other online services from rules for maintaining open access to the Internet, and Mr. Stelter says that while the two companies appear to be staking out their ground now, other wireless carriers and media companies are watching and waiting as the Federal Communications Commission looks at ways of regulating broadband.

title: Judges Reprise Testimony in Third Trial on Threats
description: Once again, one after another, three celebrated federal appeals judges from Chicago slid into the low seat just to the right of their usual, estimable perches.

title: Antonio Pettigrew, Sprinter Who Doped, Dies at 42
description: Antonio Pettigrew, who gave up his 2000 Olympic sprint-relay gold medal after admitting to doping, was found dead Tuesday in his car near his North Carolina home. Pettigrew, an assistant track coach at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill for the past four seasons, was 42.

title: ING Group Posts a Profit in the Wake of a Bailout
description: ING Group, the financial services company based in the Netherlands, said Wednesday that its net profit for the second quarter climbed to 1.09 billion euros, about $1.4 billion, more than 15 times the amount a year ago.

title: Opposing Campaigns, With One Unlikely Link
description: ALBANY  One candidate for governor, Carl Paladino, is a staunch conservative and a self-styled Tea Party activist who is mounting a serious challenge for the Republican nomination.

title: Farmers Lean to Truce on Animals Close Quarters
description: WEST MANSFIELD, Ohio  Concessions by farmers in this state to sharply restrict the close confinement of hens, hogs and veal calves are the latest sign that so-called factory farming  a staple of modern agriculture that is seen by critics as inhumane and a threat to the environment and health  is on the verge of significant change.

title: For Fed, the Choices Get Harder
description: WASHINGTON

title: The First Wave of Weary Aides Heads for the Exits
description: WASHINGTON  Linda Douglass slept nearly 12 hours the day after she left her job as a communications aide at the White House. And the day after that and the day after that. It took two weeks until she finally felt rested.

title: Odds Defied? Malloy Knows the Territory
description: As a child, Dannel P. Malloy was not given much of a chance. I was diagnosed as mentally retarded as late as the fourth grade, he recalled. His mother, he added, would not accept that.

title: Cousin Claudine Has New Stretch Bracelets
description: COUSIN CLAUDINE is making a new version of its popular stack of stretch bracelets, composed of multiple rows of beads. The brown beads look like wood but are dyed horn, interspersed with gold rings, beads and crystal balls (below, $145).

description: Marc Hauser, a Harvard academic who gained prominence with the publication of a book on the origin of morality, has gone on leave after an investigation by the university into problems with his research.

title: Anything to Declare? Well, Lets Start With ...
description: CITING exotic travel destinations as a design inspiration is about as original as pinning a collection on The Eyes of Laura Mars or anything starring Tilda Swinton. But Anna Sui has a gift for mining fashion gold from her trips around the world, which makes her an ideal guest for a show like Man Shops Globe, the Sundance Channel series that follows Keith Johnson, the globe-trotting buyer at large for Anthropologie.

title: Debts Rise, and Go Unpaid, as Bust Erodes Home Equity
description: PHOENIX  During the great housing boom, homeowners nationwide borrowed a trillion dollars from banks, using the soaring value of their houses as security. Now the money has been spent and struggling borrowers are unable or unwilling to pay it back.

title: A Fortissimo First for the Philharmonic
description: Ever since the New York Philharmonic was founded in 1842, the orchestras brass section  horn, trumpet, trombone, bass trombone, tuba  had been a mans world. Then Amanda Davidson auditioned. A graduate of the Juilliard School with a passion for Mahler, Brahms and ESPN, Mrs. Davidson, 28, became the brass sections first female member last September, having previously been principal trombonist of the San Antonio Symphony. (She competed for the Philharmonic job with Mark Davidson, 27, whom she was dating and later married.) Her title is associate principal trombone, an instrument with which she is familiar. She has been playing it since she was 6.

description: A POP-UP museum and store have opened in Harlem to celebrate basketball and sneaker heritage, as part of the World Basketball Festival hosted by Nike, Jordan and Converse. The store is selling T-shirts highlighting the national basketball teams competing in exhibition games (left, $30 off the rack, $35 customized).

description: It was a dramatic but fitting start to an evening that brimmed with political defiance. About 5:45 p.m. Wednesday, as guests began strolling into the Plaza Hotel to celebrate Representative Charles B. Rangels 80th birthday, former Mayor David N. Dinkins turned to confront a heckler.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Worsening insurgent violence in many parts of the country is raising concern about Afghanistans ability to hold a fair parliamentary election in little more than a month, a crucial test of President Hamid Karzais ability to deliver security and a legitimate government.

description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  After every morning practice, Jets Coach Rex Ryan, usually wearing green, strides into a small room in the Carl Chugger Davis Building near the prim fields and takes a spot behind a lectern with a State University of New York Cortland seal on the front.

title: Tibetan Writers Intellectual Journey Leads to Trial

title: Safety Board Says All Children on Flights Should Be in Seats
description: Airlines should no longer allow children under the age of 2 to fly in the laps of adults, according to a recommendation by the National Transportation Safety Board sent to the Federal Aviation Administration on Wednesday. The group urged the F.A.A. to require that every occupant of an airplane, regardless of age, have a seat on all flights  commercial, charter and private planes. In the letter, the board cited several accidents in which young travelers were injured or killed. While the N.T.S.B. says children under the age of 2 should be afforded the same level of protection as all other persons, the F.A.A. has rejected the recommendation several times, saying that parents unable to afford tickets for their young children would opt to drive rather than fly, resulting in more highway fatalities.

title: Union Official to Leave 2 Posts

When she took that federations helm in 2005, she became the highest-ranking woman in organized labors history. She did not give reasons for retiring, but said she would work as a consultant to the union and toward promoting economic justice. She had campaigned to succeed Andy Stern as the union president when he announced his retirement last April. She dropped her campaign when many S.E.I.U. leaders rallied behind Mary Kay Henry, a union executive vice president. Upon Ms. Henrys election in May, many union officials said it was only a matter of time before Ms. Burger stepped down.

title: Backlot Beauties
description: On a recent Friday morning, lit white by the California sun, Nigel Dare was sitting in his shop, fielding calls from a movie set. Is that a Japanese line? he asked the makeup artist on the other end. Never heard of it. But youll have it by Monday. Dare is the ultimate Hollywood candy man  a warm, personable guy who can procure Fria, an Italian makeup remover, if thats what you need, or Collyre Bleu (1) for the hungover actor with bloodshot eyes. Nigels Beauty Emporium, along with Naimies Beauty Center and Frends Beauty Supply, is perhaps the San Fernando Valleys best-kept secret: a treasure trove of rarefied cosmetics brands where Hollywood makeup artists go to keep the likes of Sandra Bullock, Megan Fox and George Clooney powdered and buffed. Here they can scour hundreds of global brands, including ones you dont see everywhere (Embryolisse (2), La Peau (3) ) and the Japanese lines much beloved by the pros (KohGenDo, Kanebo). Here they can ask for and get Kate (5), the ultrathin Kanebo eyeliner that is barely detectable on the eye. Or the French  and much stronger  version of Anthelios, the sunscreen by La Roche-Posay. Or, for that matter, Labello lip balm (4), from Germany. Frends is the granddaddy of the bunch: founded in 1940, it catered to makeup artists who were stuck on a set for 18 hours straight and running on empty. Today all three stores are about turnaround, finding products anywhere they can and even picking them up at a competitors if they have to  which, for the right client, they will.

title: Glass Half Empty
On Assignment: The Isle of Skye
description: My wife and I spent a lot of time driving on the Isle of Skye, off the west coast of Scotland, where I recently was reporting a story. That posed a few problems. First, Id never driven on the left side of the road. (Lets just say it took a few days for me to adjust.) Second, Skye is full of single-lane roads with Passing Places you end up playing a friendly little game with oncoming cars as to who will pull over. (Dont forget to wave as you pass by  its considered rude not to.) And then there was the livestock. Sheep, it turns out, will move when you honk (though we did hear stories of horned rams doing some damage upon seeing their reflection in car doors); cows are a bit more stubborn. But when youre surrounded by vistas as beautiful as those on Skye, you dont mind the occasional break in your journey.

title: Marriage in Thick and Thin
description: Continuing my slow march through responses to my gay marriage column, I want to take up two somewhat-related critiques of my argument for holding up lifelong heterosexual monogamy as a distinctive legal and cultural ideal: First, that this ideal is too essentialist, and second, that its too complicated. The too-essentialist critique has been raised by The American Prospects Adam Serwer, among others, who scoffs at my suggestion that theres anything distinctive about heterosexual relationships as heterosexual relationships: Every intimate relationship, he suggests, is distinct in its challenges and potential fruit,' and so theres no reason why heterosexual marriages as a category deserve to be singled out or idealized in any way. The too-complicated critique was raised by Matt Feeney, who writes (well, tweets) that if theres an Ockhams Razor/Parsimony standard for ideals,' then my marriage ideal doesnt meet it, because any marriage ideal strong enough to function qua ideal, as Ross uses the term, would have to be parsimonious enough to allow gay marriage.

Which brings up a second thing: Maybe its the good food, the open skies or the free-spirited students who call this city their campus, but the folks of Montreal are friendly. Ask someone for directions in the Mtro, part of the vast Underground City that stays toasty during the winter, and you may end up making drinks plans later. Thats not a bad thing, bien sr. With the citys music-charged night life, slaughterhouse-chic restaurants and post-industrial revival, it helps to have a guide.

title: The Pull of an Idyll as Years Pass By
description: I DISCOVERED the Datca Peninsula, in the southwestern corner of Turkey, purely by accident. This was in 2005. Id never been to Turkey and was trying to find a rental house somewhere  anywhere on any coast of the country  where my husband and I could spend the month of June. I was trying to finish writing a novel that took place above the Arctic Circle in midwinter, and a waterfront town in Turkey in the summer seemed about as far away as I could get from the setting of that book, as well as from the day-to-day distractions of my life in San Francisco. I envisioned a month of solid writing in a country where I knew no one and where the water and people were warm. So I typed the words Turkey, water, rental and cheap into a search engine.

title: When the Doctor Doesnt Look Like You
description: One night during my training, over dinner in the hospital cafeteria, a fellow resident and I had a discussion about the situation of one of our professors. Known for his blistering teaching sessions, this senior surgeon possessed the uncanny ability to sniff out lapses in memory or judgment among doctors-in-training. Early on in my internship, I showed up at one of his practice trauma resuscitations blissfully unprepared. I left an hour later with his booming and rapid-fire admonitions still ringing in my ears. You call yourself a doctor? he had thundered. This patient may just be a dummy, but you are killing her!

title: Letter: Bicycle Touring
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a six-day bike tour, I was delighted to read Four Corners, Two Wheels (Aug. 1). It seems that every bike tour The New York Times writes about is a pampered affair with participants crowing about the 25 miles they rode that day. How refreshing to read about a tour where you actually ride hard while enjoying the scenery. Although my bike tour was not as fancy as this one (we camped at schools and ate burritos prepared by community groups raising money for a trip to Washington, D.C.) nor as remote (much sharing of roads with semis), nothing beats riding a hard 85-plus day, getting to a small town, finding a beer, complaining about the ride and the weather, then starting all over the next day.

The drama, which currently stars Eddie Izzard, Dennis Haysbert, Afton C. Williamson and Richard Thomas, is the longest running play of the 2009-2010 season. Productions are planned for next year in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Milwaukee, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C. There are also plans for the play to be featured in London.

title: Stirrings of a Stick Shift Crusade
description: The manual transmission  an object of love and affection among many drivers, and an example of pass automotive technology to many more  is getting some serious props from Eddie Alterman, the editor of Car and Driver.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Lenny & Johns
description: The pizza shop, on Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, is an area favorite, and has been operating since 1969.

title: Think Globally, Compromise Locally
description: Bill McKibben, whose 1989 book, The End of Nature, helped coalesce and spread worry about climate change, views the national environmental groups strategy of winning support for energy and climate legislation by compromising with industry as a complete failure. The result: total defeat, no moral victories, he wrote at the environmental news site Grist, speaking of the Senates inaction on climate legislation.

title: Theater Listings: Aug. 13  19
description: Theater

title: Look Around. Thats Loyalty.
description: THERE doesnt seem to be anything special about the wood-framed photographs of Flatbush Avenue from 1946 hanging on the walls of Lenny & Johns Pizza, or the floor-to-ceiling stack of pizza boxes. The clear plastic containers of garlic, red pepper and oregano look the same as the ones at the pizzeria down the street, or across town. A slice costs $2, a pie $13 (except on Tuesdays, when its on special for $8).

title: Eat an Apple (Doctors Orders)
description: The farm stand is becoming the new apothecary, dispensing apples  not to mention artichokes, asparagus and arugula  to fill a novel kind of prescription.

title: The Tech Jam: Anything Can Happen, and Usually Does
description: ON most Sunday nights Issue Project Room  a dark, narrow performance space less than a block from the ever-festering Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn  is occupied by a cabal of tinkerers. Crates of equipment in tow, they snake cables across the floor, joining laptops, projectors, video-game consoles, synthesizers and other devices into a throbbing, multimedia web.

title: Mariah Carey and Missy Elliott at Singapore Grand Prix
description: As I reported last year from Singapore, Beyonce and Gwen Stefani of No Doubt  oh, and lets not forget ZZ Top  played at the F1 Rocks concert at the Singapore Grand Prix. The only problems were that the walk was a little far from the circuit to the stage, and the hours of the performances overlapped so that you had to choose between the racing and the music.

title: The Caucus With Tom Perriello
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Representative Tom Perriello, Democrat of Virginia, about his campaign to be re-elected for the state's 5th Congressional District.

title: Taxes No Longer So Certain
description: Death may still be certain, but taxes have never been less so.

title: Films From Another Dimension
description: A look at some of the offerings in Film Forums Classic 3-D series.

title: It Leaps (Gasp!) Off the Screen
description: DOES 3-D represent the future of the movies?

title: Look Around. Thats Loyalty.
description: There doesnt seem to be anything special about the wood-framed photographs of Flatbush Avenue from 1946 hanging on the walls of Lenny & Johns Pizza, or the floor-to-ceiling stack of pizza boxes. The clear plastic containers of garlic, red pepper and oregano look the same as the ones at the pizzeria down the street, or across town. A slice costs $2, a pie $13 (except on Tuesdays, when its on special for $8).

title: A Playground for the Arts, With Island Breezes
description: What kind of culture develops on an island? It is a place that requires a special effort to visit and a special effort to leave. It can keep people out or corral them in. It might serve as an escape, or (like Alcatraz) as a prison. It incubates and isolates. And its culture might become both ingrown and wildly experimental, maybe a bit like Manhattans.

title: Culture on Governors Island
description: A look at some of the cultural events on the island.

title: Ristretto | Cool Beans
description: New York is still deep in iced-coffee season, and while home methods like cold brew and Japanese iced coffee process are becoming more familiar, most of the discussion seems to be about techniques and gadgets instead of what coffees taste best when served on the rocks.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gansu Province and Elsewhere
description: It is nothing new to observe that sometimes the most affecting photos of hugely scaled disasters are those that focus on individuals. That said, there may be few situations even on an intimate scale that dont leave viewers thinking, As awful as the moment is, Ive seen this depicted before. The photograph leading todays report, of a man carrying his nieces coffin, by the Color China Photo agency, may be an exception.

title: Malebo, and Fishes, at Last
description: Wednesday, Aug. 11

title: The Caucus with Robert Hurt
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Robert Hurt, a state senator and the Republican candidate in the race for Virginia's 5th Congressional District.

title: Gansevoort 69 Closes Permanently
description: What was originally to be a temporary closing of Gansevoort 69 (formerly Florent) last month is now permanent.

title: 264 Japanese Carvings, Revealing Family History
description: The British ceramicist Edmund de Waal will promote his memoir, The Hare With Amber Eyes: A Familys Century of Art and Loss (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), during a two-week tour of the United States this fall. But he will be able to bring along only a few of his favorite pocket talismans: Japanese carvings called netsuke, the size of walnuts, depicting animals, fruit, peasants, samurai and erotica.

title: Galaxies of Wire, Canvas and Velvety Soot
description: One of the thrills of watching Mad Men is seeing the early 1960s as an alternating current of oppression and optimism: the cold war, the space race, the escalation of the Vietnam War, the sexual revolution. The art of Lee Bontecou, as its presented in a one-room show at the Museum of Modern Art, delivers a similar jolt.

title: Johan Santana: A Pleasant On-Field Distraction
description: For at least one game, questions about how the Mets would close games without their star closer didnt have to be answered.

title: What, Federer Worry?
description: TORONTO - On Thursday afternoon, Roger Federer did not sound, look or act like a player concerned with his age (29, as of last Sunday), or his ranking (No. 3 since Wimbledon, for the first time since late 2003).

title: Town House Surrounding Jones Wood Garden for Sale
description: THE rumble and bustle of New York City can leave even the staunchest city supporter aching for a reprieve, especially in the dense air of August. For a lucky few, the reprieve can be found in a large shared private garden, carved into the middle of a city block, invisible from the sidewalk and accessible only to people who live in the surrounding buildings.

title: Caucus Video: A Look at Virginias 5th District Race
description: One of the most competitive races for a House seat this fall is expected to be in Virginias 5th Congressional District. John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC interviewed the two candidates battling it out: Representative Tom Perriello, the Democrat incumbent, and Robert Hurt, a Republican state senator.

title: The Impresario of Islam
description: The Cairo-based music video channel 4Shbab combines the aesthetics of western music programming with the morals of more devout Muslim channels.

title: When Life in Cuba Was Elegant and Sweet
description: The glamorous, slightly risqu picture many of us have of prerevolutionary Cuba comes from the movies or the theater. Havana is the racy, romantic getaway where the prim and proper Sarah Brown begins to fall for the raffish charms of the high-rolling gambler Sky Masterson in Guys and Dolls. Havana is also where Michael Corleone in The Godfather: Part II goes to meet fellow mobsters to divvy up control of the lucrative casino business. Its the Paris of the Caribbean, the Monte Carlo of the Americas, a place where, in the words of The Godfather character Hyman Roth, the hotels were bigger and swankier than any of the rug joints weve put in Vegas, where American tourists could down exotic drinks, take in live sex shows and carouse in one of the greatest party towns on earth.

title: The Sugar King of Havana
description: Introduction

title: This Girl Has a Lot of Baggage, and He Must Shoulder the Load
description: There are some movies about youth that just make you feel old, even if you arent. Scott Pilgrim vs. the World, based on a series of sprightly graphic novels by Bryan Lee OMalley, has the opposite effect. Its speedy, funny, happy-sad spirit is so infectious that the movie makes you feel at home in its world even if the landscape is, at first glance, unfamiliar.

title: Money Money Money Money
description: Video here.

title: Islams Answer to MTV
description: The Egyptian entrepreneur Ahmed Abu Haiba isnt having a good day. A Saudi columnist has accused him of corrupting the countrys youth. A music video he has been working on for months is behind schedule. He hasnt had time to prepare for his weekly talk show, an Islamo-Egyptian version of Dr. Phil. Worse, one of the programs financiers has become upset because there was to be a woman on the show  unchaste behavior, to some. Were driving along Sheik Zayed Road in the desert outside Cairo on a bright day as the radio plays Sami Yusuf, a saccharine-sweet Muslim pop star based in London. Abu Haiba theatrically throws his arms in the air to perform his frustration. At the age of 42 he is tubby and, as a sign of his deep faith, has a large zabiba  a dark smudge on his forehead born of rubbing his head repeatedly on a prayer mat. And yet he is not a conventional man and certainly not a conventional Muslim. Today he looks more like a hip-hop mogul, with a black knit golf cap on backward and a suit of all black. And a pink tie.

title: The Banks Behind G.M.s $5 Billion Loan
description: As General Motors continues in its march toward an initial public offering, perhaps filing for one as soon as Friday, the automaker has taken big steps to bolster its financial health as much as possible.

title: So Where Exactly Is Whistling Straits?
description: There is no question that this years P.G.A. Championship is located at Whistling Straits. But where Whistling Straits is located is a more complicated matter.

title: A Return to Video Is Moving
description: With her latest show of new work at the Marian Goodman Gallery, the Dutch artist Rineke Dijkstra takes up the video camera for the first time in a dozen years, building on an early triumph that seemed destined to be an isolated event.

title: Vietnamese Voices Against a Whir of War
description: In slumberous mid-August thousands of visitors fidget and drift through the Museum of Modern Art, finding almost everything worth photographing and almost nothing worth more than a point-and-shoot glance. But in one gallery  basically a wide glorified corridor  people tend to stop, focus, even settle down in front of a three-channel video by the Vietnamese-American artist Dinh Q. Le projected across a long wall.

title: Dispatch | Paris in August Redux
description: Every August, Parisians heed the call of la plage, leaving their city to the tourists and tumbleweeds. Even though some of the biggest restaurants and galleries, and most petit boulangeries and boutiques, may be closed, theres plenty left to do. T first tackled the problem last year; a few fresh options for this year are after the jump.

title: Viewing a Vegas Casino Show by Scuba
description: No matter what youve encountered while scuba diving, chances are youve never seen anything as dramatic as a firsthand view of 14 underwater stagehands navigating 630 cues for a Las Vegas show with synchronized swimmers.

description: A photographic tour of Brooklyn club buildings.

title: Switzerland Takes Loss in Vain Attempt to Keep the Franc in Check and Aid Exports
description: ZURICH  While the rest of Europe struggles to rein in government debt, there is no talk of forced austerity in prudent Switzerland. Instead, the country is looking forward to growth of at least 2.5 percent this year, thanks to booming exports.

title: The Two Churchills
description: Winston Churchill is remembered for leading Britain through her finest hour  but what if he also led the country through her most shameful one? What if, in addition to rousing a nation to save the world from the Nazis, he fought for a raw white supremacy and a concentration camp network of his own? This question burns through Richard Toyes superb, unsettling new history, Churchills Empire  and is even seeping into the Oval Office.

title: Churchills Empire
description: Prologue

title: A Matriarch in Melbourne and Her Band of Warped Partners in Crime
description: With a bleached-blond mane, a glittering blue-eyed stare and a ferocious smile, Smurf Cody (Jacki Weaver) is the mama lion to a criminal brood of armed robbers and drug dealers in the mostly terrific Australian gangster film Animal Kingdom. The opening images of the movie, the directorial and screenwriting debut of David Michd, are statues and drawings of lions. Although the Codys live in bland-looking suburban Melbourne, it might as well be the jungle, for all they care about law and order.

description: 4:42 p.m. | Updated Noting the $19.90 annual subscription fee that comes with WaveSecure app, now owned by McAfee.

title: Setbacks in Diet Pill Study
description: One of the great hopes for weight-loss drugs is that they will be more than just cosmetic, that they will also reduce the risk of serious health conditions associated with obesity, like diabetes and heart disease.

title: Social Clubs, Long Gone, Left Their Meeting Places Behind
description: THE five-borough consolidation of 1898 was a bitter pill for many in Brooklyn, who correctly foresaw the eclipse of their influential city by the powerhouse of Manhattan. Few things document that change as well as the collapsed network of mens social clubs in Brooklyn, at least four of whose clubhouses survive.
