title: Temperamental Opposites Attract Attention
description: Both the choreographers sharing the Joyce Theaters second program this week are idiosyncratic, original, theatrically striking. On at least one level, though, they seem temperamental opposites. To Kate Weare you want to say: Lighten up! Cant you ever see the humor of a situation? Conversely, youre tempted to ask Monica Bill Barnes, Arent you ever serious about anything? And so they make an interestingly provocative double bill.

title: Guitarist of Broad Range, With Lots of Friends
description: Deference and dexterity are steadfastly correlated for the guitarist Lee Ritenour. Over the course of a 35-year solo career, he has personified a carefree sort of prowess, making no secret of his enthusiasms: slinky funk, Brazilian pop, the softer side of hard bop. Because of his breezy sincerity, hes the rare guitar-geek hero seemingly free of an outsize ego, though that impression may also stem from his warmly ingratiating music, which has often been filed under the category of smooth jazz.

title: Hot Spots: Lockboxes and Audio Books
description: This years dramatic, erratic midterms have ads to match. And theyre coming out with increasing frequency as the incumbents go home to campaign and the races solidify after primaries. Heres what weve been watching this week:

title: Manly Gore and Brawn, Not Tragedy or Poetry
description: On the very weekend that his younger sister Julia undertakes a spiritual and culinary quest around the globe in Eat Pray Love, Eric Roberts, also well within his actorly comfort zone, plays an especially despicable villain in The Expendables, the new film by Sylvester Stallone. Mr. Roberts is James Munroe, a renegade C.I.A. guy holding the strings on a Latin American puppet dictator named Garza (David Zayas), whose regime is so awful that his own daughter, Sandra (Giselle Iti), has turned against him. Munroe dismisses this family drama in what strikes me as a remarkably versatile and useful two-word phrase: Bad Shakespeare.

title: Paralysis at the Fed
description: Ten years ago, one of Americas leading economists delivered a stinging critique of the Bank of Japan, Japans equivalent of the Federal Reserve, titled Japanese Monetary Policy: A Case of Self-Induced Paralysis? With only a few changes in wording, the critique applies to the Fed today.

title: Is the Husband Going to Be a Problem?
description: I FIRST met Brendon at a student watering hole called the Dutch Goose. The name  at least the part about going halves-ies  would prove prophetic, as we turned out to be equals in so many ways. We were both Ph.D. students in the humanities: I wooed him with Shakespeare quotations, and he took my breath away with his readings of ancient Greek. It was true geek love.

title: Bloggingheads: Eat, Write, Love
description: Elizabeth Gilbert, left, author of "Eat, Pray, Love," and Susan Orlean of The New Yorker discuss the pros and cons of being a female writer.

title: A Long, Hot Summer in Mississippi That Still Burns
description: Neshoba: The Price of Freedom, a documentary by Micki Dickoff and Tony Pagano, focuses on one of the most notorious and terrible incidents of the 1960s and on its long aftermath.

title: Patti Labelle Will Join the Cast of Fela! in September
description: The Broadway musical Fela! may be closing in January, but it is going out in style. The Grammy winner Patti LaBelle is planning to join the cast at the Eugene ONeill Theater on Sept. 14 as Felas mother, Funmilayo Anikulapo-Kuti, a spokesman for the show said on Thursday. After seeing the show, I was struck by the choreography and work of Bill T. Jones, and the passion and joy that overflows from the stage, Ms. LaBelle said in a news release. Fela Kuti, a musical superstar in his native Nigeria, used his popularity to oppose the repressive military dictatorship there during the 1970s and 80s. The musical is set in the nightclub where Fela (played alternately by Sahr Ngaujah and Kevin Mambo) regularly performed his pioneering Afrobeat music. Ms. LaBelle reunited last year with the members of the group Labelle, Sarah Dash and Nona Hendryx for an album, Back to Now. But she has also been taking care of business. She has written five books, including three cookbooks, and sells her own collection of wigs and a line of signature sauces and marinades called  what else?  Lady Marmalade.

title: Footnote
description: David Mamets play Race has announced it will close its Broadway run on Aug. 21 after its 320th performance. The drama, now starring Eddie Izzard, Dennis Haysbert, Afton C. Williamson and Richard Thomas, will also be traveling across the country next year to San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Milwaukee, Philadelphia and Washington.

title: Talent Puts NBC on Top
description: Four YouTube acts advanced to the semifinals on Americas Got Talent on Wednesday as that NBC reality show topped the ratings in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates, 10.5 million viewers tuned in to the shows weekly results episode at 9 p.m., helping to lift NBC to No. 1 for the night over all. CBS, in second place, won both the 8 and 10 p.m. hours. CBSs Big Brother drew 7 million viewers at 8, finishing ahead of both NBCs Minute to Win It (6.4 million) in the time slot and the first half of Foxs So You Think You Can Dance, which averaged 6.1 million viewers from 8 to 10. ABC lagged well behind its network competitors to finish in fourth place for the night, averaging 3.8 million viewers from 8 to 10 for repeats of the networks comedy lineup, followed by a low-rated rerun of Castle at 10 (3.9 million).

title: Love, Travel, Sell
description: MOST husbands call their wives to ask what cut of steak to bring home from the grocery store. Elizabeth Gilberts husband rang her from Vietnam and asked, Do I have permission to buy a 7,000-pound marble Buddha?

title: Why Imitation Is the Sincerest Form of Fashion
description: NEW YORK CITY is one of the worlds great centers of fashion. So its not surprising that New Yorks senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, would take an interest in fashion designers. Last week he introduced legislation that would rewrite copyright law to cover their designs. But his bill could hurt the fashion industry more than it would help, and raise consumer prices along the way.

title: When the Devil on Your Shoulder Wins
description: For 20 years as a flight attendant with one airline or another, Steven Slater lived with it.

title: Pakistans President Stays Away From Devastated Region
description: Updated | Friday | 1:53 p.m. As Pakistanis continue to post video on the Internet documenting the terrible devastation caused by floods in the countrys northwest, their president, Asif Ali Zardari, was filmed on an inspection tour of flood defenses in the countrys southern Sindh Province on Thursday.

title: Moscow Express
description: If Russias Tourism Ministry keeps a blacklist of undesirables, Martin Cruz Smith has to be near the top, underlined and starred. Though the Soviet Union that once banned Smiths groundbreaking 1981 novel, Gorky Park, no longer exists, 29 years later the land he depicts in his seventh Russian mystery, Three Stations, looks no more inviting. While the enemies once were K.G.B. agents, Soviet corruption and American capitalists, now theyre power-hungry bureaucrats, Russian corruption and Russian capitalists  those trading in public utilities, as well as those trading in human flesh. At times its even less inviting than the old police state. You know whats tragic about all the money floating around? one character says. A bottle of vodka used to cost 10 rubles, just the right sum for three people to share.

title: New Android O.S. and Features
description: Google released Android 2.2, the next iteration of its phone operating system that is chockablock with new features. Unfortunately, it is being introduced only to the HTC Evo and the original Droid at the moment, but it also comes already installed on the new Droid 2, which is available in stores on Thursday.

title: AMC Picks Up New Crime Drama
description: The cable network AMC, home to Mad Men and Breaking Bad, is hoping to continue its hot streak with a new original series. The untitled shows pilot  originally called The Killing  is by the writer and executive producer Veena Sud, a producer and writer for Cold Case on CBS. This new crime drama is based on a popular Danish television series, Forbrydelsen. The American version, produced by Fox Television Studios, is set in Seattle and follows the investigation of a murdered girl. Production is scheduled to begin this fall in Vancouver with a premiere in 2011. Mireille Enos, who plays a polygamist wife with big hair on HBOs Big Love, stars as the lead homicide detective. The cast also includes Billy Campbell, Michelle Forbes, Joel Kinnaman and Brent Sexton.

title: A World Loses Balance, and an Allegory Appears
description: Stolid and humorless, larded with windy speeches about keeping Earths balance and other virtuous platitudes, Tales From Earthsea, a Japanese animated adaptation of Ursula K. Le Guins Earthsea fantasy novels, feels a little like a science-fiction Sunday school pageant. If this starchy, nearly two-hour allegory about human hubris bluntly addresses a historical moment when global warming threatens the planet and pollution is fouling the seas, its chilly, formal tone keeps you at an emotional distance.

title: New iPhone O.S. Upgrade Provides Better Security
description: Android wasnt the only operating system with an update Thursday.

title: And Work of Art Winner Is
description: Technically, you have an amazing hand, but it was your heart that really moved us tonight. Those words, spoken by the gallery owner Bill Powers, are not ones youd be likely to hear uttered in the real art world without a thick protective coating of irony. But Work of Art, the Bravo reality show whose first season came to a close Wednesday night, never exactly operated in the real art world. After 13 other aspiring art stars were dispatched with the line Your work of art didnt work for us, Abdi Farah, 22, a smiling, sideways-cap-wearing painter and sculptor and probably the shows nicest guy, won the grand prize of $100,000 and an exhibition of his work at the Brooklyn Museum, along with the accolades of Mr. Powers and the shows other judges. (In true nice-guy fashion Mr. Farah said he would give his cash winnings to his mother.) The 10-episode show, partly produced by Sarah Jessica Parker, drew a little more than a million viewers at its height  not in the league of Bravos Top Chef but not bad for a start-up. The network has not announced whether the show will be picked up for a second season.

title: Glass Menagerie Revival Is Moving to Los Angeles
description: The Wingfield family is taking its collection of glass animals and heading west. The acclaimed production of Tennessee Williamss Glass Menagerie, which started last season at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven and then moved to the Roundabout in New York, is opening at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles next month. Three members of the original cast  Judith Ivey as Amanda, Patch Darragh as Tom, and Keira Keeley as Laura  will be appearing in the production. Ben McKenzie is joining the cast as Jim OConnor, the Gentleman Caller. This fresh interpretation is directed by Gordon Edelstein.

title: Win Wars? Todays Generals Must Also Politick and Do P.R.
description: WASHINGTON  After nine years of fighting in the deserts and mountains of the Middle East, the military has concluded that the traditional, hard-earned combat skills that allowed generations of muddy boots commanders to protect American interests around the world simply are not enough to assure victory in todays wars  or career advancement through the top ranks of the armed forces.

title: Dell Accused of Concealing Evidence in PC Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Dell has been accused of withholding evidence, including e-mails among its top executives, in a lawsuit over faulty computers it sold to businesses, according to a filing made Thursday.

title: After 34 Years and Many Diets, Cathy Comic Strip to End
description: Readers who have been following the exploits of the slightly overweight and somewhat insecure comic strip character Cathy for 34 years will soon find themselves going through withdrawal. Cathy Guisewite, the strips creator, announced on Wednesday that she is ending the popular cartoons run, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Guisewite, 59, said that the autobiographical strip has been the most astonishing form of therapy, but that her creative biological clock was ticking, and she wants to try something else  although isnt sure what. The urge to spend more time with her 18-year-old daughter and her parents was also a motivation, she said. Carried in about 700 newspapers, Cathy is syndicated by Universal Uclick. Although the cartoon Cathy, above, is often frustrated by her overly loving mother, in real life Ms. Guisewite credits her mother with first urging her to write and draw comics. The final strip is scheduled for Oct. 3, after the end of the swimsuit season.

description: Its more management on the fly at General Motors. Thats certainly the impression left by its chief executive switcheroo. Swapping Daniel F. Akerson for Edward E. Whitacre Jr. may be a better long-term solution. But clumsily announcing it on the eve of a potential initial public offering filing feeds into the notion the company isnt ready for prime time.

title: How the West Won Me
description: Some homes away from home, whether owned or rented, are extensions of peoples primary residence that allow them to carry on as usual in a refreshingly different location. Thus, chic, striving Manhattanites become chic, striving Hamptonites, and suburbanites enjoy flipping burgers at the lake or in the mountains instead of in their usual backyards. Other vacation homes, however, are so radically different that they become labs for experimenting with another way of life altogether. Our house in Dubois (DOO-boyz), Wyo., which is a small cowboy town southeast of Yellowstone National Park, falls into that category.

title: A Regular-Guy Approach to Entice Men to Shop for Jeans
description: MIKE ROWE, the star of Dirty Jobs on the Discovery Channel, has tackled some arduous tasks, among them shark repellent tester and septic tank cleaner. But now he confronts perhaps the dirtiest job of all: persuading shoppers to buy a new product when the economy appears to be weakening again.

title: Spare Times Listings
description: India Day Parade and Festival (Sunday) Lower Madison Avenue will be teeming with the sights, sounds and tastes of India on Sunday at the 30th India Day Parade and Festival, commemorating the 64th anniversary of India Independence Day. The fun begins at 11 a.m. with a street fair from 23rd to 26th Streets. The first of more than 300 performers from India and the New York area will take to the stage at 2 p.m., among them dancers from the local group Aatma Performing Arts, a two-year-old troupe of male and female dancers that will perform a fusion of contemporary, hip-hop, Bollywood and traditional Indian dance (shown above at last years celebration). The groups name comes from the Hindi word for soul, explained Amit Shah, its founder and president. But before the show starts, 40 floats, 5 marching bands and hundreds of marchers will step off at 1 p.m. at 38th Street for a procession down Madison Avenue. It is all presented by the Federation of Indian Associations, which is celebrating its 40th anniversary this year. (Anne Mancuso)

description: ECO-FLOWERS FOR KIDS

title: Optimist Me
description: One of the odder criticisms I get is from people accusing me of endorsing the Obama administrations very optimistic forecasts about unemployment. What makes this strange is that during the euphoria of spring-summer 2009, when everyone was saying that we were about to see a V-shaped recovery, I was  well, lets just look at The New Yorker from May 25, 2009:

title: Ambassador Leaves Iraq With Much Still Unsettled
description: BAGHDAD  Christopher R. Hill, the ambassador to Iraq charged with reshaping the American role here, on Thursday ended his 16-month tenure in an anxious, unsettled country, with a military withdrawal afoot but a key task not done: the formation of a government that will inherit the country.

title: Asylum Granted to Mexican Woman in Case Setting Standard on Domestic Abuse
description: The Obama administration has granted asylum to a Mexican woman who was sexually abused and severely battered by her common-law husband. The decision, in a closely watched case, clarifies the exacting standard that domestic abuse victims must meet to win asylum.

title: A Sendup of India Politics and News
description: What do you if youre a debt-ridden farmer about to lose your land? If youre the brothers Naatha (Omkar Das Manikpuri) and Budhia (Raghubir Yadav), you opt to take a politicians advice: one of you  Budhia chooses Naatha  will commit suicide, thus guaranteeing your family a government subsidy.

title: Keeping Score: Running the Races Through the Computer
description: Just under 50 games remain on the schedule for each major league team, and the playoff races are coming into focus. Through Wednesday, six teams (the Yankees, Tampa Bay, Chicago, Minnesota, Texas and Boston) in the American League and six teams (Atlanta, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, St. Louis, San Diego and San Francisco) in the National League were within four games of a playoff position.

title: Hiding in Plain Sight
description: The intense public and media attention to Judge Vaughn R. Walkers decision in the California same-sex marriage case led me to wonder how the media responded 40 years ago to another Federal District Court ruling  the decision that declared the Texas criminal abortion law unconstitutional, in a case called Roe v. Wade.

title: Tales of a Trashy Bachelorette
description: A slut is just a woman with the morals of a man, proclaims Angela (Karin Anna Cheung), and she should know. Young, promiscuous and proud of it, Angela snaps post-coital candids of her studs (to remind me where Ive been) and, in the rare periods when shes vertical, makes flash cards recording age, ethnicity and penile dimensions. Dont judge: every girl needs a hobby.

title: New G.M. Chief Known as a Pragmatic Leader
description: DETROIT  For the last year, General Motors has been under the leadership of a former telecommunications executive with no tolerance for indecision or distractions, Edward E. Whitacre Jr.

title: Diving for Pearls, and a Connection to the Past
description: KUWAIT CITY  It was not like the old days: This time, the ships were smaller, the journey was shorter, the work was easier and these young sailors were surely softer.

title: In Kabul, a Service for Slain Aid Workers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Memorial services inevitably have their awkward moments. So did Thursdays gathering of Kabuls international community to remember the 10 slain aid workers, held at the old British Cemetery in Kabul, around the corner from Chicken Street.

title: A Raw Look at Corruption in the Dominican Republic
description: Pig killing is a recurring motif in La Soga, a Dominican Republic-based thriller crawling with abused livestock. Goats, lizards, cockerels and drug dealers jostle for space and screen time, but the pig reigns supreme. Whether gazing limpidly as a knife is twisted in its heart or gamboling in blissful ignorance of its fate, the porker is always in peril.

title: Canada Stops Ship Carrying 490 People
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian Navy and Coast Guard intercepted a ship off the coast of British Columbia Thursday afternoon that was thought to be carrying hundreds of Tamil migrants from Sri Lanka.

title: To Cut Demand for Electricity, Some Customers Agree to Unplug
description: Electricity use is up sharply this summer, but in a windowless room near Albany that is the nerve center of New York States grid, controllers have noticed that something else is not rising: peak load.

title: Exploring the Israel-Palestine Standoff
description: Annemarie Jacirs drama Salt of This Sea, about a Brooklyn woman who travels to the West Bank and Israel to recover her roots  not to mention her Palestinian grandfathers house and bank account, lost in the 1948 war  is a sad and engrossing look at a haunted landscape. Soraya (Suheir Hammad) and the two Palestinian men she befriends, Emad (Saleh Bakri) and Marwan (Riyad Ideis), spend much of the film negotiating both physical barriers  walls, fences, checkpoints, holding cells  and ritual humiliations to move about the rocky, scrubby country in which Emad and Marwan are trapped.

title: Stepping Out of Jordans Shadow, Pippen to Enter Hall
description: On the eve of Scottie Pippens induction into basketballs highest society, Phil Jackson recalled him as the ultimate team player. Quite the homage from Jackson, the former Chicago Bulls coach who once watched incredulously as Pippen sat down with 1.8 seconds left in a deadlocked playoff game against the Knicks and refused to get up.

title: Communication Problems May Have Delayed Search Following Alaska Plane Crash
description: The search for the plane that crashed on an Alaska hillside Monday night, killing former senator Ted Stevens and four others, may have been delayed by hours due to communication breakdowns on the ground and a problem with the planes emergency beacon, the chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board said on Thursday.

title: Learning to Walk in the Slippers of a High-Wire Artist
description: Amye Walters tried not to look down. Her feet gripped a cable less than an inch thick that stretched 21 feet in front of her. Sweat dampened her long dark hair, black tank top and spandex pants.

title: Iran Shows What It Says Is Murder Confession
description: TEHRAN  Iranian state television has broadcast what it portrayed as a murder confession by a woman who had been sentenced to death by stoning on adultery charges, in an unusual effort to deflect criticism of a case that has drawn international protests and an offer of asylum from the president of Brazil.

title: The 20s Roar Back, Without the Prohibitions
description: A speakeasy suggests a clandestine locale, so it was perhaps a misnomer that Wednesday nights event at the Museum of the City of New York, held in the open-air courtyard in front of the grand building for all the world to see, was called one.

title: Mets Season Coming Apart at Seams
description: Johan Santana was on the mound Thursday afternoon, providing the Mets with a determined performance just when they needed it most. Francisco Rodriguez, meanwhile, was sitting in the pen, only not the one at Citi Field.

title: After Layoffs, Yonkers Trims Curriculum
description: YONKERS  Students here will return this fall to bigger classes, limited Advanced Placement options and a dearth of electives in drama, music, cooking and industrial arts because there are fewer teachers to go around.

title: Would You Coach Your Mother With That Mouth?
description: Shortly after HBOs Hard Knocks was broadcast on Wednesday night, the star of the show, Jets Coach Rex Ryan, called his mother. The episode opened with a parade of profanity by Ryan, and he knew he was in trouble.

title: Billionaire Investor Nominates 3 Directors in Fight Over Barnes & Noble
description: War broke out over control of Barnes & Noble on Thursday as the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle nominated three directors to the companys board after efforts to reach a settlement between the sides faltered earlier in the day.

title: Aide to Paterson Is Charged With Assault
description: David W. Johnson, one of Gov. David A. Patersons closest and longest-serving aides, surrendered to prosecutors in the Bronx on Thursday and was charged with misdemeanor assault and five other offenses, the latest chapter in a domestic violence case that entangled the Paterson administration and led the governor to abandon his candidacy.

title: Mayors Stance on Muslim Center Has Deep Roots
description: Michael R. Bloomberg is a former Wall Street mogul with a passion for the rights of a private property owner. He is a Jew whose parents asked their Christian lawyer to buy a house and then sell it back to them to hide their identity in an unwelcoming Massachusetts suburb. And he is a politician who regards his independence as his greatest virtue.

title: Deal to Put Slots at Aqueduct Paves Way for a New York City Casino
description: After nearly a decade of false starts, squabbling and investigations, Gov. David A. Paterson and legislative leaders have approved a deal to bring casino gambling to New York City.

title: Ruing Exile, Russian Says Hes No Spy
description: LONDON  Call him the spy who wants to go home again. Except that Igor Sutyagin insists he is not a spy. And his friends warn him not to go home again.

title: Despite Costs, Clean Coal Remains Obama Priority
description: Aug. 13, 8:20 a.m. | Updated The vast remaining deposits of coal in the world guarantee that this fossil fuel will remain a big part of the global energy mix for decades to come. And that reality guarantees that countries with a lot of this resource will remain hopeful that coal can be burned without adding substantially to the atmospheres building heat-trapping blanket of carbon dioxide.

title: Wrongly Convicted Man Gets $7.95 Million Settlement
description: LOS ANGELES  A man who spent 24 years imprisoned for a murder he did not commit will receive $7.95 million from the City of Long Beach after he sued the police there for withholding evidence in his 1980 trial.

title: Jay Larkin, Theatrical Producer of TV Boxing, Dies at 59
description: Jay Larkin, who brought a theatrical background and hard-nosed negotiating to producing Showtimes boxing telecasts, ultimately helping the network rival HBO in televising pay-per-view prize-fighting, died Monday in Nyack, N.Y., He was 59.

title: Cleared, and Pondering the Value of 27 Years
description: HOUSTON  Since a judge let him out of prison for a rape that prosecutors now say he did not commit, Michael A. Green has had trouble sleeping.

title: E-Mails Show State Officials Skepticism About Willets Point Project
description: Even as the Bloomberg administration promotes the $3 billion development of Willets Point in Queens as one of its signature projects, state officials whose approval is needed have privately raised concerns over highway ramps crucial to the proposal and have questioned whether the development will ever get off the ground.

title: The State of the War
description: We believe that the United States has a powerful national interest in Afghanistan, in depriving Al Qaeda of a safe haven on either side of the Afghanistan-Pakistan border. This country would also do enormous damage to its moral and strategic standing if it now simply abandoned the Afghan people to the Talibans brutalities.

title: Lottery Numbers
Lower Scores Sprout on Rain-Soaked Greens
description: HAVEN, Wis.  Michael Lee, who oversees maintenance at Whistling Straits, has a simple dream: that rain stay away in the weeks before his course hosts a championship tournament.

title: Eyeing the Same Prize, Two Jets Guards Are Leaning on Each Other
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Just before the biggest challenge of his career, a Jets offensive lineman named Matt Slauson, an intimidating 315-pound giant with a spiky beard and tattoos covering his biceps, told Vladimir Ducasse that he would not regard him as his enemy.

title: Withholding Water and Hoping for the Best
description: HAVEN, Wis.  No one argues that Whistling Straits has the aesthetics of an old coastal links course in the British Isles. But whether it acts like one is another matter.

title: India Faces Broader Revolt in Kashmir
description: For decades, India maintained hundreds of thousands of security forces in Kashmir to fight an insurgency sponsored by Pakistan, which claims the border region, too. But protests, which have erupted for a third straight summer, have led India to one of its most serious internal crises in recent memory.

title: Under the Radar, on Top of the N.L.
description: SAN DIEGO  Heath Bell was born in Oceanside, Calif., near San Diego, but he grew up in Tustin, where most people rooted for the Angels or the Dodgers. Bell liked the Padres, and he was 7 when they reached the 1984 World Series. His friends could not share his excitement, though  they did not know who the Padres were.

title: Sharing of Data Leads to Progress on Alzheimers
description: In 2003, a group of scientists and executives from the National Institutes of Health, the Food and Drug Administration, the drug and medical-imaging industries, universities and nonprofit groups joined in a project that experts say had no precedent: a collaborative effort to find the biological markers that show the progression of Alzheimers disease in the human brain.

title: An Interview With Pat Toomey
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with former Representative Pat Toomey, the Republican candidate for the open Senate seat in Pennsylvania.

title: Spending Posts Now a Liability for Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  Membership on the Appropriations Committee used to be a first-class ticket to Congressional success, guaranteeing lucky lawmakers the ability to campaign on the federal money they had lavished on the folks back home. But the era of the appropriator appears to be on the wane.

title: Friday: The Great Manny Nosowsky
description: Its Friday the 13th and were lucky enough to get a puzzle by the great Manny Nosowsky. This is his 246th New York Times crossword in the Shortz Era. Nobody else is even close. Only six other constructors have as many puzzles as he has on Fridays alone.

title: Call-Up Rings Up $300 Taxi Fare
description: Reliever Ryota Igarashi may have brought new meaning to the phrase taxi squad with his scrambling efforts to get to Citi Field on Thursday, an amusing affair on a grim day for the Mets.

title: Failing to Block Vans, Union Wants to Run Them
description: Late last month, the citys leading transit workers union sued the Bloomberg administration to stop a plan that would replace discontinued bus routes with privately run commuter vans.

title: Ah, Dominatrix: I Knew You Way Back in High School
description: Is it all right if I go ahead and award Zach Braff the prize for the best New Yorker cartoon of the year? I dont mean that Mr. Braff, who was the star of the sitcom Scrubs, has taken up drawing for magazines (though, for all I know, he may have). Its just that playing a reluctant millionaire named Harry in Trust, a slender new comedy by Paul Weitz, Mr. Braff is the unmistakable, flesh-and-blood avatar of hundreds of pen-and-ink drawings that have appeared in The New Yorker since its inception.

title: Pettittes Simulated Outing Must Wait a Day
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Joe Girardi called Andy Pettitte around noon on Thursday, wanting to hear how Pettitte felt in his simulated outing. Pettitte had other news instead.

title: Pessimism in Asia Despite a Strong Earnings Season
description: HONG KONG

title: Theyll Do It for Nothing
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Politicians seeking to placate angry voters this election cycle might take a cue from Robert Bentley, a retired dermatologist and the Republican nominee for governor in Alabama.

title: Inquiry on Harvard Lab Threatens Ripple Effect
description: Harvards slow-motion inquiry about the laboratory of Marc Hauser, one of its star academics, has cast a shadow over the several different fields in which Dr. Hauser and his students published papers.

title: WePay Wants to Simplify Group Payments
description: The hardest part of helping organize my coming high school reunion  aside from devising ways to break the ice with old crushes and rivals  is collecting money from the alumni for tickets.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: For the Everglades, a Dream Loses Much of Its Grandeur
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  In the end, Gov. Charlie Crists effort to buy huge swaths of sugar company land for the Everglades restoration was just too much: too much money, too much land to handle, and too much of a fight with critics and the courts.

title: Stars Turn Out for USA Basketball Showcase
description: For those walking into Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night, it was strange to see the storied stage transformed into a basketball court for the USA Basketball Showcase. But what made the scene even more unusual was that on the far sideline, from left to right, sat Dwyane Wade, Chris Paul, Carmelo Anthony, Amare Stoudemire and finally, LeBron James.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 12
description: A view of the day in sports, including the European swimming championships in Hungary and the United States gymnastics championships in Hartford.

title: Alfas, Auctions and Racing Action on the Monterey Peninsula
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,208 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Sabathia Wins His 15th as Yankees Add to Their Lead
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  C. C. Sabathia started drinking water before the Yankees game Wednesday in steamy Texas, downed several cups on the team plane, and in his hotel room on Thursday he mixed in some Gatorade. He did not know precisely how much liquid he had consumed  enough, he guessed, to keep a man listed at 6-feet-7 and a generous 290 pounds hydrated on a hot night.

title: Alcatrazs Newest Star, the Melancholy Dane
description: For any director, putting on a full-scale Hamlet is notoriously intense.

title: Bloggingheads: Billionaire Leeches
description: Journalist Maureen Tkacik, left, and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate the societal value of the very wealthy.

title: New Mudslides Raise Death Toll in China
description: Rain-triggered mudslides across China have pushed up the death toll from Chinas worst flooding in a decade and left thousands trapped, state media reported on Friday. In southwestern Sichuan Province, a mudslide killed at least five people and trapped more than 500 others, the Xinhua state news agency reported. Farther north in Gansu Province, the number of dead and missing was raised after new floodwaters surged through the region, Xinhua reported. In the city of Longnan 10 people died, 12 were reported missing and 10,000 trapped by floodwaters, the local government said in a statement, Xinhua reported. In Tianshui, four people died and eight were missing, Xinhua said.

title: Vacation Apartment Rentals: Lucrative and Largely Illegal
description: Summer in San Francisco brings in gusts of chilly winds and bursts of tourists. Instead of staying in hotels, a growing number of visitors opt to live like the locals, renting apartments in the citys colorful neighborhoods.

title: In Oakland, Private Force May Be Hired for Security
description: In a basement office that serves as a police headquarters and community center, Oakland Chinatown leaders pored over maps of the neighborhood with representatives from a private security firm last week.

title: China: Government Investigates Reports of Problems With Milk Powder Diet
description: Reports that three infant girls in south-central China have developed premature breast growth while on a diet of milk powder have drawn national attention in China and a government investigation, but the Chinese manufacturer of the powder denies any problem with its product. The Health Ministry said Thursday that it had appointed a panel of nine experts to investigate the reports. The reports have suggested that the powder may contain hormones that could set off premature puberty. The formulas manufacturer, Synutra International of Qingdao, said in a statement on Wednesday that there was no scientific evidence to link its product to the infants premature development.

title: Urban Farming for Cash Gains a Toehold in San Francisco
description: Brooke Budner and Caitlyn Galloway are a common sight on the streets of the Mission district  covered in dirt and carrying baskets of salad mix from their backyard farm to Bar Tartine, a stylish upscale restaurant.

title: Many Chicago Charter Schools Run Deficits, Data Shows
description: Even as the Obama administration promotes charter schools as a way to help raise the academic performance of the nations students, half of Chicagos charter schools have been running deficits in recent years, an analysis of financial and budget documents shows, calling into question their financial viability.

title: China: Tibetan Writers Trial Postponed
description: The trial of a Tibetan writer who has criticized Chinese policies in Tibet in a recent book may be postponed, according to the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group. The group said in a statement on Thursday that it was unclear whether a postponement of the trial for the writer, whose name is Tragyal, would suggest that the authorities were questioning the premise of the trial or whether they were looking for more evidence. Mr. Tragyal was detained in April in Xining, after the publication of his book, The Line between Sky and Earth.

title: Uganda: Suspect in Bombings Says He Wanted to Kill Americans
description: The confessed mastermind of terrorist attacks that killed more than 70 people during the World Cup finals last month said Thursday that the attacks were aimed at Americans. The suspect was one of four Ugandans presented to the public on Thursday who confessed to planning the bombings in Kampala, said Kale Kayihura, Ugandas inspector general. I was reluctant to pick on Ugandans, the man identified as the groups leader, Issa Ahmed Luyima, left, 33, told journalists in Kampala, according to Reuters. My rage was with the Americans, whom I deemed responsible for all the suffering of Muslims around the world. The suspects said they were working with the Shabab, an Islamist insurgency in Somalia, which has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

title: A Candidate Takes an Unlikely Green Path
description: As a boy growing up in the long shadow of the Ida B. Wells public housing development, LeAlan Jones, the Illinois Green Party candidate for the United States Senate, learned at an early age to ignore naysayers.

title: France: U.N. Body Raises Rights Issues
description: A United Nations human rights body strongly criticized France this week, denouncing what it deemed a marked growth in racism and xenophobia. Meeting with French representatives on Wednesday and Thursday, the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, based in Geneva, expressed particular concern over a government-led debate on the national identity, President Nicolas Sarkozys proposal to withdraw citizenship from certain foreign-born criminals, and a recent decision to dismantle 300 unauthorized Roma encampments. Its time you made your dreams of equality and fraternity a reality, said the committees vice chairman, Pierre-Richard Prosper, Le Monde reported. On Thursday, Pierre Lellouche, French minister for European affairs, said the governments actions were meant to guarantee the first of human rights, which is the right to safety.

title: California Cruising: A Week of Magnificent Machines
description: Here are some of the cars that will go on auction this weekend at events in Monterey, Calif.

title: Rostenkowski, Master Politician and Benefactor
description: The one time I dined with Dan Rostenkowski in Washington, we didnt go to his red-meat favorite, a Mortons steak house in Georgetown. There hed routinely hold court with legislative chums at a table with his name affixed to a nearby metal plate.

title: With N.L.s Best Record, the Padres Head North
description: SAN DIEGO  Heath Bell does not wait for the middle innings, the way a lot of closers do, to join his fellow relievers in the San Diego Padres bullpen. He gathers the brigade after the national anthem for the walk across the Petco Park grass, with the youngest member, Ernesto Frieri, lugging a Chewbacca backpack.

title: Prosecutor Is Changed in the Trial of a Senator
description: The assault trial of State Senator Kevin S. Parker was thrown into turmoil on Thursday, as a judge granted a request by the Brooklyn district attorneys office to have two special prosecutors appointed.

title: The Pulse: A Cooling Trend on Cap and Trade
description: Like much of the Northern Hemisphere, Chicago is suffering through one of the hottest summers in recent memory, raising more discussion about global warming.

title: The Pulse: Antiviolence Ritual From a Faraway Land
description: After years of frustration, Cheryl Graves was ready to consider a different solution to Chicagos problem of youth violence.

title: Switzerland Tries to Check Franc and Aid Exports
description: While the rest of Europe struggles to rein in government debt, there is no talk of forced austerity in prudent Switzerland. Instead, the country is looking forward to growth of at least 2.5 percent this year, thanks to booming exports, Jack Ewing writes in The New York Times.

title: A Third Down Day on Wall Street
description: A decline in technology shares and weak jobs data sent Wall Street indexes down on Thursday, as traders were confronted with more signs that the global economy was slowing, Christine Hauser reports in The New York Times.

title: Greek Recession Deepens Amid Spending Cuts
description: Greeces recession deepened in the second quarter, according to official estimates released Thursday, as the country felt the painful consequences of the governments drive to reduce its debt load with aggressive austerity cuts, The Associated Press reports.

title: Indiana Lawmaker Wants Donations Returned
description: A Democratic lawmaker wants Indiana politicians and campaign organizations to return contributions they received from an Indianapolis businessman whose dealings are being investigated by the F.B.I.

title: The Hidden Income of Chinas Wealthy
description: Chinas households hide as much as 9.3 trillion renminbi of income that is not reported in official figures, with 80 percent accrued by the wealthiest people, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Dell Accused of Concealing Evidence in PC Suit
description: Dell has been accused of withholding evidence, including e-mails among its top executives, in a lawsuit over faulty computers it sold to businesses, according to a filing made Thursday, Ashlee Vance reported in The New York Times.

title: Emergent to Acquire Trubion for $96.8 Million
description: Trubion Pharmaceuticals, a Seattle biotech firm, agreed to be acquired by Emergent BioSolutions for $96.8 million in cash and stock and a potential later payment of as much as $38.7 million, Bloomberg News reported.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: In Retrospect, Most Big Deals Were Bad Ideas
description: More than half of the 100 biggest takeovers made during the last mergers-and-acquisitions boom have something in common: By one measure, they never should have happened, Bloomberg News reports.

title: U.S. Firms Paying Down Loans in Double Time
description: Speculative-grade companies are doubling the rate at which they are repaying leveraged loans, as they try to curb the likelihood of rising defaults amid signs the American economy is slowing, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Mahindra of India Has Top Bid for Ssangyong
description: Ssangyong Motor, the South Korean automaker, named Mahindra & Mahindra, the top sport utility vehicle maker in India, as its preferred buyer Thursday, demonstrating the growing clout of manufacturers from emerging markets.

title: Utah Investor Seeks Comeback in Idaho
description: A Utah investor who lost a $5 million private jet, a luxury car and his membership in the Utah Jazzs premier fan club in a bankruptcy said his company will resurrect a moribund central Idaho ski and golf resort, The Associated Press reported.

title: Warner Chilcott Prices $750 Million Debt Issue
description: Warner Chilcott, the Irish drug maker, said Thursday its subsidiaries sold $750 million of senior notes in a private placement, The Associated Press reported.

title: Vedanta in Talks to Take Control of Cairn India
description: Vedanta Resources is in talks to buy a controlling stake in Cairn Energys Indian subsidiary, The Financial Times reported. Cairn Indias stock rose 1.6 percent on the Bombay Stock Exchange in morning trading Fridayfollowing the disclosure. In separate statements, both Vedanta and Cairn confirmed talks were ongoing.

title: Cosmetic Treatment Controversy
description: By CARRIE MONTGOMERY

title: Korean Oil Concern Could Go Hostile in Bid for Dana
description: Korea National Oil Corporation has indicated it is willing to start a hostile takeover bid for Dana Petroleum after the British company formally said that K.N.O.C.s 1.7 billion offer did not reflect the value of its oil exploration program.

title: Are You Cool or Hot Under Pressure?
description: The story of a flight attendant escaping from an airplane down an inflatable chute after an altercation with a passenger has attracted a lot of attention. The City Room blog compared the response of Steven Slater, the attendant, to a difficult situation with that of pilot Chesley Sullenberger, who famously landed a plane in the Hudson River. City Room suggests that we all look inside and ask, Am I a Sully? Or am I a Slater? Which are you?

title: Report Says Buyout Sector Doesnt Beat Markets
description: New research into the private equity sector could prompt a new debate about whether buyout firms add value to their investments, The Financial Times reported.

title: Och-Ziff Said to Be Part of Lehman Rumors
description: Dick Fuld may have been right after all.

title: Hedge Fund Investment Gets July Boost
description: Hedge funds stabilized somewhat in July as investors poured more money into the sector amid rebounding stock markets, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing estimates published by HedgeFund.net.

title: Li Adds to His Stake in Hutchison Whampoa
description: Billionaire Li Ka-shing made his biggest investment in Hutchison Whampoa shares in at least seven years, boosting a stock that has already been the best performer of the month in Hong Kongs Hang Seng Index, Bloomberg News reported.

title: In Hong Kong, Where to Get Well-Heeled
description: For Hong Kong fashion mavens, shoes are often not an accessory, but the main item. So its not surprising that shoe boutiques of all styles and prices proliferate across the city. But fans of luxury footwear have been making a special pilgrimage to the recently opened Rupert Sanderson boutique, the brands flagship store in Asia.

title: Health Care, Uncertainty and Morality
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Authorities Say Ponzi Had Ties to Christian Chat Show
description: The Ontario Securities Commission has named two sons of David Mainse, the founder of the Canadian Christian talk show, 100 Huntley Street, in a case involving a $15 million Ponzi scheme, The Globe and Mail reported.

title: Myanmar Junta Sets Election Date
description: BANGKOK  Myanmar will hold its first elections in two decades on Nov. 7, the ruling junta announced Friday, setting a date for a vote that has been denounced by opponents as a means of legitimizing military power within the format of civilian rule.

title: Citigroup Helps Scions Manage Their Allowances
description: Citigroup is helping the kids of its wealthiest clients to manage their allowances. The bank, Bloomberg News reported, is testing a Web site to let millionaires children manage their money, while alerting parents and bankers when scions blow through cash too quickly.

title: Li & Fung Offers $901 Million for Distributor
description: Li & Fung, the biggest supplier to retailers including Wal-Mart Stores, is offering about 7 billion Hong Kong dollars ($901 million) for a distribution company to gain a network in China. Both companies shares rose in Hong Kong on the news.

title: Will Voice Recognition Hurt Literature?
description: Todays idea: In the annals of writing, women taking transcription were the dominant form of voice-recognition software for centuries. But no longer. Will literature itself suffer?

title: Pakistan Leader Faces Fury Over Floods
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  With Pakistanis bracing for more rain and floods, President Asif Ali Zardari struggled Friday to confront a barrage of criticism over his recent visit to Europe, undertaken while rivers gorged by monsoon rains ravaged large portions of the country  a trip that critics have derided as insensitive and a joy ride.

title: How Do Giants Fans Feel About the Jets Publicity Push?
description: In New York, if not the nation, the Jets are the team people are talking about. Thats the way the Jets like it, and their publicity push far predates Hard Knocks.

title: Growth of Euro-Area Economy Beats Forecasts
description: The euro-area economy grew 1 percent in the second quarter, a much better rate than had been expected, due largely to Germanys best quarterly performance since reunification, according to data released on Friday.

title: Stray Questions for Richard Toye
description: Richard Toyes book Churchills Empire is reviewed in this Sundays Book Review.

title: Tip of the Week: Getting Rid of Duplicate Songs
description: Have you accidentally imported the same CD twice, or do you have duplicated songs in your iTunes library? A built-in feature of iTunes lets you easily weed out doubles. Just open the iTunes program and click on the icon for your Music library on the left side of the window. Next, go to the File menu and choose the Display Duplicates option.

title: Funds Getting an Education in MGM Auction
description: With Spyglass Entertainment poised to become part-owner of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, The Hollywood Reporter examines why the venerable but debt-ridden studio would go with the independent production company rather than other options its had during the auction process.

title: A Hollywood-Wall Street Smackdown
description: In what The Hollywood Reporter Esquire blog called a real Hollywood-vs.-Wall Street smackdown, Goldman Sachs has fired back at producer Joel Silvers $30 million lawsuit, trying to have the claims thrown out of court.

title: Wall Street Tries to Sort Through Economic Reports
description: Stocks fell for a fourth straight day Friday after new economic statistics reinforced a picture of a sluggish recovery in the United States.

title: Inside the List

Will any astronauts be tossing it in their carry-ons? Some books have been launched into space. Ron Garan, a NASA astronaut who is preparing to fly to the International Space Station in March, has been posting Twitter updates about the books hes taking along, including The Blue Sweater: Bridging the Gap Between Rich and Poor in an Interconnected World, by Jacqueline Novogratz, and Muhammad Yunuss Creating a World Without Poverty. He may also find some books left behind by previous travelers, including Goethes Faust and Robert A. Heinleins sci-fi classic The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress, carried up by the former Microsoft executive Charles Simonyi during his two self-financed voyages.

description: Anna Pigeon, the stalwart National Park Service ranger in Nevada Barrs rugged wilderness novels, has been feeling her age lately (she was coming up on 50 six years ago in High Country), and shes giving serious thought to a job change. BURN (Minotaur, $25.99) might be considered a step in that direction, since it takes place mostly in the French Quarter of New Orleans and restricts its animal studies to acts of cruelty committed by bipeds who consider themselves human.

In her 17th book, she traces the history of American positive thinking to the reaction against Calvinism, and explores its current manifestations in cancer treatment, corporate retreats, megachurches and the real estate bubble.

title: Chilled to the Bone
description: I had no name, no home in time, thinks Arvid Jansen, the narrator of Per Pettersons slender, subtly incisive new novel, I Curse the River of Time. Its a statement that could apply to most of Pettersons lonely Scandinavian souls. In his books  the best known is probably Out Stealing Horses  Petterson depicts a literal and figurative geography that, to American readers, might feel a little like the starker reaches of the West, a little like the stonier shores of Maine, a little like Edward Hopper, a little like Raymond Carver. His characters are decent, laconic and perpetually, possibly existentially, chilled. They just cant get warm, cant stay warm, no matter how hard they try. At the risk of perpetrating a geographical clich, I have to say that Pettersons world feels Far Northern to the core  windswept, dimly lit, its summers and romances hard-won, deeply felt, reluctantly left behind. Memory, in this unregenerate landscape, is often the only thing these people have to get them through the winter of their discontents. They hoard it, hide it, keep it close at all times. Pettersons narratives tend to unspool in the first person, in hushed, confidential tones. Tight-lipped with one another, his characters open their hearts to the reader, making us witnesses to their most private selves. He makes the reader lean in, out of the wind, to listen closely.

title: Age of Innocence
description: Any dreamy or bookish girl who once loved Harriet the Spy should immediately take up this lively new biography of Edith Wharton by Connie Nordhielm Wooldridge. The Brave Escape of Edith Wharton tells the story of a strong-willed, unconventional and smart girl who escaped the stifling life of upper-crust New York around 1880. It includes lush photographs of that faraway time and a pencil drawing Wharton did of herself at 14 reading a book.

title: August Historical Events Fill-In
Monserrate Down, but Not Out of Sight
description: Hiram Monserrate was convicted of domestic abuse. He was the first lawmaker in Albany expelled from office since Calvin Coolidge was president. He is persona non grata among New York Democratic Party leaders. His campaign war chest is half as big as his opponents, and he has no paid staff members. His campaign office has the look of an abandoned storefront.

title: What Does W Stand For?
description: THE newly revamped W now comes with a slanted logo, as if to say, Lets go! The energized logo might be the most promising thing about the magazine, which has a new editor, Stefano Tonchi, formerly the editor of T: The New York Times Magazine, as well as a new creative director, Jody Quon. Ive been a reader of W since its broadsheet days, when it was driven by the curiosity and often deliciously snippy tongue of its founder, John Fairchild. In 2000, I wrote a profile of its then creative director, Dennis Freedman, and the way he cultivated photographers and helped bring to life sometimes-difficult ideas in fashion and art. In its long history W, at its best, was a scrappy journalistic player with a knowing sense of the people it covered.

There must be a psychological issue that keeps her from seeking dental help. But Im concerned about the wedding pictures. description: Susan Spungen has had many careers: restaurant cook and caterer, Martha Stewarts culinary right hand for a dozen years, food stylist (for T Magazine and others). In recent years, shes brought the meals in the top food movies to life, from the duck en croute for Julie & Julia (even Jacques Ppin approved) to the plot-advancing croissants in Its Complicated and now the Roman feasts in Eat Pray Love, which opens today. The Moment caught up with Spungen over a cappuccino at Bluebird Coffee to find out how she kept her pasta from outshining Julia Roberts, and to get her tips for dining in Rome.

Yet in the newly recast Next to Normal, the musical that won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in April, nobody is bouncing off the walls anymore or threatening to pull the audience into one collective meltdown of extreme feelings.

In an understated, judicious manner, he offers a radically new understanding of printing in the years of its birth and youth. Print, in Pettegrees account, was never as dignified or lofty a medium as that humanist mythology of disseminated classics would suggest.

Moraiss first novel, The Hundred-Foot Journey: close to 25 million feet, by my count, from India to England and then France, the last leg via a tricolor caravan of used Mercedes-Benzes that chugs through much of Western Europe. This is to say nothing of the psychological distance traversed by the narrator, Hassan Haji, a Muslim boy born on the edge of a slum in what was still called Bombay and then catapulted to Pariss temples of haute cuisine. title: Smellbound

Across from me sat a man in royal blue robes and a matching blue turban, with a long gray beard and kohl-rimmed eyes; on his desk, and on the shelves behind him, in a cabinet by the door  all over the room  there were small amber-tinted glass bottles, scores of them, and as we spoke he would take one up, open the top, hand it to me and invite me to smell the contents. This went on for hours. It was why Id come: to meet Dominique Dubrana, a 54-year-old Frenchman living in Italy, a Sufi convert, a grand eccentric and a genius of sorts.

If the philosophical and psychological notions behind the approach of Elegies for the Brokenhearted seem obvious or clichd  that an individuals identity is formed by the people who surround her  its execution proves deeply, satisfyingly original.

title: Am I Young Yet?
description: To celebrate the start of the football season, Im volunteering to take one for the team  no, for all teams, major and minor  by coming clean about my doping. Throughout the fall and winter of 2009, I gave myself daily shots of somatropin, the manufactured form of human growth hormone, or H.G.H., which is believed to build muscle and rev up the recovery time from injuries. Hence the drugs allure to professional athletes. In my case, I had a torn ankle tendon that required surgery, and at 48, I began to wonder whether my post-op rebound might benefit from the supposed boost of H.G.H. juice?

A few days later, on August 1st, 50 years ago this month, my country was declared independent: I was French for just 18 days! It is not easy for me to judge the 50 years of independence of my small country, now called Benin. I feel that my life has been shaped in many ways by the political tribulations of West Africa. I consider myself a true daughter of my countrys recent independence.

title: Letters: The Yoga Mogul
description: Mimi Swartzs recent article (July 25) intersperses some of John Friends philosophical and practical perspectives on yoga. It did not, however, do justice to who Friend is, what he stands for and how he is transforming the practice of yoga into an experience that connects people to the core of their own goodness and expanded sense of self. He has maintained the highest standards possible in his teaching and training and has inspired thousands of people to embrace yoga practice and ethics as a way to live life filled with joy, integrity and balance. Drawing upon the wisdom and skill of his own teachers and his extensive personal studies, Friend has created a style that honors the past while forging ahead with innovative and brilliant principles of alignment and philosophical tenets.

title: The Origins of Relatable

Our first stop was just a couple of hours away: a gas-station parking lot in Oak Hill, W.Va., where Hank Williams was found dead in his Cadillac convertible on New Years Day in 1953.

title: Buyer, Be Aware
description: During the great housing bubble and bust, journalists spent a fair amount of time searching for the perfect mortgage victim. This victim would be someone who played by the rules, took a conservative approach to his finances and simply wanted a decent place to live. He made his monthly payments on time, right up to the day that the bank informed him that his payments would balloon because of a fine-print technicality that no borrower could have understood. Just like that, the homeowner was facing foreclosure.

title: Letter: The Middle of Somewhere
description: Laura Munsons essay (July 25) was the latest in an almost unbroken string of diverse, well-written articles that have appeared in the Lives column over the past few years. Though I have been remiss in not writing sooner, I was determined to let Munson know how much I was affected by her description of what is lost as our children grow into those unrecognizable, technologically proficient semiadults and what it means to a parent to find that the seemingly lost sensitivity to nature still exists under the layers of wireless devices. This was an encouraging piece for parents and grandparents who may not yet have had such an experience.

title: The Promise and Peril of Smart Keyboards
description: Analog culture is stored in our muscle memories. Even as artifacts of the predigital world disappear, we havent forgotten the moves. How to crank up a car window. How to ease up on a clutch. How to put a needle on a record.

title: Letter: Summer Growmance
description: I had an urge to write in after reading Christine Muhlkes article (July 18). The face of American farming is definitely disappearing. As I look around in St. Johns County, Fla., it becomes more and more apparent: development and urban sprawl continue to push our agricultural community out, little by little. Teenagers like Alexandra Reau are a breath of fresh air. Whether it is passed down from generation to generation or cultivated through organizations like 4H, the love of the land and our farming history is an important part of Americas heritage. Thanks to Alexandra and all C.S.A. supporters and Americas farmers.

title: Tracing Darwins Path in Tierra del Fuego

Though the Galpagos typically draw Darwin tours, two  cruises aim to shadow the H.M.S. Beagles less celebrated time in Tierra del Fuego.

title: Paolo Canevari | Playing With Fire
description: If not for his massive rubber sculptures and short films of burning skulls, Paolo Canevari, 47, may have only been known as the ex-beau of a certain Yugoslavian performance artist. For me, Marina has always been first a woman, my companion, and then an artist, says Canevari, who separated from Marina Abramovic in 2009. Born into a family of classically trained Italian painters and sculptors, Canevari came to New York in the 1980s to assist the South Korean experimental video artist Nam June Paik. Since his first New York show in 1989, Canevari has produced politically responsive artworks in a diverse array of mediums: sculptures made of car tires, video installations and photographs. He even dipped a toe into the slightly more frivolous world of fashion after meeting Riccardo Tisci in 2007 to collaborate on a project for AnOther magazine. He gave me a Givenchy haute couture dress and said, Do what you like with it.  I burned it on a wooden cross. As for the clothing he doesnt set aflame, Canevari sticks to vintage. I have a collection of vintage suits and several vintage motorcycle jackets  around 35! Concerning the overall inspiration behind his works, including his 2007 Venice Biennale entry, Bouncing Skull, the artist is very frank. Life and death have been a source of inspiration for centuries for artists, he says. Im not an exception.

description: Follow the bees, said Franca Tantillo, owner of Berried Treasures Farm, one recent afternoon at the Greenmarket in Union Square, Manhattan, as she shopped for peaches. They know the fruit that has the most sugar, even if its only a fraction of a percent more.

title: An Interview With Martin O'Malley
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley on unemployment rates, the state budget and other issues worrying voters this election year.

title: Girls, Uninterrupted
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass.

title: At DuArt, an End to Film Processing
description: Al Young, a film editor, and his partner, Arthur Gottlieb, started the DuArt film laboratory in 1922, during the era of silent movies. Now, after 88 years, Youngs son Irwin has announced that the company will process its last roll of film this month. I grew up with film, so Im sad to see it go, Irwin Young, chairman of DuArt Film & Video, said in a statement. But most of our clients have moved to digital image acquisition, and were moving with them. The president of DuArt, Bob Smith, said the company was responsible for one of the first continuous-processing machines in 1927 and the first processing of Eastman Color negatives in 1951. The lab received an Academy Award for technical achievement in 1979 for the development of a frame-cueing system. Closing the processing lab, Mr. Young said, will enable the company to expand its digital work.

title: Contestant for Judge on Idol? Shania Twain
description: The judges chairs on American Idol  which have become increasingly musical of late, with the departure first of Simon Cowell and then of Ellen DeGeneres this month  may soon have at least one high-profile new occupant. People magazine reported that the show, preparing to enter its 10th season, is negotiating with the country star Shania Twain, above, to join the panel with the power to mint new pop stars. Nigel Lythgoe, who recently returned to the show as its executive producer, said in an interview with USA Today that he thought that she would make an authoritative judge. Shes turned country music into pop music, Mr. Lythgoe said. Ms. Twain declined to comment about the negotiations. Talks with at least one other potential superstar judge, Jennifer Lopez, have fallen apart, People reported, but Steven Tyler, the lead singer of Aerosmith, is still considering joining the show.

title: In Its Finale, Dance Is Second to Brother
description: The seventh season of So You Think You Can Dance ended on Thursday night as the 18-year-old contemporary jazz dancer Lauren Froderman, above, took home the $250,000 cash prize as this years champion. That Fox reality shows finale episode drew an average of 7.2 million viewers from 8 to 10, enough to put the network in second place in the nights ratings over all, according to Nielsens estimates. CBS placed first, drawing 7.9 million viewers at 8 for Big Brother, followed by repeats of CSI (7.6 million) and The Mentalist (8.1 million) at 9 and 10. ABC was third, earning 6.1 million at 8 for a repeat of Wipeout, and 6.2 million for Rookie Blue at 9. In the 10 oclock hour, ABCs final installment of Boston Med delivered a more modest audience of 4.7 million viewers. NBC finished a distant fourth with a lineup of reruns.

title: Kanye West to Return to MTV Awards Show
description: Maybe someone will lock the microphone to a stand this time  and bolt the stand to the stage. Kanye West, right, who notoriously relieved Taylor Swift of her mike during the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards so that he could suggest that Beyonc Knowles should have won the statuette for best female video that Ms. Swift was holding, will return to the ceremony this year to perform, on Sept. 12 in Los Angeles, the music network has announced. After the 2009 outburst Mr. West took a break from his music career, but now has said he plans to release a new album in November. He apologized in his own fashion to Ms. Swift for the hijacking, writing on his blog shortly after the incident: I feel like Ben Stiller in Meet the Parents when he messed up everything and Robert De Niro asked him to leave. But MTV has decided to ask him back, motivated probably more by ratings than by forgiveness. Fans will be glued to the screen to see what the rapper has in store for the audience, the networks statement said.

title: NBC Pulls Emmy Ads After Complaints
description: Spoofing is the sincerest form of flattery. Or at least it would seem so in the world of television. And networks competing against AMCs Mad Men for an Emmy or three were not amused when NBC, which will carry the awards on Aug. 29, released the first in a series of joking Mad Men-theme promotional ads this week for the Emmy show. The first ad  in which Jimmy Fallon,  wearing a skinny tie, does his best Don Draper, above, with the actress Christina Hendricks as Joan Harris, her character in the series  was broadcast on Wednesday night. But after complaints by other networks, it was pulled from television and the Web, and two more ads have been delayed, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The spots  all featuring Mr. Fallon, who will host the Emmys  will be kept under wraps until after voting for the awards has ended on Tuesday. Are they kidding? an unidentified official from one network told the publication. Theyre running basically ads for Mad Men in the middle of the voting process. Thats like having a presidential campaign and running an ad for one candidate. NBC told The Hollywood Reporter that the ads had been released prematurely.

title: Caucus Video: The Race for Maryland Governor
description: In Maryland this election year, one former Republican governor wants his old job back. But he must first win a primary that includes a challenger with the backing of Alaskas former governor, Sarah Palin, and then prevail over an incumbent Democratic governor who beat him four years ago.

title: Runaway Train Leaves London Scrambling
description: LONDON  It was the stuff of urban nightmare and Hollywood action film: a runaway maintenance train on Londons Underground system speeding downhill for 13 minutes  four miles  toward the heart of the city as the authorities worked frantically to clear its path of trainloads of unwitting commuters.

title: Tale of Ansel Adams Negatives Grows Hazy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It was a dream come true, straight out of Antiques Roadshow. In 2000 Rick Norsigian, a painter in a school maintenance department, bought a box of photo negatives at a garage sale in Fresno, Calif., for $45. Last month, a decade later, he stood in a Beverly Hills art gallery to announce that a team of experts had concluded beyond a reasonable doubt that Ansel Adams had taken the pictures.

title: A City That Knows Long Odds
description: ATLANTIC CITY

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: LEVI MEISNERS SHOFAR SHOP is really the corner of the living room of his third-floor apartment on 12th Avenue, and it is open for browsing for the Hebrew month of Elul. That month leads into Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year, which this year begins at sundown on Sept. 8. Mr. Meisner, 27, has a full-time office job, but every fall he sells about 100 shofars, the rams horns turned into musical instruments that are a signature of High Holy Day services. His customers, often rabbis, come through word of mouth and fliers posted on streets. Mr. Meisners horns, purchased from a dealer in Israel, are made under rabbinic supervision  hologram stickers affirm they are kosher  according to biblical and Talmudic law: softened by heating and partially straightened before a hole is drilled in the tip. They range in price from $30 to $300. On Wednesday, Mr. Meisner selected a huge spiral horn from dozens in a Dole banana box and blew a series of long and short blasts that sounded like an operatic ram stuck in a trap. Its not an impulse purchase, he said.

title: A Deadly Heat Wave and a Roosevelts Rise
description: HOT enough for you? In 1896, a blazing 10-day heat wave killed nearly 1,500 New Yorkers and, arguably, burnished the progressive and populist credentials of a young police commissioner named Theodore Roosevelt.

title: Readers Questions Answered
description: Viewing Ground Zero

title: Romance and Puppets, in Postwar France
description: Is that really from this? my husband whispered in my ear as the final notes died down and blissed-out applause erupted all around us. The that was the wistful, delicately lilting waltz Love Makes the World Go Round; the this was the sweet-and-sour 1961 musical currently in revival at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Carnival!

title: 5,000 Years of Chinese Music and Dance, in One Night
description: WHEN Shen Yun Performing Arts arrives at the State University of New York at Purchase this month, it will have played on four continents since January, bringing tales spanning five millennia of Chinese music, dance and folklore to nearly 130 cities.

title: Trickle-Up Economics?
description: Youve probably heard of trickle-down economics: the idea that tax cuts for the wealthy manage to also help the middle class and poorer. Well, in the world of marginal tax rates, welcome to trickle-up economics: the idea that tax cuts for the middle class and poorer also help the rich.

title: A Curator Goes With Her Gut
description: CROTON FALLS, N.Y.

title: Dolly! (Modestly)
description: Leslie Alexander doesnt bat her eyes or belt her lyrics with abandon as Dolly Gallagher Levi in the Gateway Playhouse production of Hello, Dolly! at the Patchogue Theater for the Performing Arts. She doesnt invite applause for making an entrance, even when she appears at the top of that red staircase in the title number. She stays in character, a widow trying to make a living as a matchmaker and self-described meddler.

title: Surfing Since Before He Was Born
description: Sean MacPherson, 45, is a co-owner and developer with Eric Goode of a cache of hip hotels including the Jane, the Bowery and the Maritime, as well as V.I.P.-friendly hangouts like the Waverly Inn. His solo ventures include a reinvention of the Crows Nest restaurant, a waterfront oldie in Montauk, N.Y., where his weekend surf shack in Ditch Plains is scant steps from the Atlantic. He lives in the West Village and Montauk with his English bulldog puppy, Stanley.

title: Arts Festival Stresses Connectivity
description: UNITY and connections are the themes of the new Southampton Arts Festival, taking place at the Southampton Cultural Center from Monday to Aug. 28, Elena Baksht, one of its founders, said.

title: Shakespeare in the Great Outdoors
description: Petruchio and Katharina will spend a few happy hours in Ridgefield on Saturday when the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival presents a free production of The Taming of the Shrew. It will be part of an afternoon event, HSBC Presents: Shakespeare on the Green and Green Expo, which will include a showcase of local environmentally friendly businesses. The performance of the Shakespeare comedy will follow the expo on the baseball field next to the Ridgefield Playhouse.

title: An Artists Revelation in a Walking Canvas
Marc Kramer Out as Daily News C.E.O.
description: The Daily News has shaken up its top ranks for the second time in less than a month.

title: A Fresh Success in a Light White
description: For most of Jamesport Vineyardss 29 years its sauvignon blanc has been one of Long Islands best. The 2009 version shows why, beginning with its inviting herbal scent and ending with an extended finish. This light signature white ($23.95), tangy and somewhat tropical, is creamy and mouth-filling.

title: A Japanese Menu and a Hip Clientele
description: AJI 53 opened in Bay Shore in the fall of 2007 and quickly earned a reputation as a Japanese restaurant of high quality. In the latest Zagat Survey of Long Island restaurants, it is tied with Kotobuki for first place among Japanese entries for food.

title: Visiting the Fish Market, Ready to Eat
description: IT can be frustrating to visit a fish market at the Shore if, like many vacationers, you dont have a kitchen handy. Some markets, though, will cook the seafood for you, offering take-out counters and full-fledged restaurants on the premises.

title: A Sweets Lovers Eden
description: The black awnings and brick facade of Sweet Rexies exterior belie the many colors within. A long row of acrylic cylinders hangs from one wall dispensing, for $3 a quarter pound, all kinds of treats  from candy necklaces and malted milk balls (both milk and dark chocolate) to cherry rock candy and chocolate-covered potato chips. The M & Ms alone come in two dozen shades.

title: Festive Mexican, Theatrics on the Side
description: OLITA Cucina and Tequila Bar, which opened last summer in the Byram section of Greenwich, next door to Port Chester, is the kind of place that is most enjoyable when visited with a group. Its loud, spirited atmosphere, to the beat of exuberant taped music, is not conducive to solitary dining. Dont even try to have a tte--tte  just dig into the food, sip a margarita and join the high-decibel chatter.

title: Mixed Views on Blagojevich
description: CHICAGO  The jury is still out in the wide-ranging corruption trial of the ousted former governor, self-proclaimed political martyr and sometime Elvis impersonator Rod R. Blagojevich. But across Chicago, there is some evidence that the court of public opinion has already rendered its verdict.

title: Hot Dogs, Griddled and Spicy
description: Summer is probably the best time to enjoy that great American classic, the hot dog. And if you arent in the mood to fire up your own grill, there are some terrific frankfurters to be had at So Dam Hot, a storefront operation in Valhalla that serves mainly takeout.

title: A Northern Outpost of Eastern Traditions
description: TRAVELING throughout Asia as a young woman, Marnie Henricksson was captivated by the food and learned how to cook much of it. After returning home and finding it difficult to obtain some of the more exotic ingredients she had used abroad, she simplified and tweaked the recipes, making them her own. The result was a repertory of uncomplicated, absolutely delicious dishes that became a cult hit soon after Ms. Henricksson opened Marnies Noodle Shop in Greenwich Village in the early 1990s.

description: Ariel Kaminer cruises the city on two river boat tours to take in the view from the water.

Blankfein, left, its chairman and chief executive, exercised stock options this week and earned millions of dollars in profits by selling the firms shares, Reuters reports.

description: The Blackstone Group, the private equity giant, agreed on Friday to buy Dynegy, the Houston power company that once sought to buy Enron, for $4.7 billion including debt, in the largest leveraged buyout so far this year.

description: The personal is still political. Michael R. Bloomberg is a former Wall Street mogul with a passion for the rights of a private property owner, reports The Timess Michael Barbaro. He is a Jew whose parents asked their Christian lawyer to buy a house and then sell it back to them to hide their identity in an unwelcoming Massachusetts suburb. And he is a politician who regards his independence as his greatest virtue.

description: In Torrington, Conn., campers at Wah-Nee take each other on to claim bragging rights.

description: WASHINGTON  The growing use by the police of new technologies that make surveillance far easier and cheaper to conduct is raising difficult questions about the scope of constitutional privacy rights, leading to sharp disagreements among judges.

Panse of Freehold, N.J. Pandit Harish C. Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Hyatt Regency Jersey City on the Hudson.
