description: HAVEN, Wis.  When a shroud of soupy fog postponed the beginning of the P.G.A. Championship on Thursday morning, Bubba Watson killed time by playing a popular puzzle video game called Angry Birds on his iPhone. At other points, he threw things at his fellow golfer Rickie Fowler as he tried to sleep.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obama delivered a strong defense on Friday night of a proposed Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero in Manhattan, using a White House dinner celebrating Ramadan to proclaim that as a citizen, and as president, I believe that Muslims have the same right to practice their religion as anyone else in this country.

description: WASHINGTON  Forget the lush beaches of Bora Bora or the Campari-soaked cafes along the Cte dAzur. And dont even think about Rome or Paris. Astute Washington politicians have long known that when it comes to politically palatable summer vacations, it is best not to cross any oceans. Or even seas.

description: As the lactic acid began to pool in Jay Alfords thighs and a searing sensation deepened in his lungs, his mind started to drift as he pushed his way through what for decades has been a staple of football training camps  the conditioning test.

description: To any regular at DeWitt Clinton Park in the Hells Kitchen section of Manhattan, he is a familiar sight, holding court from his spot on the park bench  incense burning, pipe in his mouth.

title: Galleon Founder Wins a New Hearing Over Wiretaps
description: The Galleon Group founder, Raj Rajaratnam, won a new hearing on his claim that prosecutors filed a misleading application to wiretap his conversations and that recordings should be excluded from his insider trading trial. The ruling was made by Judge Richard J. Holwell of United States District Court in Manhattan in an opinion released Friday. Prosecutors said the government secretly recorded about 2,400 conversations that the hedge fund executive had with more than 130 friends, business associates and supposed accomplices. Mr. Rajaratnam is the central figure in two overlapping prosecutions in which 21 people have been charged. He was accused of earning millions of dollars from stock trades made with inside information from corporate officials and hedge fund executives. He has denied wrongdoing.

title: Susan Dempsey, Gerald Halloran
description: Susan Elizabeth Dempsey and Gerald Halloran III were married Saturday. The Rev. Peter DeSanctis, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Isle Church in Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: Ann Buchsbaum and Glenn Zorn
description: Ann Leslie Buchsbaum and Glenn Allen Zorn are to be married Sunday at the Doral Arrowwood in Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Mitchell M. Hurvitz is to officiate, with Cantor Asa Fradkin taking part.

title: Recognized for a Layup, Inducted Too Late
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.  It made sense that the doors to the Naismith Memorial Hall of Fame would eventually open for the man known as D. J., Dennis Johnson. The sad and unfathomable part was that he would not be around to walk through them.

title: Rachel Style, David Zindel
description: Rachel Style and David Zindel were married Saturday evening at Lyndhurst Castle, an event space in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. David James, a retired Episcopal priest, officiated, with the Rev. Dr. Andrew Rienstra, a senior pastor of the Reformed Church in America, taking part.

description: DETROIT  After a dismal period of huge losses and deep cuts that culminated in the Obama administrations bailout of General Motors and Chrysler, the gloom over the American auto industry is starting to lift.

description: Marc Hausers academic career was soaring when suddenly, three years ago, Harvard authorities raided his laboratory and confiscated computers and records.

title: Gwyneth McClendon and Scott Hartman
description: Gwyneth Calvert McClendon and Scott Andrew Hartman were married Saturday evening at St. Pauls Chapel at Columbia University in New York. The Rev. James Ross Smith, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Fire and Imagination
description: The Obama administration seems to be feeling sorry for itself. Robert Gibbs, the presidents press secretary, is perturbed that Mr. Obama is not getting more hosannas from liberals.

title: U.S. Sees North Korea as Rattling Sabers for Heir
description: WASHINGTON  In the 16 years since he assumed his fathers role as North Koreas sole leader, Kim Jong-il has been denounced by the United States as a vicious dictator who starves his people, runs gulags, sets off nuclear tests and orders attacks on South Korean ships.

title: A Decade of Wooing Wins a Harlem Store for Target
description: Targets first Manhattan store opened late last month in Harlem with great fanfare. The chains mascot, a miniature bull terrier, rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange. Miss New York, Doug E. Fresh and Jerry Seinfeld attended a pre-party. Crowds lined up outside the store, the largest single investment the company has made in any of its retail properties.

title: Kristin Williams, Todd McClutchy
description: Kristin Michelle Williams, the daughter of Sheryl Lynn Williams and Tim A. Williams of Wilton, Conn., was married Saturday to Todd Daniel McClutchy, the son of Janet D. McClutchy and John H. McClutchy Jr. of Darien, Conn.

title: Meagan Crowley, Alan Hsu
description: Meagan Elizabeth Crowley, a daughter of Diane S. Crowley and Thomas A. Crowley Jr. of Spring Lake, N.J., was married on Saturday to Alan King Hsu, a son of Celia Hsu and Dr. Yao-King Hsu of Baltimore. The Rev. Kris von Maluski, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Chapel at Salve Regina University in Newport, R.I.

title: My Favorite August
description: The story in American history I most like to tell is the one about how women got the right to vote 90 years ago this month. It has everything. Adventure! Suspense! Treachery! Drunken legislators!

title: Renegade Priest Leads a Split St. Louis Parish
description: ST. LOUIS  Some say he is on a mission from God. Others say he is the devil. But no matter whom you ask in this citys tight-knit community of Polish Catholics, the name of Marek Bozek is seldom met with a shrug.

title: Jill Kalish, Matthew Levy
description: Sharon Jill Kalish, the daughter of Harriet Kalish and Mark L. Kalish of Woodmere, N.Y., is to be married Sunday evening to Matthew I. Levy, a son of Donna Wiener Levy and Gary J. Levy of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner is to officiate at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: The Other Hamptons, Born and Bred
description: Tara Israel has begun a project to document her Hamptons and the people who call it home.

title: Reids 93 Immigration Plan in News Again
description: Discussion about the 14th Amendment and its granting of citizenship to anyone born in the United States heated up again on Friday, this time focused on an attempt made by Harry Reid more than 15 years ago to end so-called birthright citizenship.

title: On the Street | Seaside
description: During Vintage Dance Week in Newport, R.I., participants spent part of their daytime hours in character, going to tea dances and touring mansions while dressed as visitors would.

title: Town Fights Suit for Namesake
description: The town of Jim Thorpe, Pa., will fight a lawsuit seeking the remains of Jim Thorpe, the athlete, filed by one of his surviving sons. By a 6-0 margin, with one member absent, the borough council voted on Thursday night to try to keep the body of Thorpe, a famous Native American athlete who has been interred at a roadside mausoleum in the eastern Pennsylvania town for more than 50 years.

title: Mattie Thompson and Daniel Mattingly
description: Mattie Lou Ming Thompson and Daniel Christopher Mattingly were married Saturday evening at the brides family farm in Pounding Mill, Va. Lalli, a Roman Catholic priest who is not related to the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Pauls Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

title: Alysia Patterson and Matthew Mueller
description: Alysia L. Patterson and Capt. Matthew J. Mueller were married Saturday evening at the Evergreen Museum and Library in Baltimore. The Rev. Theodore Bowers, a minister of the United Church of Christ and a retired United States Navy chaplain, officiated.

title: Lindy Davis, Steven Altmayer
description: Dr. Lindy Lockwood Davis, a daughter of Sally Lockwood and Lee Davis of Manlius, N.Y., was married Saturday in Ludlow, Vt., to Dr. Steven Andrew Altmayer, the son of Janis I. Altmayer and Dr. Stewart R. Altmayer of Guilderland, N.Y. title: Low Loan Repayment Is Seen at For-Profit Schools
description: Adding new fuel to the growing controversy over regulating for-profit colleges, the Department of Education on Friday released data on student-loan repayment rates at the nations colleges and universities, listing the institutions by name.

description: Jaclyn Fox Cashman, a daughter of Linda Cashman-Belton of Marshfield Hills, Mass., and Jay M. Brian McGurk, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Christophers by the Sea Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass.

title: U.S. Inquiry of Drug Makers Is Widened
description: At least a dozen major drug and device makers are under investigation by federal prosecutors and securities regulators in a broadening bribery inquiry into whether the companies made illegal payments to doctors and health officials in foreign countries.

title: Cleaner, Healthier Air
description: Earlier this year, the Environmental Protection Agency proposed a stricter nationwide health standard for smog-causing pollutants that would bring substantial benefits to millions of Americans. With a final rule expected by the end of this month, crucial senators, mainly from industrial and oil-producing states, are pushing back. They say investments required to produce cleaner air are too expensive and not scientifically justified.

title: Anne Catherine Savage, Zachary Podolsky
description: Anne Catherine Savage was married in Austin, Tex., Saturday night to Zachary Samuel Podolsky. Rabbi Rachel Kobrin officiated at the Driskill Hotel.

title: Sarah Mandel, Derek Rodenhausen
description: Sarah Hope Mandel and Derek Albert Rodenhausen were married Saturday on Shelter Island, N.Y., at the home of Dr. Edith Langner, a friend of the brides family. William A. Sulahian, a Shelter Island town justice, officiated.

title: Down on the Social Farm
description: There is nothing virtual about the latest round of acquisitions in the world of social gaming  collaborative games played on networks like Facebook. Yet there is something genuinely disorienting about it. In the past few weeks, the Walt Disney Company has purchased Playdom, one of the biggest makers of social games, and sold Miramax Films, the kind of entertainment company  a movie studio  we used to think of as real.

title: The Google/Verizon Payment Plan
description: For months, the Federal Communications Commissions efforts to guarantee nondiscriminatory access to broadband Internet have met opposition from the companies that provide broadband service and from their allies in Congress. title: Premier League Watch: Balotelli Joins Man City on Eve of New Season
description: With the English Premier League set to begin Saturday, contenders for the title are shoring up their teams and none more ambitiously than Manchester City. The club signed the Italian striker Mario Balotelli from Inter Milan after more than a month of negotiations. Balotelli, a talented but enigmatic 20-year-old, cost City a reported $35 million and has signed a five-year deal to play for Coach Roberto Mancini, the former Inter manager.

description: The Queens Pride House might go unnoticed if not for the rainbow flag that sways from one of its windows over 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights. It sits upstairs from an Indian restaurant, a Korean deli, an Italian bakery owned by Colombians and a driving school named Hawaii that is run by a man from Bangladesh  a snapshot of Queenss ethnic jumble, which the organization has embraced.

description: Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez has agreed to have anger-management treatment after his arrest Wednesday night on charges that he assaulted the father of his common-law wife. The players union will help him find a therapist or counselor.

title: Grace Lee and Al Kim
description: Grace Hee Lee and Al Yong Kim were married Saturday at Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Linda Tarry-Chard, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: David Dolby, Hero in Vietnam Battle, Dies at 64
description: David C. Dolby, who was awarded the Medal of Honor in the Vietnam War for a single-handed attack on enemy positions that saved the lives of fellow soldiers during a four-hour firefight, died Aug. 6 in Spirit Lake, Idaho. He was 64 and lived in Royersford, Pa.

description: DESPITE persistent calls for comprehensive immigration reform, the hot debate today is about an old issue: birthright citizenship.

title: Lou Smit, Detective in JonBenet Ramsey Case, Is Dead at 75
description: Lou Smit, a longtime police detective who was called out of retirement to help investigate the 1996 slaying of JonBenet Ramsey, the 6-year-old beauty pageant winner, but resigned after concluding that the police had wrongly focused on her parents, died Wednesday in Colorado Springs. He was 75.

title: Russia: Official Says Wildfires Have Not Raised Radiation Levels
description: Wildfires in territories contaminated by the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster have not led to a rise in radiation levels in Russia, the head of Russias nuclear energy agency said Friday. There are no departures from normal radiation levels anywhere in the country, said the official, Sergei Kiriyenko, Russian news agencies reported. Officials and environmentalists had warned that fires in irradiated regions could send up plumes of radioactive smoke, spreading contaminants into populated areas. The head of Russias Emergency Situations Ministry urged the police to investigate who was responsible for spreading what he called earlier rumors about increased radiation levels.

title: Shutouts Are Curing All That Ails the Mets
description: The Mets had to play their past two games without their closer, Francisco Rodriguez, who was placed on the restricted list after being arrested Wednesday night. It was assumed the Mets would be challenged to find ways to get by without him, but as it turned out they did not need a relief pitcher, let alone a closer, in either game.

title: Real Reason for Ousting H.P.s Chief
description: The resignation of Mark V. Hurd last week from his seemingly secure post as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard has got to be one of the great head-scratchers in recent times.

title: Somalia: 5 Soldiers in Puntland Are Killed in Battle With Militants
description: At least five government soldiers in the semiautonomous region of Puntland were killed Friday in a gun battle with Islamist militants near the area of Galgala, Puntlands security minister said. In a radio interview with Horseed Media, an insurgent warlord, Sheik Mohamed Said Atom, claimed credit for the killings and vowed to continue our fight until we overthrow the Puntland administration. In response, the police arrested the director of Horseed Media in Boosaaso, Abdifatah Jama Mire, stoking fears about the curtailment of press freedom in the region.

title: Discomfort Interrupts Pettittes Progress Toward a Return
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  A minor setback turned into something more serious Friday for Andy Pettitte, who was unable to push off the mound at full strength during a 50-pitch simulated outing in Tampa, Fla. The day after pushing back his outing because of tightness in his hip flexor, Pettitte told Manager Joe Girardi that his left groin did not feel completely healed.

title: Cuba: Articles by Castro Laud Ex-Candidate From Mexico
description: Comments by Fidel Castro in support of the runner-up in Mexicos 2006 presidential election, Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, threaten to revive diplomatic tensions between Cuba and Mexico, which was once one of its staunchest allies in Latin America. In articles on Thursday and Friday in the Communist Party newspaper Granma, Mr. Castro quoted from Mr. Lpez Obradors new book, which accuses the Mexican elite of improperly increasing its fortunes from 2000 to 20006, during President Vicente Foxs tenure. Mr. Castro supports the claim by Mr. Lpez Obrador, a former Mexico City mayor, that the 2006 presidential election was rigged. Mr. Castro said he had never spoken with or befriended Mr. Lpez Obrador, who is expected to run for president again in 2012.

title: In Defense of Marriage
description: On Wednesday, unless there is an order from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, gay and lesbian couples in California once again will be able to marry. Like other couples around the world, they will be able to pledge to support each other, buy some dishes, raise families, argue about the bills, maybe sit on a park bench years from now and chuckle at the hysterical old claims that their lives together would destroy the institution of marriage.

title: New China Search Engine Will Be State-Controlled
description: SHANGHAI  In an apparent bid to extend its control over the Internet and cash in on the rapid growth of mobile devices, China plans to create a government-controlled search engine.

title: Strong German Growth Lifts European Output
description: FRANKFURT  The euro area economy grew 1 percent in the second quarter of this year, a much better rate than had been expected, as Germanys best quarterly performance since reunification compensated for slow growth in Spain and Italy and a sharp decline in Greece, according to data released Friday.

The congregants who filled up the mosque near City Hall on Thursday night were mainly men, from South Asia, West Africa and the United States, and a few women  who prayed behind a partition. The feast provided for breaking the Ramadan fast, spicy curry over rice, came in plastic takeout containers from a nearby restaurant.

title: Prime Number
description: 8: The percentage of babies born in the United States in 2008 who had at least one parent who was an illegal immigrant, according to a study published last week by the Pew Hispanic Center. The study also found that 80 percent of mothers who were illegal aliens had been in the country for more than a year, a statistic that seemed at odds with a recent assertion by Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, that many illegal immigrants come here to drop a child and immediately leave. Mr. Graham has stirred controversy by proposing a reconsideration of the 14th Amendment, long interpreted as granting citizenship to anyone born in the United States.

Also, and I know I say this every time, these puzzles are best solved electronically. You can print them out but the tracking of which letters go where can get tedious and its too easy to make mistakes with a pencil and eraser.

Before this month is out, Nyad, 60, plans to step off the shores of Cuba, near Havana, and swim 103 miles to Key West. In August 1978, Nyad tried the same swim and was pulled from the raging seas after nearly 42 hours. While waiting for the arrival of a license from Cuba, which she needs to start on its soil, Nyad sat for an interview in Los Angeles.

Its a paradox that Mr. Hitchens, a confirmed atheist and the author of God Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything, can appreciate, if not relish. The countrys best-known scoffer has spurred one of the most heated discussions of belief, religion and immortality in years.

title: The Tax Cut We Can Afford
description: UNLESS Congress and President Obama act soon, Americans taxes will increase in 2011, when the cuts enacted under President George W. Bush are due to expire. Almost everyone agrees that this makes little sense given the economys fragility. But consensus ends there. The president supports permanently extending the current tax rates for all except the highest-income households, while Congressional Republicans want the entire basket of cuts to be made permanent. The prudent middle ground would be to forestall any tax increases in 2011 and to phase in higher rates on upper-income households in 2012, when the economy will be on firmer ground.

But this very readable book, The Last of the Imperious Rich: Lehman Brothers, 1844-2008 (Portfolio, $27.95), by Peter Chapman, takes a unusually long view of the situation. title: Academic Bankruptcy
description: WITH the academic year about to begin, colleges and universities, as well as students and their parents, are facing an unprecedented financial crisis. What weve seen with Californias distinguished state university system  huge cutbacks in spending and a 32 percent rise in tuition  is likely to become the norm at public and private colleges. Government support is being slashed, endowments and charitable giving are down, debts are piling up, expenses are rising and some schools are selling their product for two-thirds of what it costs to produce it. You dont need an M.B.A. to know this situation is unsustainable.

title: Tensions Over Chinese Mining Venture in Peru
description: SAN JUAN DE MARCONA, Peru  In its worldwide quest for commodities, China has scoured South America for everything from Brazilian soybeans to Guyanese timber and Venezuelan oil. But long before it made any of those forays, China put down stakes in this desolate mining town in Perus southern desert.

title: Is There an Echo in Here?
description: Congratulations to Jeffrey Harris, winner of Lollapuzzoola 3! Joon Pahk was runner up and Jon Delfin finished third. The Local (junior) division was won by Jeffrey Dubner.

title: NATO Strike Cited in Afghan Civilian Deaths
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  There is a fair chance that a NATO jet inadvertently killed five Afghan civilians during a shootout with Taliban fighters in a village in southern Afghanistan earlier this week, an American official said Saturday.

title: Red Bulls Honor Mathis
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls honored Clint Mathis, who retired this month after a colorful 13-year career in professional soccer, in an on-field ceremony before their game Saturday night against the Los Angeles Galaxy.

title: Japan, Checking on Its Oldest, Finds Many Gone
description: TOKYO  Japan has long boasted of having many of the worlds oldest people  testament, many here say, to a society with a superior diet and a commitment to its elderly that is unrivaled in the West.

title: With Keepers Obsolete, Lighthouse Duties Fall to New Set of Stewards
description: ST. HELENA ISLAND, Mich.  MaryAnn Moore and Pan Godchaux had eager smiles and the to-do list ready when their guests arrived for a four-day stay. Sweep sidewalks and dock, it said. Wash tower windows. Pump water.

title: New Stress Added to the Heart of Los Angeles Gridlock
description: LOS ANGELES  The intersection of Interstate 405 and Sunset Boulevard, cutting through a prosperous stretch of rolling Los Angeles hills and estates, is notorious for its knots of traffic and frustrating delays. Traffic is so bad that it is hard to figure out how it could get any worse.

title: Sweat | 1! (Stroke) 2! (Stroke) Sit Up! Stop Chatting!
description: The races were a week away and the Dragonflies were anxious.

title: Pakistan Floods
description: A case of the deadly waterborne disease cholera has been confirmed in Pakistans flood-ravaged northwest, and aid workers expect there to be more, the U.N. said.

title: Some States Are Lacking in Health Law Authority
description: WASHINGTON  Faced with the need to review insurance rates and enforce a panoply of new rights granted to consumers, states are scrambling to make sure they have the necessary legal authority to carry out the responsibilities being placed on them by President Obamas health care law.

title: Lighthouse Guardians
description: Nonprofit groups and volunteers have taken over care and restoration of old lighthouses.

title: Fighting Tooth and Nail, Unions Overstep
description: Michael Moritz, one of Silicon Valleys most successful venture capitalists, keeps a low profile. An early backer of Yahoo and Google, Mr. Moritz avoids the press, though he was himself once a journalist. You never see him at industry conferences. While he has given money to President Obama and a few other politicians of both parties, he has no discernible political ambitions.

title: Where the Camaraderie and Shimmer of Sweat Is Enough
description: Rock Hard Gym is not a sleek and shiny temple of sweat, coaxing in patrons with air-conditioning, lap pools and rock-climbing walls. No, Rock Hard Gym is a dump.

title: Chicago River? Nature Preserve? An Alderman Presses the Affirmative
description: Alderman James Balcers chest swelled with pride one recent morning as he stood in a weedy lot between a train viaduct and the murky South Branch of the Chicago River.

title: Block Club Carries on, but Fear and Frustration With City Persist
description: Even before the violence flared around Chicago this summer  long before someone was shot to death at the end of their block in July  Robert Brown and Michelle Lee-Sebastian saw signs of trouble.

title: Uninvited Guest at Buddhists Idyllic Retreat: Upkeep Woes
description: Perched high on a wild ridge in the Marin Headlands, solitary Hope Cottage has for decades been the unlikeliest of refuges.

title: Condor Club | North Beach, San Francisco
description: An infamous bar on the Broadway Strip, the historic Condor Club broke sexual boundaries when it became known as the worlds first topless bar in 1964. The lascivious customs of the old Barbary Coast are maintained here with naughty drink names, striptease, lap and pole dancing and nearly naked hostesses.

title: Director Striving to Open Vast Collection of Artifacts
description: Phoebe Hearst, the mining heiress and matriarch of the University of California, Berkeley, was not a woman of modest ambition, as her personal quest to create a world-class anthropology collection demonstrated.

title: Paul Ryan Rudd, Actor of Stage and Screen, Dies at 70
description: Paul Ryan Rudd, an actor of the 1970s and 80s who came to his profession late and left it early but in between drew critical praise for his work on Broadway and in the New York Shakespeare Festival, died on Thursday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 70.

title: For Top Seeds, No Guarantee of Victory, or Success
description: In a sport like tennis, it is not unusual to see a top seed win a tournament. But in chess, the margin between a No. 1 seed and most of the field is often small, and the top player is usually not the prohibitive favorite.

title: Bruno S., Street Musician Turned Lead Actor in Herzog Classics, Dies at 78
description: He wrote songs and sang them on the streets of Berlin. One told of a poor boy who grows up wishing for a little horse. The horse arrives years later pulling his mothers hearse.

title: Voter Anger No Surprise to Democrats This Time
description: NEVADA, Mo.  A year ago, dozens of protesters gathered outside the district office of Representative Ike Skelton, a Democrat who has represented a wide stretch of western Missouri since 1976. The anger they directed at health care legislation  and by extension most Congressional Democrats  left the party in a state of near panic.

title: On His Favorite Surface, Murray Hammers Nadal
description: TORONTO  For Andy Murray, the great equalizer in his rivalry with Rafael Nadal is not equipment, momentum, mood or skill, but rather surface. On hardcourts, against tenniss top-ranked player, Murray has dominated recently.

title: Francisco Rodriguez Apologizes in Return to the Mets
description: After he issued a brief public apology in the afternoon and said he would undergo anger-management therapy, Francisco Rodriguez, the Mets volatile closer, pitched Saturday for the first time since his arrest early Thursday on charges he assaulted the grandfather of his 11-month-old twins.

title: A Burial Follows a Fight in Afghanistan
description: The dispute between ethnic Hazaras and Afghan nomads is centuries old.

title: Letters: The Roots of Happiness
description: The Roots of Happiness

title: Dickey, Man of Letters, Lets Numbers Do Talking
description: The 1-0 shutout of the Phillies by the Mets R. A. Dickey on Friday night was the surprisingly impressive highlight of his surprisingly impressive season  so far.

title: For Pettitte, Frustration Before Recovery
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Even after his latest setback, Andy Pettitte was right, after all: he was ahead of schedule in his recovery from a left groin-muscle strain. But the reason he is behind schedule now is that he did not recognize an important distinction: he was not yet ready to push off a mound at full strength.

16-Year-Old Boy Is Shot to Death in the Bronx
description: A 16-year-old boy was shot to death in the Bronx early Saturday as he spent time with friends in a courtyard surrounded by apartment buildings in the Williamsbridge neighborhood, the police said.

description: When Francisco Rodriguez of the Mets was arrested after Wednesday nights game in connection with the assault of the grandfather of his children, he took attention away from an act of anger by a teammate.

description: The San Francisco Giants are a fascinating team with great stories, as Ive found this season by writing profiles of Barry Zito, the revived curveball artist; Tim Lincecum, the two-time Cy Young winner; and Buster Posey, the cleanup-hitting rookie catcher. But as many standout talents as the Giants have, they have not played as well as the San Diego Padres.

title: Red Bulls New Mix Still Needs Some Work
description: HARRISON, N.J.  On some night in the future, when their play is similarly pedestrian, the Red Bulls may be saved by a brief moment of inspiration  a flash of skill or expression of creativity  from one of their new star players.

title: Veterans Take On Grueling Race Around Manhattan
description: The 79th Street Boat Basin Caf buzzed Saturday morning with brunchgoers nibbling on omelets and sipping Bloody Marys under a sunny sky. On the pier below, the participants in the fifth annual Mayors Cup Kayak Championships launched their boats into the Hudson River for the start of an arduous, 28-mile race around Manhattan.

title: Yankees Pull Further and Further Away
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The first baseball landed deep into the left-field stands, but that was only the beginning. The next one caromed off a concrete wall beneath the batters eye, and the third one shot off Alex Rodriguezs bat with such authority and conviction that the Royals left fielder, Alex Gordon, did not even look up to follow the flight path as it soared above a waterfall and into a section of Kauffman Stadium previously deemed safe for human occupation.

title: No Jet Lag, but Record Trip on Course
description: HAVEN, Wis.  Asked about the biggest hurdles they faced this week at the P.G.A. Championship, most golfers have spoken of the frustrating fog delays at Whistling Straits or the precarious winds off Lake Michigan.

title: A Man of Few Words, Dolan Says the Wrong Ones
description: The last time James L. Dolan spoke at length about the Knicks  on the record, off the cuff, with reporters present and notebooks open  was on March 12, 2007. It was a momentous day.

title: Vows: Ann & Glenn
description: Ann Buchsbaum and Glenn Zorn were introduced at a Christmas party in 2008. Soon after their first few dates, Glenn could not stop thinking of her while he was away on a cruise. He brought her back a figurine of a penguin, one of the few animals that mate for life.

title: Correction
description: The Vows column last Sunday, about the marriage of Anne Stephens and Preston Lloyd, misstated the ages of the couple. She is 27, and he is 28 (not 28 and 29, respectively).

title: Scissors, Glue, Pencils? Check. Cleaning Spray?
description: When Emily Cooper headed off to first grade in Moody, Ala., last week, she was prepared with all the stuff on her elementary schools must-bring list: two double rolls of paper towels, three packages of Clorox wipes, three boxes of baby wipes, two boxes of garbage bags, liquid soap, Kleenex and Ziplocs.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Aug. 1, about ways to avoid high phone bills when traveling abroad, referred imprecisely to a Boingo Wireless plan for travelers who sign up for a $7.95 monthly fee. While the fee for that service, called the Boingo Mobile plan, includes Wi-Fi access for smartphones and mobile devices in hotels, restaurants, airports and more in over 70 countries, it does not provide access for computers. (A $59 plan called Boingo Global includes Wi-Fi access for both mobile devices and computers.)

title: Galleon Founder Wins New Hearing Over Wiretaps
description: The Galleon Group founder, Raj Rajaratnam, won a new hearing on his claim that prosecutors filed a misleading application to wiretap his conversations and that the recordings should be excluded from his insider trading trial, Bloomberg News reported on Saturday.

When all the controversy had settled and the chaos emptied into dusk Sunday, Martin Kaymer kept his wits about him, played the percentages and won the P.G.A. Championship at Whistling Straits.

title: Freedom
description: The news about Walter Berglund wasn't picked up locally-he and Patty had moved away to Washington two years earlier and meant nothing to St. Paul now-but the urban gentry of Ramsey Hill were not so loyal to their city as not to read the New York Times. According to a long and very unflattering story in the Times, Walter had made quite a mess of his professional life out there in the nation's capital. His old neighbors had some difficulty reconciling the quotes about him in the Times ("arrogant," "high-handed," "ethically compromised") with the generous, smiling, red-faced 3M employee they remembered pedaling his commuter bicycle up Summit Avenue in February snow; it seemed strange that Walter, who was greener than Greenpeace and whose own roots were rural, should be in trouble now for conniving with the coal industry and mistreating country people. Then again, there had always been something not quite right about the Berglunds.

title: Scrutiny for Races Is Likely to Increase

title: Petraeus Opposes a Rapid Pullout in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Gen. David H. Petraeus, the commander of American and NATO forces, began a campaign on Sunday to convince an increasingly skeptical public that the American-led coalition can still succeed here despite months of setbacks, saying he had not come to Afghanistan to preside over a graceful exit.

title: Fond Memories of a Goodwill Ambassador
description: Many people love bridge although they are not star players. Some of those work hard to make the game better for everyone. The epitome of that, Aileen Osofsky, died on June 22, at 83.

description: PANAMA CITY, Fla.  They came, they swam, they played miniature golf. They left an hour early.

title: Conditions Toughen, but Mickelson Surges
description: 4:40 p.m. | Updated HAVEN, Wis.  The weather at Whistling Straits on Sunday has been gorgeous. Temperature is around 80, and the sun is shining brightly, with blue skies and only a few cotton-ball clouds here and there.

title: Flooding in Pakistan Spreads
description: Flooding that began more than two weeks ago in the northwest now affects about one-quarter of Pakistan.

title: Empire vs. Rebel Alliance in High-Def
description: Though nearly 35 years of Star Wars fandom have yielded all kinds of memorabilia inspired by George Lucass outer-space epic, including light saber look-alikes and wearable reproductions of Princess Leias slave costume, one holy grail has lately eluded fans: a video version of the Star Wars films that takes the fullest advantage of their top-of-the-line home theater systems.

title: Attacks in Iraq Rise During Ramadan
description: BAGHDAD  Roadside bombs, booby-trapped cars and hit-and-run attacks reverberated across Iraq on Sunday, another violent day following insurgents threats to escalate their attacks during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

title: Bryan Twins Get Along and Move On After Achieving Doubles Record
description: TORONTO  The Bryan brothers never set out to become the winningest mens doubles pairing in professional tennis history. It just sort of happened.

title: Its Hello Cancer, Goodbye Inhibitions
description: Death so often seems senseless  except on television.

title: Yanks Fumble Away an Opportunity
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Yankees had more errors than hits Sunday, which is the most succinct way of explaining why they lost to the Kansas City Royals, 1-0. They negated many fine moments from this six-game trip with a sluggish performance that annoyed Joe Girardi like no other loss this season.

title: President Obama Prefers to Keep It Modest
description: The last time the press snapped pictures of a shirtless President Obama, tabloids, blogs and gossip magazines were agog with pectoral envy.

title: Times Paper in Mass. to Charge for Online Content
description: The Telegram & Gazette, a New York Times-owned newspaper in Worcester, Mass., said that it would begin charging readers to view some of the local news articles that appear on the papers Web site.

title: 50 Shots and One Week Later, an Arrest Is Made
description: Updated 5:49 p.m. | Angel Alvarez, the 23-year-old man who was shot more than 20 times by the police during a recent shootout in Harlem that left one man dead and several others injured, including two police officers, was arrested on Saturday upon his release from the hospital, said Paul J. Browne, the chief spokesman for the Police Department.

title: In Jerusalem, a Barrier Comes Down
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military on Sunday began dismantling a concrete barrier that protected residents of a once-troubled district on the edge of Jerusalem from Palestinian sniper fire.

title: Off-Road Competition Turns Deadly
description: NBC's Mara Schiavocampo reports on a fatal accident at a race called the California 200.

title: Not a Top 15 Finish, but Still a Memorable Ending for Club Pro
description: HAVEN, Wis.  Rob Labritz walked off the 18th green at Whistling Straits on Sunday to a heros welcome, posing for pictures and holding court with members of the news media outside the clubhouse.

title: Muscular Expendables Enlivens Battle for Studio
description: LOS ANGELES  After months of being chased by Carl C. Icahn, Lions Gate is chasing a box office hit.

title: The Internet  Webbies in Love, or Trying
description: Despite Princes recent proclamation of its demise, the World Wide Web is alive and worthy of scrutiny in The Internet, a busy but compact production of the Everywhere Theater Group at St. Marks Church. The show, as befits its subject, incorporates digital media  video, music samples  as well as those trusty analog standbys, movement and dialogue.

title: A Family Full of Unhappiness, Hoping for Transcendence
description: Jonathan Franzens galvanic new novel, Freedom, showcases his impressive literary toolkit  every essential storytelling skill, plus plenty of bells and whistles  and his ability to throw open a big, Updikean picture window on American middle-class life. With this book, hes not only created an unforgettable family, hes also completed his own transformation from a sharp-elbowed, apocalyptic satirist focused on sending up the socio-economic-political plight of this country into a kind of 19th-century realist concerned with the public and private lives of his characters.

title: Reclaiming the Imagination
description: Imagine being a slave in ancient Rome. Now remember being one. The second task, unlike the first, is crazy. If, as Im guessing, you never were a slave in ancient Rome, it follows that you cant remember being one  but you can still let your imagination rip. With a bit of effort one can even imagine the impossible, such as discovering that Dick Cheney and Madonna are really the same person. It sounds like a platitude that fiction is the realm of imagination, fact the realm of knowledge.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Jazz Quartet Finds Clarity and Chemistry Together
description: Ralph Alessi has never had a problem with precision or grappled publicly with the mechanics of his art. His trumpet tone conveys a rounded luminescence, like the moon in full phase, and his technique is an astonishment of fluency. The challenge for him, at least as a bandleader, revolves around emotional expressiveness, along with the issue of purpose. At times it can seem as if Mr. Alessi favors open-endedness because he doesnt trust his own conclusions or his means of making them felt by an audience.

title: Pungent Harmonies Drawn From Ancient Traditions
description: When the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center was being revamped a decade or so ago, some thought that it should give its overworked hero a rest and do something else entirely. Instead the festival has deftly continued to serve Mozart, if a bit more judiciously, and done things that are completely different.

title: Less Web Access Among Chronically Ill
description: Although the number of cyberchondriacs  people who research health information online  is at an all-time high, those who are afflicted with chronic conditions are less likely to have Internet access, according to data from Pew.

title: Unpredictable Sort
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  This Monday puzzle by Andrea Carla Michaels and Jennifer Nutt could come with its own theme music. The last theme answer spells out what the first four have in common; each ends with the name of a TV DETECTIVE. William Conrad played Frank CANNON in the 1970s. Jack Webb started playing Joe FRIDAY on radio but added television in 1951. Don Johnson was Nash BRIDGES and Adrian MONK is played by Tony Shalhoub.

title: Tapping the Web, 22,000 Miles Up
description: Satellite companies have been the also-rans of Internet providers.

title: Broadways New Desire, Learning as She Goes Along
description: There is a lot of audience impatience at the Walter Kerr Theater these days. From the moment the curtain comes up on Trevor Nunns revival of the Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler musical A Little Night Music, everyone is awaiting Bernadette Peters and her already famous performance of Send In the Clowns, the shows great second-act signature number.

title: Vergne Wins British F3
description: One of the great pleasures of this job is meeting young drivers and watching their careers develop over the years. The case of Jean-Eric Vergne is not just a case in point, but an exceptional example. The Frenchman, 20 years old, won his 12th race in British Formula 3 on Sunday and thereby became the first Frenchman to win that series.

title: Paying Tribute in Deep Shadow
description: For a half hour before Tom Krell went onstage at Glasslands Gallery in the early hours of Saturday morning, associates were setting up a white backdrop on which videos would be displayed during his set. All the while, Mr. Krells beloved 1990s R&B, from which he draws so much inspiration  Shai, Keith Sweat and so on  played over the rooms speakers.

title: Start-Up Aims to Slay Chip Goliath
description: A group of investors, including companies from the United States, Europe and the United Arab Emirates, has formed in a bid to disrupt one of Intels most lucrative franchises.

title: You Are Your Own Instrument  Slap-Happy at Lincoln Center
description: Music becomes dance, and dance becomes music, Bill Bragin announced to the crowd gathered at Damrosch Park Bandshell on Thursday night. It all becomes one.

title: Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Producer Price Index for July, housing starts for July, and industrial production and capacity utilization for July (Tuesday); and weekly jobless claims, Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for August and leading economic indicators for July (Thursday).

title: Finnish Conductor and Pianist Give Mozart a Rigorous Workout
description: The Finnish conductor Osmo Vanska arrived as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra in 2003 with high ambitions, and by any measure he has achieved great things there. But his success in raising the orchestras level of playing to international standards and winning enthusiastic support from audiences in the Minneapolis area has come from long periods of hard, focused work.

title: Obamas Visit Gulf Coast
description: The Obamas and their daughter Sasha visited Panama City, Fla., in a trip intended by the White House to spotlight the oil-stricken Gulf Coast as a recreational venue.

title: The Subject Is Heartache, but the Music Is Sweet and Light
description: The dancing began early Saturday afternoon at Central Park SummerStage. From almost the first drop of music, couples in the crowd paired off in intimate embraces, sashaying side to side in four-count steps, raising the foot on the fourth beat, the signature flourish of bachata dance.

title: Entering a Sororitys Forbidden Precincts
description: Be honest: is there a straight man in America who hasnt wondered, perhaps even fantasized, about what really goes on in college sororities?

title: Barred Muslim Scholar Back in U.S.
description: ATLANTA  After being denied entry at Kennedy Airport without explanation nearly four years ago, the South African Muslim scholar Adam Mahomed Habib was in Atlanta this weekend to give a talk at a sociology conference. His subject? Making democratic governments more accountable to the people.

title: Snooki and Snooky: Reality TV Star and Cartoon Cat
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has rejected a request from Nicole Polizzi, a k a Snooki from MTVs Jersey Shore, to trademark her nickname. According to a Trademark Office document published on the Web site TheSmokingGun.com, Snooki cannot be held as a trademark by Ms. Polizzi because of the likelihood of confusion with a 2004 trademark belonging to Brian J. Publishing, publisher of the childrens book Adventures of Snooky: Under the Sea, by Karen Monaghan-Arnone and Maureen Monaghan-Faber, about a cat lost at sea. Ms. Polizzi filed her request on Feb. 7 for the purpose of entertainment in the nature of personal appearances by a television personality, according to the Trademark Office documents. Ms. Polizzi may appeal the decision if she chooses.

title: Green Day to Serenade in the Jets New Season
description: Green Day is lending some of its star power to the New York Jets: these punk musicians (and Broadway composers) will perform during the halftime show of the Jets opening game against the Baltimore Ravens on Sept. 13, The Associated Press reported. The group will be enlisting the help of the cast of the Broadway musical  American Idiot, which revolves around Green Day songs, and Gang Green, a hardcore punk band from Boston. And if that isnt enough musical inspiration for the Jets, Nicole Scherzinger of the pop group the Pussycat Dolls will sing the national anthem and perform in a pregame concert, which will also feature the guitarist Slash, outside the New Meadowlands Stadium. The halftime show will, of course, end with fireworks.

title: Books and Authors, in New York and Abroad
description: The Brooklyn Book Festival will once again fill Borough Hall Plaza in Brooklyn Heights with all things literary on Sept. 12. This year, its fifth, the festival will partner with local clubs, bookstores and cultural institutions, like the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Bell House and St. Anns Warehouse, to present additional book-related events. The festival will bring more than 200 authors to Brooklyn for discussions and book signings. Among them will be Salman Rushdie, Mary Gaitskill, Colson Whitehead, Rosanne Cash, Russell Banks and Gary Shteyngart, to name a few. A complete schedule can be found at brooklynbookfestival.org. ... The Edinburgh International Book Festival in Scotland is featuring appearances from 10 of the 13 authors on the long list for this years Man Booker Prize, Britains most esteemed literary award, BBC News reported. Christos Tsiolkas (The Slap) opened the festival on Saturday, with other Booker-nominated writers, including David Mitchell (The Thousand Autumns of Zacob de Zoet) and Emma Donoghue (Room), among others, to come during the next two weeks. More news from the festival, which continues through Aug. 30, is at edbookfest.co.uk.

title: Director Is Lined Up for Justin Bieber Film
description: Paramount Pictures has found a director for its new documentary about Justin Bieber. Jon M. Chu, whose latest film, Step Up 3D, was recently released, has been hired to direct the 3D film chronicling Mr. Biebers rise to the top of the music charts and into young girls hearts, Reuters reported. In a statement, Mr. Chu, above, said, Most people dont know that his is a true underdog story, and I hope to tell it in a compelling, genuine way, using all source materials available to convey his tale of becoming an icon for this digital age. A release date has been set for Valentines Day weekend. ... Danny Boyle, the Oscar-winning director of Slumdog Millionaire, will soon be releasing a film based on the true story of the rise of another underdog of sorts. 127 Hours, which stars James Franco as the mountain climber Aron Ralston, who amputated his arm to escape being trapped by a boulder at the bottom of a canyon in Utah, will close the London Film Festival, BBC News reported. The full schedule for the festival, which runs from Oct. 13 to 28, will be announced next month.

title: Internet Proposal From Google and Verizon Raises Fears for Privacy
description: WHEN elephants fight, the saying goes, only the grass gets trampled.

title: Teller Tries His Hand at Off-Broadway Thriller

On Sept. 25, Ms. LuPone presents her solo concert The Gypsy in My Soul, singing songs associated with her career on Broadway, and on Sept. 26 Mr. Ma will play two concerts with the Knights, a New York City chamber orchestra conducted by Eric Jacobsen. title: Swan Song
description: When fashion editors were given an intimate viewing of Alexander McQueens final collection in Paris this past spring, this dress was not part of it. Perhaps the last piece touched by the designers hands, it was made by McQueen especially for his longtime friend Annabelle Neilson, and its only outing has been to Elton Johns White Tie and Tiara Ball in June. Neilson was notorious for wearing McQueens clothes and she did so with a fierceness befitting her status as his muse. A sheer black jumpsuit from 2006, a mere figment of McQueens imagination that left nothing to anyone elses, generated reams of chatter and flaunted the designers devilish streak. Indeed he was often heralded as fashions enfant terrible No. 1. But in this simply elegant silk charmeuse gown with its collar of silvered feathers, Neilson appeared as the vision of an angel.

title: Numberplay: The Relativity of Probability
description: The determination of probabilities is a well-established branch of mathematics. Very often probability calculations are simple and yield exact values that seem absolute and objective. Not so! Today I give you three scenarios with questions whose calculations are mostly simple. They are meant to show two things: first, that probability is relative  the probability of something may be very different depending on the way it is measured; and second, that probability is a measure of our ignorance. Any piece of knowledge, no matter how seemingly irrelevant, can change the probability for us.

title: Lawyer Battles Back Against DC Comics in Superman Dispute

In its complaint, DC Comics claimed that Mr. Toberoff had manipulated the heirs for years in an effort to capture a huge share of the copyrights for himself. In asking the United States District Court for the Central District of California to dismiss the complaint, Richard B. Kendall, a lawyer for Mr. Toberoff, called it an absolutely meritless attack that was meant to undermine Mr. Toberoffs relationship with the Siegel and Shuster heirs in the wake of a previous victory in court over DC Comics. A hearing in the case is set for Oct. 18.

title: Go for Broke | Herv Leroux at Colette

I called the store immediately for more information in the hopes that the price was somewhere in the realm of my Amex limit. As it turns out the dress is by Herv Leroux, who you may remember as Herv Leger, the king of bandage. The bad news? 4,630 euros. If this werent enough to bring a tear to my covetous eye, I was immediately reminded of another dress I couldnt afford, in my fashion fledgling days back in the early 90s, modeled by a smoldering Karen Mulder on the Leger runway. I kept a photo of it pinned to the bulletin board of my cubicle for at least a year. To be sure, a lot has changed since my first Leger obsession, but what hasnt changed is that the man still has a way with elastic. And a girl can still dream, right?

Mr. Duchonvy was previously slated to play a man who sees the face of God during an office shooting; Ms. Peet will do double duty as that mans wife, Ginger, and Gingers cousin, Jesse.
