title: Birmingham Ballpark Lives to See 100
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Mitch Earnest, an 18-year-old catcher from Decatur, Ga., was reaching for his bat to go out on deck at Rickwood Field when he was told Babe Ruth also reached for his bat in this same place during an exhibition game. Earnest paused for a moment to consider his next at-bat.

title: Fed Adopts Rules Meant to Protect Home Buyer
description: The Federal Reserve on Monday moved to end a controversial lending practice that had helped propel the housing boom to unsustainable heights and then accelerated its collapse.

title: White-Shoe Shuffle
description: White leather lace-ups, as recently worn by Mark Ronson, are associated with mimes and 80s tribute bands, but they actually have a stylish past. In the early 1970s, Serge Gainsbourg, Frances patron saint of cool, was looking for gloves for his feet, and his sex-kitten lover Jane Birkin turned him on to white Repetto jazz shoes. The shoes became one of Gainsbourgs signature flourishes, with the singer famously going through 30 pairs a year until his death in 1991.

title: Questions Linger as Shrimp Season Opens in Gulf
description: ABOARD THE KRISTY MISTY, in the Gulf of Mexico  Well before dawn on Monday, Nicky Alfonso set out down Bayou Terre aux Boeufs in his 38-foot shrimping boat, heading for open water.

title: Killer Trade Deficits
description: I agree with everything this NYT editorial has to say about the economics of widening international imbalances. Where I disagree is on the issue of negotiating strategy. My colleagues believe that we should lecture the Chinese on what a bad thing theyre doing, but not actually threaten sanctions, lest we start a trade war. My belief is that this gets us nowhere.

title: Where All That Money Went: The H.P. Case
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: New Law Allows Sex Trafficking Victims to Clear Names
description: Gov. David A. Paterson has signed a law that will allow victims of sex trafficking to clear prostitution convictions from their criminal records. Advocates for sex workers said the bill, signed on Friday, is the first of its kind. It allows an individual to have a conviction vacated if she was forced into prostitution, and it also applies to related crimes like loitering.Its a hard reality that trafficked people are often arrested, convicted, and released without the justice system realizing whats really going on, Sienna Baskin, co-director of the Sex Workers Project at the Urban Justice Center, which helped write the bill, said in a statement.

title: Cancer: Expert Panel Calls for Aggressive Fight Against Cancer in Poorer Countries
description: A panel of prominent figures in global health called on Monday for an end to the assumption that cancer is a disease of the rich and for both poor and donor countries to place the same emphasis on fighting it that they now do on infectious diseases like AIDS and malaria.

title: German Pop Singer on Trial for Concealing H.I.V. Status From Sexual Partners
description: A German singer charged with causing grievous bodily harm to a man who contracted H.I.V. after having unprotected sex with her admitted in court on Monday that she had concealed the fact that she was infected with the virus from the man, and from two other sexual partners.

title: Ex-Israeli Soldiers Photos Condemned
description: TEL AVIV  An Israeli woman who completed her military service last year posted photographs of herself from the army posing with blindfolded and bound Palestinian prisoners under the title The Army ... The Most Beautiful Time of My Life, producing enraged commentary on the Internet and condemnation from the military.

title: New York Send-Off | Line-Reading in Central Park
description: Rain slicker? Check.

title: Analysts: Lilly Faces Growing Financial Pressure
description: The Indianapolis drugmaker Eli Lilly & Company is facing growing pressure from Wall Street to make a deal with another company as it heads toward the biggest patent cliff in the industry.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: No, this is not another picture of hungry flood victims in Pakistan. Shakil Adil of The Associated Press has created something different: a picture of increasingly frenzied desperation. Its not in the outstretched hands at the center of the frame. Its whats in the right hand of the solitary figure at the right edge of the picture. Take another look.

title: Fringe Festival Journal: South Pathetic
description: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival began over the weekend. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors.

title: Choosing a Coach: Maradona Over Bradley?
description: Diego Maradona  through his agent  offered his managerial services to Aston Villa, citing his love of the English countryside and the countrys respect for privacy as good reasons the English Premier League club should hire him. And if that isnt enough to persuade Villas owner, Randy Lerner, the agent points out: Maradona is available.

title: Drilling Permits for Deep Waters Face New Review
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Monday that it would require significantly more environmental review before approving new offshore drilling permits, ending a practice in which government regulators essentially rubber-stamped potentially hazardous deepwater projects like BPs out-of-control well.

title: When Friends Disappear During a Health Crisis
description: During times of crisis, we often depend on our friends for support. Now, psychologists are just beginning to explore why some friends seem to disappear during difficult times, unable to cope with other peoples trauma.

title: The Great Wellfleet Croissant Invasion
description: Not since the Great Portland Gale of 1898, the Pendleton Shipwreck of 1952 or perhaps the Red Tide Scare of 2005 has Cape Cod been in such a tizzy. This time, however, the calamity is entirely man-made, flaky and delicious. The Great Wellfleet Croissant Invasion of 2010 has divided communities, polarized families and added substantial girth to throngs of well-heeled summer tourists.

title: A Wild Man Grows Up (Just Enough)
description: SHANE SMITH, a founder of Vice, the streetwise, testosterone-fueled culture and fashion magazine, still chugs canned American beer. He still listens to Bad Brains. And he still favors tattered Vans skateboard shoes and black T-shirts. That much is the same.

title: Switch Sports After Injury? Never!
description: In todays Personal Best column, Gina Kolata writes about her own passion for running and why some athletes, including herself, stubbornly refuse to switch sports, even after repeat injuries.

title: Solid Sound Festival
description: The music and arts festival at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams, Mass., was curated by the indie rock band Wilco.

title: Apple Hires Expert on Mobile Payments
description: Over the last decade Apple has expanded into a number of industries besides computers, including music, mobile phones, movies and books. Now Apple could be going after something else: cash.

title: Step 1: Post Elusive Proof. Step 2: Watch Fireworks.
description: The potential of Internet-based collaboration was vividly demonstrated this month when complexity theorists used blogs and wikis to pounce on a claimed proof for one of the most profound and difficult problems facing mathematicians and computer scientists.

title: A Flight Attendants Lot Is Not a Happy One
description: RIGHT after a JetBlue flight attendant, Steven Slater, plunged down an emergency chute last week with beers in hand, Rene Foss started thinking about working the escapade into a song for the next edition of her musical revue, Around the World in a Bad Mood.

title: A Quest to Make the Morgan Seaworthy
description: MYSTIC, Conn.  The shipbuilders are long dead, their knowledge gone. The shipyard no longer exists. No blueprints survive, nor ships models.

title: Restoring the Last Wooden Whaler
description: Restorers are spending $10 million to make the worlds last surviving wooden whaling vessel, the Charles W. Morgan, seaworthy.

title: Do Arts at Governors Island Need Governing?
description: What kind of culture develops on an island? asked Edward Rothstein in Fridays Weekend section. Eight hundred yards from Manhattans shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, Mr. Rothstein wrote, which he characterized as eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On the ArtsBeat blog, New York Times critics from several disciplines discussed the islands role as a cultural destination: Mr. Rothstein, a cultural critic at large; Jon Pareles, the chief pop music critic; Charles Isherwood, a theater critic; Alastair Macaulay, the chief dance critic; and Ken Johnson, an art critic. Here are excerpts from the conversation; the full text is at nytimes.com/artsbeat.

title: Critics Picks Video: Broadway Danny Rose
description: In this weeks Critics Pick, A. O. Scott looks at Woody Allens show-biz comedy Broadway Danny Rose, starring Mr. Allen as a washed-up talent agent.

title: History Repeats Itself: Antigone, Then Snooki
description: In Long Story Short, a snappy recap of human civilization as seen through the skeptical eyes of a standup comic, Colin Quinn traces the roots of various contemporary phenomena, including the economic crisis, the Middle East conflict and Jersey Shore, back through the centuries to the Greeks and beyond.

title: Wilco Builds a Festival for Itself
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.  In the final stretch of the Solid Sound Festival on Sunday, under light rainfall and a darkening sky, Jeff Tweedy augmented his solo acoustic set with reinforcements. He enlisted members of the Autumn Defense, Pronto and the Nels Cline Singers, three very different groups that had played here over the previous three days. Or, to put it another way, he was leading a slightly modified version of Wilco, his steadfastly ambitious rock band. The patrons of this first-time event, held at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, were primed to appreciate the distinction.

title: Icahn Pushes Ahead With Energy Investments
description: The filings are out and it looks like the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has set his sights on four energy companies, two of which are heavily involved in exploration and production: Anadarko Petroleum and Chesapeake Energy. Mr. Icahns stakes in these companies could mean that he is thinking about a major shakeup in their capital structures.

title: Mets Rodriguez Injured Thumb in Altercation
description: The Mets 2010 season continued in its downward spiral on Monday with the disclosure that Francisco Rodriguez tore a ligament in his right thumb last week while he was in an altercation with the father of his common-law wife.

title: Pairings: Poblano Peppers With Smoky Filling and Mezcal Salsa
description: You do not have to serve smoked salmon with Scotch or fried chicken with bourbon. But mezcal is so deeply rooted in the heart of Mexico that whatever you serve alongside begs for chilies and cilantro at the very least.

title: Mezcal, Tequilas Smoky, Spicy Cousin
description: I FEEL almost as if I have to whisper my feelings about mezcal. It is so immersed in legend and colorful misrepresentation that its a shame to spoil it all with truth. And yet the truth can be so richly rewarding that I may as well shout it out.

title: Old Battle Rejoined Over Michelangelos David
description: A longstanding tug of war has begun again between the city of Florence and the Italian state over Michelangelos David, after a report by state-appointed lawyers was made public. The document argues that although the statue was commissioned by the Florentine Republic in 1501, Italy became the rightful titleholder after its unification in the 19th century. At stake are both pride of ownership and millions of dollars in annual ticket sales. Florences mayor, Matteo Renzi, sought to rebut the claim, saying, according to news reports, that a decree issued shortly after unification granted the city ownership of the building where David was displayed. The national governments lawyers replied that the decree made no mention of the statue itself. With its representation of Goliaths slayer, David was a symbol of the freedom and autonomy of the Florentine Republic and an important source of civic pride. At a press conference on Monday, Mayor Renzi declared that Michelangelos David belongs to Florence  there are no legal doubts, all the documents confirm it. Italys culture minister, Sandro Bondi, meanwhile, issued a statement on Monday describing the battle over the statue as absurd and inopportune.

title: Conductor Arrested on Child Support Charge
description: En route to Alice Tully Hall from Copenhagen, the conductor Paul Hillier made an unusual detour before leading the ensemble Ars Nova Copenhagen at Lincoln Centers Mostly Mozart Festival on Friday night: He spent part of last week in a New Jersey jail after he was arrested on an outstanding warrant for criminal nonpayment of child support. The Oregonian reported that Mr. Hillier, above, who was born in England and lives in Denmark, was indicted on Aug. 5 by an Oregon grand jury on four felony counts of criminal nonsupport for failing to make approximately $90,000 in payments for his two daughters who live in that state. He was apprehended at Newark International Airport on Wednesday and taken to Essex County Jail. In addition to serving as the chief conductor of Ars Nova Copenhagen, Mr. Hillier has also been the principal conductor of the Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir and won a Grammy Award in February. The Oregonian reported that Mr. Hillier wired the money to an account in the Support Enforcement Division of Oregons Multnomah County. Jennifer James, a deputy district attorney there, said Mr. Hillier has been fairly cooperative, once we got his attention.

title: Golf Is Good to CBS
description: 60 Minutes, Big Brother and professional golf lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday. The networks afternoon coverage of the P.G.A. Championship ran well into the start of prime time, earning CBS more than 10 million viewers from 7 to approximately 8:30 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. NBC ranked a distant second place on the night, with three back-to-back episodes of Law & Order: Criminal Intent, which averaged 5 million viewers from 8 to 11. ABC was third with low ratings for The Gates at 10 (2.6 million), while Fox finished in fourth place with comedy reruns.

title: Lawyer Fights Back Against DC Comics
description: Marc Toberoff, the lawyer who has represented heirs to the Superman creators Jerome Siegel and Joseph Shuster in their fight to reclaim copyrights from DC Comics, a division of Warner Brothers Entertainment, asked a court in Los Angeles on Friday to dismiss the complaint filed against him personally last May in connection with the long-running legal battle. In its complaint, DC Comics claimed that Mr. Toberoff had manipulated the heirs for years in an effort to capture a huge share of the copyrights for himself. In asking the United States District Court for the Central District of California to dismiss the complaint, Richard B. Kendall, a lawyer for Mr. Toberoff, called it an absolutely meritless attack that was meant to undermine Mr. Toberoffs relationship with the Siegel and Shuster heirs in the wake of a previous victory in court over DC Comics. A hearing in the case is set for Oct. 18.

title: Theater News
description: Amanda Peet will join David Duchovny in MCC Theaters production of Neil LaButes Break of Noon, the theater announced on Monday. Mr. Duchovny was previously slated to play a man who sees the face of God during an office shooting; Ms. Peet will do double duty playing that mans wife, Ginger, and Gingers cousin, Jesse. The play, to be directed by Jo Bonney, will begin previews at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Oct. 28 and open on Nov. 15; its limited run is scheduled through Dec. 12. MCC Theaters second production of the 2010-11 season will pair Laurie Metcalf (Roseanne, Brighton Beach Memoirs) with her November director, Joe Mantello for the world premiere of Sharr Whites Other Place. In this thriller, Ms. Metcalf will play a woman who finds herself at the center of a mystery just as she hits upon a potential breakthrough in the treatment of Alzheimers disease. It is to begin at the Lortel on March 10 and open on March 28, with a limited run through April 24. ... Mos Def, Jeffrey Wright and Paul Dano are among the cast members in Lincoln Center Theaters coming production of John Guares play A Free Man of Color, the theater announced on Monday. Mr. Guares drama, set in New Orleans in the early 19th century, will be directed by George C. Wolfe. Previews begin on Oct. 21, with opening night set for Nov. 18 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: Eastwoods Hereafter To Close Film Festival
description: Clint Eastwoods Hereafter, a movie about the intertwining experiences of people who have dealt with death, near-death and the afterlife, will be the closing-night selection of the New York Film Festival, on a program that will also feature new works by Jean-Luc Godard, Mike Leigh and Kelly Reichardt, among other directors, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Monday. Hereafter, directed by Mr. Eastwood, above, and written by Peter Morgan (The Queen, Frost/Nixon), chronicles the gradual connections of an American psychic (played by Matt Damon), a French journalist (Ccile de France) who has a brush with death in the 2004 tsunami and a London schoolboy who loses his twin brother (Frankie and George McLaren). It is scheduled to be shown on Oct. 10 at Alice Tully Hall. The festival will also present Mr. Godards Film Socialisme, Mr. Leighs Another Year and Ms. Reichardts Meeks Cutoff, among the 25 additional main-slate features that were announced, as well as programs on the movies of Masahiro Shinoda, Fernando de Fuentes and Olivier Assayas. The festival, which starts on Sept. 24, has announced that it will open with David Finchers Social Network, and its centerpiece film will be Julie Taymors adaptation of The Tempest.

title: A Tribute to Alban Berg and His Viennese Influences
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  My job tonight is to allay any residual fears you might have, the conductor Leon Botstein said from the stage of the Sosnoff Theater at the Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College here on Friday night.

title: Mos, Jeffrey Wright To Reunite in New Guare Play
description: Lincoln Center Theaters production of John Guares play A Free Man of Color will reunite Mos Def, who is going by the name Mos for this production, and Jeffrey Wright, who appeared together in the 2002 Broadway production of Suzan-Lori Parkss Topdog/Underdog.

title: Cultures Converge on Battery Park
description: With singular generosity, the Battery Dance Company each summer presents a free outdoor festival, giving most of the attention to guest troupes. These Downtown Dance Festivals have included weekend performances under the trees in Battery Park. Few New York settings are lovelier: The stage and most of the audience are in shade, with marvelously dappled sunshine through the leaves; the audience sees the light over the Hudson shimmering behind the dancers.

title: Beyond the Congo: Fishing for Different Species in Smaller Rivers and Tributaries
description: Saturday, Aug. 14

title: Barclays to Pay $298 Million for Violating Trade Law
description: 8:09 p.m. | Updated Barclays has agreed to pay nearly $300 million to settle accusations that the bank facilitated illegal transfers of dollars for countries that were sanctioned by the United States including Iran, Cuba, Libya, Sudan and Myanmar, according to documents filed Monday in Federal District Court in Washington, The New York Timess John Eligon reports.

title: Bookstore Arrives, and Sides Are Taken
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, N.Y.  Ever since Books & Books opened its doors on Main Street here last month, it has missed out on some of the adulation usually reserved for new independent bookstores in the age of Amazon.

title: Mets Closer Facing Season-Ending Surgery
description: HOUSTON  The Mets came to Texas to escape. They had scored all of nine runs in a six-game homestand, had endured the humiliation of watching their top reliever marched in handcuffs into a Queens courthouse and had become irrelevant bystanders in the battle for playoff spots.

title: Israeli Bloggers Copy Controversial Images From Facebook
description: Israeli bloggers moved quickly on Monday to make copies of a pair of controversial images posted on Facebook by a former Israeli soldier  showing her posing next to blindfolded Palestinian prisoners  before she blocked access to her photographs, which were shown and discussed on Israeli television before the day was out.

title: From Driving a Maserati to Sleeping on Dads Sofa
description: Big Lake, a comedy beginning on Tuesday night, counts among its producers Will Ferrell and his creative partner Adam McKay, who with virtually each project seem to hoist a big, frosty cold one to the American thirst for schadenfreude and say, Drink up. Together they have given us Talladega Nights, Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy and the HBO comedy Eastbound & Down, among other ventures, which all involve the pummeling of egomaniacal jackasses into so many bits of ground chuck. In the best-case scenarios, we see the entitled morons descent all the way down, but Big Lake (Comedy Central) starts at the bottom after the beating is over and most of the fun is long gone.

title: Vaccination Is Steady, but Pertussis Is Surging
description: For four weeks, my 11-year-old daughter has been coughing. It is not your run-of-the-mill summer cold, but a violent, debilitating cough that takes over her body, usually at night.

title: Drawing Room Drama
description: Behind a bright green gate on a tiny street in Paris sits a magical pink house. A fig tree dominates the summer garden. The winter garden, across a narrow gravel walk, is anchored by a pine tree.

title: Letting a Flying Hairy Arm Take It Away
description: Following a dedication page that offers his fifth novel to the memory of Kurt Vonnegut  implicitly announcing as his goal to employ Vonneguts shades of dark comedy and fluorescent farce  Rick Moody turns things over in The Four Fingers of Death to one Montese Crandall. This character is not the narrator of the novel but the author of a slab of sci-fi horror hack work coextensive with it. This is to say that Mr. Moody here undertakes an extended impersonation of a long-winded ham, convincingly so.

title: Steep Drop Seen in Circumcisions in U.S.
description: Despite a worldwide campaign for circumcision to slow the spread of AIDS, the rate of circumcision among American baby boys appears to be declining.

title: Cohen Moves Deeper Into Oil
description: Carl C. Icahn was certainly not alone on Monday in disclosing his growing interest in the oil industry. Steven A. Cohen, left, the prominent hedge fund manager, has also raised his bets on oil companies, including Exxon Mobil and BP  even though the latter has taken a severe hit to its finances and reputation because of the oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: LISTENING. To the Patient (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrew Roth, American-Born Chronicler of British Politics, Dies at 91
description: LONDON  Andrew Roth, a New York-born journalist with left-wing ideals who fled the McCarthy-era America of 1950 for a new life as a meticulous and often abrasive chronicler of the foibles, business links and private lives of British politicians, died in London on Thursday. He was 91.

title: Felony Indictment in Chess Federation Case Is Dismissed
description: A felony indictment against a member of the United States Chess Federation, the games governing body, has been dismissed. But the defendant still faces 34 misdemeanor counts for allegedly breaking into the e-mail account of a former federation board member.

title: Nonprofits Review Technology Failures
description: WASHINGTON  At a gathering last month over drinks and finger food, a specialist at the World Bank related the story of how female weavers in a remote Amazonian region of Guyana had against all odds built themselves a thriving global online business selling intricately woven hammocks for $1,000 apiece.

title: Photo Replay: Aug 16
description: Images from the day in sports, including a look at the Youth Games in Singapore.

title: G.O.P. Seizes on Mosque Issue Ahead of Elections
description: WASHINGTON  Republican Congressional candidates on Monday intensified efforts to inject the divide over construction of an Islamic center near ground zero into the midterm campaigns while the Senates top Democrat said he objected to the mosque being built there.

title: Judge Seeks More Data on Citigroup Settlement
description: A federal judge said Monday that she was not ready to approve the governments $75 million settlement with Citigroup of charges that it misled investors about billions of dollars in potential losses from subprime mortgages, The Associated Press reports.

title: The Ontology of Plagiarism: Part Two
description: The huge number of negative comments on my column arguing that plagiarism is more a professional than a moral infraction fall mainly into two groups: those who criticize me for an argument I dont make and those who offer as a rebuttal an argument I do make.

title: The Appendix, Inner Beauty and Listening to the Patient (4 Letters)
description: When the Appendix Calls

title: A One-Man Show Rich With Southern Flavor, and Humidity
description: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival began this weekend. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors:

title: Energy Costs Push Prices Up Sharply in Europe
description: Higher energy prices drove inflation in the euro area to an annual rate of 1.7 percent in July, the highest level in 20 months but still within the range considered acceptable by the European Central Bank.

title: Looking This Way and That, and Learning to Adapt to the World
description: The infants and toddlers resemble cyborgs as they waddle and crawl around the playroom with backpacks carrying wireless transmitters and cameras strapped to their heads. Each has one camera aimed at the right eye and another at the field of view, and both send video to monitors nearby. When the video feeds are combined, the result is a recording in which red cross hairs mark the target of a childs gaze.

title: A Calcium Quandary
description: Q. Ive been told that vitamin C and calcium from milk cancel each others benefits if taken together. So how come orange juice is fortified with calcium?

title: In New Jersey, a Parks Spring Water Is Prized. Polluted, Too.
description: MILLBURN, N.J.  In a densely populated place, people prize their slivers of nature and links to a pastoral past. Which might explain why David Giannakopoulos disregarded the signs, rounded the fence, stuck his head under a rock and took a drink.

title: Ex-ConAgra Unit Settles With U.S. Over Artificial Oil Trade
description: WASHINGTON  As 2007 came to a close, oil prices were hovering close to $100 a barrel and many analysts were expecting prices could exceed that in the new year.

title: A Reason for Diversity of Ants May Not Hold
description: There are more than 300 species of nocturnal velvet ants (actually wasps that resemble ants) in the Southwestern deserts of the United States. The easy explanation for the incredible diversification is that as the Rocky Mountains emerged millions of years ago, multiple, isolated deserts formed, leaving ample opportunity for speciation to occur. But the easy explanation may not be the right one.

title: To Enjoy Champagne, Treat It Like Beer, Study Says
description: Champagne may be a symbol of life at the top, but it is best poured into a tilted glass just like that other sparkling beverage, the plebeian beer, according to a new study.

title: Wide Variety of Breeds Born of Few Genes
description: Spaniels have notably floppy ears, basset hounds have extremely short legs, and St. Bernards are large and big boned. Not to mention Chihuahuas.

title: An Indian Churchs Colorful Tribute to Mary
description: WEST SAYVILLE, N.Y.  Without doubt, many more people line the sidewalks to see the St. Patricks Day Parade in Manhattan than to watch the St. Mary Malankara Indian Orthodox Churchs annual Assumption Day Parade, which began here on Sunday with the usual blowing of the kumbu horn and the dancing of the koladi by the congregations teenage girls, dressed in saris and banging sticks.

title: No Charges Against DeLay in Abramoff Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Tom DeLay, a Texas Republican and former House majority leader who resigned from Congress in June 2006 in a spectacular fall from political power, will not face federal corruption charges over his dealings with the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff.

title: Judge Not Ready to Decide on Citigroup Settlement With S.E.C.
description: Citigroup failed on Monday to win a judges approval to pay $75 million to settle claims by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the bank misled investors by understating subprime-related holdings.

title: For Knicks Dolan, a Fine Line Between Contrarian and Chaos
description: It has been four long years since James L. Dolan issued his significant progress edict to Isiah Thomas, with Thomas stewing alongside him, like a child being warned to make all gone with the veggies on his plate.

title: Levels Plummet in Crucial Reservoir
description: Water levels in Lake Mead, the Colorado River reservoir, fell sharply again this summer and are nearing an elevation that would set off the first-ever official water shortage on the river, The Arizona Republic reported last week.

title: Court Extends Stay on Allowing Gay Marriage
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal appeals court has extended a stay on same-sex marriages in California until it decides whether a ban on such unions is constitutional.

title: Who Visits the Emergency Room? 20 Percent of Americans, Insured or Not
description: Americans, insured and not, make ample use of hospital emergency rooms: One out of every five visited an E.R. at least once in 2007, the latest year for which the National Center for Health Statistics has data.

title: P.G.A. Draws a Line in the Sand
description: It is not every day that someone loses a golf tournament and becomes the nations most popular player overnight. But Dustin Johnson, denied a chance to win the P.G.A. Championship on Sunday because he accidentally violated a rule, appears to suddenly have the biggest fan club in the sport.

title: Are Poverty Tours Demeaning?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Clarion Call on Energy: Our Goals Can Be Achieved
description: To the Editor:

title: Its All About You, and Millions of Others
description: MORE than four decades ago, Cass Elliot advised, "Make your own kind of music." Since then, exhortations by advertisers to express individuality  by, oddly enough, consuming mass-market products  have grown louder.

title: Arrival of the Tigers Puts Grandersons Struggles in Sharp Relief
description: The flip side to the Johnny Damon coin Monday night was Curtis Granderson, and a legitimate question was this: Which team  the Detroit Tigers or the Yankees  is better off with the two high-profile players having switched sides?

title: Irish Stories
description: P. ONeill  not the former Treasury Secretary  has a great blog post about Ireland, its banks, and its mess. Strangely comforting for an American; were not alone, it turns out, in our policy morass.

title: Reality of G.O.P. Rhetoric
description: To the Editor:

title: Teenager Is Held in India After His Mother Is Killed
description: CECIL, Pa.  A teenage boy from Pennsylvania was being held in a juvenile center in India on Monday, awaiting a hearing after being accused of murdering his mother last week as they were vacationing at a luxury resort, according to news media reports in India.

title: Bedbugs in Flight
description: To the Editor:

title: High in the Andes, Keeping an Incan Mystery Alive
description: SAN CRISTBAL DE RAPAZ, Peru  The route to this village 13,000 feet above sea level runs from the desert coast up hairpin bends, delivering the mix of exhilaration and terror that Andean roads often provide. Condors soar above mist-shrouded crags. Quechua-speaking herders squint at strangers who arrive gasping in the thin air.

title: Should New York Hold a Constitutional Convention?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reluctantly, Court Upholds a Sexual Abuse Conviction
description: Proclaiming itself bound by technicalities, a federal appeals court on Monday upheld a lower courts decision not to overturn the conviction of Jesse Friedman, a Long Island man who served 13 years in prison for sexually abusing several children in a 1980s case later made famous by the movie Capturing the Friedmans, a documentary that questioned his guilt.

title: Old West Showdown Is Revived
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Billy the Kid is dead and buried. So is the lawman who shot him. But in this city of adobe homes and historical plaques, the past and present are sometimes as hard to separate as the Kids finger was from his trigger.

title: Fans in Green and Blue Give Life to Drab Stadium
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Obama Stumps for Democrats and Economic Agenda
description: MILWAUKEE  President Obama excoriated Congressional Republicans on Monday for seeking to stymie his economic agenda, delivering a harsh critique of what he said was obstructionism that put political calculations ahead of the welfare of average Americans.

title: Repair Made, Space Station Heads Back to Normal
description: With a replacement cooling pump successfully installed Monday, the International Space Station could be back to almost normal by Tuesday.

title: Officer Gets More Time to Fight Discharge Under Dont Ask Policy
description: Lawyers for an Air Force officer facing possible discharge under the militarys ban on homosexuality, Lt. Col. Victor J. Fehrenbach, have reached an agreement with the government that will give him time to fight a discharge in federal court. Under the agreement released Monday, the Air Force said that it would not make a decision on Colonel Fehrenbach before Aug. 27 and that if it decided to discharge him, it would take no action for 21 days after notifying him of that decision. Colonel Fehrenbach asserts that discharging him under the militarys dont ask, dont tell policy would violate his rights and cause him irreparable harm.

title: Despite H.P.s Efforts, Spectacle of a Chief Goes On

A new book from Assouline, celebrating Hilfigers 25th anniversary, covers these greatest-hit moments and more. (You may not be invited to the anniversary bash, but you can tune in with his playlist, below.) Here is Hilfiger, in a photo from the book, with his wife, Dee, on their way to Kid Rocks wedding. Shine on you crazy diamond, indeed!

title: Notes On Koo (Wonkish)
description: Ive just finished rereading Richard Koos The Holy Grail of Macroeconomics, as part of a multi-book review project. Its one of the few books out there that talks about what you should do in the aftermath of a burst bubble  almost everyone else obsesses on the causes of the bubble, and possibly on how to prevent the next bubble, neither of which is the clear and present issue.

title: Liquidity Preference And Loanable Funds, Revisited
description: A brief revisiting of the issues I raised more than a year ago regarding alternative views of interest rates.

title: G.M. Recall for Seat Belts Affects 243,000 Crossovers
description: DETROIT  General Motors said Tuesday that it was recalling 243,000 large crossover vehicles to check for a problem that could prevent their rear seat belts from latching safely.

title: A Second Frugal Budget Update
description: Its time for a second report on the nitty-gritty of my frugal budget. During the middle five weeks of my trip, I once again averaged well under my $500-a-week (about $70 a day) maximum. Heres how it breaks down, including transportation costs this time.

description: In yet another setback in efforts to treat Alzheimers disease, Eli Lilly & Company announced on Tuesday that it had halted development of an experimental treatment after the compound actually made patients worse in two late-stage clinical trials.

She certainly didnt make this choice to fill her free time  her first novel, Chosen, is coming out this fall, and most authors clear their calendars for an event like that. But her overstuffed calendar  and her sons  is precisely the reason she is making this choice.

description: Updated | 3:07 p.m. In an interview with Israeli Army radio on Tuesday, a former Israeli soldier said, I still dont understand whats wrong with photographs she posted on Facebook of herself posing next to blindfolded Palestinian detainees.

description: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival began last weekend. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors.

title: An Israeli Finds New Meanings in a Nazi Film
description: For almost half a century, an unfinished Nazi propaganda film of the Warsaw Ghetto, simply titled Das Ghetto and discovered by East German archivists after the war, was used by scholars and historians as a flawed but authentic record of ghetto life. Shot over 30 days in May 1942  just two months before deportations to the Treblinka extermination camp would begin  this hourlong silent film juxtaposed random scenes of Jews enjoying various luxuries with images of profound suffering.

title: Quote Unquote | Suri You Must Be Kidding

description: Shares in American Apparel, the clothing choice of urban hipsters, plummeted more than 13 percent as the company disclosed receiving a federal subpoena over its change in accounting firms.

title: Weather Extremes and Climate Change
description: In an article on Sunday, I outlined the relationship between climate change and a rise in extreme weather. Scientists cite several statistical indicators that suggest the number of extreme events like heat waves and floods is rising. This evidence has taken on a new meaning in this summer of weather disasters, especially the floods in Pakistan and the heat wave in Russia. The United States has not been spared from weather extremes, notably deluges like the disastrous downpour in Tennessee that led to extensive flooding in May.

title: 1933 Delage Wins Best of Show at Pebble Beach
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  A week of intense automobile worship on the Monterey Peninsula concluded with more than $100 million worth of classic cars changing hands at auctions, several new models being introduced by manufacturers and a 1933 Delage winning the coveted title as Best of Show.

title: New Zealand Billionaire to Buy Maker of Hefty Bags
description: The Reynolds Group, part of the global packaging business owned by New Zealands richest man, said Tuesday that it would pay about $4.4 billion for Pactiv, the maker of the Hefty brand trash bags. With debt included, the acquisition is valued at about $6 billion.

title: Walken and Talking: Christopher Walken Hosts The Leonard Lopate Show for a Day
description: Listeners who tuned in Monday to The Leonard Lopate Show on WNYC expecting to hear its regular host got an unusual surprise: Christopher Walken, the Deer Hunter and Behanding in Spokane star, loaned his lifelong interest in broadcasting and burgeoning skills (not to mention his unmistakable stop-and-start delivery) to the program, where he acted as guest host for the afternoon, and conducted interviews with friends and colleagues like Jack OBrien and Richard Easton; his Behanding co-star Zoe Kazan; the chef Lidia Bastianich and her mother, Erminia Motika; and the dancer and choreographer Jacques dAmboise, who shared his airtime with a couple of surprise guests.

title: Between Cuomo and Lazio, a Contentious History
Mets Look to Fight Back
description: Whatever goes wrong for you today, you can take solace in the fact that you are not the New York Mets. And if you are the New York Mets, all we have for you is at least you are not the golfer Dustin Johnson.

title: Were Officials Wrong, or Just Doing Their Jobs?
description: An interesting phenomenon of the Dustin Johnson rules controversy is that Monday seemed to be the day that most defended Johnson and blamed the rules officials. On Tuesday, however, the tide seems to have turned in favor of crediting the rules officials with simply doing their jobs.

title: Deng Xiaoping: A Political Wizard Who Put China on the Capitalist Road
description: Like Mao Zedong and Zhou Enlai before him, Deng Xiaoping was among the small group of revolutionary elders who fought as guerrillas for the Communist cause and then dominated the leadership of the People's Republic they proclaimed on Oct. 1, 1949.

title: New England Welcomes President Roosevelt
description: Hartford, Conn., Aug. 22 -- President Roosevelt began his tour of New England today amid scenes of remarkable enthusiasm. Landing from the yacht Syiph, at New Haven, shortly after 1 o'clock in the afternoon, his progress to this city was a continued ovation. This evening he addressed an audience of more than 5,000 persons in the Coliseum here.

title: Gene Kelly, Dancer of Vigor and Grace, Dies
description: Gene Kelly, the dancer, actor, director and choreographer who brought a vigorous athleticism, casual grace and an earthy masculinity to the high romance of lavish Hollywood musicals, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83.

title:
Sacco and Vanzetti Put to Death Early This
Morning
description: Charlestown State Prison, Mass., Tuesday, Aug. 23 -- Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti died in the electric chair early this morning, carrying out the sentence imposed on them for the South Braintree murders of April 15, 1920.

title: Shell Shock | Oystering on Cape Cod
description: The best-tasting oyster I will ever consume came at 8 a.m. on a warm late-July Wednesday in the middle of Wellfleet Harbor. I was attempting to remove the mollusks various attachments with a small Estwing drywall hammer when its shell accidentally cracked open. With few viable options, I selflessly did the humane thing: I slid it down my gullet. It was delectable  rich, creamy and absurdly fresh  and no more than 30 seconds between sea and belly.

title:
Hurricane Rips Through Florida and Heads
Into Gulf

title: Jorge Luis Borges, A Master of Fantasy and Fable, is Dead
description: Jorge Luis Borges, the Argentine short-story writer, poet and essayist who was considered one of Latin America's greatest writers, died yesterday in Geneva, where he had been living for three months. He was 86 years old.

title: Tasting a Variety of Mezcals
description: As you might be able to tell by my column this week, I love mezcal. Even more so than its cousin tequila, which I love as well, mezcal is the most under-recognized great spirit on the planet.

description: Five weeks after wildlife authorities rounded up Prospect Parks geese and gassed them, provoking the ire of residents and wildlife advocates alike, legions of new, death-defying geese continue to move into the prime real estate that is Prospect Park Lake.

title: On Our Radar: Pakistans Climate Debate
description: In Pakistan, there is rising debate over whether climate change is to blame for the countrys devastating floods. Global warming results in catastrophic weather events, a Pakistani geographer and water specialist says. The recent floods are a result of climate change, undoubtedly. [Inter Press Service]

Washington Rally; President Sees Gain for
Negro

title: Franzen in Webster Groves
description: A common thread running through the fiction of Jonathan Franzen is the authors preoccupation with the Midwest, specifically with its cities and suburbs: St. Louis (The Twenty-Seventh City), Evanston, Ill. (Strong Motion), St. Louis again (called St. Jude) in The Corrections and now St. Paul, Minn. (in Freedom, to be published later this month). As it happens, Franzen, though he grew up in the St. Louis suburb Webster Groves, has been an East Coaster for 30 years or more. He attended Swarthmore College (class of 1981), worked briefly in Cambridge, Mass., and is today a more or less entrenched Manhattanite.

title: On Assimilationists and Nativists
description: Theres been a lot of criticism of my columns suggestion that the idea of America as a distinctive culture  English-speaking, Anglo-Saxon and/or Western, Protestant and then Judeo-Christian  has driven both a positive assimilationism and a darker nativism over the years, and indeed that these two impulses are often intertwined. Many writers seem convinced that that assimilation and nativism arent intertwined at all, but rather diametrically opposed. Nativism in the late 19th century was preoccupied with keeping foreigners out of the United States, not assimilating them, Jamelle Bouie writes. The pro-assimilation forces are on the progressive side, in the first camp Douthat mentions, objects Phoebe Maltz, rather than having anything to do with cultural conservatives. The assimilationists and the exclusionists arent and havent been the same people, Jacob Levy tweets. And so forth.

Starting at 6 p.m. both days there will be a Champagne reception and preview of the food for those who buy $80 tickets. General admission, $50, starts at 7 p.m. The theme this year is New York vs. San Francisco, with chefs from both cities, including Richard Torrisi and Dan Barber from New York, Brian Leth and Jeremy Fox from the West Coast, preparing food. title: Mets Picasso Exhibition Is One for the Record Books
description: Pablo Picasso, you still got it! The Metropolitan Museum of Art said on Tuesday that its recent exhibition of works by that 20th-century titan of creativity was its seventh-highest-attended show in the museums history. The exhibition, called Picasso in The Metropolitan Museum of Art, drew 703,256 visitors during its 17-week run from April 19 through Aug. 15, making it the museums best-attended show since 2001. The Met said that the exhibition, which featured the museums complete Picasso holdings of some 300 examples of the artists painting, drawing, sculpture and ceramics, attracted as many as 10,000 visitors on some busy Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. Still, it wasnt enough to top the Mets sixth-most-attended exhibition, The Horses of San Marco, which drew 742,221 visitors over seven months in 1980. Maybe next time, Picasso.

The furloughed James Bond star Daniel Craig has already been chosen to play the journalist Mikael Blomkvist in the film, which Sony Pictures plans to release on Dec. 21, 2011. All three Millennium novels, including The Girl Who Played With Fire and The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets Nest, were previously adapted into Swedish-language films, the first two of which have been released in the United States.

title: Christopher Walken, Radio Host For a Day
description: Listeners who tuned in Monday to The Leonard Lopate Show on WNYC expecting to hear its regular host got an unusual surprise: Christopher Walken, below, the Deer Hunter and Behanding in Spokane star, lent his lifelong interest in broadcasting and his growing skills (not to mention his unmistakable stop-and-start delivery) to the program, where he acted as guest host for the afternoon, and conducted interviews with friends and colleagues like Jack OBrien and Richard Easton; his Behanding co-star Zoe Kazan; the chef Lidia Bastianich and her mother, Erminia Motika; and the dancer and choreographer Jacques dAmboise, who shared his airtime with a surprise guest, Eddie Izzard. After taking the rest of Monday to recuperate from his debut, Mr. Walken said on Tuesday that the experience was pretty intense and very thrilling. Im a nervous person, Mr. Walken said in a telephone interview. But of course, it was completely unknown territory. And really being on the other side of the interview.

title: ABC To Announce New Dancing Stars
description: Dancing With the Stars is taking the shows promotion to a new extreme, with plans to announce its new contestants in a prime-time news conference on ABC later this month. The event  with actual reporters in attendance  will be shown live during the reality show Bachelor Pad on Aug. 30, the network said on Tuesday. If any show can get away with such a stunt, its Dancing, which recruits celebrities for the competition twice a year. Last spring was the shows most-watched season. The new season starts on Sept. 20. The co-hosts of the competition, Tom Bergeron and Brooke Burke, above, will host the news conference, ABC said. There will even be a question-and-answer session with the new cast members, although that part of the event may not be televised live on ABC, a network spokeswoman said. The announcement will be presented in its entirety the next day on ABC.com.

title: Bachelor Pad Draws Few
description: The second week of ABCs spin-off Bachelor Pad drew only modest interest in the ratings on Monday. According to Nielsens estimates, 5.4 million viewers tuned in to the reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., about a million less than the shows premiere a week ago (6.4 million). ABC finished in a virtual tie for second place on the night with NBC, which broadcast a two-hour repeat of last weeks YouTube performers on Americas Got Talent (4.7 million). At 10, CBSs CSI: Miami rerun (5.6 million) outperformed both Dateline on NBC (5.2 million) and Dating in the Dark on ABC (3.8 million). CBS led the night over all, despite broadcasting all repeats, including the sitcom reruns Two and a Half Men (8.3 million) and The Big Bang Theory (8 million) in the 9 oclock hour. Fox finished in fourth place with a new episode of Lie to Me at 9 (4.9 million), following a rerun of House at 8 (3.6 million).

title: Online-Only Art Fair Set For January
description: The conventional art fair  for which collectors, dealers and other art world professionals jet into a city for several days of looking, buying, going to parties and networking  is about to face a challenge. The online-only VIP Art Fair, which will take place for the first time in January, is similarly time-limited (a week long), but different in almost every other way from a normal fair. The booths are virtual; conversation (and haggling over prices) will take place by instant messaging, phone or Skype; and no one will get sore feet. The event is the brainchild of two couples, the art dealers James and Jane Cohan and the Internet entrepreneurs Jonas and Alessandra Almgren. So far several major galleries have signed up, including Gagosian, David Zwirner, White Cube, Hauser & Wirth and L&M Arts. The cost to galleries in the most elite category is $20,000, which Mr. Cohan said the founders estimated to be about a fifth the cost of doing a conventional art fair (including booth, transportation, hotels and shipping). Asked whether people would be willing to spend money on art they hadnt seen in person, Mr. Cohan said that buyers most likely would be people already familiar with a given artists work. The fair will take place Jan. 22 to 30. Anyone can browse, but to interact with dealers, you will have to be invited by one of the exhibiting galleries or pay a fee of $20 or $100.

title: Dylans Art Exhibition To Feature New Paintings
description: We suppose an exhibition of paintings by Bob Dylan could depict anything from Einstein disguised as Robin Hood to a fight between Ezra Pound and T. S. Eliot  and thats just if he sticks to the lyrics of his song Desolation Row. So what will visitors to Mr. Dylans show at the Danish National Gallery in Copenhagen actually see when it opens there next month? As Kaspar Monrad, the museums curator and director, told Agence France-Presse, the works will include paintings of Brazil, like the one above, containing scenes from daily life in the cities, the slums and the countryside in Brazil where Bob Dylan has been several times. The exhibition, which will run at the museum (known locally as the Statens Museum for Kunst) from Sept. 4 through Jan. 30, was announced last year. The museum said on Monday that it would include 40 acrylic paintings and 8 drawings created by Mr. Dylan specifically for the show. Mr. Monrad said the paintings, whose subjects also include a familiarly Dylan-esque array of gypsies, gangsters and politicians, were inspired by American realism from the start of the 20th century and a deep affinity with painters like Matisse. In a statement Mr. Dylan simply said, It was an honor to be asked and a thrilling challenge to create the works.

The result, in a debut of mango, strawberry and banana flavors, all made from freshly pured fruit rather than commercial pures, comes swirled into cups, by itself or accompanied by diced fruit, nuts, granola or other toppings. Now, the mini-popovers are on the cafe menu; diners can choose four of them instead of one big one, or a basket of a dozen in place of three. Her Web site now sells a kit for baking the minis at home, including mix, a pastry brush, raspberry jam or apple butter and two pans, each making 12. We feel this is also a way of helping the environment with automatic recycling, said Laura Nuter, an owner of the new store and of Grab Specialty Foods in Park Slope, Brooklyn. title: Welcome Back | John Derian for Target
description: September is almost here, with its cooler temperatures (at least we in New York hope theyre cooler) and, even better, the arrival of a new John Derian collection for Target. The East Village master of decoupage plates, trays, lamps and other decorative items has followed his 2008 effort for the design-centric retailer with a bigger, more varied collection that includes stationery, home dcor, housewares and storage  all at Ill-take-10-of-those prices. Signature designs run through the collection: for example, a silhouette that adorns the cover of a composition book ($2.50) also appears on a ceramic mug ($4.99). Storage bins covered in geranium-leaf or moth prints are too pretty to hide in a closet, and there are plastic trays for every possible use. My favorites among the latter are the Tapered Tray ($19.99, shown here in pale geranium), which is large enough to carry drinks outside, or to stack books or magazines. A smaller tray ($12.99) is perfect for organizing jars of cotton swabs and makeup brushes in the bathroom or for putting your keys on near the front door. Its image of a pink room (called House-Mouse in the collection), taken from a late-19th-century German print, is one of Derians favorites. Its so conceptual, he said, as if youre putting your things down in a room. And the oval tray ($12.99), with its Home Sweet Home motto (based on a print that Derian found when he bought an old frame), would look great hanging on a wall, with its old-fashioned, almost camp sensibility. Derian particularly likes the way that these pieces work in modern as well as more traditional rooms. They all cross over, which is cool, he added. The collection will be available beginning Sept. 5, but as always with Targets designer collaborations, supplies are limited.

title: Noeud Papillon | Twisted Misters
description: Like that of most men, York Wus first experience with a bow tie involved a wedding. My cousin was getting married, and I hated the tie that came with my tuxedo, Wu recalls. So I decided to make my own. From that moment, he was a convert, showing up at the Toronto design firm where he worked sporting a different handmade bow tie every day. With his new line, Noeud Papillon  French for butterfly knot, the double Windsor of the bow tie world  Wu has elevated the geekiest of accessories to I-want-one status. His designs range from a studded black leather version to a white chiffon confection that does double duty as a Wildean boutonniere. (Female friends have been known to borrow it as a hair ornament.) The attention he lavishes on them  each one is handmade from couture-grade fabrics and individually numbered, with no visible stitches  rivals that which Alber Elbaz of Lanvin, Wus design hero and himself a bow tie man, devotes to his frocks. I want Noeud Papillon ties to be the equivalent of Lanvin, he says, structured and strong on the inside, elegant and effortless on the outside.

But no, these glories are intended to greet me and the other guests unlucky enough to be in town during the last two weeks of August, a fortnight when everyone else is rumored to have fled the city.

title: The Independent 529 Rebrands Itself
description: In an effort to attract more accounts, the Tuition Plan Consortium has changed the name of its Independent 529 plan product to the Private College 529 Plan.

title: Picasso Show Makes the Mets Top 10
description: Pablo Picasso, you still got it! The Metropolitan Museum of Art said on Tuesday that its recent exhibition of works by that 20th-century titan of creativity was its seventh highest-attended show in the museums history. The exhibition, called Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, drew 703,256 visitors during its 17-week run from April 19 through Sunday, making it the museums best-attended show since 2001. The Met said that the exhibition, which featured the museums complete Picasso holdings of some 300 examples of the artists painting, drawing, sculpture and ceramics (above is his Seated Harlequin from 1901), attracted as many as 10,000 visitors on some busy Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. Still, it wasnt enough to top the Mets sixth most-attended exhibition, The Horses of San Marco, which drew 742,221 visitors over seven months in 1980. Maybe next time, Picasso.

title: Dr. Laura Retreats After Use of Epithet
description: Following criticism and the loss of advertisers after her use of a racial epithet 11 times on her long-running radio talk show last week, Laura Schlessinger said on Tuesday night that she would not renew her contract for the show when it expires at the end of the year.

title: Betty White Gets Busier
description: Betty White may be 88, but shes certainly not finished acting. And shes not finished writing books, either. Ms. White  the Hot in Cleveland star, who will also be seen on Community and just about anywhere else that a television set or computer monitor is on  just signed a deal to write two books for G. P. Putnams Sons, the publisher announced on Wednesday. The first book, Listen Up!, is about life lessons learned during her incredibly varied and long career in Hollywood, with an emphasis on the extraordinary past 15 years of the stars life, according to a statement, and is scheduled for release in spring 2011. The second book, scheduled for publication in 2012, is called The Zoo and I, and will have stories about Ms. White and the animals at the Los Angeles Zoo. (She is on the board of trustees of the Greater Los Angeles Zoo Association and an animal rights advocate.) She has written two books and was a co-author of three. In a statement, Ms. White said, Much as I love what I do for a living in show business, I love writing even more.

title: A Classic Cookbook Returns, Canned Soup and All
description: Who says there isnt still an appetite for Hootenholler Whisky Cake?

title: Talent Wild Cards Win
description: Wild Card night on Americas Got Talent, in which 12 previously eliminated acts got a second chance in the competition, helped NBC top the ratings on Tuesday. According to Nielsens estimates, 10.1 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour talent program from 9 to 11 p.m., more than any other show in prime-time. NBC did not lead the 8 p.m. time slot, however, as a rerun of Minute to Win It (5.2 million) could not compete with ABCs Wipeout (8.9 million) or CBSs repeat of NCIS (8.7 million). Despite a line-up of all reruns, CBS ranked second on the night, earning 7.6 million at 9 for NCIS: Los Angeles and 5.2 million at 10 for The Good Wife. ABC was third with Shaq Vs. (5.1 million) and Primetime (4.5 million) from 9 to 11 while Fox placed fourth with back-to-back repeats of Glee (3.8 million).

title: Despite Scandals, Indian Mining Bosses Thrive
description: BELLARY, India  Janardhana Reddy insists he is not a king. No, no, no, he protested, as a servant trotted across the courtyard to deliver a cup of cooled water. Men with machine guns stood outside. An architect waited to discuss the new mansion, while another man hovered nearby, sitting in the grass.

title: She Said, They Said: Ms. Tequila Vs. Juggalo
description: Juggalo Gathering LLC, the company that produces the Gathering of the Juggalos concerts, said on Wednesday that neither it nor the band Insane Clown Posse was responsible for an incident in which Tila Tequila, right, the reality television star and singer, was attacked by fans after taking the stage at the festival on Saturday. In a statement, the company said: Ms. Tequila was made aware, in advance, of her unpopularity with many Juggalos at the Gathering, but she insisted on performing. She was even paid in full before her performance, and was told that she did not have to perform, but if she did decide to perform, she could leave the stage the minute that she felt uncomfortable. Juggalo Gathering LLC added that the performer exacerbated the situation when she removed her top, exposing herself, which seemed to mock and further antagonize the crowd. Tila Tequila, whose real name is Tila Nguyen, filed a complaint with law enforcement officials in Hardin County, Ill., where the festival was held. She has said that she required stitches after audience members pelted her with rocks, glass bottles, firecrackers and waste from portable toilets.

title: Eminem Reclaims Charts
description: It was bound to happen. Although the Arcade Fire had its moment in the spotlight when it beat out Eminem for the No. 1 spot on the Billboard album chart last week, the natural order of the pop universe has been restored, with Eminems Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope) retaking No. 1 by a wide margin. Recovery sold 133,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, landing the album at the top of the chart for the sixth time in eight weeks. The Arcade Fires album, The Suburbs (Merge), fell to No. 2 with 52,000 sales, a 66 percent decline from the week before. (Although sales for Recovery have dropped since it was released, they have held steady in the mid-100,000s, and the album has sold a total of 2.1 million copies so far.) The soundtrack to the Disney Channel movie Camp Rock 2: The Final Jam (Disney), with songs by Demi Lovato and the Jonas Brothers, opened at No. 3 with 41,000 sales. Black Label Society, led by Zakk Wylde, Ozzy Osbournes former guitarist, is No. 4 with its new Order of the Black (E1), which sold 33,000.

title: Strange Second Life of Life and Times of Tim
description: A few weeks ago, Steve Dildarian appeared to be as down-and-out as the perpetually troubled protagonist on his HBO animated series The Life and Times of Tim. That was in June, when the network told him it would not be picking up a third season of that cartoon comedy, on which he serves as creator, writer, producer and the voice of its title character. Then, before Mr. Dildarian had time to gather his belongings or shop the show to another network, HBO reversed course and told him a few days ago that The Life and Times of Tim would be resurrected for Season 3. So why the sudden reversal of fortune? Honestly, I dont know, he said in a phone interview. Sometimes Im the last to know these things. In a statement, Mike Lombardo, the president of HBO programming, said simply that the show has a passionate fan base both in terms of viewers and within the company, and the network was convinced that Tim should be part of our plans for 2011. Given that it takes about 10 months to a year to create new episodes of the show, Mr. Dildarian said he hoped to get back to work quickly. The last thing I need is more breathing room, he said.

title: The Real Jerry Lee Lewis Will Be In the House
description: Levi Kreis has earned praise, and a Tony Award, for his portrayal of the rebellious rocker Jerry Lee Lewis, below, in the Broadway musical Million Dollar Quartet, but come next month hes going to have a little competition for that role. Mr. Lewis  the Killer himself  plans to attend the Sept. 10 performance of the musical at the Nederlander Theater and will play onstage with its cast in a special post-show jam session, publicists for the production said on Wednesday. During its Broadway run, Million Dollar Quartet has had musical artists like Melissa Etheridge, Larry Gatlin and Guy Davis perform with its cast, but this guest shot is unique: Mr. Lewis, 74, the Louisiana-born performer of Great Balls of Fire and Whole Lotta Shakin Goin On, is the last surviving member of the real-life Million Dollar Quartet, the serendipitous assemblage at which he, Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash and Carl Perkins recorded together at Sun Records in 1956. Mr. Lewis and Mr. Kreis are also to duet on a song that will appear on a deluxe version of Mr. Lewiss album Mean Old Man.

title: Yummy, Yummy, Yummy, Ive Got Bears That Are Gummi
description: As happy as a kid in a candy store is still a familiar expression, even if candy stores are becoming scarce. But how would a child holding an executive position behave in the board room of a candy company?

title: Hindu Deities Conjure Magic in Movement Downtown
description: As surprising New York juxtapositions go, none surpass those provided each August by the Erasing Borders festival of Indian dance in its contributions to the Downtown Dance Festival. Here is a downtown plaza surrounded by skyscrapers, with people coming and going at lunchtime and a soundtrack that includes the harbor and city traffic; and here in the open air are dancers in full Indian costume performing traditional forms that derive from the opposite side of the world.

title: Why Johnnys College Isnt What It Used to Be
description: Andrew Hacker and Claudia Dreifus have written a lucid, passionate and wide-ranging book on the state of American higher education and what they perceive as its increasing betrayal of its primary mission  for them, the teaching of undergraduates. That both are academics  one a well-known professor (Mr. Hacker) and the other consigned to the adjunct, or what they call contingent, faculty (Ms. Dreifus, who is also a frequent contributor to The New York Times)  provides them with memorable, often acerbic anecdotes that neatly offset their citations of statistics and (it must be said) their sometimes rather sweeping generalizations.

description: Bergdorf Goodmans seventh floor recently got a major injection of color, with an installation of furniture and accessories by Jean Boggio, the French designer. Mr. Boggio, who built a following around his jewelry designs, teamed up with the manufacturer, the Franz Collection, three years ago. It is not his first foray into home furnishings  he has also created pieces for Baccarat, Haviland and Roux-Marquiand  but it is his most comprehensive collection, and this is the first time the collection has been shown in the United States. A lot of new, exciting furniture tends to be very contemporary, and although this is contemporary in feeling, it also has a very traditional and classic element to it, said Nicholas Manville of Bergdorfs.

(His first name is Edward, after his father, but he goes by his middle name, which was not inspired by Gone With the Wind. title: Cooking With Dexter: Bait and Wish
description: First well get the grill going hotter than a blacksmiths forge. Well strip the papery wrappers from the tomatillos and lay them above the coals alongside planks of onion and a chili pepper, maybe two. Ill flip the vegetables as they sear, and as usual, the tongs wont be long enough to keep my hands from scorching like bare feet on the beach parking lot. The onions will char, then the peppers. The tomatillos will fight the heat, blistering in anger and spitting juice at the hissing coals, then theyll give up and collapse in on themselves. They go back indoors, into the blender. Quickly, before the coals dim, Ill chop the peppers and onions and a bunch of cilantro. Stir it all together, and theres a salsa. Now to cook the fish. Its a bluefish, an entire side, big enough to feed the whole family and some stray friends. Onto the grill it goes, skin up. Well close the lid so the smoke insinuates itself into the oily fillet. Turn it once. My sons will hover like thirsty mosquitoes. Now it will be time to spoon grilled salsa verde over our dinner, the freshest bluefish weve ever eaten and the first one landed by Dexter, our proud 6-year-old.

The official, Thad W. Allen, a retired Coast Guard admiral, said there was no timetable for completing the relief well. But he said that in the meantime, BP was preparing to replace the damaged blowout preventer on the Macondo well with a new one, which could be used to help manage pressure within the well. BP has estimated that there are about 1,000 barrels of oil in the Macondo well, trapped between seals at the top and cement at the bottom that was pumped in this month. One concern is that using the relief well to pump more cement into the Macondo well could raise the pressure within that well, damage the seals and, potentially, result in a spill of the oil.

title: Tress Test
description: Would Catherine Deneuve have made as convincing an ice maiden had she been a brunette? That question gets explored in depth in Brune/Blonde, an exhibition by Alain Bergala opening this October at the Cinmathque Franaise in Paris. Blondes, as it turns out, were most often cast as housewives until the 1930s, when flaxen-haired women became typecast as sultry and dangerous. A book of the same name will be released concurrently and include essays by film and cultural historians like Michelle Perrot, Dominique Pani and Stphane Guguan, along with an interview with Deneuve herself. And to get to the root (pun intended) of the issue, Brune/Blonde looks beyond cinema to the significance of womens hair color in art (Alphonse Mucha, Francesca Woodman) and mythology. Somehow we already knew Rapunzel couldnt have pulled off a Louise Brooks.

(It is currently open until 5 p.m. on those days.) To offset the change, the museum will open an hour later, at 11 a.m. Weekend hours, from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., will remain the same.

title: Two Running Stars Train While Pregnant
description: Runners Paula Radcliffe and Kara Goucher are famous for standout performances in the marathon and other events. Now both women, pregnant and due on the same day in September, are also training together during pregnancy.

title: Helping a Toddler Grieve
description: Daniel Cho was a cellist. He said good-bye to his wife, Julia, and his 22-month-old daughter, Audrey, when he left on a European tour in June  a few weeks of touring with Regina Spektor. He was making his mark in the music world after years of working two jobs and chasing a dream. The day before he was to appear with Spektor at the Montreux Jazz Festival in Switzerland, he went to Lake Geneva, showed friends some videos of Audrey that he carried on his iPhone, left his phone and wallet on a towel and went for a swim. What happened next is not clear, perhaps never will be, but somehow Dan, who was a strong swimmer, drowned. He was 33.

title: A Man With a Memorial: Vonnegut Library to Open in the Fall
description: Though he may or may not continue to exist in the Tralfamadorian sense of the word, a part of Kurt Vonnegut will live on in an Indianapolis library dedicated to him that will contain artifacts from his life and career. The Associated Press reported on Wednesday that the Kurt Vonnegut Memorial Library will have its opening in November, where it will display first-edition books by the Slaughterhouse Five and Sirens of Titans author, who died in 2007, as well as a replica of his writing studio, items he collected during his service in World War II and numerous rejection letters he received before achieving his literary fame.

title: From Idol to Broadway: Justin Guarini Joins Women on the Verge Musical
description: Months before the official opening of Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, theatergoers have thrilled to each incremental casting announcement for this musical adaptation of the Pedro Almodvar comedy, as celebrated Broadway stars like Patti LuPone, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Sherie Rene Scott and Laura Benanti were added to its ensemble. Who, these impatient observers wondered, would be cast in the final principal role of this production? Now they have their answer.Justin Guarini, the runner-up on the first-ever season of American Idol, has joined the musicals cast, Lincoln Center Theater said on Thursday. Mr. Guarini, who was edged out by Kelly Clarkson for the Idol crown in 2002, will play the role of Carlos, the son of Ivan (Mr. Mitchell) and Lucia (Ms. LuPone). It will be the Broadway debut of Mr. Guarini, who previously appeared in a workshop version of the Beach Boys musical Good Vibrations and with Ms. Clarkson in the film From Justin to Kelly.

Cranes great-grandfather Raphael Lwenfeld , who was Tolstoys German translator and biographer, had visited the Tolstoys at their estate, Crane writes, and he was distressed by Sophias ill-treatment by Leo Tolstoys disciples  one subject of the book Parini reviewed. It was an interesting story, and we asked him to expand on it.

title: Seeing Things | Free City Goes Hollywood
description: Free City, Nina Gardunos creative enterprise that is equal parts shop, gathering place and artistic outpost, recently vacated its storefront in the Malibu Country Mart in preparation for a move to Hollywood. I visited Garduno last week at Free Citys workshop, just around the corner from its new space under construction on Highland Avenue, for a sneak peek at what will be on offer in the new Free City Supershop Supermat.

title: Clay Mates
description: Animals often pair up with humans in Nathalie Djurbergs Claymation videos, so it wasnt a surprise to see a blue snake bat yellow goo-goo eyes at a naked yogi in the Swedish-born artists latest work, Snakes Know Its Yoga. What was strange was the setting for the installation: the basement of the Natural History Museum in Basel, Switzerland, this past June. Then again, a storeroom full of animal bones was appropriate for an artist whose territory lies somewhere between the grotesques of Goya and the darker regions of Pee-wees Playhouse.

title: Geraldine Brooks Wins Literary Peace Prize
description: Geraldine Brooks, a novelist and journalist who covered conflicts in the Balkans, the Middle East and Africa, was named the recipient of the 2010 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for Lifetime Achievement, its organizers said on Thursday. Sharon Rab, the founder and a chairwoman of the Dayton Literary Peace Prize Foundation, said that Ms. Brooks reveals to her readers what their political leaders try to hide  the ugly realities of conflict and its destructive effects even on those far from the frontlines. She continued, We are delighted to be honoring a writer whose skill, imagination, and unique background allow her to create vivid characters whose stories help people understand the vital importance of fostering peace throughout the world. Ms. Brooks, 54, also the winner of the Pulitzer Prize in fiction in 2006, for her novel March, will receive a $10,000 prize.

He has been on countless front pages and has had a front-row seat at more than a few Senate hearings. So one might wonder when he has time to buy and sell Manhattan real estate.

title: Glaxo Memo on Avandia Is Questioned
description: Federal drug regulators ordered GlaxoSmithKline to send a letter to key doctors describing a July expert advisory panel that discussed the risks of Avandia, the companys controversial diabetes medicine. description: A poll released on Thursday by Time magazine found that many Americans express suspicious views of Islam, and more say that building a Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero in New York City would be an insult to the victims of 9/11 than say it would serve as a symbol of religious tolerance.

title: Fete Accompli | Target at The Standard
description: Look up might have been the catch phrase of last nights Target Kaleidoscope Fashion Spectacular at the Standard Hotel but there was plenty to dazzle the eye everywhere you turned. Even before the entire south side of the hotel was transformed into a neon spectacular featuring 66 models in 155 rooms, a visual feast that hinted at artist In Sook Kims Saturday Night voyeuristic hotel series, the Standards biergarten was a light show of flashing rave rings and bright psychedelic bellinis. Holding court in the middle of the colorful fray were Gossip Girl sweetheart Penn Badgley, Prabal Gurung, Richard Chai, Marchesas Georgina Chapman and hubby, Harvey Weinstein. Elsewhere, little Langley Hemingway and Leigh Lezark, who dominated in a game of table tennis earlier in the night, huddled in a secluded corner. In other words, plenty of eye candy for the onlookers on Washington Street craning their necks to spy on the invited peeping Toms.

description: LONDON  Bill Millin, a Scottish bagpiper who played highland tunes as his fellow commandos landed on a Normandy beach on D-Day and lived to see his bravado immortalized in the 1962 film The Longest Day, died on Wednesday in a hospital in the western England county of Devon. He was 88.

title: Another Take on Crostini
description: I based Tuesdays column on a peach crostini I tasted at Romans in Brooklyn last month. More recently, I returned to the restaurant. The crostini was off the menu, and in its place was a special of figs nestled on a bed of ricotta, topped with spiky arugula. It was reminiscent of the crostini  the sweet fruit, creamy cheese and tangy greens  but without the crunch of toasted bread. I liked the dish a lot, especially the luscious figs, which were grown as locally as you can get: in the Bushwick backyard of Scarlett Lindeman, one of the cooks.

title: A Pop Cartoon Springs Out of the Playbook
description: KATY PERRY was sinking. It was a listening party for her new album, Teenage Dream, and there was a beach theme, with palm trees, surfboards and gallons of sand trucked in to decorate a Midtown event space. If she were Lady Gaga she might have required a walkway built of trellised stuffed animals or prostrate assistants; instead there were just models in bikinis, eating cotton candy and tossing a beach ball: postcard Americana. Ms. Perry wasnt happy when she saw the small desert between her and her seat  I dont want sand in my stilettos, she said, pouting, echoing one of her lyrics  but she is just a regular girl gone big, so she gamely tottered across the sand in her four-inch platforms, the heels disappearing with each step. Wearing flip-flops isnt really in the pop star playbook.
