title: A Response to Andrew Sullivan (I)
description: To round out my comments on gay marriage, Im going start by taking up the second half of Andrew Sullivans criticism of my original column, because thats where youll find his most powerful argument: Namely, that opponents of gay marriage are ignoring the reality of gay lives, the integration of gay couples into mainstream American culture, and the fact that homosexuality isnt going to (and shouldnt have to) slip back into some kind of closet in order to keep lifelong heterosexual monogamy safely on its pedestal. Whats more, by ignoring these realities and failing to offer gay couples any institutional support, we are guilty of  well, Ill let Sullivan take over from here:

title: Poetry Comes to Newark
description: Newark will be turned into a Poetry Village in October, when the Dodge Poetry Festival, the largest of its kind in the nation, comes to town. Opening Oct. 7, the 13th biennial will feature an impressive lineup of poets, including four poets laureate  Billy Collins, Rita Dove, Kay Ryan and Mark Strand  as well as other acclaimed wordsmiths like Galway Kinnell, Amiri Baraka, Bob Hicok, Martn Espada, Dunya Mikhail, Joseph Millar, Nancy Morejn, Sharon Olds, Marie Ponsot and Claudia Rankine. More than 20,000 people are expected to attend the four days of readings and discussions. The festival is usually held at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., but it ran into financial difficulties this year. That is when the City of Newark and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center agreed to help sponsor the festival with the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation.

title: Well to Be Sealed After Labor Day

title: Warming Seas Threaten Coral Off Indonesia
description: A striking rise in sea temperatures in waters off Indonesia may be responsible for one of the most rapid and destructive coral bleaching events on record, a marine conservation group reported this week. Large swaths of coral reef in the Andaman Sea off the north coast of Sumatra are now up to 80 percent bleached, with more colonies expected to die off in the coming months, according to marine biologists who conducted extensive surveys of the area.

title: Quant Funds Struggle to Revive Boom Times
description: They were revered as the brightest minds in finance, the quants who could outwit Wall Street with their Ph.D.s and superfast computers. But after blundering through the financial panic, losing big in 2008 and lagging badly in 2009, these so-called quantitative investment managers no longer look like geniuses, and some investors have fallen out of love with them, The New York Timess Julie Creswell reports.

title: Peace and War
description: Jonathan Franzens new novel, Freedom, like his previous one, The Corrections, is a masterpiece of American fiction. The two books have much in common. Once again Franzen has fashioned a capacious but intricately ordered narrative that in its majestic sweep seems to gather up every fresh datum of our shared millennial life. Franzen knows that college freshmen are today called first years, like tender shoots in an overplanted garden; that a high-minded mom, however ruthless in her judgments of her neighbors ethical lapses, will condemn them with no epithet harsher than weird; that reckless drivers who barrel across lanes are almost always youngish men for whom the use of blinkers was apparently an affront to their masculinity.

title: Our Lesser-Known Allies in Afghanistan
description: KABUL  What do the Greek, Mongolian, Latvian and British Armies have in common? Theyve all been in Afghanistan before: the Greeks under Alexander; the Mongols under Genghis Khan; the Latvians as part of the Soviet Union; and the British more than a few times. They are also current members of the International Security Assistance Force, and contribute troops to the coalition mission in Afghanistan.

title: 36 Hours in Portland, Me.
description: PORTLAND, Me., is known for three Ls: lobster, lighthouses and L. L. Bean (O.K., make that four Ls). Heres another: local. In recent years, this city on the coast of Maine has welcomed a wave of locavore restaurants, urban farms and galleries that feature local artists. Abandoned brick warehouses are being repurposed as eco-friendly boutiques. In the main square, a 19th-century building has been refashioned into a farmers market. And everywhere you look, this once-sleepy industrial town is showing signs of rejuvenation  usually by keeping things local.

title: Mexicos Freedom Trail
description: MY earliest political memory is of an elementary-school trip five decades ago to the Angel of Independence, the golden winged statue atop a soaring marble column in the heart of Mexico City, where my parents had recently moved from New York. Though I cant remember the exact year of the outing, it was certainly on Sept. 16, the day Mexico celebrates the beginning of its long War of Independence (1810-21) from three centuries of Spanish colonial rule.

title: An Ancient City in Turkey Finds New Life in Modern Art
description: ON a searingly hot Saturday in early June, a small crowd of residents and tourists stood inside the entryway of the 14th-century Zinciriye Medresesi, a mosque and former medrese, or center of Islamic study, in Mardin, an ancient town in southeastern Turkey. Hanging in a row on a wall beneath the narrow rooms vaulted ceiling were front pages from recent issues of Turkish, French and British newspapers. Each was missing a headline, and visitors took turns inscribing their own on strips of paper stacked beneath the display.

title: No Dog Days in Deal Land
description: Another day, another billion-dollar deal  or two. Hey, people! Dont you know its August?

title: Theater Talkback: The Replacements Greatest Hits
description: Strange but true: the best new show in town this summer isnt a new show at all, technically. Im speaking of the revival of A Little Night Music, which sings with new subtlety and emotional force now that the celebrated Broadway veterans Bernadette Peters and Elaine Stritch have taken over the key roles of Desire Armfeldt and her caustic mum.

title: Bed Intruder Rant Earns Family a New Home
description: Updated | 7:46 p.m. It began with unlikely fodder for music, comedy or pop culture stardom: a local news report about an attempted rape. But then the victims brother stepped before the camera and delivered a lecture to the stranger who had tried to attack his sister one night last month in Huntsville, Ala., that somehow managed to be both deeply angry and oddly compelling.

title: For H.P. and Dell, Troubles at the Top Have Yet to Hurt the Bottom Line
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Executives from Hewlett-Packard and Dell, Americas two largest computer makers, ought to be rejoicing when parents open their wallets in August to arm their offspring with shiny new computers for the school year.

title: When Heroism Means Finding Truth
description: What soldier, anticipating his death in combat, wouldnt want to be remembered as a fallen hero who gave his life for his comrades? What grieving family wouldnt accept the official account, however fraudulent, of a son or daughters heroism, stifle their doubts, keep their mouths shut and be content to find some comfort in the ritual honors?

title: Spare Times
description: Around Town

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: ZOOFARI PASSPORT ADVENTURE

title: Dear FloFab: My Stepdaughter Ate My Doggie Bag!
description: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Movie Listings and Film Series
description: Movies

title: Bobby Thomsons Shot Heard in the Maternity Ward
description: Since she was a little girl, Mary Tallmer believed a really cool story about her birth.

title: Theater Listings: Aug. 20  26
description: Theater

title: Celebrating 100 Years of Alfa Romeo at the Concorso Italiano
description: This is the Bergdorf Goodman of car shows, gushes a woman at the bar of the Mission Ranch, a coastal resort owned by Clint Eastwood in Carmel, in Northern California. Outside, a summer fog hangs like a thin, gray curtain over the low marshland. I tell myself it is a good thing. The old vehicles run better in damp air.

title: Rockabilly, Barbecue and 70s Movies, on the Cheap
description: Rockabilly, gin and fast cars. It could be a fast and furious weekend for misers in the city this week:

title: The Challenge of Estimating Closing Costs for a Home
description: If youre buying a new home this year, the initial estimate from your lender of closing costs is likely to be closer to what youll ultimately pay than it would have been in the past.

title: Ladies, Feel Free to Let Loose
description: IN a room no different from many rehearsal spaces  small, bare, air-conditioned  some 20 women dance as if no one is watching.

title: The Reality Tradition
description: It may be tempting to view some reality TV series as unprecedented cultural lows, but observing the lives of indolent exhibitionists is nothing new.

title: Step Forward in Limiting Smoking Scenes in Films
description: LOS ANGELES  The figures are in: Hollywood has actually been snuffing the smoke out of movies.

title: House Tour: Livingston, N.Y.
description: WHAT House with three bedrooms, one and a half baths.

title: Tipsy Diaries: Cocktail Mashup
description: Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, takes on three bespoke cocktail experts in an experiment in improvised mixology.

title: Outsiders in French Society, Battling Occupiers and Collaborators
description: The closest person to a protagonist in the gripping historical mosaic Army of Crime is the eminent Armenian poet Missak Manouchian (Simon Abkarian). A militant Communist and hero of the French Resistance, executed by the Nazis in 1944, he is the noblest figure in a sprawling, semifictional movie that has enough characters to fill an entire neighborhood.

title: Name Your Potion: Bourbon, Cardamom, Twinkies?
description: It wasnt a question so much as a setup, a taunt. You can make a drink with anything? the young man asked.

title: Heat on the Rocks
description: Drinks  even drinks with recipes  are fickle, changeable things. I learned this in the course of coming up with my own cocktail, and the price I paid for the lesson was a fleeting sensation that my lips were on fire.

title: Whos a Joker? Steve Miller to Teach at U.S.C.
description: Up until now, wed always believed that Steve Millers rhyming of Texas, facts is, justice and taxes in Take the Money and Run was the most surprising turn hed taken in his pop-music career. But the man who some call the Space Cowboy, others describe as the Gangster of Love, and still others simply call Maurice may have outdone himself by becoming an instructor at the University of Southern California.

title: For $30 a Month, Serenity
description: Everyone knows swimming is excellent exercise, but it is also terrific therapy. Nothing frees my mind as dependably as the rhythm of my arms and legs propelling me from one end of the pool to the other. Also, as I have discovered in the 18 months since the death of the man I loved, in the pool, no one can tell the water running down your face is tears.

title: Banks Stuck With Bill for Bad Loans
description: If nobody does their job right, and disaster ensues, who should pay for the sins of all?

title: Delta Sells Tickets Through Facebook
description: Delta Airlines recently added a feature on its Facebook page that allows users to book travel through the social networking site. The application, the Delta Ticket Window, offers a pared-down version of the booking service on Deltas own (also recently retooled) Web site. There is no option to book a multicity trip or to buy a ticket using rewards, for example. But there is one crucial add-on: you can share your travel plans with friends of your choice.

title: From Luxury to Necessity, and Back Again
description: For years Americans had been labeling more and more appliances and other purchases as necessities, rather than luxuries. Microwaves, computers and other wonders of modern civilization, upon being adopted in greater numbers, became more likely to be considered need-to-haves instead of nice-to-haves, according to surveys conducted by the Pew Research Center.

title: Ludwig and Amadeus, Meeting for a Nightcap
description: The members of any string quartet will tell you that it takes a great deal of disciplined work to achieve technical finesse and control. The four young Parisian men who form the Ebne Quartet have certainly worked hard, which partly explains why they are increasingly viewed as one of the standout quartets of the new generation.

title: Exposed Wounds, and a Family Wielding Salt
description: Christophe Honors radically unsentimental family portrait, Making Plans for Lna, takes on a formidable challenge: How do you prevent viewers from losing patience with a central character whose neurotic, self-destructive behavior is so infuriating that the impulse is to flee?

title: Yes, Theyre Sleazy, but Not Originals
description: It is tempting to view Jersey Shore or any Kardashian sister as the knell of civilizations end.

title: When an Actor Casts Himself as an Artist
description: The art world prefers its artists to start out destitute and unknown, working from inside the system toward increasing visibility and renown. Early deprivation and obscurity count as dues paid, reflecting seriousness and a willingness to sacrifice. This familiar progression assures us that an artist is one of us.

title: One Restaurants History, Spiked Desserts and All
description: Spaghetti, spinach and French fries, all smothered in cream sauce: the menu at Soul Kitchen, a decrepit restaurant in a converted warehouse in an industrial section of Hamburg, Germany, may not be to everyones palate. But the place attracts a scraggly following of regulars who exit in a huff after its manager, Zinos Kazantsakis (Adam Bousdoukos), hires Shayn (Birol nel), a snooty culinary prima donna, as its new chef.

title: Turn On (MP3s), Tune In and Ride
description: BIKE riders in New York have a secret, a communal understanding about the pleasures of navigating the urban landscape, flowing through traffic and observing the city in a way that pedestrians and drivers cant. That secret is often expressed in a smile or a nod to another rider while passing on a bridge or stopped at a light, a conspiratorial acknowledgment of a shared moment with strangers in a city that can seem impervious to them.

title: Grim Reapers Slicing and Dicing Societys Foibles
description: Taking sketch comedy long-form, as many whove seen Waynes World 2 will almost certainly acknowledge, comes with considerable risk. All creative efforts assume some, but this particular shape-shift threatens to turn cultish devotion to bored dismissal. Its as dangerous as the alienation of thousands of 15-year-old boys who, alone in their rooms with their beer bongs, have been happily regurgitating every line of a favorite act as if Olivier reciting Shakespeare, only to become resentful once the sacred has been bastardized by big-budget Hollywood jerks. Sometimes you dont want the foie gras entre, just the amuse-bouche.

title: How to Use Facebooks New Location Feature
description: 8:00 p.m. | Updated Fixing information about Places and non-iPhone users.

title: Home Grown
description: Lizzie Owens likes to keep things close to home. So when the 27-year-old designer of the Highland mens-wear label moved to Manhattan from her hometown of Salt Lake City, she set up shop on the outskirts of TriBeCa and enlisted two childhood friends, Mike Franks and Cramer Tolboe, to be her business partners. Weve known each other all our lives, Owens says. Even our dads are business partners.

title: Hendrix and Handel but Mostly Hendrix
description: Jimi Hendrix died 40 years ago on Sept. 18, after ingesting too many sleeping pills and too much red wine at a girlfriends apartment in London. To commemorate the anniversary, the Handel House Museum in London is reuniting artifacts from his last performances and from his tiny apartment, next door to Handels Georgian town house on Brook Street in the upscale Mayfair district.

title: Inside the Knockoff-Tennis-Shoe Factory
description: A shopkeeper in Italy placed an order with a Chinese sneaker factory in Putian for 3,000 pairs of white Nike Tiempo indoor soccer shoes. It was early February, and the shopkeeper wanted the Tiempos pronto. Neither he nor Lin, the factory manager, were authorized to make Nikes. They would have no blueprints or instructions to follow. But Lin didnt mind. He was used to working from scratch. A week later, Lin, who asked that I only use his first name, received a pair of authentic Tiempos, took them apart, studied their stitching and molding, drew up his own design and oversaw the production of 3,000 Nike clones. A month later, he shipped the shoes to Italy. Hell order more when theres none left, Lin told me recently, with confidence.

title: The Lights of Big Brothers Eyes, Blinking in the City
description: If youre walking along East 52nd Street at night, you might notice a medium-rise building thats developed a kind of nervous tic. Its the glass-fronted Austrian Cultural Forum, where inside the lights flash on and off at unpredictable intervals.

title: Heady Intersections of Ancient and Modern
description: Wandering around the Rubin Museum of Art, which specializes in traditional art of the Himalayas, you happen upon a case containing a set of curious, cylindrical, silvery objects. Looking closely, you discover they are not antique artifacts but beer cans with their printed surfaces sanded away. More scrutiny reveals that their bottoms have been perforated by a pointed instrument, and that if you examine the other end and peer in through the drinking hole, you see a glowing, dotted-line image of a Tantric deity.

title: Glaxo Memo on Avandia Is Questioned
description: Federal drug regulators ordered GlaxoSmithKline to send a letter to crucial doctors describing a hearing in July where an expert advisory panel discussed the risks of Avandia, the companys controversial diabetes medicine.

title: African Art World Nestled in Tenafly
description: TENAFLY, N.J.  You can count the number of American public museums devoted entirely to African art on a few fingers.

title: All You Can Jet Passes Sold Out
description: According to the JetBlue Web site, both types of All You Can Jet passes are sold out. Sun Country Fall Free For All passes seem to still be available. (If you missed it, we compared the passes yesterday.) Did anyone out there scoop one up? Where do you plan to fly?

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Tim Wimborne of Reuters is one of the agency photographers who have distinguished themselves in bringing the worlds attention to the unabating misery in Pakistan. His work can be seen in the slide show, Pakistan Flood Relief. Kevin Frayer and Shakil Adil of The Associated Press are also doing exceptional work. Another compelling image by a Reuters photographer (Slide 4) comes from Bob Strong in Afghanistan. And Corentin Fohlen is shooting in Paris for The New York Times (Slide 9).

title: Our Buildings, Ourselves
description: My husband and I were not pioneers in loft living, although we had good friends who were, and our eventual move to downtown Manhattan had probably been set in motion by the long evenings spent in their large, unconventional spaces in Tribeca.

title: Excerpt: 'Death Comes to Town'
description: The short IFC series reunites the Kids in the Hall comedy troupe.

title: My Brothers Keeper (Assembly Required)
description: TEN years ago my mother died in my arms, propped up on plush, monogrammed Laura Ashley pillows with Frank Sinatra singing My Way through Sony Walkman earphones strapped to her head. The Walkman didnt fit the dcor, and neither did I. My mother and I were not close, and it was somewhat ironic that, of her four children, I would be the one rubbing her spongy forearms and kneading her ice-cold feet as she prepared to lay her burden down.

title: Actress Didi Conn Lists Rockland House
description: ITS been decades since the world was introduced to the high school kids of Grease  first the musical and then the movie  yet the songs still get stuck in your head. Only last month, Didi Conn, the actress who played Frenchy, the beauty school dropout, in the 1978 movie, hosted a sing-along of Grease tunes at the Hollywood Bowl.

title: A Tenuous Existence
description: The French government has begun cracking down on illegal camps of Roma, immigrants mostly from Romania or Bulgaria.

title: Expulsion of Roma Raises Questions in France
description: LA COURNEUVE, France  About 100 French riot police officers swooped down on an encampment of Roma here at 7 a.m. Thursday, taking names and filling out expulsion orders. Fully padded, but without helmets, the officers were aggressive but polite, accompanied by a Romanian policeman and three interpreters.

title: Speyer Daughter Sells Co-op
description: Real Estate Runs

title: Atlantic Hurricane Season Set to Intensify
description: Brian McNoldy, a meteorologist at Colorado State University who maintains a useful Web site on tropical storms in the Atlantic Ocean, has distributed an alert about a particularly noteworthy wave of low pressure moving west from Africa that appears likely to become a hurricane within a week. His note also dispels any notions that this has been a sleepy Atlantic and Caribbean storm season:

title: Living With the Aches That Wont Go Away
description: For the fortunate, pain is temporary and finite, with a clear beginning, middle and end. But for more than 70 million Americans, including Melanie Thernstrom, pain is chronic, and the primary reason that they seek medical care. The medical profession has been slow to recognize this development. There is currently one board-certified pain specialist in the United States for every 25,000 patients, she writes in her new book, The Pain Chronicles. That number, however, is likely to grow as pain is redefined not as a symptom but as a disease that can eventually rewrite the central nervous system, causing pathological changes to the brain and spinal cord, and ... greater pain.

title: The Art of James Franco
description: Images from a new exhibit at the Clocktower Gallery.

title: Out on a Limb
description: Freida Pinto is not one to shy away from a grand gesture. As my friends and family are quick to remind me, I have always been a big drama queen, Pinto, 26, recalls over breakfast in a Midtown hotel suite. As a child, I would stand in front of the mirror and pretend I was this or that person from television. All I needed to do was realize it and recognize what I wanted to do.

title: Geithner Haunted by a Goldman Past He Never Had
description: Timothy F. Geithner has been misidentified as a former Wall Street insider from Goldman Sachs so many times since he became the Treasury secretary that he and his advisers had taken to joking about it. Then the joke backfired.

title: Hot Spots: Threats and Responses
description: This week, we were especially taken with campaign ads that prompted unusual responses, like a Florida spot drawing an unusual rebuke from a normally neutral party and a Minnesota campaign that has attracted a boycott drive against Target.

title: In W.P.S., a Job, an Adventure, a Challenge
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog during the defending champions 2010 season.

title: Democrats Meet, With an Eye on November
description: ST. LOUIS  The Democratic National Committee opened its summer meeting here on Thursday, with party leaders taking a moment to bask in legislative achievements on health care and financial regulation even as they braced for the prospect of deep losses in the fall elections.

title: A Paris House and a Playful Street Link
description: IT seems appropriate to say I love the new Herms scarf site, jaimemoncarre.com, which the Paris company just introduced. Ive been a fan of the main Herms site, but this is a clever addition for a house that is known for silk scarves and derives a lot of revenue from them. Herms focuses on young women in Paris, London, New York and Tokyo, offers brief bio sketches and then shows how they wear scarves  which are having a comeback. The photographs are a cut above street-fashion images, and yet not as glossy-perfect as those found in magazines.

title: Fords Models
description: The agency that set the standard for American beauty in the 50s is getting an overhaul. Is there a Ford in your future?

title: 2011 Ferrari 458 Italia
description: The Italia says that beauty doesnt have to be sacrificed to modern performance.

title: Covering Its Tracks Paid Off Handsomely
description: ITS a common hobby, searching for surviving pieces of the 1910 Pennsylvania Station, like ironwork, brass handrails and other fragments, amidst its vulgar replacement of the 1960s.

title: The Body Shop
description: The year was 1958. Eileen Ford was traveling through Europe, hoping to discover a new face or two for the Ford Model Agency, the company she ran back in New York with her husband, Jerry. Though Eileen didnt find any potential stars abroad, she was far from discouraged when she returned. A Long Island-raised, Barnard-educated woman driven by a surplus of weapons-grade ambition, Eileen was already well known in the industry for being immune to emotions like discouragement. Also, she had noticed something pleasing about the style of the European girls  a reminder of how and why her company had already become the most successful of its kind. Long regarded for their sophisticated, heroically unapproachable beauty  an aesthetic that had been the dominant face of fashion throughout the 50s  many of the girls now seemed to embrace a more wholesome look. They were pert and welcoming, bright-eyed and often blond-haired: eager, in short, to project a kind of dewy innocence. Everyone there, Eileen noted when she got back, wants to look American. Which was one way of putting it. Were she less a believer in the power of modesty, Eileen could just as easily have said everyone wanted to look like a Ford model.

title: Streetscapes | Terminal City
description: There are still remnants of what was conceived as Terminal City, a unified matrix of development on the new real estate created when the tracks surrounding Grand Central Station were covered.

title: New to America, Discovering Its Glitter
description: Maos Last Dancer is the story of a young and flexible Chinese man who comes to America, where hes seduced by disco, creative freedom and a honey-haired Houston virgin, and decides to stay.

title: Giants Phillips Is Looking Forward to His Return
description: ALBANY  Giants safety Kenny Phillips is good-humored, almost kid-like, by nature, often wearing a smile and munching Gummi Bears after lunch at training camp. Since he arrived here, though, his impatience to return has been obvious.

title: Your Ex Has a Problem. Its You.
description: I live with a former boyfriend who is one of my closest friends. Recently, he began sleeping with our new next-door neighbor, whom I have not yet met. Im not interested in rekindling our romance, but this situation makes me feel icky. Here are my ground rules: never sleep with your exs sister, her friends or her next-door neighbors. Ive encouraged his seeing other women, just not the ones who live right here! But my ex doesnt understand the problem. Do you?

title: Supercalifragi  Oops, Wrong Nanny
description: Emma Thompson is back, warts, snaggletooth and all, to teach unruly children lessons in self-reliance and to remind parents that theyre basically useless if sometimes amusing appendages in Nanny McPhee Returns.

title: Off-Road Racing Promoters Permits Suspended
description: The Bureau of Land Management acted on Thursday to suspend the permits for Mojave Desert Racing, the promoter of last weekends deadly off-road race near Lucerne Valley, Calif.

title: Up Front: Linda Robinson
description: The book Linda Robinson reviews on the cover of this weeks Book Review, Eliza Griswolds Tenth Parallel, is about some of the most troublesome of the worlds trouble spots.

title: Christians and Muslims
description: The influential political scientist Samuel P. Huntington theorized about the clash of civilizations. The journalist and poet Eliza Griswold takes on the same topic in a much more visceral way: she traveled through the torrid zone to see, smell, taste and write about it. Her book The Tenth Parallel is a fascinating journey along the latitude line in Africa and Asia where Christianity and Islam often meet and clash. Since Americans commonly equate Islam with the Arab Middle East, this book is a useful reminder that four-fifths of Muslims live elsewhere. Its also an intimate introduction to some of those who live in places like Nigeria, Sudan, Somalia, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines.

title: In a Baste and Switch, a New Father Is Born
description: The moment the scatterbrained romantic comedy The Switch loses its last shred of common sense occurs on a New York City bus. A stranger admiring the little boy accompanying Wally (Jason Bateman), the neurotic bachelor who narrates the story, comments that he looks just like his father.

title: Young Lawyers Turn to Public Service
description: WASHINGTON  In August 2008, Nathan Richardson committed to following in the footsteps of so many young lawyers before him: a summer position with a big law firm, followed by a job offer before he ever cracked open a third-year textbook. And then everything changed.

title: Imam Behind New York Project Starts Mideast Tour
description: CAIRO  Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf, the organizer of the planned Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan, arrived in Bahrain on Thursday to begin a three-country tour of the Persian Gulf sponsored by the United States State Department.

title: A Bull Market in Sketchy Art
description: When youve really made it on Wall Street, you fill up your Fifth Avenue co-op with expensive art, just as surely as snow is followed by little boys on sleds (to paraphrase Arthur Okun, the legendary Yale economist).

title: Blagojevich Items Go Up for Bid, Including Elvis
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill.  A bad week for Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, got a little worse on Thursday when a moving company here auctioned off his personal items to the highest bidder because he failed to make payments on a storage unit.

title: G.M. Chief Sees I.P.O. As Exit Sign
description: DETROIT  Since he became chief executive of General Motors in December, Edward E. Whitacre Jr. has lived for the day that G.M. would become a public company again and shed the stigma of government ownership.

title: Census Survey Asks Too Much, G.O.P. Says
description: The Republican National Committee is demanding that the Census Bureau stop being so nosy, or at least stop requiring that Americans comply.

title: Is It Normal Grief, or Depression?
description: To the Editor:

title: Making a Game Out of Beating Expectations
description: MADRID  Of all the coaches who overlooked Stephen Curry as a young player, Mike Krzyzewski acknowledges that his missed evaluation may be the most glaring. Curry attended Dukes basketball camp as a youngster, making Krzyzewski and his staff among the first who labeled Curry as too short, too thin and too one-dimensional.

title: Access at Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: With Manning Already Out, Giants Lose His Backup
description: ALBANY  The Giants do not know how long quarterback Eli Manning will be unable to wear a helmet because of the stitches in his forehead, but the team will be thin at quarterback for the next few weeks.

title: The Best Eggs
description: To the Editor:

title: Australias Labor Party Faces a Fight for Survival
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia has not had a recession in nearly 20 years. It is one of the few industrialized countries to have emerged unscathed from the global downturn, riding the wave of Chinas insatiable demand for raw materials. Gross domestic product grew by 2.7 percent last year, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia, and unemployment was an enviable 5.3 percent in July, about half the rate of the United States.

title: The Unraveling of America
description: To the Editor:

title: PGA Says Viewership Decline Shouldnt Be Costly in TV Talks
description: Drama is not always enough to sell viewers on golf. Sometimes these devotees seem to disappear into an Irish mist as if they were waiting for Tiger Woods to become Superman again.

title: Parks Worker Is Raped at Playground in Brooklyn
description: A parks department employee was raped on Thursday morning by a man armed with a box cutter at a playground in Brooklyn, according to the police.

title: Fishs Strong Play Continues
description: 10:50 p.m. | Updated

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,214 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Dont Drop Out of School Innovation
description: HOW much evidence does the government need before trying something new in the troubled realm of public education? Should there be airtight proof that a pioneering program works before we commit federal money to it  or is it sometimes worth investing in promising but unproven innovations?

title: Moscow Weather Back to Normal After Fires
description: MOSCOW  The warm voice of a tenor rehearsing at the open window of an opera house here floated out over a breezy courtyard filled with people doing what until Thursday was downright unpleasant and at times potentially life threatening: relaxing outdoors.

title: Covering the Bases
description: There are hundreds of baseball movies, but the truly good ones pretty much begin and end with Ron Shelton (Bull Durham and, to a lesser extent, Cobb). Gary Lundgrens debut feature, Calvin Marshall, aspires to that league but doesnt rise above Class A.

title: Over a Billion Years, Scientists Find, the Moon Went Through a Shrinking Phase
description: The Moon is shrinking.

title: Government Gadfly in Teaneck, N.J., Is Killed
description: TEANECK, N.J.  Not everyone in town knew Joan Davis, but it seemed that way. Her never-failing presence at various township meetings was the stuff of local lore.

title: OReilly Distances Himself From a Video Promotion
description: This summer Bill OReilly, the biggest star on the Fox News Channel, lent his name  inadvertently, he says  to a Web ad that lured viewers to sign up for a financial newsletter sold by Newsmax, the conservative Web site.

title: Fatalities on the Job Fell in 2009
description: The total number of fatal workplace injuries fell by 17 percent last year, to 4,340, down from 5,214 in 2008, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported on Thursday.

title: Bow Wow Hits It Big
description: The comedy Lottery Ticket may be the video director Erik Whites first feature, but the prevailing presence in this crowd-pleaser is Ice Cube, whose evolution from hip-hop threat to screen paterfamilias is now complete. (Was he really once one of gangsta raps founding fathers in N.W.A.? I guess hes been busy masterminding the Friday, Barbershop and Are We There Yet? franchises  and being an executive producer here.)

title: Screen Test | Freida Pinto
description: Freida Pinto discusses her childhood aspirations, her career thus far and her thoughts on the film industry.

title: Math Lessons for Locavores
description: Leesburg, Va.

title: Blagojevich Trial Ends Fitzgeralds Successes
description: CHICAGO  Around here, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney for the Northern District of Illinois and, lately, the overseer of the prosecution of former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, has been called a modern-day Eliot Ness. His name has been tossed about, without his participation, as a future mayor or governor or something. A radio host once introduced him as the biggest Chicago guy or gal there is, aside, maybe, from Oprah Winfrey.

title: Appeasing the Bond Gods
description: As I look at what passes for responsible economic policy these days, theres an analogy that keeps passing through my mind. I know its over the top, but here it is anyway: the policy elite  central bankers, finance ministers, politicians who pose as defenders of fiscal virtue  are acting like the priests of some ancient cult, demanding that we engage in human sacrifices to appease the anger of invisible gods.

title: Now Playing: A Short Film Starring Branded Content
description: IN Charley, a nine-minute film by Dee Austin Robertson, a young couple visiting New York for a romantic weekend, Courtney and Ryan (played by Alexia Rasmussen and Brian McElhaney), are first seen through a glass door with an Ace Hotel sign painted on it. Ryan pulls along a suitcase with a strap that bobs behind him like a leash leading a dog, a scene that foreshadows the pet-related tension between the couple: Courtney proceeds to talk obsessively about her cat, Charley, ruining the weekend.

title: New Afghan Intelligence Chief Aims to Build Trust
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans new intelligence chief said this week that the Taliban appeared to have the upper hand in the insurgency but could still be defeated with better cooperation between Afghan and coalition forces and a stronger government effort to build trust in the rural communities.

title: Culture Collisions in the Andes
description: In Altiplano, primitivism and modernism collide when bereaved women from opposite ends of the socioeconomic spectrum ignite a self-consciously spiritual tale of ecological exploitation.

title: California: Company Banned From Racing
description: The federal Bureau of Land Management on Thursday suspended off-road racing events run by Mojave Desert Racing Productions, the corporation responsible for a race last Saturday in which eight people were killed when a truck rolled into spectators. Races organized by other groups will be reviewed and approved on an individual basis, said a spokesman for the agency. The suspension will stay in effect while San Bernardino County officials investigate the fatal accident at the California 200 off-road race in Lucerne Valley.

title: Pettittes Words and Character Carry Weight
description: The moral to this story is, be careful whom you choose as your training partner. Its almost as dangerous as pillow talk, the kind of shop talk that goes on when two buddies lift weights and run laps.

title: California: Police Group Backs Marijuana Measure
description: A national group of African-American law enforcement officers has endorsed Proposition 19, a ballot measure that would tax and regulate marijuana in California. The National Black Police Association, which has more than two dozen chapters across the country, announced the endorsement in Sacramento, where the organization is holding a national conference. In a statement, Neill Franklin, the executive director of Law Enforcement Against Prohibition, which supports Proposition 19, said that prohibition takes a toll on people of color across the country. He added: Californians finally have an opportunity to do something about it. The measure would allow possession of up to an ounce of marijuana for personal use.

title: Foreclosures Grind On
description: There is a lot of grim economic news out there, including Thursdays report that initial claims for unemployment insurance rose to half a million people last week. The news on housing  where the financial crisis began  is also bad. And the governments response to high foreclosure rates continues to fall far short of what is needed to help Americans hold on to their homes and to stabilize home prices.

title: Screen Test | Cheryl Tiegs
description: Ms. Tiegs on her modeling career, her body image, and her definition of beauty.

title: Islamic Center Exposes Mixed Feelings Locally
description: In the storm of anger and accusation over an Islamic center and mosque planned near ground zero, one thing seems clear to Laique Khan: His fellow Muslims have a right to build the project.

title: People Magazine Subscribers to Receive Free Access on iPads
description: The iPad application for People will be free to readers who subscribe to the magazine, the first step toward what Time Inc., the worlds largest magazine publisher, hopes is a model for the bundling of print and digital sales for all its publications.

title: Democrat Keeps Pelosi at Arms Length
description: Representative Joe Donnelly really wants to tell voters that hes independent.

title: Once Bound for Cooperstown, Now Headed to a Courtroom
description: Days before Roger Clemens was to testify before a House committee in February 2008, Congressional leaders gave him one final chance to change his mind and not speak publicly.

title: U.S. Assures Israel That Iran Threat Is Not Imminent
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, citing evidence of continued troubles inside Irans nuclear program, has persuaded Israel that it would take roughly a year  and perhaps longer  for Iran to complete what one senior official called a dash for a nuclear weapon, according to American officials.

title: At the Far Edge
description: For months, it has been clear that Republican Congressional candidates would benefit from independent voters dissatisfaction with President Obama. With the Republican field now largely in place, all voters might want to take a close look at who those candidates are.

title: Mental Illness in New Jersey, Secretly
description: The independent film Hiding Divya wants to shine a light on a social problem: the covering up or ignoring of mental illness among South Asians. And while the movie has its heart in the right place, the first-time writer-director Rehana Mirza doesnt yet have the skills to shape the narrative into something moving or revealing.

title: For Digital Artists, Apps Provide New Palette
description: Publishers were not the only ones drooling when Apple unveiled its iPad to great fanfare in the spring. Digital artists also marveled at the devices potential.

description: It is like a message from the afterlife.

title: A Nurse as Dominatrix
description: Midway through Modern Love Is Automatic, a scruffy film by Zach Clark about a nurse who decides to log time as a dominatrix, someone asks the nurse, Lorraine (Melodie Sisk), why she wants to try this new career. She has no answer. And at that moment, you may think that Mr. Clark, too, has no answer to the question of why he wanted to make a movie about a dominatrix. After all, he adds nothing to the whips-and-leather cinematic clichs.

title: Lilly Moves Closer to Approval to Market Cymbalta for Chronic Pain
description: A federal panel on Thursday voted narrowly to recommend allowing Eli Lilly to market its blockbuster antidepressant Cymbalta for some chronic pain conditions like lower back ailments that affect millions of Americans.

title: Meeting the Man Who Made Him the (Mistaken) Messiah
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Behind Fraud Charges, New Jerseys Deep Crisis
description: New Jersey got in trouble with federal regulators this week for misrepresenting the health of its pension funds. But the bigger problem may be what the state was trying to hide: a long-brewing crisis in its ability to pay retirees.

title: Inquiry Into Ex-Sheriffs Motor Pool
description: New Jersey authorities are investigating whether the Passaic County Sheriffs Department motor pool repaired the vehicles of donors to the campaign of the former sheriff, according to people briefed on the inquiry.

title: Newsom Steps Away From Limelight on Same-Sex Marriage
description: On the night of Aug. 4, after a federal district judge struck down Proposition 8, Californias ban on same-sex marriage, a gaggle of San Francisco politicians worked their way up the City Hall steps to rally the jubilant crowd of 800 that was roaring its approval for the landmark ruling.

title: Economy in Britain Shows Signs of Strength
description: LONDON  The British economy showed signs of strengthening Thursday after reports that the countrys budget deficit shrank at a faster pace than expected in July and retail sales posted the biggest gain in five months.

title: First Niagara to Acquire Rival Bank for $1.5 Billion
description: Bank deal makers have been all but dormant the last two years, with few lenders willing to contemplate a merger in the aftermath of a financial crisis.

title: No Names, Please
description: A rare bipartisan move is afoot to crimp one of the clubby abuses of the United States Senate  the secret hold that lone lawmakers employ anonymously to block worthy bills and nominees. Secret holds have been used by both parties to halt progress and extort concessions, even after a measure has been enthusiastically approved for advancement by committee majorities.

title: Giants May Pass on Another Summer in Albany
description: ALBANY  The mileposts in Giants history since 1996 can be traced to the University at Albany, the host of the teams training camp for the last 15 years.

description: After it became clear Thursday that Lance Berkman was headed to the disabled list, the Yankees realized they needed another infielder on the roster.

title: Google and Yahoo Win Appeal in Argentine Case
description: BUENOS AIRES  In a rare victory for Google and Yahoo Argentina, an appeals court has cleared the companies of defamation for including sex-related Web sites in their search results for an Argentine entertainer.

title: Frank Kermode
description: I met Frank Kermode, who died Tuesday at age 90, more than 20 years ago over coffee at Columbia University, where he was teaching. I had come to propose writing a profile about him, a project that went nowhere mainly because the magazine I had hoped to write for didnt write about literary critics in those days. Kermode didnt dismiss the idea, and so I heard, that afternoon, about the Isle of Man, where he was born in a herringless winter, as he later wrote.

description: Journalists see many things in high-profile court cases that never get reported. Jurors fall asleep. Lawyers roll their eyes. Family members shake their heads.

title: Program Offers Support for Victims of Domestic Violence, but It Is Challenging
description: For any first-time visitor, Cook Countys Domestic Violence Courthouse  with its unmarked hallways and frequently abandoned information desk  presents a navigational challenge. For an abuse victim, who may be terrified and injured, the blank walls and empty corridors are just the first bewildering step in a long, convoluted and impersonal process.

title: With Martz in the House, Playoffs Beckon
description: In Alaska, where I recently visited, its hard not to notice the bears. Black bears, grizzly bears, Kodiak bears, Chicago Bears. Yes, even 2,912 miles from their Bourbonnais, Ill., training camp, word reaches a traveler that this simply has to be the Bears year.

title: $375,000 Lexus LFA: Ferrari Fighter or Exotic Fantasy?
description: MILLVILLE, N.J.

title: Judge Sees Evidence to Tie Man in Shootout to Felony
description: Citing extremely strong circumstantial evidence, a judge ruled on Thursday that there was reasonable cause to believe that a man who had been hit numerous times during a shootout in which the police had fired 46 rounds committed a felony.

title: In Iraq War, Soldiers Say They Had a Job to Do
description: BAGHDAD  Staff Sgt. Lucas C. Trammell, a tank gunner with the Third Infantry Division, fought his way into Baghdad in 2003. He was back in 2005, abandoning the tank for foot patrols in a very unsafe Ramadi, and again in 2007 as bodyguard for a battalion commander in Baghdad.

description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Someone should open a HASE stadium in Queens just to really confuse solvers. Maybe not; this Friday puzzle is a typical Brad Wilber construction, meaning its tough enough already. Its so full of trickery that its hard to know where to start.

description: Is there room enough in Manhattan for two loving tributes to the heyday of the hair band?

description: MORE automakers are offering free scheduled maintenance as an incentive for customers to choose their brand, and to encourage existing owners to remain loyal when they are ready for their next vehicle.

description: As American forces withdraw, Anthony Shadid and Stephen Farrell assess Iraq's unstable political establishment.

title: Despite Risks, an Addictive Treat Fuels a Chinese City
description: XIANGTAN, China  If the residents of this city seem a bit lively on even the hottest days or most frigid nights, check their mouths. That minty scent and cracking sound come from a fragrant pick-me-up that men, women and even children chew from breakfast until bedtime.

title: In Monterey, Classics Turn Bankable
description: MONTEREY, Calif.

title: A Met Who Is Forgotten but Not Gone
description: HOUSTON  The Mets clubhouse these days is a mix of apprehension and business as usual. The team is perilously close to playoff irrelevance, so the players know every game counts. But they try to remain loose by joking with one another, playing cards and sipping beers after games.

title: From Houston to the Bronx, Some Divisions on Clemens
description: HOUSTON  Roger Clemens went to high school here, played college baseball at the University of Texas a few hours away and led the Astros to two playoff appearances in his three years on the team. A seven-time Cy Young Award winner, Clemens still lives in the area, and his son Koby is now in the Astros farm system.

title: Russia: More Evidence in Crash That Killed Poles
description: Russia on Thursday gave Polands chief military prosecutor 11 volumes of new evidence in the April 10 plane crash that killed President Lech Kaczynski of Poland and 95 others, many of them top-ranking officials in the Polish government. The evidence included interviews with witnesses, photographs of the crash site, results of forensic testing of victims bodies and amateur video of the wreckage made shortly after the Russian-built Tu-154 aircraft crashed into a wooded area near Smolensk, in western Russia, Russian news agencies said. Polish officials have complained that Russia was slow in handing over the evidence. The Polish military prosecutor, Gen. Krzysztof Parulski, said Thursday that charges could be filed on the basis of the evidence, but he did not elaborate.

title: South Africa: Rubber Bullets Wound Striking Workers
description: A strike for higher wages by more than one million public employees  teachers and health care workers among them  entered its second day on Thursday. At least five strikers were wounded when a police officer fired rubber bullets at a crowd trying to block the exit ramp of a Johannesburg highway, the police said.

title: The Netherlands: Witness-intimidation Inquiry
description: A judge at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague has ordered an independent inquiry into complaints by defense witnesses and associates of the Serbian nationalist leader Vojislav Seselj, that investigators working for the prosecution in the past had pressured or intimidated witnesses for Mr. Seselj. Mr. Seselj, a former leader of the Serbian Radical Party, surrendered to the court in 2003 to face charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity in the former Yugoslavia. He has frequently disrupted proceedings and threatened the court while acting as his own lawyer. Although the trial is continuing, Mr. Seselj was recently sentenced to 18 months imprisonment for contempt of court and revealing the names of protected witnesses.

title: For Intel, a Merger Of Fish and Fowl
description: Intels $7.7 billion deal to buy the security firm McAfee is a surprising gamble. Mobile devices are the chip industrys future, and Intel has fallen behind. It is betting that combining McAfees security software with its hardware will give it a leg up. But investors who knocked down Intels shares are rightly skeptical the chip maker can pull it off.

title: Harold Connolly, Who Beat Odds in Olympics and Romance, Dies at 79
description: Harold Connolly, who overcame a withered left arm to win the hammer throw in the 1956 Melbourne Olympics and who then, after a storybook cold war romance, married the womens discus champion, Olga Fikotova of Czechoslovakia, died on Wednesday in Catonsville, Md. He was 79.

title: North Korea: South Korea Boat Broke Law, North Says
description: North Korea confirmed Thursday that it was holding a South Korean fishing boat and its seven-man crew, 11 days after its navy detained the craft in the Korean Peninsula. The crew members  four South Koreans and three Chinese  confessed to fishing illegally in North Korean waters on Aug. 8, the Norths state-run news agency, KCNA, said. It did not clarify whether or when North Korea would release the crew, which South Korea has been requesting.

title: Fish Defeats Gasquet to Advance to Quarterfinals
description: Just as one American tennis player is surging, another may miss the United States Open. Mardy Fish continued his blistering summer play, winning for the 14th time in his past 15 matches, beating Richard Gasquet, 7-5, 6-2, Thursday to advance to the quarterfinals at the Cincinnati Masters in Mason, Ohio.

description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton is expected to announce Friday that Israel and the Palestinians will return to direct negotiations for the first time in 20 months, delivering the Obama administration a small victory in its protracted effort to revive the Middle East peace process, two officials briefed on the situation said Thursday evening.

title: Talks on Opening Clinic in St. Vincents Building Are Stalled Over Birth Control
description: Negotiations to open an urgent-care center at the shuttered St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village have been stalled by a dispute over financial terms and by demands by former officials of the institution, a Roman Catholic hospital, that birth control not be made available there, officials close to the negotiations said on Thursday.

title: Fan Jumps From Balcony
description: A young man jumped from the balcony at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, N.Y., on Wednesday night and plunged 25 feet to the seats below, the New York State Park Police said. The man fell shortly before 10 p.m., during a sold-out Phish concert, and was airlifted to the Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, N.Y., where he was treated for his injuries, the police said in a statement. Several news reports said the man was 25, but the police said his identity was still being confirmed; a spokeswoman for the hospital said a man had been taken there by helicopter from the theater on Wednesday night and was in critical but stable condition. His name was not released. Live Nation Entertainment, the promoter of the concerts at Jones Beach, and representatives of the band did not respond to requests for comment.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Justin Guarini of idol Joins Musical Cast
description: Months before the official opening of Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, theatergoers have thrilled to each incremental casting announcement for this musical adaptation of the Pedro Almodvar comedy, as celebrated Broadway stars like Patti LuPone, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Sherie Rene Scott and Laura Benanti were added to its ensemble. Who, these impatient observers wondered, would be cast in the final principal role of this production? Now they have their answer. Justin Guarini, above, the runner-up on the first season of American Idol, has joined the musicals cast, Lincoln Center Theater said on Thursday. Mr. Guarini, who was beaten by Kelly Clarkson for the Idol crown in 2002, will play the role of Carlos, the son of Ivan (Mr. Mitchell) and Lucia (Ms. LuPone). It will be the Broadway debut of Mr. Guarini, who previously appeared in a workshop version of the Beach Boys musical Good Vibrations and with Ms. Clarkson in the film From Justin to Kelly. Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown is directed by Bartlett Sher with a book by Jeffrey Lane and music and lyrics by David Yazbek. It is to begin previews at the Belasco Theater on Oct. 2 and open on Nov. 4.

description: maim \mam\ verb

title: And So It Goes: Vonnegut Library to Open
description: Though he may or may not continue to exist in the Tralfamadorian sense of the word, a part of Kurt Vonnegut, below, will live on in an Indianapolis library dedicated to him that will contain artifacts from his life and career. The Associated Press reported on Wednesday that the Kurt Vonnegut Memorial Library will have its opening in November, where it will display first-edition books by the Slaughterhouse Five and Sirens of Titans author, who died in 2007, as well as a replica of his writing studio, items he collected during his service in World War II and numerous rejection letters he received before achieving his literary fame. We have boxes of rejection letters, Edie Vonnegut, the authors oldest daughter, told The A.P., letters saying, You have no talent and we suggest you give up writing. He did not have an easy time of it, and I think for anyone who wants to be a writer, it will be important for them to see how tough it was for him. The 1,100-square-foot space will also feature the Purple Heart that Vonnegut was awarded for a wound he received as a soldier, as well as a gallery of his line art and his cigarette-stained Smith Corona typewriter.

title: Geraldine Brooks Wins Literary Peace Prize
description: Geraldine Brooks, a novelist and journalist who covered conflicts in the Balkans, the Middle East and Africa, was named the recipient of the 2010 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for Lifetime Achievement, its organizers said on Thursday. Sharon Rab, the founder of the Dayton Literary Peace Prize Foundation, said Ms. Brooks reveals to her readers what their political leaders try to hide  the ugly realities of conflict and its destructive effects even on those far from the frontlines. She continued, We are delighted to be honoring a writer whose skill, imagination, and unique background allow her to create vivid characters whose stories help people understand the vital importance of fostering peace throughout the world. Ms. Brooks, 54, also the winner of the Pulitzer Prize in fiction in 2006, for her novel March, will receive a $10,000 prize.

title: Brooklyn Museum to Extend Hours
description: Beginning Oct. 6 the Brooklyn Museum, above, will keep later hours, the museum announced, staying open until 6 p.m. on Wednesdays and 10 p.m. on Thursdays and Fridays. (It is now open until 5 p.m. on those days.) To offset the change, the museum will open an hour later, at 11 a.m. Weekend hours, from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., will remain the same. Clearly theres a need for more opportunities post-5 oclock, whether its families with kids getting out of school, or people coming from work, or younger people going on dates, the museums director, Arnold L. Lehman, said in a phone interview. We wanted to make a change that would better accommodate a very broad-based audience. He said the museum would organize programs for Thursday and Friday evenings, like lectures and films. The museum will hire a few extra people in visitor services and the store to accommodate the new hours, he said, but in both instances our hope is that our suggested admission will more than cover whatever costs we have. The museum, which suggests that adults contribute $10, has struggled over the last decade in its attempts to increase attendance and to navigate between serving established museum audiences and attracting new audiences with populist fare. (Attendance in 2009 was 340,000, down 23 percent from the year before.)

title: Conductor Speaks Out After His Arrest
description: Paul Hillier, below, the conductor who was arrested en route to his appearance at the Mostly Mozart Festival for nonpayment of child support, said he was withholding the money from his former wife because she did not allow his daughters to visit him, The Daily Mail of London reported on Wednesday. Mr. Hillier, the chief conductor of Ars Nova Copenhagen, was indicted on Aug. 5 by an Oregon grand jury on four felony counts of criminal nonsupport for failing to make approximately $90,000 in payments for his two daughters, who live in that state. Last week he was apprehended at Newark Liberty International Airport, taken to the Essex County Jail and released  after wiring the money he owed  in time to attend his ensembles performance at Alice Tully Hall last Friday. In a statement, Mr. Hillier, 61, told The Daily Mail that he had been treated with great courtesy and understanding by the Department of Homeland Security officials who detained him. He added that he had paid his child support to his daughters, now 24 and 19, regularly for several years, but despite the visitation rights he had been granted in his divorce, the visitation was totally and very effectively prevented by the girls mother. Mr. Hillier wrote: I feel this loss very deeply, and I feel that my rights as a father have been comprehensively trampled into the ground.

title: Essar Looking Outside India for Acquisitions
description: This has been a week of heightened interest in Indias power companies, with Blackstone taking a chunk of Moser Baer Projects Private and indicating it would invest $4 billion in the country over the next 5 years. Now, The Financial Times reports, Indias Essar Energy is considering its own acquisitions off the subcontinent.

What sets this retrospective apart is that it has dedicated half of the screenings to his early period as a director in Britain, including some lesser-known films, starting on Sept. 10. Drought and the collapse of farm prices did the rest. A newly vulnerable landscape peeled up from its moorings and blew away before the eyes of a horrified nation.

Then she added, Only divine creation could have created such an organ. I didnt want to hear her religious views, but I felt vulnerable, because I was having a test performed in a doctors office, and said nothing. Should I speak to her boss? P.W., PASADENA, CALIF.

title: The Poetry of Prose
description: We English speakers have been terribly insecure about our ability to communicate in our native tongue for at least 200 years, if the number of books aiming to correct errors in our speech and writing released during that time is any measure. Basic grammar books have existed since the 16th century, but it wasnt until the 18th that guides like Robert Bakers Reflections on the English Language (1770) and James Elphinstons charmingly titled Inglish Orthoggraphy, Epittomized (1790) began specifically addressing common mistakes of usage. It was in the 1800s, though, that anxiety over usage really started to mount, with hundreds of grammars and polemics finding their way to print: 1829 saw The Vulgarities of Speech Corrected: With Elegant Expressions for Provincial and Vulgar English, Scots, and Irish; for the Use of Those Who are Unacquainted With Grammar; in 1841 there was Decline of the English Language: The Cause and Probable Consequences; and A Plea for the Queens English came out in 1863. For the most part these were pragmatic and steely-eyed affairs, not the kinds of books to employ excess humor or display too-great charity regarding the vicissitudes of usage.

title: Inside the List

Freedom, Jonathan Franzens long-awaited follow-up to The Corrections, is almost certain to make the best-seller list, so lets just get our coverage out of the way now. Like its predecessor, Freedom is set mainly in the Midwest, and Franzens own Midwesternness has drawn plenty of commentary. Sam Tanenhaus, who calls the new novel a masterpiece of American fiction on our Aug. 29 cover, recently wrote in a blog post, Franzen is attuned to the differences between the Eastern Seaboards voluptuary pleasures and indulgences, and the midlands homelier values. Meanwhile, Sam Anderson of New York magazine, in his rave, scored the Midwestern literary metaphor of the year, saying that some of Franzens sentences are so well written you want to pluck them out, stab them with little corn holders and eat them.

A teacher and a counselor at her college attempt to understand her and eventually introduce her to a Craig Venter-like geneticist; she becomes a celebrity, with mixed results. Powers manages the difficult feat of making the young woman plausible and even fascinating, and the book is an excellent introduction to Powerss work, our reviewer, Jay McInerney, said.

His response to Saras death is not so much stoic as anesthetized. He goes about his routines of healthy breakfast, swimming, work and more work, seeming increasingly numb and remote. title: Beyond the Paper

Their jobs are about to be rendered obsolete as offset printing, with its keyboard entry and computer tape, ushers in an era of electronic publishing that will ultimately lead to the World Wide Web and beyond. You learned the skill and now the bottoms dropping out, Rabbits boss at the plant says as he lays him off. title: Forms and Functions
description: In 1847, Oliver Byrne, surveyor of Her Majestys settlements in the Falkland Islands and author of numerous mathematical works, wrote and designed an illustrated book so far ahead of its time that, with the exception of a few pass typographical details, it could have been published today. In fact, it has been published today, as a stunning boxed facsimile edition. Given its less is more layout and primary-color palette  red, blue, yellow, black  THE FIRST SIX BOOKS OF THE ELEMENTS OF EUCLID: In Which Coloured Diagrams and Symbols Are Used Instead of Letters for the Greater Ease of Learners (Taschen, $59.99) prefigures the art and design of 20th-century avant-garde movements. Yet although the illustration on the title page is the spitting image of a de Stijl and Bauhaus design, the mid-19th-century publishing date disqualifies it from being modern in the Museum of Modern Art sense of the word.
