description: THERE is one superpower the actor Tom Welling, who plays a young Clark Kent in Smallville, would love to have in real life.

title: Mad Men and the Time & Life Building
description: Fans of the AMC series Mad Men, about the advertising business  and life in the United States  in the 1960s love to analyze each episode and discuss whether the nitty-gritty details are realistic or represent the writers and producers taking creative license.

title: Growing Concern About Tainted Eggs After Recall
description: A national outbreak of salmonella was linked on Friday to another major egg producer, Hillandale Farms, prompting the recall of an additional 170 million eggs in 14 states.

title: The Merchant of Death Diet Plan
description: While the wife of a Russian businessman detained in Bangkok since 2008 looked distraught on Friday as a Thai court rejected his plea to be released, photographs of the man in handcuffs and leg irons, Viktor Bout, revealed that his stint behind bars has at least helped him to shed some excess weight.

title: Adventure Guide to Mexico
description: Mexico offers lesser-known adventure experiences found deep in the jungle or near small fishing villages and offshore reefs.

title: Now Showing | VPL in Action
description: Clothes dont really come to life until they are on a living  moving  body. So whatever you want to make of the proliferation of electronic media, it makes sense that a lot of fashion designers are gravitating toward film and video as a way of presenting and promoting their collections. I feel videos are much more liberating in that they show movement and action, says the designer Victoria Bartlett. In my eyes its a more modern way of capturing an image. There is a natural ease that comes with video  its more spontaneous and produces more surprising results. For her fall collection, which she says is all about fracturing, fragmenting and re-assembling, she teamed up with the artist Jessica Mitrani and the dancer Maria Hassabi to create a video that explores Siamese twinning with graphic, optical effects created in post-production, and also with a pair of doubled underwear.

title: Manhunt in Arizona Ends in Arrests
description: PHOENIX  The escaped inmate and his fiance who were captured Thursday night after three weeks on the run had used their knowledge of the wilderness, their ability to talk a good game and their guns to elude a huge multistate search, the authorities said.

title: On This Beach, No Evidence of New York Cynicism
description: When a faithful reader sent along news of an academic study concluding that surfing boosts ones mood, Waves could not wait to run the results past New York-area surfers.

title: Pellegrini to Return Outside Capital in His Fund
description: 4:38 p.m. | Updated Paolo Pellegrini, the hedge fund manager best known for helping John A. Paulson earn billions by betting against subprime mortgages, plans to return outside investor capital in his firm by Sept. 30.

title: U.S. Mortgage Relief Effort Is Falling Short of Its Goal
description: The Obama administrations mortgage relief program, originally intended to shield three million households from foreclosure, now looks as if it will permanently help as few as one-sixth of that number.

title: National Team Gives Chicagos Rose Bigger Stage to Prove He Can Lead
description: Derrick Rose grew up on the South Side of Chicago, so he has a keen appreciation of Michael Jordans Bulls. Those teams were far different from the more recent incarnations, and Rose, who was 9 when Jordan was in his final season in Chicago, has seen many players come and go since then.

title: The Littlest Redshirts Sit Out Kindergarten
description: AFTER all those attentive early childhood rituals  the flashcards, the Kumon, the Dora the Explorer, the mornings spent in cutting-edge playgrounds  who wouldnt want to give their children a head start when its finally time to set off for school?

title: Its Actual Life. No, Its Drama. No, Its Both.
description: JEAN-LUC GODARD once observed that every fictional film is a documentary of its actors. Jacques Rivette finessed the aphorism, proposing that every film is a documentary of its own making, not only a record for posterity of the people in it but also a window into the culture that produced it.

title: In Atlantic Debris, Good News and Bad
description: Global production and disposal of plastics of all kinds has grown roughly five-fold since the early 1980s, but that increase is not reflected in the amount of plastic debris found in the western North Atlantic, according to a study published Friday in the journal Science.

title: Hamburger Helper | Fatih Akin
description: With Head-On (2004) and The Edge of Heaven (2007), Fatih Akin made two important films that mine the politically charged frontier between Turkey, the country abandoned by Akins immigrant parents, and Germany, where the director was born and raised. These stories, by turns exuberant, brooding and violent, are the first parts of what Akin calls his love, death and the devil trilogy. Soul Kitchen, which opens in New York today, is Akins latest film but it is a break from the trilogy, not its finale. The devil, Akin says, will have to wait.

title: Gumbo Along the Hudson
description: IT was another scorching day in New York, but in his short-sleeve shirt, black jeans and snakeskin shoes, Dr. John, the piano-playing, politically assertive singer and songwriter from New Orleans, was quite comfortable.

title: Bank of Americas Ex-Chief Denies Fraud Charges
description: 6:43 p.m. | Updated  Kenneth D. Lewis, the former chief executive of Bank of America, responding to a lawsuit filed early this year by the attorney general of New York, denied allegations of fraud in connection with the banks merger with Merrill Lynch, The New York Timess Louise Story reports.

title: The Disease: Fatal. The Treatment: Mockery
description: WHAT can you say about a 25-year-old girl who died?

title: D.I.Y. Music Labels Embrace D.I.Y. Film
description: ON a midsummer night a few dozen people, many in glasses and with messenger bags, gathered at Zebulon, a bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to watch a new low-budget movie called The Builder. The story of a contemplative Irish immigrant, it moved slowly, driven by atmosphere rather than dialogue, but the audience watched patiently at small candle-lit tables, beers in hand. It was the antithesis of a typical summer-movie outing, but that was sort of the point.

title: A Case for Carrying an Extra Wedge, or Two
description: At a recent golf clinic, Annika Sorenstam asked the three dozen recreational golfers standing around her how many wedges they carried in their golf bags. Only one golfer said four.

title: Emanuel Ungaro: A History
description: An interactive timeline of the designers history.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: the Mormon Tabernacle Choir, Katy Perry, Tosh.0 and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Here Comes the Bride. Again.
description: SARAH LANDMAN wore an elaborate silk satin and tulle gown on June 12, befitting her traditional wedding to David Schwarz. But by the time a band started playing for their 350 guests on the grounds of the Philadelphia Navy Yard, Ms. Landman had ditched her Oscar de la Renta for a custom-made white cocktail frock embellished with sequins and ostrich feathers.

title: The Fall of the House of Ungaro
description: When I first heard this story from Asim Abdullahs own lips, over tea at the St. Regis hotel in New York, I thought he was one of the saddest cases I had ever met. He is really in over his head, I thought, and he isnt even done yet. I should probably tell you that this was not my first meeting with Asim Abdullah  that occurred late one night in January, briefly and quite by chance, as I was leaving the Htel Plaza Athne in Paris following dinner with some girlfriends, but clearly it left an impression on me. As we set foot toward the revolving door, one of my friends, a lively, stunning woman, nudged me and said under her breath, Thats the man who owns Ungaro.

title: For Pianist, Software Is Replacing Sonatas
description: The pianist Robert Taub was puttering around the house one afternoon in 2004 while his teen-age daughter was practicing for a violin lesson  a Schubert sonatina in A minor. His assessment of her playing was diplomatic: She needed to be reminded about notes and rhythms.

title: E-Books Make Readers Less Isolated
description: VOLUMES have been written about technologys ability to connect people. But burying ones nose in a book has always been somewhat isolating  with its unspoken assertion that the reader does not want to be disturbed. So what about a device that occupies the evolving intersection between?

title: Morning Miracle
description: 1. Balls and Ghosts

title: Tribune Co. Bankruptcy Plan Hits New Snag
description: 6:53 p.m. | Updated  The troubled saga that has become the Tribune Company bankruptcy unraveled further on Friday as a lawyer for the publishing giant said negotiations with creditors had broken down, The New York Timess Jeremy W. Peters reports.

title: Week in Pictures, Aug. 20
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: How to Be Frugal and Still Be Asked on Dates
description: Saving may be making a comeback, but it still hasnt gotten its sexy back, particularly if youre a man.

title: On Dance: A Q. and A. With Li Cunxin
description: When Mikhail Baryshnikov defected from the Soviet Union in 1974, it was a major news event, drawing world attention to both the ballet dancer and ballet. But he was hardly the only dancer to defect from a Communist country and take up residence in the West in that era. Li Cunxin (pronounced Lee TZWUN-sheen) left his home in rural China and his way of life to pursue ballet in the United States, a journey chronicled in Maos Last Dancer, a new movie by Bruce Beresford.

title: The Balfour Declaration
description: Chapter One: Palestine Before World War I

title: Book Review Podcast: Eliza Griswold
description: This week: Eliza Griswold, author of The Tenth Parallel; Chrystia Freeland on the problem with business journalism; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: At the Royaltons Bar, a Collective of Cocktail Talent
description: Like a Danny Ocean of the cocktail world, Howard Wein, senior vice president of food and beverage of Morgans Hotel Group, has cherry-picked some of the most prominent and talented bar figures from across the United States to create the liquor program at Forty Four, the lobby bar and restaurant of Midtown Manhattans Royalton  hotel, which closed this summer for a revamp and is set to reopen in mid-September.

title: Eurofile | Smitten With Sitges
description: Just before dusk in Sitges, Spain, a few bathers are still bobbing up and down in the gentle surf of the Mediterranean, and a man dressed in white is stacking the beach loungers for the day. Starlings streak through a melon-colored sky garnished with raspberry-colored clouds, and when the lights come on at the parish church on the promontory overlooking the sea, it means its probably time to start to thinking about dinner.

title: No Charges Filed Against Working Families Party
description: Federal prosecutors have closed an investigation of the Working Families Party without filing any charges, party officials said on Friday, a major boost for the beleaguered organization as it gears up for the November statewide elections.

title: Films in Search of the Faithful
description: LIKE the Nativity story told at Christmas, or the 30,000th rerun of Its a Wonderful Life, the story of mainstream cinema and Christian America has a familiar ring to it: a surprise hit comes along, revealing a huge, underserved religious audience ready to be relieved of its entertainment dollars. There is a subsequent gnashing of teeth or rending of garments along the corporate canyons of Hollywood. Regret, anguish and then some gestures of atonement, through marketing outreach and promises of more faith-friendly entertainment.

title: G.M. Names Perry Head of Marketing for Chevrolet
description: Joel Ewanick, vice president for American marketing at General Motors, announced Thursday that Christopher J. Perry would replace Jim Campbell as vice president for Chevrolet marketing. Mr. Campbell will remain a part of the Chevrolet marketing team as vice president for performance vehicles and motorsports.

title: A Leaner Fish Hungers for Open Success
description: MASON, Ohio  The burger joint taunted Mardy Fish.

title: Addressing Money in Your Online Dating Profile
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I look at the question of whether frugality is sexy. Apparently, a lot of people dont think so, though plenty of people will at least admit that frugal people are smart.

title: Umpires Moved, and a Tactic Is Removed
description: Bill Walsh had figured out every angle of his West Coast offense by the time Brent Jones was a young tight end for the San Francisco 49ers. But more than 20 years later, Jones is still struck by an edge Walsh had divined that never appeared in a playbook.

title: Lost Auction Features Prop Cars
description: Theyre not exactly vehicles youd find at the Barrett-Jackson auctions, but for fans who followed the six seasons of Lost, a 40-year-old Chevrolet Camaro and an old blue-and-white Volkswagen Type 2 van may be valuable mobile souvenirs.

title: Sternberg: Chief Director of Private Dream Factory
description: MOST of Hollywoods great directors were compulsive storytellers  spellbinders, as different as John Ford and Samuel Fuller, who liked nothing better than to spin a gripping yarn.

title: Embedistan: Embedding in Iraq During the Invasion and the Drawdown
description: At dusk one day in late March 2003, an editor got through on my satellite phone somewhere out in the desert north of Najaf, where I was embedded with the First Brigade of the Armys Third Infantry Division as it pushed toward Baghdad.

title: Your Experience With Tutors for Your Children
description: In this weekends Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan looks at the world of private tutors for school-age children, whether for specific subject matters, standardized test preparation or college admissions.

title: Democracy, the Hard Way
description: Congratulations, New York: You are about to be compliant with federal election guidelines. True, it took about eight years, and sure, 49 other states got there first. But dont worry about that.

description: Sooner or later, every traditional faith has to confront sexual impropriety by its spiritual leaders: extramarital sex, or sex with the wrong people (members of the congregation, minors) or, for supposedly celibate clergy, any sex at all.

title: In the City, Serious Laughter
description: Every week, a group of people gather in a Manhattan textile office to exercise their laughter. No joke. It's called laughter yoga, and its popularity is growing.

title: Judge Rejects Challenge Against Willets Point Project
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg won a victory on Friday for his $3 billion blueprint for apartments, offices and stores in the shadow of Citi Field in Willets Point, Queens, when a judge rejected a challenge from opponents in the area.

title: Music That Rises Above the Citys Roar
description: NEW York is a ceaseless cacophony of screeches, rumbles and honks, an improvisational score of stilted, urban jazz. Some call it noise. We drown it out with our iPods, become inured to sleeping and working under it and eventually tune the city out. But New York is also filled with veritable sidewalk symphonies: free, live concerts in public places that attract their own devoted groupies.

title: Wikipedia Editing for Zionists
description: Updated | Monday | 10:14 a.m. This week in Jerusalem, two Israeli groups hoping to smite their online enemies, both domestic and foreign, began a course in the Zionist editing of Wikipedia entries.

description: SHANGHAI  Not long ago, China and the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto seemed to be locked in battle.

title: Lambs Club to Open for Breakfast, With Lunch and Dinner Soon
description: It has taken years for Sant Chatwal to convert what had been the Lambs Club, in a landmarked Stanford White building at 132 West 44th Street, into the Chatwal Hotel. Geoffrey Zakarian, the executive chef of the Lambs Club restaurant in the hotel, has already been on board for three years.

OS/2 Fiesta Bowl  are from hunger. One marketer, however, is devoting its first sponsored bowl game to fighting hunger.

description: The bag of tricks that NFL Films uses to turn the repetitive thump-and-crunch of football into operatic entertainment hasnt changed much over the last 40 years. Wagnerian music. Voice-of-God narration. Steam rising off overheated players. Slow-motion passes that ... take ... forever to nestle in a receivers hands.

title: An Abundance of Tomatoes
description: Arisco Farms maintains numerous greenhouses, in which it grows herbs, annuals, perennials and various other ornamental plants. But in a summer that has been hot and sun-drenched, you may come away with the impression that this 70-acre enterprise is all about tomatoes.

description: The second Friday of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan is marked in the first three pictures in the slide show. Slide 4 offers a most unusual angle on an all-too-familiar scene: the delivery of desperately needed food to a besieged village.

description: MADDI GILJE, who will soon leave home in St. Louis to start at New York University, has chatted all summer with her new roommate, Amelia Dudley of Baltimore. She could be talking to her twin.

description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass.  As if the cover of Time magazine were not enough, now the writer Jonathan Franzen has a presidential plug to add to the advance publicity for his latest novel, Freedom: On Friday President Obama bought the book on the first full day of his 10-day stay on Marthas Vineyard.

title: Gyros-a-Go-Go
description: Kalamaki, a new cafe in Roslyn, offers Greek street food with a pedigree. The owners are also the people behind Trata, the refined Mediterranean seafood restaurant in Roslyn (with a second Trata in Water Mill and Kouzina by Trata, a sibling, in Manhattan). Here they are turning out souvlaki and gyros in a sleek, modern space with six tables and additional seating at the counter.

title: Striving for a Menu as Nice as the Scenery
description: VIEW is aptly named. The Oakdale restaurant, formerly known as Riverview, has the panoramic vistas of the Connetquot River and the Great South Bay that have always made this location special. Now the restaurant is too.

description: AFTER 22 years in a four-bedroom two-bath high ranch in Lindenhurst, Michele Cacciatore is headed north. To the North Shore, that is.

title: New Online Help From Fannie Mae
description: SINCE foreclosures started to rise sharply in 2007, struggling borrowers have been offered a lot of help online. Some is well-meaning, but some is simply a scam in the form of expensive debt relief services that may be offered free elsewhere.

title: A Rental Rebound in Fairfield County
description: AT this time last year, the Fairfield County housing market was so saturated with rental properties that landlords were cutting rents to hold onto tenants.

title: Hudson Square
description: THE compact area known as Hudson Square  and also known, at times, as West SoHo and the South Village  is nestled among three of the most desirable neighborhoods in Manhattan: the West Village, TriBeCa and SoHo. As luxury condominiums take root in this once overwhelmingly commercial sector, it is establishing a presence.

title: Caretakers of a Vanishing Little Italy
description: FOR decades, the signs along East 116th Street have promoted cheap airfare to San Juan and Mexico City, and the restaurants and bodegas have hawked cuchifritos and tacos. Except for venerable institutions like Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church and culinary landmarks like Raos and Patsys, little survives from the days when East Harlem was the citys largest and most vibrant Italian-American neighborhood.

title: A Lot of Laundry, and a Little Luck
description: SINCE their arrival in the city two years ago, Jennifer McCarron and Brandi Molitor have had more than their share of bad apartment luck.

description: HERES what a lagging market looks like in Alpine, N.J., the town perennially identified by Forbes Magazine as one of the most expensive ZIP codes in the country:

title: Just Hanging Out Under the Bridge, in Summers Heat
description: Why then just close the eyes  and wait for the day to come  the happy day to come when flesh melts at so many degrees, says Winnie in Samuel Becketts Happy Days, up to her waist in earth. Later she mentions this hellish sun to whose light she is exposed. It is by no means sure that the day of eventual melting will indeed be happy.

title: Alternative Asanas
description: Activities like laughter yoga, AntiGravity yoga and acroyoga may bear little resemblance to a traditional yoga practice, but have benefits of their own.

title: In Balances and Counterbalances, the Classicism of India
description: Amid the often flimsy dance offerings of the New York International Fringe Festival, its heartening to find something as beautiful, serious and substantial as Swaha: Rituals of Union (would that it had a more winning title). Performed on Wednesday by five women from Trinayan Dance Theater in the Odissi style of Indian dance, its a 70-minute suite of solos, duets and larger ensembles that demonstrates a range of truly classical virtues.

title: Brant vs. Brant: Divorce Celebrity Style
description: AROUND 9:55 a.m. on Aug. 6, a parade of lawyers filed into Room 7B at the courthouse in Stamford, Conn., to hear a motion in the divorce case between the newsprint magnate Peter M. Brant and his estranged wife, Stephanie Seymour. Last year Ms. Seymour, a beauty prized for her angel-winged walk as a Victorias Secret model, sued to end their 15-year marriage. She claimed he was too controlling. He contended she cheated on him and abused drugs and alcohol.

title: Portraits of a Marriage
description: The bitterness of a dispute between a former model and her wealthy husband has taken on a life of its own.

title: Heading West: A Ballet Dancer From China Looks Back
description: When Mikhail Baryshnikov defected from the Soviet Union in 1974, it was a major news event, drawing world attention to both the ballet dancer and ballet. But he was hardly the only dancer to defect from a Communist country and take up residence in the West in that era. Li Cunxin (pronounced Lee TZWUN-sheen) left his home in rural China and his way of life to pursue ballet in the United States, a journey chronicled in Maos Last Dancer, a new movie by Bruce Beresford.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 20
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include bilingual nannies, the annual Assumption Day Parade and Central Park trees.

title: George Georgiou in Modern Turkey
description: Correction appended | Through a series of haunting architectural and landscape scenes of Turkeys rush toward modernization  and the resulting tension between the secular and the modern  George Georgiou has visually put his finger on a kind of listless alienation which at times can seem to pervade globalized society. Turkey, traditionally a bridge between East and West, seemed a logical choice for such a cautionary vision.

title: Garb Fest
description: Oh, those are fantastic! I want to see them! Theyre adorable! Let me fix your socks, Patricia Fox cries out when she spies Suzanne Goldens shoes, a pair of black and white Comme des Garons winkle pickers festooned with rhinestone buckles that serve as a counterpoint to the rest of Goldens black-and-white Junya Watanabe ensemble. Fox, who is wearing a veiled chapeau with a blossom brim, a 1950s sequined floral jacket, a chiffon dress with a hobble skirt and a pair of beaded gloves, is meeting Golden for the first time at a tea party I have organized at the Carlyle Hotel, an event I refer to (but not out loud) as a nutty-dressers luncheon. In addition to Golden and Fox, there are two other invited guests: Tziporah Salamon (1930s cheongsam, bamboo pinwheel hat, 200-year-old Chinese handbag) and Iris Apfel (a tunic made by one of Chinas ethnic minorities, a clanging necklace from a Tunisian souk, signature humongous spectacles). Ive been seeing these grande dames around town for years, and now, finally, Ive got them all in one spot  at one table  so I can ask them how it came to be that the four of them glitter like spectacular if wacky jewels in an otherwise mostly mundane pedestrian landscape.

title: One Night, Two Shows, Four Masters
description: Despite the thorough dissimilarity between the two concerts that the Mostly Mozart Festival presented on Thursday night, you could tease out common threads if you tried hard. Both the performance by the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall and the after-hours recital by the pianist Jeremy Denk at the Kaplan Penthouse hung on a central duality. The Freiburg ensemble offered works by Haydn and Mozart for side-by-side comparison; Mr. Denk performed what appeared to be disparate works by Liszt and Beethoven, proving in the process that the pairing was far from incompatible.

title: Atlantic Yards Show Finds a Home Stage
description: The downtown theater company the Civilians has announced that its new show, In the Footprint: The Battle Over the Atlantic Yards, will open in November at the Irondale Center, a theater space not far from the future home of the planned 22-acre development. In the Footprint, a series of songs and monologues, is about the conflicts over the building of the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project near Brooklyns downtown that is to include eight million square feet of apartments, offices, stores and an arena for the New Jersey Nets. The shows material has been taken from interviews that members of the Civilians conducted with Brooklyn residents, community organizers, business owners and politicians who are either for or against the project. Performances are scheduled to begin on Nov. 12 and continue through Dec. 11 at the center at Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Fort Greene. The Civilians have scheduled a cabaret performance with songs from the show at Joes Pub on Sept. 10.

title: Brother Outruns N.F.L.
description: The latest Big Brother elimination helped CBS earn another ratings victory as that reality show drew 7.5 million viewers on Thursday night, according to Nielsens estimates. With live coverage of the N.F.L. preseason, Fox finished in a virtual tie for second place with ABC. Final ratings were not immediately available for the matchup between the New England Patriots and Atlanta Falcons, but preliminary estimates show the game drew roughly as many viewers as ABCs average for the night with a Wipeout rerun at 8 (6.6 million), Rookie Blue at 9 (6.4 million) and the debut episode of Nightline Prime: Secrets of Your Mind at 10 (4.1 million). NBC was a distant fourth with repeats.

title: When Heroes Return
description: THE scene around the basketball court at Holcombe Rucker Park in Harlem was bordering on chaos.

title: Colbert to Welcome Home Iraq Troops With Specials
description: As American troops return from concluding combat operations in Iraq, some of them will soon be deployed to a friendlier front: the studio audience of The Colbert Report. During his Comedy Central show on Thursday night, Stephen Colbert, right, said that he would devote two of his shows, on Sept. 8 and 9, to celebrating and thanking American service members. Announcing the special series, Been There, Won That: The Returnification of the American-Do Troopscape, Mr. Colbert said: No matter how you felt about this war, we Americans sent them off to fight it. And now that its over, we should thank them. And quickly, because I think a lot of them are getting sent to Afghanistan. Comedy Central said in a news release that the two episodes will feature guests including Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.; Gen. Ray Odierno, the commander of the United States military forces in Iraq; and Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia. The audiences on those nights, the network said, will comprise veterans and active-duty service men and women in the studio as well as by satellite audiences from Walter Reed hospital, Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Fatal Dive Onto Stage at California Concert
description: One day after a man was injured after jumping from a balcony at a Phish concert in Wantagh, N.Y., a concertgoer was killed at a performance by the Swell Season in Saratoga, Calif., after diving onto the stage and landing near the band. Sgt. Rick Sung, of the Santa Clara County Sheriffs Office, said on Friday morning that sheriffs deputies were dispatched about 9 p.m. on Thursday to the Mountain Winery after reports that a man had jumped from a roof above the stage. The man, whose name was not released, attended the concert with a friend. The friend told sheriffs deputies that the man had disappeared during the outdoor performance, leaving behind his personal belongings, then reappeared on the roof, from which he jumped. Sergeant Sung said a doctor in the audience and an emergency medical technician at the performance space tried C.P.R. but were unable to revive him. The death is being investigated as a suicide, pending an autopsy.

title: Patterson and Meyer Are Top-Earning Authors
description: The publishing industry may be in the doldrums, but it appears that James Patterson ($70 million), above left, Stephenie Meyer ($40 million), above right, and Stephen King ($34 million) are not. They topped the list of the 10 highest-paid authors, according to Forbes magazine, which tracked earnings collected over the last year, ending June 1. They were followed by Danielle Steel ($32 million), Ken Follett ($20 million), Dean Koontz ($18 million), Janet Evanovich ($16 million), John Grisham ($15 million) and Nicholas Sparks ($14 million). No. 10 was J. K. Rowling ($10 million), even though she did not publish a new book that year.

title: Troubled Folk Museum Receives a Reprieve
description: The financially struggling American Folk Art Museum received a reprieve on Thursday. Six months after disclosing that it could no longer make payments on the $32 million it borrowed through a bond issue to finance its new building, the museum has reached a forbearance agreement with the company that insured its bonds. The agreement, which expires on June 30, means that the insurer, ACA Financial Guaranty, will cover payments to the bondholders and will not immediately exercise its rights under the financing agreement, which include foreclosing on the museums home. The museums director, Maria Ann Conelli, wrote in an e-mail that the institution considered the agreement a positive step forward, but that the details were confidential. ACA officials did not respond to phone messages left at their office. The bonds were issued through the Trust for Cultural Resources, a public benefit corporation created in 1980 to help cultural institutions finance capital projects. The museum, which has occupied its home on West 53rd Street since 2001, is the first organization to default on an agreement to pay off bonds that have been issued through the trust.

title: Not Just Peking Duck, but a Ceremony
description: PEKING DUCK, a centuries-old tradition in Beijing restaurants, customarily comprised several courses. John Blofeld, an English scholar who lived in Beijing (then called Peking) during the 1930s and wrote about its culture in City of Lingering Splendour (Shambhala Publications, 1989), describes the progression of dishes like this: First the crisp skin was carved from the bird, tableside, in pieces, and wrapped in hot bread with shredded spring onion and sauce; this was followed by an omelet cooked in duck fat; then the meat, sauted with bamboo shoots; the innards, batter-fried; finishing with soup, made from the bones.

The format will be a first for the orchestra under the conductor and music director William Boughton.

Now in its third summer, Rockaway Taco attracts robust weekend crowds of beachgoers, many from neo-bohemian north Brooklyn, who line up for tacos, quesadillas, plaintain chips and fresh juices and vie for the few ottoman seats on the outdoor patio. Ms. Reichl, 62, who was the dining critic for The New York Times before joining Gourmet, is the author of four memoirs and is currently working on a cookbook and a novel. She and her husband, Michael Singer, 70, a retired news producer for CBS, have a son, Nick, 21, who attends Wesleyan University, and a 17-year-old cat, Stella, as well as an apartment on the Upper West Side.

Sales will increase at least 8 percent, to $3.74 billion, in the next fiscal year, which ends July 31, 2011, the company said. Excluding some costs, earnings will rise at least 12 percent, to $2.36 a share. Analysts had estimated revenue of $3.72 billion and profit of $2.30 a share on average. Intuit is adding Internet features and using acquisitions to offer more online services. The recently purchased Mint personal finance site increased its customers to more than three million last quarter. Shares in Intuit rose $5.83, or 15 percent, to $44.60.

description: New York State needs a tough, honest and smart attorney general to attack the culture of corruption in Albany, protect consumers and the environment, and promote civil rights. An effective attorney general also can take on major national issues. Eliot Spitzer, before becoming governor and imploding, went after Wall Street fraud. The present attorney general, Andrew Cuomo, has forced reforms on the corrupt student loan industry.

title: Mexico: 6 Police Officers Held in Fatal Abduction of Mayor
description: Five local police officers and a transit officer have been arrested in connection with this weeks kidnapping and killing of Mayor Edelmiro Cavazos of Santiago, a town about 20 miles south of Monterrey in the northern state of Nuevo Len, state officials said on Friday. One suspect had been assigned as a guard to Mayor Cavazos, and the others are accused of acting as lookouts for a group of gunmen who took the mayor from his home on Sunday night. His body was found on Wednesday on the side of a mountain road. He had been bound, blindfolded and then shot to death.

title: Russia: Putin Ousts Forestry Chief
description: Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin dismissed the head of Russias forestry service on Friday in the wake of this summers horrific wildfires, which consumed more than two million acres of land and caused more than 50 deaths. Mr. Putin had criticized the official, Aleksei Savinov, for shoddy fire prevention efforts, which he said allowed the blazes to burn out of control, overwhelming firefighters and consuming whole villages. Mr. Savinov will be replaced by his deputy.

title: Ukraine: Searching for a Missing Journalist
description: President Viktor F. Yanukovich said on Friday that he was taking personal control over the search for a missing investigative reporter, whose disappearance over a week ago has prompted colleagues and rights groups to raise concerns about the possibility of foul play. Mr. Yanukovich called on law enforcement agencies across Ukraine to do everything possible and impossible to find the journalist, Vasyl Klymentyev, the editor of a newspaper in the eastern city of Kharkiv, a statement on the presidents Web site said. Press freedom advocates have complained about media censorship since Mr. Yanukovich took office in February.

The extension is also expected to help Russia in its role as an arbiter of the conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the separatist region of Nagorno-Karabakh. The new agreement also allows forces from the base to be deployed outside the borders of the former Soviet Union.

Just say this is a comedy of errors, without getting into it, he insisted with his signature mordancy, a year before he resigned in disgrace. title: Whos a Joker? Miller to Teach at U.S.C.
description: For a long time, Steve Millers rhyming of Texas, facts is, justice and taxes in Take the Money and Run was the most surprising turn hed taken in his pop-music career. But he may have outdone himself by becoming an instructor at the University of Southern California. The Thornton School of Music at the university said that Mr. Miller, the guitarist and front man of the Steve Miller Band, will serve as an artist in residence starting with the fall term. He will present master classes for undergraduates enrolled in the schools popular-music and music-industry programs, and lead seminars on tour planning and record production as well as workshops on more specific topics like guitar tone. Every time he comes into contact with students, he just comes away energized and wants to work with them on more of a sustained basis, Chris Sampson, associate dean of the Thornton School, said in a telephone interview. Mr. Miller is expected to be on campus at least twice a semester, following a schedule similar to the Thornton Schools other artists in residence: Patrice Rushen, the pianist and singer, and Lamont Dozier, the songwriter and producer.

Originally thinking they were empress tree pods, which are similarly sculptural but smooth, I brought them back to my workspace, where a friend helped to correctly identify them as Datura stramonium, or jimsonweed, and their source (the garden of a local artist around the corner).

Championship, where he at least made the cut and finished in a tie for 28th, but lately he has been spraying the ball so badly that even the sternest critics of his personal life  the ones who wanted to ostracize him from golf  have to feel a little sorry for him. At the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational at Firestone two weeks ago, he looked like a hacker, hitting more trees than fairways on the way to posting a 75 and a 77 in the last two rounds.

title: Prime Number

The audience has aged at twice the rate of the general population, according to Baseline, a trend that is changing the way broadcasters are approaching their business. The younger demographic once sought by the networks has increasingly migrated to cable and the Web, leaving the broadcasters to court older viewers, an adjustment that some in the industry welcome. Dont discount people who are in their 50s and 60s. ..., one executive told The Associated Press. The reality is these are the people with the money.

title: How Fox Betrayed Petraeus

Still, the battle that has broken out over this project in Lower Manhattan  on the hallowed ground of a shuttered Burlington Coat Factory store one block from the New York Dolls Gentlemens Club  will prove eventful all the same. And the consequences will be far more profound than any midterm election results or any of the grand debates now raging 24/7 over the parameters of tolerance, religious freedom, and the real estate gospel of location, location, location.

title: Surprise, Surprise, Surprise
description: I just saw the movie Invictus  the story of how Nelson Mandela, in his first term as president of South Africa, enlists the countrys famed rugby team, the Springboks, on a mission to win the 1995 Rugby World Cup and, through that, to start the healing of that apartheid-torn land. The almost all-white Springboks had been a symbol of white domination, and blacks routinely rooted against them. When the post-apartheid, black-led South African sports committee moved to change the teams name and colors, President Mandela stopped them. He explained that part of making whites feel at home in a black-led South Africa was not uprooting all their cherished symbols. That is selfish thinking, Mandela, played by Morgan Freeman, says in the movie. It does not serve the nation. Then speaking of South Africas whites, Mandela adds, We have to surprise them with restraint and generosity.

title: For Social Security, a Birthday Makeover
description: Social Security, now celebrating its 75th birthday, is receiving mixed diagnoses. Some analysts think the program is on solid fiscal ground for decades to come, while others fear that the impending retirement of the baby boom generation precipitates a crisis. In either case, it is always worth considering innovations to make the program more efficient and equitable. The Op-Ed page editors asked six experts to recommend specific fixes that could be part of a comprehensive reform package for the nations largest social insurance program.

Yet even after the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, Russia remained the worlds leading chess country. Its strength might be a vestige of the Communist-led system, or of the countrys historical affinity for the game.

title: The Cte Fleurie
description: To the Editor: Normandys Quiet Glamour (Aug. 8) clearly misses the mark. I just returned from a three-day visit to Normandy with my wife and youngest daughter. The restaurants, film festival stars and horse racing lionized in the article pale in comparison to the Norman- dy D-Day sites, which were not even mentioned. The Normandy beaches and related sites and monuments, including the American Cemetery and Memorial, honor and memorial- ize our soldiers and their important sacrifices. The article would have presented a much more accurate and significant depiction of Nor- mandy if the author had also includ- ed them.

title: When Hendrix Met Handel at a London Flat
description: If you have ever dreamed of having a snoop around Jimi Hendrixs apartment, now you can. Forty years after his death, the American rock legend, who performed, recorded and lived in London, will be reincarnated through the Hendrix in Britain exhibition at the Handel House Museum, starting Aug. 25. And for two weeks only, the apartment Hendrix lived in, next door to the museum, will also be open to the public for the first time since his death in 1970.

title: The Taylor Rule And The Bond Bubble (Wonkish)
description: Heres a thought for all those insisting that theres a bond bubble: how unreasonable are current long-term interest rates given current macroeconomic forecasts? I mean, at this point almost everyone expects unemployment to stay high for years to come, and theres every reason to expect low or even negative inflation for a long time too. Shouldnt that imply that the Fed will keep short-term rates near zero for a long time? And shouldnt that, in turn, mean that a low long-term rate is justified too?

title: The Ghosts of Unquiet Souls Doomed in a Wartime Ghetto
description: The Dybbuk, the 1914 play written by S. Ansky that is a pre-eminent work of Yiddish theater, dramatizes the Ashkenazi Jewish myth of a dislocated soul that inhabits a living person. Anskys play itself has something of a shape-shifting spirit, revised many times for the stage, film, dance and even opera. In revisiting the story, the English playwright and director Julia Pascal, who has often mined Jewish themes for their universality, has framed it in the context of the Holocaust, powerfully elevating a folk tale to an existential meditation.

title: Footnote

Directed by Christopher Luscombe and featuring Christopher Benjamin as Falstaff, the show was a hit when it was staged two years ago at Shakespeares Globe in London. It reopened there Thursday night, will travel to Los Angeles from Oct. 14 to 24 and then will arrive at Pace Universitys Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, where it will run from Oct. 28 through Nov. 7.

title: The Pacific and Betty White Among Emmy Winners
description: The sweeping World War II mini-series The Pacific was the most-honored program at the Creative Arts Emmys on Saturday, winning a total of seven statues for sound editing, makeup, visual effects and casting, among other categories. The Creative Arts awards, primarily technical in nature, were a precursor to the Emmys telecast on NBC next Sunday. The Pacific (with, from left, Tom Budge, James Badge Dale and Joshua Helman) helped bring HBO to a total of 17 awards, topping second-place ABC, which received 15. Notably, Betty White was named best guest actress in a comedy for her appearance on Saturday Night Live. The Tony Awards telecast in June 2009, hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, was the winner in the special class category. While most Emmy winners are associated with networks, one independent production, the fan film StarWarsUncut.com, was recognized this year in a relatively new category, outstanding creative achievement in interactive media. The Creative Arts ceremony will be shown Friday on the E! channel.

title: Gift to the Harn Museum
description: During Dr. David A. Cofrins life he offered critical financial support to the Samuel P. Harn Museum of Art at the University of Florida in Gainesville. His death last year at age 88 did not end his contributions, however. The Harn museum has announced that Dr. Cofrin bequeathed 312 works of Asian art estimated to be worth $4.2 million and established a million-dollar endowment for the acquisition of Asian art. Dr. Cofrin and his wife, Mary Ann, helped establish the museum; it is named after Mary Anns father, Samuel Peebles Harn, an alumnus of the university. Since 1983, the Cofrins have donated more than $30 million to the Harn, according to the museum. The latest gift includes jades, ceramics, cloisonn and bronze, glass, ivory and lacquers from Japan, China and Southeast Asia. These will eventually be housed in a new 26,000-square-foot extension named the David A. Cofrin Asian Art Wing.

title: Author Credit for Widow of Baseball Historian
description: In baseball terms you might describe it as a walk-off hit deep into extra innings. Dorothy Jane Mills, below, the widow of the revered baseball historian Harold Seymour, has been belatedly recognized by Oxford University Press as co-author, along with Mr. Seymour, of three landmark scholarly works on the history of baseball, Publishers Weekly reported. Tim Bent, Oxfords executive editor, said that Ms. Mills, 81, formerly Dorothy Z. Seymour, would be given formal credit and that her name would now accompany her late husbands on the covers and title pages of Baseball: The Early Years (1960); Baseball: The Golden Age, (1971); and Baseball: The Peoples Game (1991). Mr. Bent said that to his knowledge, Oxford had never before changed the authorship of a major scholarly work. In an interview with The New York Times in March, when she was recognized for the first time along with Mr. Seymour by the Society for American Baseball Research, Ms. Mills said that she had served as the primary researcher and essentially a co-author of all three books but that her husband had steadfastly refused her request that her work be credited. All these things were done jointly, she said. He just couldnt share credit. And I didnt say anything at the time, because at the time, wives just didnt do that. He died in 1992, and in her 2004 autobiography, A Womans Work, she described her extensive role in the creation of the books. Ms. Mills, who is now at work on a historical novel about baseball, said that even after all these years, she still does not consider herself a fan: You write a lot more objectively about a subject youre not in love with.

title: The Expendables Tops Box Office Again
description: Aging action heroes ruled the North American box office for the second weekend in a row. The Expendables (Lions Gate), with Sylvester Stallone leading an ensemble cast, was No. 1 with about $16.5 million, bringing the cumulative total to about $65 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data. Vampires Suck (20th Century Fox), a low-budget spoof of the Twilight movies, was second with about $12.2 million for a five-day total of $18.6 million. Vampires Suck, which opened on Wednesday, appeared to narrowly beat Julia Roberts as her Eat Pray Love (Sony Pictures Entertainment) took third place with $12 million, earning a total of $47.1 million in North America since it opened on Aug. 13, a soft result that has renewed worries that Ms. Roberts has faded as a box-office draw. The comedy Lottery Ticket, from Alcon Entertainment and Warner Brothers, opened in fourth place with about $11.1 million. Fifth place appeared to be a tie, with each earning about $10.1 million: The Other Guys (Sony), with a new total of $88.2 million, and Piranha 3-D, a new horror romp from the Weinstein Company. Two other new movies fared poorly despite wide releases: Nanny McPhee Returns (Universal Pictures), already a hit overseas, earned $8.3 million. The Switch (Walt Disney Studios), a comedy starring Jennifer Aniston and Jason Bateman, sold $8.1 million.

title: Van Gogh Painting Remains Missing
description: A van Gogh painting valued by some experts at $50 million was stolen from a Cairo museum on Saturday, Egypts minister of culture announced. Egyptian law enforcement officials blamed lax security at the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum for the incident, saying that none of its alarms and only a few of its surveillance cameras were working when the painting (above, known as Poppy Flowers and Vase and Flowers), a depiction of a vase filled with yellow poppies, was sliced from its frame and taken. The culture minister, Farouk Hosni, announced shortly after the disappearance of the painting was made public that it had been recovered at the Cairo airport and that two Italians had been arrested in connection with theft. But Mr. Hosni said later that he had been given bad information and that the search continued. Egypts top prosecutor, Abdel Meguid Mahmoud, told the BBC that the museums security system was nothing more than a facade. He said museum officials had been looking for spare parts to mend the system but hadnt managed to find them.

So as the fifth anniversary of Katrina approached, Mr. Lee went back to New Orleans this year, hoping to tell the story of that citys recovery and rejuvenation, starting with the Super Bowl victory of its underdog New Orleans Saints football team.

description: ATLANTA  In February 2007, Alberto R. Gonzales, the attorney general under President George W. Bush, issued a stern warning to those who murdered blacks with impunity during the civil rights era: You have not gotten away with anything. We are still on your trail.

description: Update | Aug. 23, 10:35 p.m.: Corrected information about manual control ring on PowerShot S95Canon has unwrapped three new PowerShots, highlighted by a lightweight Elph model that packs a 10X optical zoom into a very slim package.

description: Just when you thought Coney Island had been considered from every possible documentary angle, our pals at Lens have posted a starkly picturesque portfolio by a photographer named Andy Levin, who in the late 70s began exploring Coney Island as a G-rated family destination, not entirely unlike the seaside community on Long Island where he was raised. As G-rated family destinations go, its pretty gripping. Check it out on Lens.

title: The Bidding War for 3PAR
description: 3Par, a data storage company, is the billion-dollar prize in a battle between two tech heavyweights, Hewlett-Packard and Dell. Who wants it more? Or perhaps the question really is: Who needs to win this to make a public statement?

title: Baseball Chases Leak of Financial Documents
description: Major League Baseball is narrowing down the search for who was behind the leaks of team financial reports that reveal how profitable the Pittsburgh Pirates are despite an 18-year string of losing records, and how much they, the Florida Marlins and the Tampa Bay Rays receive in revenue-sharing from wealthier clubs, according to a baseball executive who was not authorized to speak publicly.

title: Food Photography: How to Plan a Food Shoot
description: Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce. There are several things that you have to be very conscious of when planning a food shoot. The first thing I do, almost without fail, is look at a weather report. Like surfers, baseball managers and airline pilots, you will become an amateur meteorologist when you commit to a food photo shoot. I prefer to shoot in daylight whenever possible, and the quality of that light is obviously a major factor.

title: Study Finds No Link Tying Disaster Losses to Human-Driven Warming
description: The pull of the front-page thought and the eagerness of climate campaigners to jog the public have sometimes created a tendency to tie mounting losses from weather-related disasters to human-driven global warming.

title: Notes From the Underground | Fischerspooner
description: The homecoming leg of Fischerspooners recent tour found Casey and the gang at the Highline Ballroom on Aug. 12. It was a performance powerful in its energy and creativity, complete with gaggles of costumed dancers in full geisha makeup, wigs and electric hats. The disarmingly sweet Casey Spooner charmed a room of 150 dancing fans at this semi-private show with tales of another age, when the band performed at MoMA and felt like it still had yet to emerge.

title: Jumble of Air Safety Rules
description: Aviation officials often cite the industrys low accident rate after a plane crash, and statistics back up their assertions: last year, there were about 2.5 accidents for every one million commercial flights worldwide.

description: Over the course of his career Andrea Bocelli has sold millions of records, helped to close out the 2010 World Cup in a grand finale concert, performed Jingle Bells with the Muppets and been praised by no less an authority than Celine Dion. But he has never performed on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Piniellas Exit
description: On the occasion of his retirement, allow me to share my favorite Lou Piniella moment, from his days as a player for the Yankees: it was a World Series game, with all the usual tension, and Piniella was up to bat. He swung at a pitch so hard, he corkscrewed himself around, and with his legs twisted, he fell over sideways. He was laughing so hard, it took him several minutes to get back in the batters box. Everyone on the field was laughing too: opposing players, umpires included. I was not a Yankees fan. I was laughing.

title: Nepals Parliament Fails in 5th Try to Select Prime Minister
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Nepals Parliament on Monday failed for a fifth time to select a new prime minister, in a deepening political stalemate fueled by ego and ideology that is alienating the public and crippling the government and the economy in this Himalayan nation.

Nascar began running the three races 15 years ago.

Egypts minister of culture, Farouk Hosni, retracted an announcement that the painting was recovered at the Cairo airport, saying the announcement was based on faulty information.

At Cape Royds, he photographed a man holding a diminutive Adlie penguin under its wings as if it were a toddler. Another photograph shows a man about to pet a seal pup.

Last year, this question prompted a shouting match on The Moment, with readers arguing about the artistic merit of a series of Andy Warhol Polaroids shown at Danziger Projects. Now the artist and filmmaker Julian Schnabel shows us his own Polaroids in a new book by Prestel creatively titled Julian Schnabel: Polaroids. In addition to shots of his Montauk, N.Y., studio, his family and a series of rephotographed late-19th-century images called Crazy People, Schnabel pointed his rare 1970s-era Polaroid camera at Lou Reed, Placido Domingo, Christopher Walken, the Beastie Boys and Mickey Rourke. description: A small gathering of 50 or 60 people; roughly 95 percent white, 90 percent male, a few blond-haired kids, average age 45, all nodding in assent as a series of speakers explains that our government is conspiring against us and fabricating massive lies in order to hide its own crimes and frighten us into giving up our constitutional rights and liberties.

title: Henry Hudson Parkway, 9:43 A.M.
description: Rain on a car windshield distorted the view of a tree and the Hudson River on the West Side Highway near 95th Street on Monday morning.

title: A Man of Many Roles Reads the Market Right
description: THE actor Liam Neeson has played Oskar Schindler and Rob Roy; he has portrayed a scientist, a monk and  many times over  a romantic. This summer, he played a role that required less of the dashing hero: apartment seller.

title: A Big Star Transforms Into a Small Moon for a Season
description: 30 for 30, ESPNs yearlong series of original documentaries, keeps paying dividends. On Tuesday night it brings us the first nonfiction film by the king of the modern sports drama, Ron Shelton (Bull Durham, White Men Cant Jump,Tin Cup).

title: Acuvue Contact Lenses Are Recalled in Asia and Europe
description: The eye care unit of Johnson & Johnson said on Monday that it was recalling several million disposable soft contact lenses sold primarily in Japan, but also in five other countries in Asia and 19 counties in Europe.

title: Eli Broad Selects Diller Scofidio + Renfro to Design New Museum
description: The philanthropist and art collector Eli Broad has selected the architecture firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro to design a museum for his contemporary art collection on Grand Avenue in downtown Los Angeles, Mr. Broad and his wife Edythe announced on Monday. The museum also received its last round of public approvals on Monday when the Grand Avenue Authority, a panel of city and county officials, approved a plan to lease 2.5 acres of county-owned land to Mr. Broad.

title: Studying Acupuncture, One Needle Prick at a Time
description: For at least 2,000 years Chinese healers have used acupuncture to treat pain and other ailments. Now Western doctors want proof that it works.

title: Vain Glorious | Liz Earles Cult Cleanser
description: Who: Liz Earle Naturally Active Skincare, a 15-year-old botanicals-based brand located on the Isle of Wight, Englands aptly nicknamed Garden Isle.

title: Scholars Test Web Alternative to Peer Review
description: For professors, publishing in elite journals is an unavoidable part of university life. The grueling process of subjecting work to the up-or-down judgment of credentialed scholarly peers has been a cornerstone of academic culture since at least the mid-20th century.

title: Dr. Harvey Cushings Patients
description: Dr. Harvey Cushing, one of Americas first neurosurgeons, kept extensive samples from his practice, but many of the details have been lost. Here is a sample of his body of work.

title: From Argentina, Interpretations of an Argentine Interpreter
description: The impetus for Guillermo Kleins new music, and the basis of most of his rapturous set at the Village Vanguard on Sunday night, is a set of melodies written or adapted by Cuchi Leguizamn, an Argentine modernist-folklorist composer and poet who died in 2000.

title: In Power Grab, the Force Is With Him
description: LENOX, Mass.  Take a good look at the recumbent, inanimate figure that occupies center stage at the beginning of Shakespeare & Companys rousing production of Richard III. Thats the last time youll see it so motionless or so horizontal. The body is that of the title character of Shakespeares grisliest history play. And as portrayed by John Douglas Thompson, this monarch-in-the-making quickly establishes himself as a man who is almost never still and who takes absolutely nothing lying down.

title: Biden: U.S. Remains Committed to Helping Iraq
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Monday that the American pull-out of combat troops from Iraq does not mean that the United States is abandoning the country, promising instead to remain committed to helping Iraqis.

title: Giving Fashion Editor a Makeover
description: NINA GARCIA, the Project Runway judge and fashion editor, was on a flight from New York to Paris fashion shows last year when a flight attendant crouched beside her and meekly tried to strike up a conversation. Just another fan of the show, Ms. Garcia assumed, seeking gossip.

title: Carry-Ons and Courtesy Need to Co-Exist
description: SPIRIT recently surprised the airline industry by introducing fees of $20 to $45 each to stow carry-on bags in overhead bins. In a Web video, Ben Baldanza, the chief executive of Spirit Airlines, describes the problem while his body is scrunched inside a bin.

title: Photographer Withdraws Lawsuit in Shepard Fairey Case
description: The photographer who took the shot of Barack Obama that was later transformed by the street artist Shepard Fairey into the well-known Hope campaign poster has withdrawn a lawsuit against the Associated Press, in which he claimed he was not working for the agency when he took the picture.

title: For Spike Lee, a New Requiem for New Orleans
description: Four years ago Spike Lee took his cameras to New Orleans to document the disaster wrought by Hurricane Katrina in 2005, as told by the people still dealing with its calamitous effects. The film Mr. Lee returned with was When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts, a four-hour HBO documentary that won a Peabody Award and three Emmys. As the fifth anniversary of Katrina approached, Mr. Lee went back to New Orleans this year, hoping to tell the story of that citys recovery and rejuvenation.

title: New Site For Artworks
description: A panel of city and county officials on Monday approved a plan to lease 2.5 acres of land owned by Los Angeles County to the philanthropist and art collector Eli Broad for his contemporary art collection in downtown Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. The deal advances Mr. Broads proposal to build the museum with his own money, up to $100 million for construction and $200 million more for an endowment. He has said that he would pay $7.7 million for a 99-year lease. Mr. Broad, whose 2,000-piece collection includes major works by Jeff Koons, Cindy Sherman and Andy Warhol, considered at least two other sites for the museum before deciding on the current one, located next to Disney Hall and across the street from the Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: Bocelli To Perform at Met
description: Over the course of his career, the Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli, below, has sold millions of records, helped to close out the 2010 World Cup in a grand finale concert, performed Jingle Bells with the Muppets and been praised by no less an authority than Celine Dion. But he has not performed on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera. On Monday the Met said that Mr. Bocelli would make his Met solo recital debut on Feb. 13. The concert will feature Mr. Bocelli singing works by Handel, Beethoven, Wagner and other composers, with accompaniment by the pianist Vincenzo Scalera (but no Muppets). Tickets will go on sale Sept. 12.

title: Egyptian Official Arrested In Theft of Painting
description: Prosecutors have arrested a top official in Egypts culture ministry and several museum security guards pending an investigation into the theft of a van Gogh painting over the weekend, Reuters reported. The painting of a vase filled with yellow poppies is known as Poppy Flowers or Vase and Flowers and is valued at more than $50 million; it remains missing after being stolen Saturday from the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum in Giza, where none of the alarms and only some of the security cameras were working at the time. Egypts culture minister, Farouk Hosni, retracted an announcement that the work was recovered at the Cairo airport, saying the announcement was based on faulty information. On Monday Mohsen Shaalan, a deputy culture minister who heads the departments fine arts division, was detained, and he and the guards were accused of negligence and failing to carry out their employment duties, according to the Egyptian state news agency, though no formal charges have been filed. Reuters said nine other officials from the culture ministry had been prevented from traveling while the investigation continues. In an interview Monday with Agence France-Presse, Mr. Hosni said: The search is ongoing. We still havent found the painting.

title: Another Favre Return, Another Football Win
description: NBCs broadcast of an N.F.L. exhibition game that featured Brett Favres brief four-play return to the Minnesota Vikings dominated the ratings on Sunday, helping the network lead the night by a wide margin in prime time. Final audience figures for the game, which the Vikings lost, 15-10, to the San Francisco 49ers, were not immediately available on Monday, but Nielsens preliminary overnight estimates for the game were higher than for any other program on the night. The estimates also showed that the live football broadcast attracted slightly fewer viewers than the N.F.L.s Hall of Fame exhibition game that drew 11.4 million two weeks ago. CBS ranked second over all, garnering its best ratings with 60 Minutes (8.2 million) and Big Brother (7.8 million). ABC was third with repeats followed by a new episode of The Gates (2.8 million) while Fox finished fourth with its lineup of animated sitcom reruns.

title: New Visions of Old Works
description: Since 2006 the filmmaker Peter Greenaway, below, has done a series of installations using technology to illuminate and reinterpret famous paintings. So far none have been displayed in the United States. But from Dec. 2 to Jan. 6 Mr. Greenaway will bring his exploration of Leonardo da Vincis Last Supper to the Park Avenue Armory. For one night in 2008, he turned the real Last Supper, which is in the refectory of Santa Maria Delle Grazie in Milan, into a sound-and-light show using projectors, computers and speakers. Light and shadows played over the painting, parts seemed to move and some images appeared three-dimensional. Mr. Greenaway will do the same thing at the Armory, but with a full-size reproduction of the mural, set within a recreation of the refectory. The installation at the Armory will also feature other projections including parts of another work by Mr. Greenaway based on Veroneses Wedding at Cana, which was exhibited at the 2009 Venice Biennale.

title: A Fringe Too Tame? Too Bad
description: Does it matter that New York has a drearily mediocre Fringe Festival?

title: HSBC Seeks to Acquire Major Stake in Nedbank
description: HSBC, the international bank, said Monday that it was in exclusive talks with the African insurer Old Mutual to buy a controlling stake in the South African lender Nedbank, as it aimed to strengthen its presence on a continent that was one of Chinas major trading partners.

title: Singer Dies After Jump at Belgian Pop Festival
description: The lead singer of a British pop band died Friday after jumping from a telecommunications tower at a Belgian festival. The incident followed others at rock performances earlier in the week where concertgoers jumped from great heights and were injured or killed. The Guardian reported that Charles Haddon, the 22-year-old singer of Ou Est Le Swimming Pool, an electro-pop music trio from London, died at the Pukkelpop festival in Hasselt, Belgium, in a jump that followed his bands performance that night. A statement by the festival said that Mr. Haddon had decided to take his own life, adding, Our thoughts and sympathies go out to his family and friends. Last Wednesday, a man at a Phish concert in Wantagh, N.Y., jumped from the balcony at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater and sustained injuries. The following night a concertgoer at a performance by the Swell Season jumped from a roof at the Mountain Winery in Saratoga, Calif., onto the stage and was killed.

title: Edinburgh Fringe Plays Coming To New York
description: At least a couple of the popular productions among hundreds of current offerings at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe are headed to New York in the coming season. Penelope, the latest play by Enda Walsh, will be presented at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn (where his plays The Walworth Farce and The New Electric Ballroom have been produced). A production of the Druid Theater of Galway and scheduled to run in Brooklyn Oct. 23 to Nov. 14, Penelope is an absurdist interpretation of part of Homers Odyssey. Also headed to New York, and also to St. Anns, from Feb. 24 to March 27, 2011, is Beautiful Burnout, above, about the allure, competition and potential dangers of boxing, by Bryony Lavery (Frozen). It includes grimace-inducing intricately timed fights and fight-training sequences, choreographed by Steven Hoggett (Black Watch, American Idiot) and Scott Graham. Both shows received Fringe First awards by The Scotsman newspaper for the best new plays of the festival.

title: Your Ballot Designs: An Interim Report
description: This weekend, The Timess City Critic reviewed New Yorks new voting machines, which well be using for the first time during primary elections on Sept. 14, and found them to be a confusing mess. So City Room invited readers to reinvent the ballots and submit your ideas for a better design.

title: On an Island During a Rainstorm, a Titan of Entertainment Appears
description: Diddy first appeared in shadow on Sunday night, 20 feet tall behind a scrim, a Superman come with the intent to rescue.

title: Vale Denies It Is Potashs White Knight
description: Forget about one possible white knight for Potash. Vale, the big Brazilian mining company, denied on Monday afternoon that it was in talks to acquire the giant Canadian fertilizer company.

title: How to Submit a Wedding Announcement
description: To submit news of your wedding to The New York Times, please follow these instructions closely. Click here for the form to submit your announcement.

title: Booksellers Brace for Mockingjay Landing
description: Long before it was published, it reached the coveted top spot on Amazon.com. Its publisher ordered an enormous number of copies printed. Eager readers have planned to celebrate its arrival at elaborate midnight release parties.

title: A Long-Forgotten Tale Rises From the Irish Sod
description: The Mint Theater is certainly making an elegant case that the Abbey Theater in Dublin missed an opportunity almost 70 years ago when it declined to produce Wife to James Whelan, a drama by Teresa Deevy (1894-1963), whose six previous plays had been staged to some acclaim there.

title: Apple Patents a Desktop Touch-Screen Computer
description: It was only a matter of time.

title: Swedish Prosecutor Hopes to Conclude Investigation of WikiLeaks Founder Soon
description: In an interview with the Swedish newspaper Aftonbladet on Monday, Swedens chief prosecutor, Eva Finne, said that she expects to make a decision about whether or not to charge the founder of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, with the crime of molestation or harassment this week, hopefully tomorrow.

title: On Our Radar: Coal Plant Construction
description: More than 30 new coal-fired power plants have been built since 2008 or are under construction, representing the coal power industrys largest expansion in decades. Building a coal-fired power plant today is betting that we are not going to put a serious financial cost on emitting carbon dioxide, an energy policy expert says. [Associated Press]

title: Arms Dealer Faces New Charges
description: Efraim E. Diveroli, the brash young Miami Beach arms dealer who landed a $300 million contract with the Pentagon to buy and ship munitions to Afghanistan only to have it unravel in a sprawling criminal case, was in custody again in Florida on Monday, facing new federal charges.

title: A.I.G. Pays Back $4 Billion in U.S. Loans
description: The bailed-out insurer American International Group confirmed on Monday that it had paid back nearly $4 billion in government loans in its single largest cash payment so far to reduce its debt to taxpayers, Reuters reports.

description: Elizabeth Demaray, an artist based in Brooklyn, is at the counter at a McDonalds in Midtown Manhattan. She is ordering up a storm. Cheeseburger. Apple dippers. Chicken nuggets. French fries. Baked apple pie. A strawberry shake.

description: The Fields Medals, often considered the most prestigious awards in mathematics, have been given to four men in diverse areas of research.

description: To the amazement of seismologists, they missed a magnitude-8.0 earthquake last year.

title: Readers Share Their Home Video Setups
description: As part of our Sofa Wars package, where we examined the battles being waged between start-ups and media and cable companies over the television screen, we asked our readers to share their thoughts, habits, hacks and overall experiences with the new ways we watch television.

description: Picplz, a low-profile photo sharing start-up from the founders of Imeem, expanded its reach Monday with the introduction of an iPhone app.

description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.  Secretary of Education Arne Duncan set an ambitious goal last year of overhauling 1,000 schools a year, using billions of dollars in federal stimulus money.

description: WASHINGTON  A federal district judge on Monday blocked President Obamas 2009 executive order that expanded embryonic stem cell research, saying it violated a ban on federal money being used to destroy embryos.

description: STOCKHOLM  Although Swedish prosecutors have yet to complete their review of sexual abuse accusations that two Stockholm women made last week against Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks Web site, those who say they have detailed knowledge of the case discount conspiracy theories linking it to efforts to discredit WikiLeaks.

title: Judges Taking Tougher Line on Bank Settlements
description: Everything was rolling along traditional lines. A bank broke the rules. The government found out. The company agreed to pay a fine and improve its behavior. And then the judge assigned to approve the deal blew his top.

title: Iran: Officials Suspended Over Detainees Treatment
description: Irans top prosecutor said Monday that three judiciary officials had been suspended in connection with the mistreatment of detainees at a notorious holding center during the unrest that followed last years disputed presidential election, the semiofficial Fars news agency reported. Mistreatment at the holding facility, known as Kahrizak, prompted widespread outrage last year, especially after it emerged that the son of a leading conservative figure had been beaten to death there. Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ordered the center closed, and the government began an investigation. In December, the Judicial Organization for the Armed Forces said that three men had been killed while being detained at Kahrizak.

title: A Magazine Now Tailored to the Not Necessarily Retired
description: WHEN Nancy Perry Graham, the editor of AARP The Magazine, attended a Bruce Springsteen concert at Giants Stadium in New Jersey last October, she and several editors on her staff wore black T-shirts with the words AARP The Magazine  Rocking Generations of Readers printed on the back.

description: Andrew M. Cuomo is a relatively rare bird as a gubernatorial candidate, as he already has executive experience that gives us a window into his thinking and management style.

description: MAUMEE, Ohio  As he travels through Ohio, Rob Portman, the Republican Senate candidate, talks to economically stressed voters incessantly about jobs  how to keep existing ones and create new ones for workers who have seen opportunities vanish as businesses cut back or pulled out of this once-proud manufacturing hub.

description: The irrational economic exuberance of the 1990s and 2000s has been rightly criticized for creating overheated markets and overextended pocketbooks, particularly in housing. That money, especially in luxury apartment towers, promoted a group of designers who emerged largely in the wake of postmodernism and who brought an unprecedented level of futuristic glamor to domestic lifestyles. Think Frank Gehry, Jean Nouvel and Herzog & de Meuron, people referred to, derisively or not, as starchitects.

description: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read.
