title: Muscle Injuries Rattle an Oregon High School
description: Two dozen Oregon high school football players who went to a hospital last week complaining of sore and swollen muscles  including three who required surgery  probably suffered from an extreme version of a muscle syndrome caused by intense exercise, sports medicine experts said Monday.

title: A Difficult Decision for Johnny Damon
description: Could Johnny Damon actually play for the Boston Red Sox again? If he does, the folks at Fenway Park will face the ultimate test of the Jerry Seinfeld Theory that sports fans basically root for laundry.

title: Some Service Restored on L.I.R.R.
description: A short in a pair of waterlogged track cables in Queens on Monday led to the near-total shutdown of the Long Island Rail Road and hours of waiting for thousands of stranded commuters, a frustrating reminder of the fragility of a rail network still dependent on antiquated equipment.

title: In the Fields of Italy, a Conflict Over Corn
description: VIVARO, Italy  Giorgio Fidenato declared war on the Italian government and environmental groups in April with a news conference and a YouTube video, which showed him poking six genetically modified corn seeds into Italian soil.

title: McCain Looks to Complete a Comeback
description: PHOENIX  Workers were busy decorating the Phoenix Convention Center on Monday in preparation for an event honoring Senator John McCain, who is finishing up a bruising primary battle. This will be no retirement party, however. Six more years! is expected to be the refrain.

title: Amid Furor on Islamic Center, Pleas for Orthodox Church Nearby
description: The furor over plans to build an Islamic center two blocks from ground zero had already been joined by several politicians. On Monday, two politicians were joined in turn by officials of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, who sought to use the controversy to focus attention on their long-stymied effort to rebuild a church destroyed on 9/11 at the foot of the World Trade Center.

title: Afghans Say NATO Troops Killed 8 Civilians in Raid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Officials and residents of Baghlan Province, in northern Afghanistan, accused NATO troops on Monday of killing eight civilians during an early morning raid.

title: Are Mergers Back? Well, Sort Of
description: On Wall Street, it is called the black car indicator  a reference to the limousines lined up around investment banks to ferry home young analysts who have pulled near-all-nighters while working on deals.

title: As Claims for Spill Losses Shift to Administrator, Queries Follow
description: BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss.  The day is here, Kenneth R. Feinberg announced on Monday at the American Legion Post 139 Bingo Hall, just over a mile from this towns quiet gulf beaches. If youve got a claim from BP, those days are over, he continued. BPs out of the business.

title: Maintenance of Oil Rig Is Subject at Hearing
description: HOUSTON  Government investigators are turning their attention this week to actions by onshore managers for BP and Transocean that may have contributed to the oil rig disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Fresh From College, Still Eager to Learn
description: For all the commotion kindled by the Red Bulls acquisitions of the international stars Thierry Henry and Rafael Marquez, what often has been overlooked has been the near-flawless play of two rookies plucked from the American college system.

title: In Scarred Land, a Haven for Victims of Acid Burns
description: TRAPAENG VENG, Cambodia  Touch Eap stroked her husbands scarred and discolored back as she described the night six years ago when she poured a tub of acid over his head, burning off his eyes and ears and lips and leaving him as dependent on her as a child.

title: Blazing Campaign Trails in a Certain 3-Inch Heel
description: Reshma Saujani has a lot to say about her bid to challenge Representative Carolyn B. Maloney in the Sept. 14 Democratic primary, and I listened carefully as I accompanied her while she canvassed in Astoria, Queens, on Saturday afternoon.

title: Dr. James M. Tanner, an Expert in How Children Grow, Is Dead at 90
description: Dr. James M. Tanner, an English pediatrician who developed standards for measuring a childs development during puberty and helped define what constitutes normal growth, died Aug. 11 in Wellington, near Taunton, in southwestern England. He was 90.

title: Ground Zero: Its Boundaries Are Elastic
description: The question is basic, first raised in this space months ago. It matters even more now with the intensified struggle over Park51, the Muslim community center and prayer space planned for Park Place, two city blocks and a dogleg from ground zero.

title: Ooh-la-la!
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE NOTES  Todays puzzle was the creation of a crossword class sponsored by J.A.S.A. (the Jewish Association of Services for the Aged) and taught by the 17-year-old constructor Caleb Madison. This article has all the details.

title: For Mets, Wild Card Is, Who Stays?
description: Only 38 games remain in the regular season, and the Mets are eight games back in the National League wild-card standings. The end is fast approaching. A playoff appearance is a distant fantasy but mathematically possible, which is why no decisions have been made regarding major changes.

title: George David Weiss, Writer of Hit Pop Songs, Dies at 89
description: George David Weiss, a songwriter who had a hand in some of the biggest hits of midcentury pop music, recorded by some of the biggest stars, died on Monday at his home in Oldwick, N.J. He was 89.

title: A Case of Mental Courage
description: In 1811, the popular novelist Fanny Burney learned she had breast cancer and underwent a mastectomy without anesthesia. She lay down on an old mattress, and a piece of thin linen was placed over her face, allowing her to make out the movements of the surgeons above her.

title: Yankees Rookie Gives as Good as He Gets
description: TORONTO  The major league leader in home runs, who three innings earlier clobbered a ball halfway to Saskatchewan, had just watched a 92-mile-per-hour fastball zip over his head and rattle off the backstop. The pitch was more high than inside, but Jose Bautista probably could not tell the difference, and he popped up off the dirt to glare at Ivan Nova, the Yankees rookie starter who was glaring right back at him with his arms outstretched.

title: A Hero Named Bobby
description: I was surprised  but probably shouldnt have been  that so many people had never heard of Bobby Thomson, who died at his home in Savannah, Ga., last week at the age of 86.

title: The Yens Lesson for the Yuan
description: AMONG the many points of tension between the United States and China, perhaps the single greatest one concerns exchange rates. For more than a decade, Beijing has kept the value of the renminbi, also known as the yuan, more or less constant to the dollar, a strategy that critics say increases the price of American exports to China and fuels the rapidly growing trade deficit with Beijing.

title: A Real Debate on Taxes
description: A deadline is supposed to concentrate the mind. But the year-end expiration of the Bush-era tax cuts, and the November elections, are having the opposite effect.

title: Tainted Eggs
description: The blame for the nationwide recall of tainted eggs must fall on the producers who allowed their eggs to become contaminated and distributed them for sale. But after a decade of tainted beef, spinach, the list goes on  federal officials also must take the rap for moving too slowly to strengthen the countrys food safety system.

title: Rangel on the Hot Seat in Debate
description: It was a gentle but unmistakable nudge President Obama gave Representative Charles B. Rangel recently, suggesting in an interview three weeks ago that Mr. Rangel, 80, should retire to end his career with dignity.

title: Mr. Lazios Bid for Attention
description: The former congressman Rick Lazio may be the front-runner in the Republican primary race for New York governor, but he lags far behind the Democratic nominee, Andrew Cuomo, in both the polls and fund-raising. That may explain, but can never excuse, his increasingly hysterical attacks on plans to build an Islamic community center and mosque two blocks from ground zero.

title: Far From Ground Zero, a Good-Will Tour
description: MUHARRAQ, Bahrain  The latecomers to Sheik Salah al-Jowders majlis, or weekly assembly, wished peace upon their cousins and shook all the mens hands before sitting down on the deep striped sofas that lined the oblong reception hall.

title: Lottery Numbers
Acid Rain 30 Years On
description: Just over 30 years ago, a skeptical Daniel Patrick Moynihan persuaded his Senate colleagues to approve a major study to see whether a relatively unknown phenomenon called acid rain was worth worrying about. The study, completed in 1990, showed that pollution blowing eastward from coal-fired power plants was killing off aquatic life. One-quarter of the Adirondacks 3,000 lakes and streams had become too acidic to support fish life, or were headed that way.

title: Commission Votes to Put Term Limits on November Ballot in New York City
description: Should New York City leaders be limited to two terms in office? Should the fine for violating conflict-of-interest laws increase? Should the city reduce the number of signatures required to get on a ballot?

description: Adam Serwer, left, of The American Prospect and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate the danger of radicalization of American Muslims.

title: Roche Backs New Method for Drug Delivery to Cells
description: The Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche is throwing its weight behind an experimental technology that could be used to treat a number of diseases.

title: Radiation, Risks Are Focus of Breast Screening Studies
description: When Dr. Deborah Rhodes orders a diagnostic test that involves radiation, she consults a chart in her office that lists the amount of radiation exposure from each test. She considers the patients total past exposure, and then carefully weighs the risks and benefits of each test and any alternative approaches she can take.

The Hollywood Reporter said G4 had committed to 10 episodes of Bomb Patrol: Afghanistan, which will document a Navy Explosive Ordnance Disposal unit as it trains in the United States and is deployed in the war zone. Neal Tiles, the president of G4, told The Hollywood Reporter that the show provides a rare opportunity to showcase the work of the courageous men and women on the front lines and would also connect with the young male viewers already tuning in to G4 programs like Attack of the Show! Mr. Tiles said, Both G4 and the Navy like this for the same reason: It appeals to the tech side of G4s demographic. Bomb Patrol: Afghanistan is planned for a spring debut.

title: Climate CSI Team Takes on Russian Heat

One goal is to gauge any contribution from the global buildup of human-generated greenhouse gases. Ill soon be interviewing Martin Hoerling, the climate scientist who heads this effort, but I wanted to highlight the teams latest product, an incredibly thorough post mortem on the Russian heat wave, posted on August 13. [6:38 p.m. | Updated  Tom Yulsman at the University of Colorado interviewed Hoerling about Russian heat and the climate attribution team (it helps to be local) and I encourage you to have a read.]

title: Weekend Orchestra Seats to the Met for $25?
description: Its hard to imagine being able to see a Metropolitan Opera weekend performance from an orchestra seat for $25  particularly when the top ticket price is $420. But Agnes Varis, a Met board member, believes opera is for everyone, so she has decided to subsidize 13,600 seats for weekend performances for the 2010-11 season. The program extends a weekday Rush Ticket program sponsored by Ms. Varis that subsidizes 200 seats at $20 each for every weekday performance, excluding galas. I thought a weekend program would give even more people an opportunity to enjoy the opera, Ms. Varis said in a statement. The Met has never been greater. The seats in the orchestra and Grand Tier, which range from $322 to $137, will be available for $25 through weekly drawings for Friday evening, Saturday matinee and Saturday evening performances. (The premieres of new productions of La Traviata, on Dec. 31, and Die Walkrie, on April 22, are not part of the program.) Entry forms will be available only at the Mets Web site, metopera.org. Beginning Sept. 27, every Monday through the end of the Met season in May operagoers can sign up for the drawings, which will be held on Tuesday mornings. Winners names will be posted by noon. The number of tickets available will vary each week.

title: The Gates Path to an Energy Revolution

But the heart of the conversation, published today on the magazines Web site, was about how to make non-polluting energy technologies so cheap that coal reverts to being the shiny black rock it was before the industrial revolution.

title: Ansel Adams Trust Sues
description: The debate over whether negatives bought at a California garage sale are really the lost work of Ansel Adams has now landed where it always seemed destined: a courtroom. The Ansel Adams Publishing Trust, which controls the licensing rights to Adamss work, filed a federal trademark infringement suit Monday in San Francisco as part of an effort to block the sale of prints by Rick Norsigian, a Fresno school-maintenance worker who bought the negatives 10 years ago for $45. The suit argues that Mr. Norsigian and a consulting firm run by his lawyer, Arnold Peter, have acted knowingly, willfully and with malice in marketing the negatives as Adamss work, according to a report in The Bay Citizen. Prints from the negatives are being sold online and through a Beverly Hills, Calif., gallery. Mr. Peter said in a statement that he was disappointed by the lawsuit, which he described as an effort to harass Mr. Norsigian.

title: New York City Opera Announces Season
description: The soprano Lauren Flanigan, who last year sang the title role in Esther for New York City Opera, above, will return to the opera company for its 2010-11 season to sing the role of Myra Foster in Sance on a Wet Afternoon, a new work by Stephen Schwartz (Godspell, Wicked), New York City Opera said. Sance on a Wet Afternoon will have its debut at the David H. Koch Theater on April 19 as part of a season that will open on Oct. 27 with a new production of A Quiet Place by Leonard Bernstein and Stephen Wadsworth. Other planned productions include Strausss Intermezzo, opening Oct. 31; Donizettis Elixir of Love, opening March 22; and a program of monodramas, opening March 25, comprising John Zorns La Machine de ltre, Arnold Schoenbergs Erwartung and Morton Feldmans Neither, with a libretto by Samuel Beckett. City Opera will also present a fall concert, Lucky to Be Me: The Vocal Music of Leonard Bernstein, on Nov. 6 and 7, featuring the Broadway performers Victoria Clark, Christine Ebersole, Kelli OHara, Donna Murphy, Michael Cerveris, Darius de Haas and Michael Urie.

title: After Upheaval, Not All Is Well With Thai Youth

Other performers and authors who will appear in conversations with that magazines contributors include the Office star Steve Carell, the actress Patricia Clarkson, the musician James Taylor, the fantasy writer Neil Gaiman and the filmmaker Werner Herzog. The festival, which runs from Oct. 1 through 3, will also feature panel discussions on Saturday Night Live, with Seth Meyers and other cast members, and moderated by The New Yorker editor, David Remnick; on vampires in popular culture, featuring Stephen King and the Twilight screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg and moderated by Joan Acocella; and on the rise of the political right, with the FreedomWorks chairman, Dick Armey, Representative Anthony Weiner, Democrat of New York, the CNBC host Rick Santelli and The New Yorkers Jill Lepore, also moderated by Mr. Remnick. A full lineup for the festival will be posted at newyorker.com/festival.

title: Katie Finneran to Leave Promises

Katie Finneran, also above, who won a Tony Award for her scene-stealing Act 2 turn as the barfly Marge MacDougall, is leaving the cast on Oct. 10. A spokesman for the show announced on Tuesday that Ms. Finneran and Darren Goldstein, who married on Sunday, were expecting a baby in the winter. Mr. Hayes, who shares a memorable Christmas Eve jitterbug with Ms. Finnerans character in the musical, is signed to appear through Dec. 26, as is his co-star, Kristin Chenoweth, who plays his main love interest. The show, which opened in April, was one of last seasons biggest hits. Producers said that a new Marge would be announced soon. The role is small, but juicy: like Ms. Finneran, Marian Mercer won the best-featured-actress Tony playing Marge in the original 1968 production.

title: Britain: Daughter Is Born to Prime Minister and Wife
description: Prime Minister David Camerons wife, Samantha Cameron, gave birth to the couples fourth child, a daughter, on Tuesday at the Royal Cornwall Hospital, near where the family is vacationing. The prime minister, left, said they had not decided on a name for the baby, whose birth had been expected next month. After experiencing contractions, Mrs. Cameron went to the hospital around 8 a.m., and the baby, weighing just over six pounds, was delivered around noon by Caesarean section. Mr. Camerons office said he would take some paternity leave. British men may take two weeks off in the 12 months after a child is born. In 2000, Prime Minister Tony Blair and his wife, Cherie, had their fourth child, the first born to a serving prime minister in more than 150 years.

title: Israel: Arabic to Be Taught to Fifth-Graders
description: The study of Arabic will be compulsory for fifth-grade students in Jewish public schools in Northern Israel under a pilot project starting in September, an Israeli Ministry of Education official said Tuesday. Arabic is already compulsory from seventh to ninth grade in Jewish schools throughout the country, after which it is elective. The program will begin with about 50 Arab teachers, and could expand depending upon its success and the availability of teachers, said Shlomo Alon, the ministrys chief supervisor for Arabic language. The program is a way for students and teachers to look at the other and to share views about life, customs and culture, Mr. Alon said. About half the students in northern Israel are Arab, and the study of Hebrew is mandatory in Arab schools.

title: California: Colleges Cut Kaplan Tie

Under the agreement, which was apparently never used at any of the states 112 community colleges, Kaplan was offering students a 42 percent discount, making the cost about $216 a credit, compared with $26 a credit at the community colleges.

A new entry in Mr. Dylans Bootleg Series, The Witmark Demos  M. Witmark & Sons was one of his early publishers  will be released by Columbia Records on Oct. 19, Billboard reported. It consists of 47 demo recordings that Mr. Dylan made from 1962 to 1964. Among the tracks that will appear on this two-CD release are early versions of future standards like Blowin in the Wind and The Times They Are A-Changin,  as well as songs that have not been previously released in any version, like Guess Im Doing Fine, Long Ago, Far Away and Ballad for a Friend. title: Tax Charges Prevent Crocodile Dundee Star From Leaving Australia
description: Paul Hogan, the Australian actor whose Crocodile Dundee movies and tourism ads for American television were surely responsible for the sale of thousands of shrimp and countless accompanying barbies, is not having a good day, mate. A lawyer for Mr. Hogan said the actor was being prevented from leaving Australia until he pays millions of dollars in back taxes, Reuters reported. Mr. Hogan, who is based in the United States, is being investigated by Australian officials who say he put film royalties in offshore tax havens, a charge he denies. His lawyer, Andrew Robinson, said in a statement that Mr. Hogan was served with a departure prohibition order by the Australian Taxation Office when he traveled to Sydney last week for his mothers funeral. The process of detaining Paul in Australia away from his wife and child in Los Angeles has devastated Paul, Mr. Robinson wrote in a statement. A spokesman for the Australian Taxation Office told Reuters that he was unable to comment on individual taxpayers.

title: Second Thoughts About Parenting
description: Alison Patton is a divorce lawyer and mediator. She watches marriages unravel. She is more than familiar with the seven-year itch, when partners find themselves annoyed with things they used to find endearing and when new realities seem to set in.

title: Welcome (and Welcome Back) to FiveThirtyEight
description: FiveThirtyEight.com premiered on March 7, 2008, three days after Hillary Rodham Clinton won the Democratic presidential primaries in Texas and Ohio  victories that were widely described as giving her momentum in her race for the Democratic nomination. Mrs. Clinton was already well ahead in the polls in the next big primary contest, in Pennsylvania.

title: There Are Bubbles, And Then There Are Bubbles
description: On the whole, I find it amazing and distressing that fear of new bubbles is playing such a large role in current policy discussion, leading too many prominent economists to recommend raising interest rates in the face of a hugely depressed economy. Even if you believe that excessively low policy rates were a key reason for the housing bubble  which I dont  the idea that we should be raising rates now brings to mind the old joke about the motorist who runs over a pedestrian, then tries to fix the damage by backing up, and running over the pedestrian a second time.

title: Letter: An Elegant Hospital
description: To the Editor: The excellent article on the Greenbrier resort in West Virginia, Nothing Boutique About It (Aug. 15) by Dwight Garner, made an important omission. The Greenbrier also served as the United States Armys Ashford General Hospital, from which I was discharged from the Army in February 1946. I arrived after three years of living only in tents, barracks and bombed-out houses and was amazed to end my service in such luxury, with German prisoners of war as servants, fine meals in an elegant dining room, and Sammy Snead as golf pro.

title: Military Computer Attack Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON  A top Pentagon official has confirmed a previously classified incident that he describes as the most significant breach of U.S. military computers ever, a 2008 episode in which a foreign intelligence agent used a flash drive to infect computers, including those used by the Central Command in overseeing combat zones in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Yana Paskova on Henri Cartier-Bresson
description: Yana Paskova, 28, was born in Bulgaria, raised in Chicago and is now based in New York. She has worked across the United States and in Eastern Europe, Russia and Asia. Her work has appeared in The New York Times, Newsweek, The Chicago Tribune and Time Magazine. Amanda Rivkins conversation with Ms. Paskova has been edited and condensed.

title: Another Record Low for Housing

title: Now Showing | Hussein Chalayan at Lisson Gallery
description: The more banal aspects of clothing a body have never hampered Hussein Chalayans creativity. In fact, he has long been inspired by disembodiment  an idea that poses a challenge, perhaps, for the fashion runways but one that is certainly well suited to an art gallery. For I Am Sad Leyla (zgnm Leyla), the designers solo exhibition at Londons Lisson gallery, which opens Sept. 8, Chalayan has created a sound-art installation that includes audio, film, sculpture, musical notation and yes, even a bit of fashion.

title: Elin Nordegren Ends Silence
description: By the end of the week, you are almost guaranteed to be sick of hearing about Elin Nordegrens first interview about the divorce from Tiger Woods  People magazine does have a knack for tripping your overkill buzzer even if you never actually pick up the magazine  but before that sets in, you have to give Nordegren credit for mastering public relations, something at which her famously philandering ex-husband failed so spectacularly.

In years past, we have been to Wyoming and Colorado but this year we returned to what may be my favorite state, Montana. Specifically, the area around Glacier National Park.

description: Tucked cozily under the Brooklyn Queens Expressway near Union Avenue in Brooklyn, the Kustom Kills and Hot Rod Thrills car show celebrated its 10th anniversary on Saturday. The annual show devoted to pre-1964 rat rods and rust rides is organized by the New York Rumblers Hot Rod and Kustom Car Club, which said this years show was the biggest yet.

title: Dealing With Scarcity
description: Julian Cribb, in his book The Coming Famine (which I reviewed today over in Arts), contends that weve already seen peak oil  the time when production can do nothing but decline. He then goes on to deduce that since weve likely seen peak fertilizer, peak water and peak land as well, weve probably seen peak food. This at a time, as we all know, when not only is the worlds population growing but also becoming generally better off  that is, more and more people want to eat like Americans.

The Democrats now have an approximately 20 percent chance of losing 10 or more seats in the Senate, according to the model, which would cost them control of the chamber unless Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida, who is running for the Senate as an independent, both wins his race and decides to caucus with them.

Insurgents unleashed a wave of roadside mines and more than a dozen car bombings across Iraq, killing dozens, toppling a police station in the capital and sowing chaos and confusion among the soldiers and police officers who responded.

title: Coppola to Receive Thalberg Award
description: Francis Ford Coppola will receive the Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award this year from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, while honorary Oscars will go to the director Jean-Luc Godard, the actor Eli Wallach and the film preservationist Kevin Brownlow, the academy said on Wednesday. The recipients were chosen by the academys board of governors on Tuesday evening, and the awards will be handed out at a dinner ceremony in Los Angeles on Nov. 13. Mr. Brownlow is known for his work on films of the silent era. Mr. Godard, whose credits include Breathless and King Lear, has been a central figure in French film, and Mr. Wallach has appeared in a long string of features, including The Misfits and The Magnificent Seven, after he made his debut in 1956 in Baby Doll. The Thalberg award, named for the legendary MGM executive, recognizes Mr. Coppolas work as a producer of films including The Conversation, The Godfather: Part II and Dracula.

title: Dollar Thriftys Promising Day in Court

I watched the first hour of the hearing in Delaware Chancery Court on Wednesday, courtesy of Courtroom View Network, and my opinion from that time is that Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. is not going to enjoin the deal. He is also unlikely to touch the termination fee or the matching rights that Hertz has negotiated in its agreement. At most, he may require Dollar Thrifty to make more disclosure about the sale process.

In fact, when the Shopbop buyers are bullish on an item, Ms. Sutter said, her staff will take that as a cue to cut the garment in another pattern or color. Youre crazy not to pay attention to what they do.

title: Baryshnikov and Cunningham Company Embark on New Collaboration
description: Though Merce Cunningham is no longer with us, some of the biggest stars in the dance world are working to ensure his legacy. BAC Flicks: Mondays With Merce, a new monthly film series and programming collaboration, is intended to educate audiences about Cunninghams legacy and creative process. description: Starting in the 1970s, the French publishing house Robert Laffont issued a series of cookbooks by young chefs who were gaining fame as developers of what was then being called nouvelle cuisine  and what is now pretty mainstream. The Laffont authors included Michel Gurard, Jean and Pierre Troisgros, Alain Chapel and so many others.

title: Can Preschoolers Be Depressed?
description: Kiran didnt seem like the type of kid parents should worry about. He was the easy one, his father, Raghu, a physician, says. He always wanted to please. Unlike other children in his suburban St. Louis preschool, Kiran (a nickname his parents asked me to use to protect his identity) rarely disobeyed or acted out. If he dawdled or didnt listen, Raghu (also a nickname) had only to count to five before Kiran hastened to tie his shoes or put the toys away. He was kind to other children; if a classmate cried, Kiran immediately approached. Our little empath! his parents proudly called him.

title: Bernadette Peters To Star In follies In Washington

Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, scheduled to run May 7 through June 5. Casting for Sallys husband, Buddy, and the musicals other unhappily married couple, Phyllis and Ben, will be announced later, the Kennedy Center said on Wednesday in its statement about Ms. Peters. The revival will be directed by Eric Schaeffer, who oversaw the Kennedy Centers Sondheim Celebration in 2002 and is now artistic director of Signature Theater in Arlington, Va. Ms. Peters is under contract through early November for A Little Night Music. Whether she will follow up her Night Music with a Kennedy Center-to-Broadway transfer of Follies is an open question.

title: Disney Studios Withdraws From Animation Group
description: Walt Disney Studios has withdrawn from a group that hands out trophies for animation achievement. For years Disney has privately groused about the Annie Awards, presented by the Hollywood chapter of the International Animated Film Society. Disney has complained that the guild allows anyone to buy a membership (in contrast to most awards-bestowing organizations) and that Disneys rival DreamWorks Animation has too much power because it gives its employees free guild membership. Variety, which reported the split, noted that Disneys Pixar entries had won 6 of the last 10 top Annie prizes. But Disney started to agitate more aggressively for changes in 2009 after DreamWorks Animations Kung Fu Panda won a raft of Annies, and Pixars Wall-E won nothing. Wall-E went on to win the Oscar for animation that year. We believe there is an issue with the way the Annies are judged, and have been seeking a mutually agreeable solution with the board, Ed Catmull, president of Disney Animation and Pixar Animation, said in a statement. Although some initial steps have been taken, the board informed us that no further changes would be made to address our concerns. Antran Manoogian, the guilds president, told Variety, The Annies are about honoring the best in animation, and we will continue to do so.

title: Ice Buckets
description: JASON ROWAN, 42, is a cocktail maker who creates customized drinks for private events. He also writes about cocktail culture for magazines and has a blog called Embury Cocktails, which he describes as a clubhouse for drinking and cocktail enthusiasts.

title: New Releases Cant Top Eminems Recovery
description: Eminem reigns over the Billboard chart yet again this week, beating a wave of new releases. Eminems album Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope) is No. 1 for the seventh time, with 116,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Intimacy: Album III (Motown) by the R&B singer Kem opens at No. 2 with 74,000 sales, and God Willin & the Creek Dont Rise (RCA), the new album by Ray LaMontagne and the Pariah Dogs, is No. 3 with 64,000. Iron Maidens Final Frontier (Universal Music Enterprises) reached No. 4 in its first week, with 63,000 sales, and Trace Adkinss Cowboys Back in Town (Show Dog/Universal), also new, is No. 5 with 50,000. Next week there is likely to be a shake-up because Katy Perrys new Teenage Dream (Capitol) is expected to have strong sales.

title: Lohan Leaves Rehab
description: Lindsay Lohan, below, was released from a Los Angeles rehabilitation center on Tuesday, making her a free woman less than two months after she was sentenced to 90 days in jail for violating the terms of her probation, Reuters reported. Ms. Lohan, the 24-year-old actress and Mean Girls star, served 22 days at the rehabilitation center at Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center after her release on Aug. 2 from the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif., where she arrived on July 20 to begin serving her jail term. Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court sentenced Ms. Lohan on July 6 after she missed a probation hearing in May stemming from her 2007 arrests on charges of drunken driving and drug possession. Judge Elden S. Fox on Wednesday ordered Ms. Lohan to undergo psychotherapy and addiction-counseling sessions until November and submit to random drug and alcohol tests.

description: Tribeca Film Festival organizers announced on Wednesday that the 10th annual festival would be held April 20 to May 1.

title: Dylans Demo Recordings To Be Released This Fall
description: Bob Dylan may be too busy with his painting career and his year-round touring to create an album of new material, but that wont keep a new Dylan album from hitting shelves in the fall, this one comprising material from the earlier end of his 50-year career. A new entry in Mr. Dylans Bootleg Series, The Witmark Demos (M. Witmark & Sons was one of his early publishers), will be released by Columbia Records on Oct. 19, Billboard reported. This two-CD release consists of 47 demo recordings that Mr. Dylan made from 1962 to 1964. Among the tracks are early versions of future standards like Blowin in the Wind and The Times They Are A-Changin, as well as songs that have not been previously released in any version, like Guess Im Doing Fine, Long Ago, Far Away and Ballad for a Friend. Columbia will also release on Oct. 19 new vinyl versions of Mr. Dylans first eight albums, taken from their original mono mixes.

title: Helping New Parents While Confronting Her Own Fatal Illness
description: During her first pregnancy, in the mid-1980s, Karen Storek was desperate for information about giving birth and caring for her baby. She decided that there needed to be a place where new parents could gather and disseminate parenting advice, from before conception to the first grade.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: The Facebook Movie
description: The Social Networkalso known as the Facebook movieis coming in October, but already theres been drama behind the scenes. Miguel Helft, The New York Times technology reporter covering Facebook, and Michael Cieply, who covers media for The Times, recently examined the tensions between the filmmakers and Facebook executives. Bettina Edelstein speaks with Mr. Helft on this weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast about the disagreements over the movie, its portrayal of Facebooks founder, Mark Zuckerberg, and how Facebook has responded.

title: Imam Rauf and Moderate Islam
description: To some extent, the controversy surrounding the Cordoba Initiatives Lower Manhattan venture is really a controversy about how non-Muslim Westerners should relate to the would-be spokesmen for a moderate (or moderate, depending on your point of view) Islam. One school of thought, prominent among conservatives but associated with liberal thinkers like Paul Berman as well, holds that anything short of an absolute commitment to Enlightenment values is unacceptable from such figures, and that moderate Muslims must demonstrate this commitment, and prove their secular bona fides, by making a frontal assault on Islamic culture as it currently exists. To this school, explicitly-liberal figures like Ayaan Hirsi Ali or Irshad Manji represent the beau ideal of moderate Islam, because theyre forthright in their critiques of Muslim societies failings, and unstinting in their insistence that the Western way of faith and politics is ultimately superior. A high-profile bridge-builder like the ubiquitous Tariq Ramadan, on the other hand, is much more suspect, and possibly beyond the pale because he tends to use different language and strike different notes depending on his audience, because he often seems to be making excuses for illiberalism in the Islamic world, because hes less-than-forthright in his condemnations of certain kinds of extremism, and so on down the line. To his critics, such bobbing and weaving is proof enough that his moderate Islam project is really just a flowery fraud and a Trojan Horse for Wahhabism, with no redeeming value whatsoever. And this critique is easily extended to many other self-described moderates as well  including, lately, Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf, who arguably has a stronger claim to moderation than Ramadan, but who seems to share some of his more evasive qualities when the conversation turns to, say, Hamas or the Islamic Republic of Iran.

title: Louisiana: $1.8. Billion for Schools Lost to Katrina
description: The Obama administration will give New Orleans $1.8 billion in a lump-sum reimbursement for schools that were damaged or destroyed in the flooding after Hurricane Katrina, Senator Mary L. Landrieu, a Democrat, announced Wednesday. The settlement will pay for 87 school campuses in the city to replace the 127 that existed before Katrina. The public education system in New Orleans was in the first stages of a radical overhaul before the storm, with the creation of a state-run Recovery School District in addition to the pre-existing Orleans Parish School Board. Over three-fifths of the citys students now attend charter schools. A spokeswoman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency did not confirm the figure but said that a major announcement would come later in the week.

title: The Wrong Kind of Enthusiasm

title: Religion-Based Groups Protest Aid Restriction
description: More than 100 religion-based organizations are protesting a provision in pending legislation that would prohibit them from receiving federal money if they consider a job applicants religion when hiring. In a letter sent Wednesday to all members of Congress, the groups contend that the provision would dilute protections they have under the 1964 Civil Rights Act and the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, as well as under the First Amendment of the Constitution. The provision is in legislation to reauthorize the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, which makes grants to nonprofit social service organizations with programs in those areas. While many of the groups signing the letter do not get money from the agency, they say the language of the provision is so broad it will affect other, unrelated sources of federal grants.

title: Theater Company Avoids Eviction in Deal With M.T.A.
description: The Lower Manhattan theater company 3-Legged Dog has reached an agreement with its landlord, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, that will allow it to stay in its home at 80 Greenwich Street, The Wall Street Journal reported. In May the M.T.A. threatened to evict the company. At that time 3-Legged Dog owed more than $300,000 in back rent and interest. In a deal reached Wednesday, the company will pay on Oct. 15 all the rent owed since June 1. It will pay the rest over roughly three years, at an interest rate of 5 percent. In addition, the M.T.A. will forgive $59,000 to settle claims related to 3-Legged Dogs construction costs in the building. The executive artistic director of 3-Legged Dog, Kevin Cunningham, said the company had increased its earned income in recent months and had also received a major grant from a New York foundation, which he said would be announced in October.

title: Letter: The Second Coming
description: Andrew Cuomo  though he may not campaign in the political poetry made famous by his philosopher-king paterfamilias  has it within his power to govern with the administrative lan of an innate problem-solver. And should he ascend to the throne of Albany, Cuomo the younger will surely avoid the blunders and moral pitfalls of Eliot Spitzer and David Paterson. Still, governing the Empire State has become as thorny as it is thankless. The perennially depressed upstate economy, a fractious Legislature and yawning budget deficits make New York nearly ungovernable. Yet while he lacks Mario Cuomos gravitas, Andrew Cuomo is preternaturally decisive. Such tenacity should serve him in good stead.

title: Letter: Shift Paradigm
description: The Medium column about smart keyboards perpetuates a misleading legend about the qwerty layout: that it was done to reduce key jamming. The true story urges close minding by designers of new keys and layouts. The qwerty inventor, Christopher Sholes, relied on years of study with trial users to inform his eventually successful design. Critical among his findings was that maximizing alternation of hands on successive keys greatly speeds human use. Reducing key jamming was useful, too, but could have been done in many other ways. The moral of the story is that before making changes or additions to this wonderful and globally necessary device, the results concerning human usefulness and usability need to be empirically evaluated  something easily done but much too often neglected.

title: Letters: Dumping Across the Digital Divide
description: I found Pieter Hugos photo portfolio appropriately haunting. All too frequently those of us living in technologically advanced countries want those in developing countries to have the technology we have. In many cases the countries we donate to are not ready for this technology. There are huge graveyards and dusty storerooms throughout underdeveloped countries that are full of useless equipment that have missing parts or that lack reusable components. Some equipment, in particular medical-diagnostic equipment, breaks down with no means of service. The organization I work with supplies medical and surgical supplies to the Fiji and Solomon Islands. We are very realistic about bringing these countries equipment that is infrastructure-appropriate. Gift giving is a wonderful thing, but that giving must be well thought out and responsible. The best gift we can give countries that wish to increase their level of technology is training in servicing and repairing what we send to them. That is sustainable technology.

title: In Japan, Party Ex-Leader Will Challenge Premier

title: Letter: My Life in Therapy
description: While Im glad to know that Daphne Merkin (Aug. 8) has had positive experiences in psychoanalysis, much of what she describes  endless treatments without much progress, blame for being resistant rather than an analyst who also accepts responsibility for shortcomings, withholding clinicians who dont acknowledge loving or other feelings  is typical of a more old-fashioned though still prevalent way of working. Contemporary psychoanalysis and in particular the school of thought that has come to be known as relational psychoanalysis emphasizes greater patient-analyst collaboration, the analysts selective self-disclosure and other techniques designed to address many of the concerns and limitations Merkin has experienced in her admirable quest to live a more contented life.

title: Letters: The Copyright Enforcers
description: I am concerned that John Bowes article (Aug. 8) may leave the false impression on readers that all business owners are required to pay licensing fees for playing music in their establishments. The Fairness in Music Licensing Act, which was strongly opposed by Ascap, BMI and other performing-rights organizations, exempts certain business establishments from licensing fees. Under the act, small business establishments can play audio music from radio, television, cable or satellite sources without having to pay any licensing fee, provided that certain guidelines are met. This exemption is called the home-style exemption. Generally, to qualify for the home-style exemption, the business must use a consumer-style receiver and cannot transmit the music beyond its establishment or charge admission for listening to the music.

title: Letters: I Tweet, Therefore I Am
description: I read Peggy Orensteins essay (Aug. 1) regarding Twitter and the letters in response to the article and felt compelled to write. I come from a developing country, where technology has more connotations than connectivity, and have found that it is important to be in the stream of people, if only virtually, before one can dwell on know thyself. In cities like Mumbai or remote villages in India with their sprawling inequality and islands of poverty, Twitter and other social-networking sites, for all their drawbacks with regards to privacy, intimacy and introspection, have provided a platform of equal sharing and have been silently revolutionary from the bottom up. Social-networking sites have gone a step ahead in expanding the notion of the self and democratizing the essence of the social consciousness. No doubt ruminations of the self and the complete attention to the joy of the moment are lifes DNA of emotional existence, but the Internet and social-networking sites can be a ladder in reaching that level of awareness for the entirety of humanity.

title: I Get Around
description: Somewhere in the United States, there may be an attic containing the written remnants of a previously unchronicled 20th-century life that was even more astonishing than the one the writer Justin Spring discovered in San Francisco a few years ago. But even the most skeptical reader of his new book, Secret Historian, will have to admit that the bar is now set high. Samuel Steward, the subject of this absorbing act of biographical excavation, had many identities, including several that the subtitle of the book omits: pioneering sex researcher, collector of celebrity conquests, drug addict, masochist, Catholic (briefly), Navy enlistee (even more briefly), conquistador of vast provinces of Americas pre-Stonewall homosexual subculture. Most fortuitously, he was apparently a graphomaniac who documented his long, dark, exuberant, sad, dangerous life in journals, an unpublished memoir, reams of letters, poems, erotica, semifictionalized short stories and even a 746-entry card catalog of his sexual history, scrupulously maintained over five decades and in some cases ornamented  perhaps for future biographers?  with what Spring decorously calls DNA-verifiable evidence of his liaisons.

Toward the end of this trek, the hero meets up with an old friend, with whom he competes over who had walked the farthest, starved the longest, felt the most hopeless; they were athletes in the hard-luck Olympics. Earlier, at a bus stop in Gaza, the hero comes across someone who is everything he doesnt want to be: Musa the Drunk, a homeless Somali man, the poster boy of failed migration. Both moments reveal the weaknesses in this young novelists phenomenal, fast-forward story.

Heavy on the cowbells and bass drum, the full band was fronted by the energetic Nic Offer, who flailed around in regal purple slip-ons and something close to pajamas.

title: Steam-Driven Dreams
description: Steam is cool. Or rather, hot: the technology that helped usher in the Industrial Revolution shows up these days in neo-nostalgic steampunk fiction, design and fashion. Its not just affection for leather and brass that drives the fascination; harnessing the power of steam broke humans out of what William Rosen calls the Malthusian trap that had kept mankind ever on the brink of famine and collapse. His book, The Most Powerful Idea in the World: A Story of Steam, Industry, and Invention, is a sneaky history  ostensibly about the origins of the steam engine, though actually about much more.

title: The Storm Tracker
description: It has been five years since Hurricane Katrina hit New Orleans and undermined our faith in the competence of government. Now that were entering another hurricane season, have you thought about what could happen if winds whip up the waters around the Deepwater Horizon BP oil spill?  Thought about it a lot. Not much changes.

title: Jersey as a Nickname for New Jersey
description: Commenting on my column about beach lingo from the Jersey Shore and elsewhere, Gary Muldoon writes: "If someone from the Garden State comes from 'Jersey,' do those residents refer to someone from the Empire State as being from 'York'?"

title: How to Send Your Son Off to College, Again
description: Evan is off. Its different the second time. He and his Dad headed out on the nine-hour drive this morning, in the car hes now allowed to keep on campus. His younger brother and I waved from the curb. No tears from me this year. Well, maybe one or two. But mostly the feeling that the calendar has turned another page, and he is one step further on his own journey.

title: Does Your Language Shape How You Think?
description: Seventy years ago, in 1940, a popular science magazine published a short article that set in motion one of the trendiest intellectual fads of the 20th century. At first glance, there seemed little about the article to augur its subsequent celebrity. Neither the title, Science and Linguistics, nor the magazine, M.I.T.s Technology Review, was most peoples idea of glamour. And the author, a chemical engineer who worked for an insurance company and moonlighted as an anthropology lecturer at Yale University, was an unlikely candidate for international superstardom. And yet Benjamin Lee Whorf let loose an alluring idea about languages power over the mind, and his stirring prose seduced a whole generation into believing that our mother tongue restricts what we are able to think.

title: Where Hatred Ruled
description: First, the facts. Willie McGee, an African-American driver of a grocery-delivery truck, was accused of raping a white woman, Willette Hawkins, in November 1945 in Laurel, Miss. After deliberating for less than three minutes, an all-white jury sentenced him to death, and the small-town crime, as Alex Heard writes, became famous around the world. Bella Abzug, long before she became a congresswoman, served as McGees defense lawyer during the appeals process, working on a case that today evokes the story line of Harper Lees To Kill a Mockingbird. Albert Einstein, Norman Mailer and Paul Robeson supported McGee, and left-wing journalists ranted about the trial in The Daily Worker. In contrast to their reports, The Eyes of Willie McGee does not crackle with rage, despite its horrific ending: on May 8, 1951, McGee was electrocuted in the local courthouse, leaving an odor of burned flesh in the room.

description: Television is on a creative roll, but for some reason the Emmys have slumped into Brezhnev-style stagnation, with the same shows winning the top honors year after year. 30 Rock has been named the best comedy three years in a row and is nominated again in 2010, while Mad Men is in line to win a third Emmy for best drama. However deserving those shows may be, again is not the most exhilarating word in awards-show language.

title: N.H.L. in Talks to Start League for Women
description: TORONTO  Faced with the threat of their sport being excluded from the Winter Olympics after 2014 because of a lack of competitiveness, womens hockey officials have held preliminary discussions with the N.H.L. about forming an N.H.L.-supported womens league, representatives from both sides confirmed Thursday.

title: Future World
description: Before he became a writer, Douglas Coupland (Generation X, JPod) studied art and design, so his current collaboration with the Canadian clothing company Roots is no surprise. Roots X Douglas Coupland, a collection of clothing, accessories and even furniture, stems from the Canadian writers interest in the way that electronic media have connected the far-flung provinces of his homeland. Among other things, the collections test-pattern logo is reproduced on hang tags and a T-shirt; a motherboard pattern adorns tights and a miniskirt; and tables (the Electric table, shown here, is $1,000) have legs inspired by Canadas ubiquitous electrical transmission towers. The Paris retail mecca Colette has picked up the limited-supply collection, which goes on sale there Sept. 7. Its also available at selected Roots stores in Canada, or at usa.roots.com.

description: Since the publication of Night Soldiers in 1988, Alan Furst has made a considerable reputation as a writer of historical spy thrillers. These are set in that fraught period of European history starting in 1933, with Hitlers rise to power, and ending in 1945. Though Furst is a native New Yorker, he lives some of the time in Paris and has adopted a European sensibility  perhaps aiming to evoke the atmosphere of his books, which have been compared to the works of John le Carr and Graham Greene.

description: When Proenza Schoulers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez imagined bringing their fall 2010 collection to life in a video they immediately thought of Harmony Korine. The writer of Kids and director of the troubling art-house favorites Gummo, Julien Donkey-Boy, and most recently 2009s Trash Humpers, was ideal, in their minds, to take on the theme of innocence they had explored in the clothes. The results will appear the first week in September on the Proenza Schouler website. We caught up with the designers and the filmmaker to see how it all went down.

title: Postcards From My Literary Staycation
description: The last two summers, many cash-strapped Americans opted for a staycation: a slimmed-down getaway close to home. A staycation might take you to Cooperstown or Manassas or a town associated with luckless witches. But it would not take you to Machu Picchu or Venice.

description: In his review of Encounter, Milan Kunderas latest book of essays, John Simon discusses the authors affection for exiles who, like Kundera himself, write in a language not their own.

title: The Language of Exile
description: The Czech novelist Milan Kunderas new essayistic book, Encounter, his fourth, is alternatingly elegiac and celebratory. An migr from the Communist horror of what was then Czechoslovakia, he settled in Paris and proceeded to write in French. But he discovered in France the sense that we have come to the era of post-art, in a world where art is dying because the need for art, the sensitivity and the love for it, is dying.

title: Paperback Row
description: MASTERS OF SEX:  The Life and Times of William Masters and Virginia Johnson, the Couple Who Taught America How to Love, by Thomas Maier. (Basic Books, $18.95.) Human Sexual Response, published in 1966, attempted to analyze sex scientifically, and it debunked many myths (while introducing a few new ones). This biography explores the complicated and not especially happy lives of Masters and Johnson, for whom sex was part of the job description and love was elusive. THE EAST, THE WEST, AND SEX: A History, by Richard Bernstein. (Vintage, $16.) Bernstein searches for evidence that the vision of a sexualized East we know as Orientalism exists in reality in this accessible, much-researched and far-reaching book, as our reviewer, Toni Bentley, described it. Along the way he examines Marco Polos report on imperial concubines in the 14th century and the writings of Gustave Flaubert and Sir Richard Burton. However, he tends to gloss over the power imbalance between Western men and impoverished Eastern women.

title: When Your Landlord Fights a Foreclosure Sale
description: Back in the October Bucks post What to Do When Your Landlord Is Going Through Foreclosure, I described how I came home to find a notice on our buildings front door, and another in our mailbox, saying the foreclosure process had begun on the property. So I did some research on what rights tenants have in such situations.

title: Where It Hurts
description: A simple understanding of pain would be this: Its a biological response to injury or disease. Treat the cause and the pain abates. The body, after all, is a relatively efficient machine. But what happens when the wound wont heal? And what if pain doesnt stem from injury or disease, but is itself the problem?

title: Den of Antiquities
description: In a remarkable interlude in Willa Cathers novel The Professors House, a New Mexico cowboy named Tom Outland describes climbing a landmark he calls Blue Mesa: Far up above me, a thousand feet or so, set in a great cavern in the face of the cliff, I saw a little city of stone, asleep. It was as still as sculpture, . . . pale little houses of stone nestling close to one another, perched on top of each other, with flat roofs, narrow windows, straight walls, and in the middle of the group, a round tower. . . . I knew at once that I had come upon the city of some extinct civilization, hidden away in this inaccessible mesa for centuries.

title: Long Island Confidential
description: Heres a formula I just learned: math teacher (hapless, feckless) plus stepdad (bloviating jackass) plus interloping cabal of unsavory characters equals a pleasingly odd and intelligent novel in the hands of Matthew Sharpe. Or maybe I should say in the prose of Matthew Sharpe. Whats most winning about You Were Wrong, Sharpes fourth novel, is its acumen and the brio with which his sentence-making bears it out. This book is rich with devastatingly comic observations about people, places and things  observations that fortify a novel whose subject and, well, whose stake in the horror and pathos of being alive seem flimsy in comparison.

title: Revolutionary Road
description: A few blocks from my home in Westchester County lies Boston Post Road, a ribbon of retail dotted with Dunkin Donuts franchises, gas stations and drive-through banks. Indeed, for much of its span between New York and Boston, the Post Road is, in Eric Jaffes apt phrase, a gluttonous commercial wild. But in his valuable if uneven history, The Kings Best Highway, Jaffe burrows under the asphalt to reveal a thoroughfare of deeper distinction. Starting with its pastoral founding by American colonists, who exploited rocky, slippery paths that Indians had burned out of the wilderness, he tells how the road became the artery for an inchoate mail service, with loping riders carrying wax-sealed letters from tavern to tavern  the first post offices  and distributing newspapers that united the scattered colonists to revolt against the British. He traces the changes brought on by stagecoach, trolley, bicycle, reminding us that robust railroads led to the neglect of highways, until the automobile enabled the highways revenge.

title: Hangover in a Strange Land
description: Writing comedy about foreign travel has become more challenging in the days since Mark Twain mocked the Moors of Tangier, and even since P. J. ORourke wrote in his 1986 essay Among the Euro-Weenies that the French are a smallish, monkey-looking bunch and not dressed any better, on average, than the citizens of Baltimore. Jokes at the expense of many nations are dicey, and Europe has a small safety zone that includes the Austrians and the French. Credit goes to David Sedaris for wringing the last possible shred of humor out of the American-in-Paris tale 10 years ago, in Me Talk Pretty One Day. At that point, travel writers probably should have banded together in one of those self-regulating industry associations aimed at defusing public hostility and declared a moratorium on wisecracks about Old Europe.

title: New Yorks Huckleberry Friend
description: BACK in Hannibal, Mo., Jane Clemens had no idea that her 17-year-old son, Sam, her sixth child, had gone so far East to be a journeyman printer. She was surprised by a letter, his earliest known to survive, postmarked Aug. 24, 1853:

title: Her Darkest Places
description: Near the end of Shirley Jacksons most famous novel, The Haunting of Hill House, the heroine, a lonely young woman named Eleanor, thinks to herself, What I want in all this world is peace, a quiet spot to lie and think, a quiet spot up among the flowers where I can dream and tell myself sweet stories. And Eleanor does dream, but the stories, for her as for her creator, are rarely sweet. The very welcome Library of America edition of Jacksons work, edited by Joyce Carol Oates, contains, in addition to Hill House, 46 of her short stories, another novel  her last, We Have Always Lived in the Castle  and an essay on the furious reactions to the magazine publication of her peerlessly disturbing 1948 tale The Lottery. Although few of the narratives collected here are as terrifying as Hill House or as shocking as The Lottery (which is about an exceptionally nasty small-town ritual), theres precious little comfort in any of them. Theyre quiet, usually, told in calm, precise, scrupulously unsensational prose, but peace of the kind for which poor Eleanor yearns is always elusive. Theres none apparent in the wide world  Jackson wrote at the height of the cold war, when anxiety was general, even fashionable. The first story in the book, The Intoxicated, is about a 17-year-old girl who sobers up an inebriated partygoer with a coolly imagined vision of the end of civilization: Maybe therell be a law, she speculates, not to live in houses, so then no one can hide from anyone else, you see. And Jackson knew too well that theres not much peace in houses, either: no place, anywhere, to hide.

description: Movies

title: Nuclear Family
description: As he crossed the street time cracked open before him and he saw a way to the future, death into the world and all our woe, the shape of things to come. The date of this revelation was 1933; he is the physicist Leo Szilard; time cracked open because he had just realized how to initiate a nuclear chain reaction.

title: Bruce Springsteen Illuminates Darkness On the Edge of Town
description: More than three decades after Bruce Springsteen first advised us that theres a spot out neath Abrams Bridge and a darkness on the edge of town, you would think that maybe circumstances had changed. But no: the darkness remains on the edge of town, and yet somehow its gotten bigger. On Thursday Columbia Records said it was preparing two releases commemorating Mr. Springsteens 1978 album, Darkness on the Edge of Town, and containing rare materials from its recording sessions. On Nov. 16, the label will put out The Promise: The Darkness on the Edge of Town Story, a boxed set containing three CDs and three DVDs that include a remastered version of the album, 21 previously unreleased songs, a 1978 concert by Mr. Springsteen in Houston and a documentary film about the album. On Nov. 14 Columbia will also release a two-disc set called The Promise that contains the previously unheard songs from the album.

title: Inside the List
description: WISH YOU WERE DEAD: As Sweden goes, so goes the United States, at least when it comes to thrillers. The Postcard Killers, a collaboration between James Patterson and the Swedish crime writer Liza Marklund, hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 1, five months after it topped the charts in the Land of Larsson in Pattersons first experiment with an out-of-town tryout. The story takes off in Stockholm, where a Swedish journalist receives one in a series of postcards from picturesque European locales indicating where a pair of vicious killers will strike next. She then forms an odd-couple team with a stoic American detective (and father of one of the victims) and starts tearing around in search of the evildoers. Sound familiar? Patterson and Marklund have insisted they started planning their joint venture before Lisbeth Salander got her No. 1 global best seller tattoo.

title: Footnote
description: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has announced the appointment of two new co-directors for the Ailey School, its training academy. Tracy Inman and Melanie Person will take over its leadership, a role previously held by Denise Jefferson, the longtime director, who died last month. Mr. Inman and Ms. Person have served as co-directors of the schools junior division and associate directors of the Ailey School.

title: Heart of Iowa as Fault Line of Egg Recall
description: CLARION, Iowa  The scrambled eggs, as always, were hissing in a skillet on a recent morning at a coffee shop here, in an egg-producing county that has suddenly found itself at the center of the nations egg recall over salmonella. But the conversation at the weekly gathering of local ladies turned uncharacteristically tense.

title: Bridge Projects richard Iii, Starring Spacey, In Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn, no stranger to schemers, misfits and would-be Machiavellis, had better make room for one more. On Thursday the Bridge Project  the theater collaboration among the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Old Vic Theater in London and the British production company Neal Street  said it would bring a new staging of Shakespeares Richard III to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2012 for the projects final season. Not content to serve solely as the artistic director of the Old Vic, Kevin Spacey, above, will play the lead in the production, directed by Sam Mendes. Representatives for the Bridge Project said the play would run at the Harvey Theater, February through April, then embark on a short international tour before its transfer to the Old Vic from May through August, followed by a longer tour. Additional casting is still to be announced.

title: Talent Again Pushes NBC to Top
description: The first 5 of the Top 10 performers were selected to advance on Wednesdays edition of Americas Got Talent as 10.3 million viewers tuned in to the NBC reality show, according to Nielsens estimates, lifting the network to No. 1 in the nights ratings, compensating for NBCs more modest results with the game show Minute to Win It at 8 (6.3 million) and rerun of Law & Order: SVU at 10 (5.6 million). CBS placed second, drawing its best ratings at 8 with Big Brother, which earned its most viewers in almost a year (7.9 million). At 9 and 10, CBS broadcast repeats of Criminal Minds (6.6 million) and CSI: NY (6.2 million). Fox was third with a two-hour MasterChef from 8 to 10 (5.1 million) while ABC was fourth with reruns.

title: Dance New Amsterdams Reprieve
description: Eviction proceedings against Dance New Amsterdam, a dance space in Lower Manhattan, scheduled for Thursday have been postponed until Sept. 27, its executive director, Catherine Peila, said. Dance New Amsterdam subleases space in a city-owned building at 280 Broadway from Fram Realty, which holds a commercial lease on the building. The organization owes Fram more than $500,000 in back rent. Ms. Peila said Dance New Amsterdam was in talks with the landlord and hoping for reduced rent, maybe through allowances from the city or a nonprofit tax abatement. Asked if the city was playing a role in negotiations or if it would reduce Frams rent to help, Jennifer Blum, a spokeswoman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, which manages the citys real estate, said in a statement that the sublease between Fram and D.N.A. is a private transaction that the city was and is not a party to. Fram Realty did not return phone calls.

title: Hurds $30 Million Farewell From H.P.
description: After being kicked out of Hewlett-Packard, Mark V. Hurd is cashing out.

title: Lawrence Wrights Gaza, Onstage
description: Lawrence Wright, the Pulitzer Prize-winning New Yorker writer, has developed a second career as a playwright and performer. His last play, My Trip to Al-Qaeda, had a successful run at the Culture Project in 2007 and has been made into a documentary film that will have its premiere on HBO Sept. 7. Now he has a new play, The Human Scale, based on his reporting in Gaza, which he will perform Oct. 2 to 31. A co-production of the Public Theater and 3-Legged Dog, The Human Scale will be directed by the Publics artistic director, Oskar Eustis, and performed at 3-Legged Dogs home at 80 Greenwich Street in Lower Manhattan. The company avoided eviction by reaching a deal this week with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, its landlord, to pay overdue rent.

title: Will Forte to Leave SNL
description: It looks like MacGruber has accidentally detonated his last explosive device for now. Will Forte, the longtime Saturday Night Live cast member who portrayed that incompetent adventurer among other eccentric characters, will not be returning to SNL when that NBC late-night series begins its 36th season this fall. In an e-mail a representative for Mr. Forte, right, said he offered thanks to his colleagues and the Saturday Night Live producer Lorne Michaels, writing: After eight great seasons, Will has made the decision to move on from SNL to pursue new opportunities. He is eternally grateful to Lorne and all of the incredible people he worked with over the years. Mr. Forte joined Saturday Night Live in its 2002-3 season.

title: Chlo Exit

title: Ozawa To Limit His Work In Return Appearances
description: The conductor Seiji Ozawa, above, said on Thursday that he had successfully completed a treatment for esophageal cancer, but that his continuing recovery would require him to curtail his appearances at the Saito Kinen Festival Matsumoto in Japan next month. Mr. Ozawa, who in January announced that he had cancer and has canceled several months worth of dates while he recovers from surgery, said in a statement that his doctor has declared that I am completely cancer free at this time. But he added that the doctor had told him not to stand on a podium for long periods because of a sciatic problem that Mr. Ozawa wrote had gotten much worse, since I was not able to move my body while recovering from the operation. Mr. Ozawa said he would not conduct two orchestra programs at the festival, where he is to make his return appearance on Sept. 5, and would conduct only the first movement of Tchaikovskys String Serenade at the start of each concert. (The movement runs about 10 minutes.) Mr. Ozawa said he hoped to make a full recovery in time for his scheduled appearances at Carnegie Hall in December.

But a victory for Mr. Miller is considerably more likely than not, and even if he were to fall a few votes short, the election will have been far closer than anyone anticipated.

title: Ireland And Spain, Revisited
description: A couple of months back I asked, does fiscal austerity actually reassure markets? I noted there the curious case of Ireland, which embraced savage austerity early on; quite a few press reports declared that this had gained it the confidence of markets, but the actual numbers said otherwise. And I noted the contrast with Spain, which has been relatively slow and reluctant to embrace austerity, but has been treated no worse by investors.
