description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  By now, the story of Urban Meyers return to the Floridas sideline has become familiar. He stepped down, went to practice the next day and became inspired to come back after watching his team.

title: Super Cars Inspire Mixed Feelings in London
description: LONDON  With his canary yellow Ferrari at rest in the forecourt of one of the most expensive hotels in Londons upscale West End, its eight-cylinder, race-bred engine burbling, a young Arab man who gave his name as Khalefa spoke with whimsical regret about the array of even faster, more expensive super cars parked nearby that belonged to other young men like himself from the Persian Gulf oil states.

title: Al, All Of The Time
description: For tomorrows column.

title: Borrowing by Euro Zone Companies Falls 1.3%
description: FRANKFURT  Borrowing by companies in the euro zone fell at an annual rate of 1.3 percent in July, the European Central Bank said Thursday, in a reminder that economic activity has not returned to normal despite record growth in Germany.

title: House Tour: Garrison, N.Y.
Restoring the Studio of a Meticulous Sculptor
description: Daniel Chester French, the sculptor best known for the saddened seated president portrayed in the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, lived tidily in studios full of plaster dust and stone chips. He wore a jacket and tie while sculpturing at his homes in Greenwich Village and the Berkshires. He kept meticulous records of his trips abroad, modeling and casting processes and clients payments of tens of thousands of dollars for statues of politicians, soldiers and goddesses.

title: F.T.C. Drops LimeWire Investigation
description: LimeWire, the file-sharing service found liable for copyright infringement in May, has received a bit of good news.

title: Emerald Deities of Fervor and Flux
description: WASHINGTON  From whatever vantage point we look, if we are prepared to look historically, civilizations reveal themselves to be processes and not things. These true words by Sheldon Pollock, a scholar of Sanskrit and Indian history at Columbia University, also apply to art.

title: Safety in Numbers? Not for This Heroine
description: The ingredients of Kevin Guilfoiles fast and furious new thriller will be familiar to many readers:

title: The Thousand
Whos the Voyeur Now, Picasso?
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  Degas and Picasso make an odd couple, a Realist-Impressionist and a restless Modernist born nearly 50 years apart. But their relationship, as seen through the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institutes Picasso Looks at Degas, isnt the tempestuous kind typical of blockbuster shows. Neither a partnership (Picasso and Degas) nor a competition (Picasso/Degas), its about one artist regarding another, calmly and from a distance.

title: Miami Mayor Rethinks Marlins Parking Deal
description: Perhaps too little, too late, Mayor Tomas Regalado of Miami on Thursday asked the city attorney to look into whether the city could reopen its contract to build a parking garage for the Florida Marlins.

title: Fehr Wont Discuss Union Job
description: TORONTO  Donald Fehr has declined to confirm or deny reports that he has agreed to become the next executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association.

title: Korea's Human Convection Ovens
description: Roasting inside a charcoal kiln has become something of a craze in South Korea these days.

title: When Stoic Samurai Faced the Camera
description: Its obvious from the start that Samurai in New York isnt going to be about robed warriors taking the city, in spite of the sensational name. The shows subtitle  The First Japanese Delegation, 1860  makes that pretty clear, and the introductory wall text spells it out: The visit in question, 150 years ago, was all about trade, a matter of setting up a business agreement.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: The Pakistani Taliban called the presence of foreign relief workers in their flood-ravaged country unacceptable on Thursday and suggested that militants could carry out attacks against members of aid groups, Salman Masood reported. Any violence would add strain to relief efforts that have been slow to reach the millions of Pakistanis uprooted by the worst flooding in the countrys history. A spokesman for the United Nations dismissed the threats, saying that its aid work remained unaffected by security worries. But the United States State Department said it was concerned that militants may well attack foreign aid workers or Pakistani government officials trying to help flood victims.

title: Kiln Saunas Make a Comeback in South Korea
description: HOENGSEONG, SOUTH KOREA  In the relative cool of midnight, Seo Seok-gus workers break the seals on the kilns and, using long steel hooks, drag out what remains of the oak logs that were inserted a week before and have by now turned into smoldering charcoal. It gives off a hypnotic glow Mr. Seo calls my flower. The temperatures inside the clay domes reach up to 1,400 degrees Celsius.

title: Have Your Brunch and Listen to It, Too
description: WEEKEND brunch is a luxurious, late-morning salve, a counterpoint to no-nonsense weekday breakfasts devoured on subway platforms or half-chewed while reading e-mail. Hangovers are tended to with syrup-soaked pancakes and jam-slathered toast, as diners drift gently into a not-unpleasant carbohydrate haze. (It helps that brunch is also one of the rare instances in which its acceptable  encouraged, even  to slurp a cocktail at noon.)

title: Forgetting of Things Past: A Duet Off-Key
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass.  The Memory Show, which recently opened at Barrington Stage Company here, is a musical in search of a melody. That is what it intends to be. In shaping a portrait of a mother with Alzheimers disease and the angry, impotent daughter who cares for her, the young composer Zach Redler has written a score that follows the patterns of minds grasping, often in vain, for clarity, conviction and lost time.

title: Netflix Now Playing on an iPhone Near You
description: Netflix has been streaming movies for instant viewing of movies for some time on PCs and game machines. As of Thursday, Netflix is on the iPhone as well.

title: Israeli Actors Boycott Theater in Settlement
description: Updated | Friday | 8:52 a.m. Two Israeli actors have announced that they will not travel with the countrys national theater company to perform in a new cultural center nearing completion in the West Bank settlement of Ariel.

title: Barrichellos 300th Grand Prix
description: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS  The summer break has finally ended and Formula One has arrived in rainy Spa for the seven-race countdown to the end of the season. But it is the count of the number of races that Rubens Barrichello has participated in that is the talk of the paddock today.

title: Complaint Box | M.V.P., Most Vacuous Praise
description: The parents and players on my 7-year-old sons baseball team assembled near the pitchers mound on a recent Saturday. Under a blazing sun, the boys lined up to receive a handshake from the coach, a trophy and an entreaty to smile from their camera-toting parents.

title: Girls, Bedrooms and the Devil
description: A look at three films that get their chills from innocent girls possessed.

title: Charges Settled Over Fake Reviews on iTunes
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Discerning Internet users know that glowing online reviews of things like books or restaurants cannot always be trusted. But federal regulators are serving notice that if you stand to gain financially from the review you are writing, you should be upfront about it.

title: Streetscapes | Avery Architectural Library
description: A new online collection of real estate brochures at Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library of Columbia University casts light on how developers approached their markets.

title: Taking a Long, Cool Look at Both Sides of the Law
description: If there were such a thing as GQ Jr. or Esquire for Kids  a young-dude analogue for magazines like Seventeen or Teen Vogue  it might be something like Takers, a primer in juvenile, aspirational cool for guys who might not be able to handle the suavity of the Oceans 11 franchise or the leathery angst of The Expendables.

title: The Persuasive Pamphlets of Another Time
description: THIS apartment will sell itself! But few of them really do. Nearly as soon as the apartment was invented, so, too, was the sales brochure, ranging from the simplest of floor plans to color photos of the lap pool and the French concierge.

title: Till Death Does She Part
description: I divorced a few years ago, after a 23-year marriage, and recently remarried. But my sisters remain close with my ex-wife. They spent time with her during the weekend of my wedding and invited her to my nephews bar mitzvah. Ive expressed displeasure in having to see my ex-wife at family celebrations when I no longer wish to, and I told them that their relationship with her is preventing them from becoming closer with my new wife. They appear indifferent. What should I do?

title: All Kiss-and-Tell and Wink-and-Nod at a Crowded Dinner Party
description: Quite a lot happens in Change of Plans, Danile Thompsons crowded comedy about a Paris dinner party and its aftermath. There are (in no particular order) near- and actual divorces, last-minute reconciliations, a terrible accident and a miraculous cure, a secret marriage and a surprise pregnancy. Mostly, there is marital infidelity, which seems to come as naturally to the middle-aged, middle-class French couples who populate the film as shopping for goat cheese or going for a medical checkup.

title: In the Latest Religious Battle, a Call to Arms for Mother Teresa
description: On the 26th of August 90 years ago, American women won the right to vote with the adoption of the 19th Amendment to the Constitution. That step toward a more perfect union was honored in New York style on Thursday night when the Empire State Building bathed its upper floors in lights of red, white and blue.

title: Terror Suspects Canadian Idol Audition Tape Returns to Haunt Him
description: The Toronto Star reported on Thursday that a suspected member of an Ontario terror cell who was arrested on Thursday appeared on national television in 2008, as a failed contestant for the reality game show Canadian Idol.

title: With the Help of a Gangly Giant, Tottenham Is on the Move Again
description: LONDON

title: Mourinho's Arrival Adds Fizz to Spain's 2-Horse Race
description: MADRID  Upon joining Real Madrid last week, Mesut Ozil, the German midfielder of Turkish descent, was asked in his welcome news conference whether he was observing the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

title: Young Love, Back When It Was Sweet and Innocent
description: Suburban America in the late 1950s and early 60s as depicted in Flipped, Rob Reiners sentimental ode to puppy love in that innocent era, might as well be another world, for all its resemblance to the one we live in today. Mind you, it isnt paradise. But as the movies soundtrack of golden oldies unwinds in the background, you cant help being struck by the romantic optimism and modesty of early rock n roll ditties cranked out in the years before the term high-tech entered the vocabulary.

title: A Newspaper Apologizes to United Nations Climate Chief
description: Last December, Britains Sunday Telegraph newspaper published a 2,000-word article accusing Rajendra Pachauri, the chairman of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, of potential financial conflicts of interest.

title: Knicks Wrap Up Youthful Roster but May Be Without Azubuike
description: Landry Fields signed his rookie contract Thursday, completing a Knicks roster that is younger, deeper and more talented than any recent edition. It comes, however, with one minor asterisk.

title: Two Vastly Different Enemies Share a Common Thirst for Blood
description: From the heaving mass of carnage in Neil Marshalls galumphing, atavistic gorefest, Centurion, a cautionary message struggles to escape. Beware of overreaching, ye imperialists. The indigenous people of whatever region you presume to conquer know the territory a thousand times better than you do and will eventually prevail.

title: Panel Presses BP on Its Safety Record
description: HOUSTON  Federal investigators pressed senior BP officials on Thursday about whether the company had a troubled record of safety problems even before the Deepwater Horizon oil rig disaster.

title: Critic Gets to See How the Other Half Squirms
description: For years, the sports columnist Jay Mariotti has cultivated a self-righteous and divisive personality that turned him into a local star at the Chicago Sun-Times and then a national voice at AOL FanHouse and ESPN.

title: The Way We Think, in a Heated Time
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Portrait Artist in the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Trapped Miners in Chile
description: To the Editor:

title: Loosening the Devils Grip in Louisiana
description: The Devil is in the entrails in The Last Exorcism, an unusually restrained and genuinely eerie little movie perched at the intersection of faith, folklore and female puberty.

title: Months After Marathon Match, Mahut Still Has Far to Go
description: His back aches, his legs are sore and he requires far more sleep than his schedule permits. But two months after he lost the longest tennis match in history, Nicolas Mahut is being asked to play extra tennis this week.

title: Some of His Dreams Have Come True, but Taylor Keeps Dreaming
description: PARAMUS, N.J.  The beginning of the FedEx Cup playoffs means different things to different players. Some of the major players have their eye on the $10 million jackpot at the end of the final playoff event, while others are closing their eyes and dreaming.

title: Germany: Singer Is Convicted for Transmitting H.I.V.
description: A German court on Thursday convicted a musician of causing bodily harm to an ex-boyfriend for having unprotected sex with him though she knew she was infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The singer, Nadja Benaissa, 28, who performed with the band No Angels, avoided prison, receiving a two-year suspended sentence because she expressed deep remorse throughout the trial in Darmstadt, in the western portion of the country, German news agencies reported. Her former boyfriend said she infected him during a brief relationship they had in 2004. A German court ruling in 1988 made it a crime for a person aware of having H.I.V. to not inform a sexual partner of his or her condition. Offenders face up to 10 years in prison, and courts here have handed out lengthy terms.

title: Acrimony Behind the Scenes of Gulf Oil Spill
description: This article is by  Clifford Krauss, Henry Fountain and John M. Broder.

title: This Is Not a Recovery
description: What will Ben Bernanke, the Fed chairman, say in his big speech Friday in Jackson Hole, Wyo.? Will he hint at new steps to boost the economy? Stay tuned.

title: Agent Wanted Backup Charge in Synagogue Bomb Case, Defense Says
description: Worried that an investigation was going cold, a special agent in charge of a case in which four people were later accused of plotting to blow up synagogues in the Bronx appeared to suggest that the F.B.I. needed a backup plan: gun charges against the suspected leader, according to e-mail read on Thursday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Maligned FEMA Chief Visits New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  Put yourself in my shoes, said Michael Brown. Youve just come out of a meeting where youve just told your boss that nothings working, I cant make stuff happen, state and local government arent doing what they need to do, the federal government isnt doing what it needs to do, things are bad. And he comes out and tells me Im doing a heck of a job?

title: Rain Turns First Round Into Day of Target Practice
description: PARAMUS, N.J. When Tiger Woods teed off Thursday in the first round of the Barclays at 7:10 a.m., it was long before the grandstands filled with spectators and television coverage began. But more significantly, it was long before the sun rose high in the sky and started to dry out the rain-soaked Ridgewood Country Club course.

title: Gay Bush Aide? No Bombshell in Age of Fiscal Cares
description: Had a former chairman of the Republican National Committee announced in 2004 that he was gay, it would have been a bombshell. In that hard-fought election year, Republicans and Democrats were rushing to condemn a court for establishing the right to same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.

title: For Once, Hope in the Middle East
description: Washington

title: A Family Brand With Big Dreams for Its Soy Milk
description: THE cola wars were so 20th century. Now, Madison Avenue is leading the charge in a series of battles involving food products that are meant to be perceived as healthier fare.

title: Nine Justices and Ten Commandments
description: While the politically manipulated controversy over the proposed Islamic center in Lower Manhattan will eventually end, there is one dispute over religious symbolism and identity that remains, apparently, endless. Im referring to the continuing effort by state and local governments to post the Ten Commandments in public places.

title: Facing Long Mine Rescue, Chile Spares No Expense
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  The government has consulted NASA about the extreme isolation of space. Chilean Navy officers have come to discuss the emotional stress of living in a submarine. Doctors stand at the ready with antidepressants. Even a tiny home theater is being funneled down in plastic tubes to occupy the 33 miners stuck in their subterranean home.

title: Legacy of Torture
description: The Bush administration insisted that enhanced interrogation techniques  torture  were necessary to extract information from prisoners and keep Americans safe from terrorist attacks. Never mind that it was immoral, did huge damage to this countrys global standing and produced little important intelligence. Now, as we had feared, it is also making it much harder to try and convict accused terrorists.

title: The Egg Scare and Beyond
description: The recent problems with salmonella-contaminated eggs is a reminder of how much more needs to be done to keep dangerous germs out of the American food supply. The Food and Drug Administration should urge egg producers to vaccinate their hens promptly. The Senate must pass long-stalled legislation that could strengthen the hand of regulators to prevent and control outbreaks of all food-related illnesses.

title: Islamic Center Also Challenges a Young Builder
description: Sharif el-Gamal is a relative newcomer to the New York City real estate business. He got his brokers license in 2002. He is developing two condominium projects: turning a building in TriBeCa into six lofts, and planning apartments on what is now a West Side parking lot. He comes from the well-off family of a bank executive, but not from real estate billions.

title: A Big Surprise: Troubled Assets Garner Rewards
description: American taxpayers are already poised to make unexpected billions from rescuing the nations banks. Now, they could reap another sizable profit from a government program devised to purge troubled real estate assets from the financial system.

title: Lottery Numbers
Truth and the Troubles
description: Northern Ireland is finally hearing long denied and much needed truths. In June, a reinvestigation finally set the record straight on the 1972 Bloody Sunday massacre, in which British troops opened fire on a Catholic civil rights march in Londonderry, killing 14 unarmed people and wounding 13. Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain won deserved plaudits for his forthright apology.

title: A Looking Glass Steer
description: Being a farm kid used to be simpler. That was our thought upon learning that this years grand champion steer at the Iowa State Fairs 4-H Market Beef competition is a clone of the 2008 grand champion steer. This years winner  who weighs 1,320 pounds and is named Doc  was conceived from an ear punch taken from his esteemed predecessor. The result was a cloned bull that was then neutered to produce Doc the steer.

title: Yankees New Boss Determined to Carry On
description: Hank Steinbrenner brought to mind the image of the Boss as he barked at his players to get onto the stage for a news conference. Lets go! he said.

title: Fleeing Mideast Dictators Unscheduled Stop
description: The premise had promise, but Baghdad, Texas, a clumsy comedy directed by David H. Hickey, quickly disappoints with an inconsistent tone and painful overacting.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 26
description: Tiger Woods played like the Tiger of old, there was fierce competition on the badminton courts of Paris and Manny Ramirez forgot to was his batting helmet, all during an action-packed day of sports.

title: Struggling Cities Shut Firehouses in Budget Crisis
description: SAN DIEGO  Fire departments around the nation are cutting jobs, closing firehouses and increasingly resorting to rolling brownouts in which they shut different fire companies on different days as the economic downturn forces many cities and towns to make deep cuts that are slowing their responses to fires and other emergencies.

title: I.R.S. to Drop Suit Against UBS Over Tax Havens
description: The Internal Revenue Service said Thursday that it would drop a closely watched civil lawsuit against the Swiss bank giant UBS after the Swiss government said it was on course to hand over details on thousands of American clients suspected of using their accounts to evade taxes.

title: Developer of Tablets Loses Apple as Customer
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple severed ties with a small Silicon Valley design firm that for nearly a decade had helped with the development of some of its products, after the firm showcased its own prototype tablet computer.

title: With Tejada Struggling, Castillo Finds Mets Still Have a Role for Him
description: Mets Manager Jerry Manuel abides by a philosophy that dictates that the lineup be determined by what gives his team the best chance to win on a given day. That decision is magnified when it comes to his second baseman.

title: Stryker Settles Case That Claimed Deception
description: The Stryker Corporation, a maker of artificial hips and knees, will pay $1.35 million to settle claims that it marketed items without regulatory approval and misled health care providers about the use of its products, the Massachusetts attorney general said Thursday.

title: A Trauma in Peru
description: As tense as a clenched fist and just as communicative, Fausta (Magaly Solier), the heroine of The Milk of Sorrow, scuttles around her mountainside neighborhood in Lima, peering from beneath bangs like guillotine blades. Her mother has just died, leaving Fausta with a deathbed song of rape and violence suffered during the terrors, Perus decades of civil strife. As a defense against similar violations  and, indeed, any sexual connection  Fausta has blocked her vagina with a potato, oblivious to the physical consequences.

title: Pursuing an Asian Health Network
description: SINGAPORE  No matter how healthy or rich Asian economies are, one thing is certain: Asians will never stop getting sick.

title: The Parent Model
description: During the first half of this year, German and American political leaders engaged in an epic debate. American leaders argued that the economic crisis was so bad, governments should borrow billions to stimulate growth. German leaders argued that a little short-term stimulus was sensible, but anything more was near-sighted. What was needed was not more debt, but measures to balance budgets and restore confidence.

title: Hot Spots: Homages
description: Are the political ad writers channeling Quentin Tarantino these days? Over the past week, weve noticed an unusual number of spots that fall under the category of homage.

title: Immigration Agency Ends Some Deportations
description: Immigration enforcement officials have started to cancel the deportations of thousands of immigrants they have detained, a policy they said would pare huge case backlogs in the immigration courts.

title: Estimate Lowered of Typical Flu Toll
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday substantially lowered its often-quoted estimate of how many people die in a typical flu season, to 24,000 from 36,000.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,230 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

description: San Jose, Calif.

title: A Risk for Cancer Patients

description: To the Editor:

title: Paterson Misled Inquiry Over Tickets, Report Says
description: Gov. David A. Paterson misled state investigators about his acceptance of free tickets to the World Series last year, according to the independent counsel, Judith S. Kaye, who has asked the Albany County district attorney to determine whether Mr. Paterson should be charged with perjury.

title: Pakistan Flood Sets Back Infrastructure by Years
description: SUKKUR, Pakistan  Men waded waist deep all week wedging stones with their bare hands into an embankment to hold back Pakistans surging floodwaters. It was a rudimentary and ultimately vain effort to save their town. On Thursday, the waters breached the levee, a demoralizing show of how fragile Pakistans infrastructure remains, and how overwhelming the task is to save it.

title: A Teenage Zombie Crush
description: A zombie movie like no other, Make-Out With Violence uses an undead crush to explore one of our most wrenching transitions: that long, hot summer between high school and adulthood.

title: Keeping Score: The Number Beyond M.V.P. Numbers
description: At the end of August, the narratives around baseballs top awards have formed, and the contenders are jockeying for position for the stretch run. The 60 writers who vote for these awards have their reasons for how they vote, but as a body they often favor runs batted in leaders on playoff teams for the Most Valuable Player awards.

title: Pakistans Progress Is Lost in Floodwaters
description: Pakistani and international relief officials despaired that the nations worst natural calamity had ruined just about every physical strand that knit the country together.

title: Siblings in Mexico City, Criminally Exploited
description: Based on a true story and unfolding, we are told in the films opening moments, exactly as it happened, Daniel & Ana takes a dispassionate look at the aftermath of a particularly heinous crime.

title: Things Pieced Together
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE NOTES  This is a pretty remarkable achievement, stacking a pair of full-width, two-line phrases in a grid. These are the sort of harebrained ideas that constructors try from time to time, usually destined for the file of near misses, but Corey Rubin made this one work.

title: Cleveland Museum Names Director
description: The Cleveland Museum of Art has named David Franklin, currently the deputy director of the National Gallery of Canada, as its new director. Mr. Franklin will assume the post on Sept. 20, taking over from Deborah Gribbon, who has served as interim director for the last year. The museums previous director, Timothy Rub, left to run the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Mr. Franklin has been at the National Gallery of Canada since 1998. In 2008 he was involved in a controversy there over deleted e-mails, which resulted in his dismissal. He was later rehired. In Cleveland Mr. Franklin will inherit a $350 million expansion project designed by Rafael Violy, scheduled for completion in 2013.

title: Man in Cab Stabbing Showed Zeal for Veterans
description: He could not have struck a more thoughtful tone. My name is Michael Enright, he began in an e-mail sent in August 2009 to a young military veteran who had written a memoir about being a medic in Iraq.

title: Franz Schurmann, Cold War Expert on China, Dies at 84
description: Franz Schurmann, an expert on China during the cold war and a globe-trotting professor who helped found the Pacific News Service, a provider of news and commentary about Asia, died on Aug. 20 at his home in San Francisco. He was 84. The cause was complications of Parkinsons and Alzheimers diseases, his wife, Sandy Close, said.

title: American Flight Uses a Firms Satellite-Based Landing System
description: Portable global positioning system devices that let travelers know precisely where they are and, more important, direct them to where they want to go, have been around for years. But airline pilots in the United States often must still rely on antiquated ground-based radio and radar equipment to land at airports.

title: C. Joseph Genster, Marketer of Metrecal, Dies at 92
description: C. Joseph Genster, who masterminded the marketing of Metrecal, the meal in a can for dieters that swept America like the Hula-Hoop at the beginning of the 1960s, died Aug. 17 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 92.

title: A Newspaper Apologizes to Leader of Climate Panel
description: Aug. 27, 8:19 a.m. | Updated  From my friends over at the Green Blog:

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Bloggingheads: A Dangerous Debate?
description: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com debate the effects of the public discussion about Park51.

title: Michel Montignac, Creator of Trend-Setting Diet, Dies at 66
description: Michel Montignac, the self-trained French diet promoter who wrote best-selling books and built a business based on the idea that losing weight depends on what you eat, not how much, died Sunday at a clinic in Annemasse, France. He was 66 and lived in Juvigny, France.

title: I.C.B.C. and BOC Set for Slower Growth
description: The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and Bank of China, two of the top Chinese lenders, signaled a peaking of earnings growth after strong second-quarter profits, as they slow their lending and focus on asset quality.

title: All Hail, His Samminess, Back in the Glare
description: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Doctor Doesnt Work Hard to Hide Symptoms of Medicare Fraud
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: A Thriving Industry Built on Low-Compensated Temp Workers
description: Tory Moore worked at the same packaged-food warehouse in Kankakee for six years, but he was denied a loan and apartment rentals after being told he did not have a real job.

title: On Harvard Misconduct, Climate Research and Trust
description: April 25, 1:44 p.m. | Updated | The journal Science has published new work that largely replicates the conclusions of the controversial 2007 paper on primate intelligence by Marc Hauser that was at the heart of the dispute discussed below.]

title: Blagojevich Retrial Poses Questions for Judge
description: During the eight weeks Judge James B. Zagel of Federal District Court presided over the trial of former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, he often expressed his frustration with defense attorneys behavior and the pace of the proceedings.

title: Perjury Inquiry May Outlast the Governors Term
description: Little more than four months before Gov. David A. Paterson is to leave office, his legacy now rests largely in the hands of P. David Soares, the Albany County district attorney. And it could take all of his remaining days as governor, if not more, to determine his fate.

title: Assessing the Damage as Flooding in Pakistan Moves South
description: Map shows flooding in Pakistan since the initial flash floods that killed hundreds of people in the Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa region.

title: Looking Askance at Acquisitions
Anatomy of a Scene: Centurion
description: Neil Marshall, the director of Centurion, discusses a scene from his film.

title: Reyes Has Another Flare-Up, and Mets Continue Limping Toward Finish
description: The happy-go-lucky reputation of Jose Reyes accurately reflects his disposition. But the ugly reality for the Mets is that his fragile nature, and his seeming impatience when recovering from injuries, is becoming just as notable.

title: University to Manage Home Costs of President
description: The University of California has appointed an official to manage spending and operations at President Mark G. Yudofs new private residence, after Mr. Yudof ran up nearly $700,000 in expenses and involved senior university officials in time-consuming personal matters over a rented mansion in the Oakland Hills.

title: Word of the Day | circumscribe
description: circumscribe \sr-km-skrib\ verb

title: Forever Stoked for More Tasty Waves
description: At the beginning of Highwater, Dana Brown, its writer, director and narrator, expresses some ambivalence about the highly commoditized circus that surfing has become. Mr. Brown knows which side his board is waxed on, however  his family has been deeply involved in the mythmaking that sells surfing gear ever since his father, Bruce, made The Endless Summer in 1966  and Highwater settles into celebratory mode. Even a surfers death becomes an occasion for spiritual uplift.

title: David Weber, Southwest Expert, Dies at 69
description: David J. Weber, whose groundbreaking works on the American Southwest under Spain and Mexico opened new territory for historians, died on Aug. 20 in Gallup, N.M. He was 69 and lived in Dallas and Ramah, N.M.

title: In Scandals Wake, Police Turn to Quick, Cheap Test for Drugs
description: When Sgt. Chris Schaffer confiscates a brick of what he suspects is cocaine, he no longer sends the material to the San Francisco Police Department crime lab.

title: A Green Idea That Sounded Good Until the Trees Went to Work
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Burning Man Radio Steps Out of the Box
description: The Burning Man festival is not an easy place in which to be separated from your friends, particularly if you dont speak English and are not used to the hot, dusty Nevada desert where the art and music gathering takes place each summer.

title: Judge Resigns Amid Reports of Discovery on Computer
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge resigned last week after court officials discovered what may have been pornography on his work computer, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Way Is Cleared for Developer to Build Trade Center Towers

title: Frank Gehrys Fish Lamps
description: Frank Gehry designed the first of his famous fish lamps in 1983, when he was asked by the Formica Corporation for ways to use the companys new laminate product, ColorCore, which was colored all the way through, rather than just on the surface. When Gehry was playing around with the material, he broke a piece, which looked to him like a fish scale  and the rest is design history, with the fish swimming into the collections of art world notables like Jasper Johns. On Sunday, Fish Forms: Lamps by Frank Gehry opens at the Jewish Museum. Organized by Ruth Beesch, the museums deputy director for program, the exhibition, which includes just eight lamps, was inspired by the glass fish lamp in the museums own collection. The lamps themselves are engaging objects, the gentle glow of the light within them contrasting with their substantial, expressionist bases. But they were never designed just for the sake of making something. The fish form was something that had fascinated Gehry for its purity and its dynamism and was well on its way to becoming a major theme in his architecture, a point that is made quite well in a video that accompanies the exhibition, which runs through Oct. 31.

Producers of Foxs American Idol said in a statement reported by The Associated Press that they do not use pitch-correcting technology to tweak the singing voices of their shows contestants. The statement appeared to be a pre-emptive measure at a time when The X Factor is being assailed for misrepresenting the abilities of its contenders. Producers of The X Factor, which Mr. Cowell created and plans to bring to American television next year, have acknowledged that they used the pitch-correcting program Auto-Tune to correct the voices of some singers on the show, though they said it was to compensate for the different microphones used during their performances. description: A new theatrical adaptation of Ovids Metamorphoses, set in World War II Britain and mixing live music, video and puppetry with stage performance, received the Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh Award on Friday at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. The award covers all expenses for a three-week production at Off Off Broadways Flea Theater. This new Metamorphoses, a retelling of the Roman poets mythological tales from the London-based theater company Pants on Fire, will run at the Flea in TriBeCa in January. The production was adapted and directed by Peter Bramley, artistic director of Pants on Fire, with original music by Lucy Egger. Ms. Tambor, a portrait artist and long-time Edinburgh Fringe theatergoer, created the award in 2004 to bring a top work from the summertime Scottish festival to New York each year. Last years winner was the Dublin-based Guna Nua theater companys production of Elaine Murphys Little Gem.

title: Event About Lost Adams Work Is Canceled
description: A film about the discovery of the disputed lost negatives of the photographer Ansel Adams will not be shown at California State University, Fresno, as planned, the university has announced. The October screening had been arranged by Arnold Peter, an alumnus who is a lawyer for Rick Norsigian, the man who bought the negatives, one of which is above, at a garage sale 10 years ago. Mr. Peter, who is the executive producer of the film, told the university last week that he no longer wanted to show it there. He said in a statement to The Bay Citizen on Friday that the screening no longer made sense because Adamss grandson and the managing director of the Ansel Adams Publishing Rights Trust, who dispute that the 65 negatives are the work of Adams, had not agreed to take part in a discussion at the screening. The trust has filed a lawsuit to block the marketing of the negatives as Adamss works. Experts working with Mr. Norsigian say they feel sure that Adams created the negatives. But the finding has been challenged by several parties, including the Center for Creative Photography, which Adams co-founded and which had been neutral in the debate. We have no reason to believe that these negatives are, in fact, the work of Ansel Adams, and we support the efforts of the Ansel Adams Publishing Rights Trust to protect its rights in this matter, the center said in a statement on Friday.

title: Trevor Nunn To Don a New Cap at Oxford
description: Having taken the summer to recover from the blistering competition for its professor of poetry chair, has Oxford University just opened the door to another heated rivalry? On Friday the university said it had named Trevor Nunn, the venerated former director of Britains National Theater and of productions from Cats to the current Broadway revival of A Little Night Music, as a visiting professor based at St. Catherines College at Oxford. The official title that Mr. Nunn will hold, however, is the Cameron Mackintosh Visiting Professor of Contemporary Theater, a post endowed by a fund named for that producer of theatrical hits like Phantom of the Opera and Les Misrables, among others. Students of theater (and of good ol slapfests) may recall that Mr. Nunn said earlier this summer that he felt betrayed by Mr. Mackintosh, who hired new directors for a 25th-anniversary Les Misrables revival being staged at the Barbican this fall; Mr. Mackintosh responded that he was saddened by Nunns inaccurate and ungracious remarks. But in his acceptance of the Oxford position Mr. Nunn was gracious, writing in a statement: Having been invited to fulfill this role on two previous occasions, I am so pleased that this time the dates have worked out. His yearlong appointment is to begin in October.

title: Keeping You Entertained (and on Your Toes)

She and her Auntie Martha were on their way to a new life in an Edinburgh flat. A short time later, the bus riders would discover that this immigrant was not going to shop on the Royal Mile, visit Edinburgh Castle, see the Palace of Holyroodhouse or do anything else on her list. Instead, she was to be quickly assimilated into a world of sex slavery.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: LUDLOW RESIDENCE, a sleek Lower East Side dormitory of the School of Visual Arts, has opened about one-third of its 20 stories to 120 students, mostly freshmen, from Baruch College. Kevin Ng, 20, a senior who spent his first three years at Baruch commuting from his parents home on Staten Island, was hired as a resident assistant in the building, Baruchs first dorm, where students pay $1,100 a month for a diminutive single with a shared bathroom. I still cant believe Im here, he said Wednesday as he pointed out some of the perks at Ludlow: free laundry machines that send a text message when a load is done, a communal kitchen with stainless-steel appliances, views of the Williamsburg Bridge and the Empire State Building from some floors, and a landscaped terrace. Baruchs vice president for student affairs, Ben Corpus, said that the college began searching for dorm space four years ago, and that in a survey, most students indicated they wanted to live in a dorm. They still have some version of the Animal House image in their minds when they think of the college experience, Dr. Corpus said. Were happy to provide some of that spirit. But no alcohol is allowed at Ludlow, so students mingled Monday at a mocktail mixer  juices, soda and the like. Not quite Animal House, though there was a foosball table.

title: Kenya: Sudans Leader Visits
description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan arrived in Kenya on Friday to participate in a ceremony inaugurating the countrys newly minted Constitution, flouting international demands for his arrest on genocide charges. Mr. Bashir faces two arrest warrants: one issued in July by the International Criminal Court in The Hague on three counts of genocide and one from March 2009 for war crimes and crimes against humanity. In theory the warrants could be enforced by any of the courts member countries, which includes Kenya. The role of the international court is particularly delicate in Kenya because in March its judges authorized formal criminal investigations of the political leaders who organized the violence that convulsed the country after its disputed 2007 election.

Ms. Hadid, above, who in 2004 became the first woman to win the Pritzker Prize for Architecture, was born and reared in Baghdad. The bank building was attacked on June 13 by suicide bombers and gunmen in military uniforms, just as staff members were leaving work. The bombers blew themselves up while gunmen clashed for hours with bank security officers. The Islamic State of Iraq, a group affiliated with Al Qaeda in Iraq, claimed responsibility.

title: Britain: Premier Avoids an Attack

The accounts, quoting military officials, said the helicopter carrying Mr. Cameron and Air Chief Marshal Sir Jock Stirrup, Britains top military officer, had been airborne for five minutes heading from a joint British and American military base in the Helmand desert to a remote front-line base for British troops in the town of Shahzad on June 10 when Taliban radio messages about the planned attack were intercepted by a coalition eavesdropping unit. The helicopter was diverted to another British base. Officials at 10 Downing Street said they had no comment on the report.

Two Frank Lloyd Wright-designed texitle-block houses  in Southern California have been languishing on the market  one for two years, the other a year  though the owners have slashed millions of dollars off the prices, Jori Finkel reports in The Los Angeles Times. What makes the houses especially rare is that Wright built only four such homes, using rows of patterned concrete blocks both as decoration and supporting walls. Both have maintenance issues, and, as the paper noted, they dont have high-end comforts for high-end buyers such as spa-style bathrooms or chefs kitchens. Still, the lack of interest puzzles preservationists. One owner is considering a deal to move one of the houses to Japan. Wright designed the houses with modularity in mind: they can be taken apart and reassembled, block by block.

title: Prime Number
description: 190: The amount, in dollars, that a family earning $75,000 a year would need to save each month over 18 years to cover expenses at a public college ($51,000 over four years), according to Fidelity Investments. To compute the out-of-pocket cost, Fidelity calculated how much in scholarships, grants and gifts the family could expect to receive, and assumed the savings would be invested in a 529 plan that delivered a return in line with what the companys age-based investment option would provide. description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Give the constructor Richard Chisholm a hand for todays Monday puzzle. In fact, give him two. That would be more appropriate. Mr. Chisholm turned 86 this year. The photo on XWord Info shows him at an outdoor cafe in Barcelona, Spain. Solving may or may not keep the brain agile, but perhaps constructing does.

title: Handsome Guy Is Dying, but He Can Afford Care
description: One of the odder movies to come down the Bollywood pike recently, Nagesh Kukunoors genre-defying Aashayein (Wishes) looks at dying in a comic-cosmic way that embraces both magical thinking and fatalism.

description: When the pianist Steven Beck played Stravinsky, Schoenberg and Debussy at Bargemusic on Friday evening, the intellectual rigor of the early-20th-century works on the program was a palate cleanser after the heady emotions in the flurry of Schumann and Chopin bicentennial events this season.

description: With their contract due to expire at midnight on Sunday, the players of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra on Saturday rejected the administrations proposals for a renewal and authorized their negotiating committee and union to call a strike if necessary.

title: China Fortifies State Businesses to Fuel Growth
description: BEIJING  During its decades of rapid growth, China thrived by allowing once-suppressed private entrepreneurs to prosper, often at the expense of the old, inefficient state sector of the economy.

Koch Theater; and $25 for the fourth ring. Single tickets are on sale at nycballet.com or through CenterCharge, (212) 721-6500.

title: Theatrical Spills and Award Thrills
description: Brooke Shields, below, broke her right hand during rehearsals for Leap of Faith, a new musical at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles, but her representative told People.com that the injury was not expected to delay the show, which begins previews on Sept. 11. The production, which also stars Ral Esparza, has music by Alan Menken and lyrics by Glenn Slater, and is based on the 1992 Steve Martin film of the same title about a bogus faith healer in rural Kansas. Producers have said they hope to bring it to Broadway. ... The first Horton Foote Prize for playwrights has been awarded for two plays: Lynn Nottages Ruined won for outstanding new American play, and Will Enos Middletown took the award for promising new American play. Each winner will receive $15,000 and a photograph of Foote, the playwright and screenwriter (To Kill a Mockingbird) who died last year at 92.

title: A Beatles Toilet Gets Top Dollar
description: A toilet that once belonged to John Lennon was sold for 9,500 (about $14,700) at an auction in Liverpool on Saturday, Reuters reported. Lennon had the blue-and-white porcelain commode removed from his home in Tittenhurst Park in Berkshire, in southern England, where he lived from 1969 to 1971; he gave it to a builder, John Hancock, telling him to put flowers in it or something, according to the auction catalog. Mr. Hancock stored the toilet in his shed for 40 years, and on Saturday it was sold to an unidentified buyer as part of a sale of Beatles-related memorabilia that included a rare mono copy of Lennon and Yoko Onos album Two Virgins and a harmonica that belonged to Lennons son Julian.  Those items went for 2,500 (about $3,900) each.

title: Last Exorcism Tops Slow Weekend at the Movies
description: Movie theaters were quiet over the weekend, with ticket sales for the Top 12 films down 11 percent compared with the same period last year. A PG-13 rating and a wide release helped push the horror movie The Last Exorcism (Lionsgate) to No. 1 with about $21.3 million in grosses, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles sales data. (Right, Ashley Bell, on bed and Caleb Landry Jones.) Takers, a moderately budgeted crime thriller from Sony Pictures Entertainment, was a close second with $21 million. Sylvester Stallones Expendables (Lionsgate), the No. 1 film for the last two weeks, fell to No. 3 with $9.5 million, bringing its total to $82 million. Eat Pray Love (Sony) was fourth with $7 million for a new total of $60.7 million, while The Other Guys (Sony), starring Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg, was fifth with $6.6 million, for a total of $99.3 million. A rerelease of Avatar (20th Century Fox) with eight minutes of new footage squeezed $4 million more out of that blockbuster to bring its domestic box office total to $753.8 million.

title: Rookie Nova Delivers Outing Yankees Have Been Missing
description: CHICAGO  A few hours later, Ivan Nova would be making his second career start for a team locked in a tense division battle. So before going to sleep Saturday night, he placed a call to his mother, Altegracia, who was back in New York. You have nothing to worry about, she told him.

title: Paris Hilton Arrested on Drug Charge
description: Paris Hilton, below, was arrested in Las Vegas late Friday night on suspicion of felony cocaine possession after a small container of the drug fell out of her purse in full view of a police officer, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Hilton, 29, was in a black Cadillac Escalade being driven down the Strip by her boyfriend, Cy Waits, when a police officer smelled marijuana smoke wafting from the car and pulled it over. When Ms. Hilton stepped out of the car and reached for some lip balm, Sgt. John Sheahan of the Las Vegas Police Department said, a bindle of cocaine in a plastic bag came out of her purse. She was booked and released on her own recognizance, and by 2:56 a.m. on Saturday wrote on Twitter that she was in bed enjoying the television show Family Guy. Ms. Hilton was arrested this year in South Africa on suspicion of marijuana possession while attending the World Cup, but the charges were dropped.

title: Court Wins for Dicaprio
description: Leonardo DiCaprio won victories in court last week against two women he had accused of abusive behavior. On Wednesday Judge Carol Boas Goodson of Los Angeles County Superior Court granted a temporary restraining order against Livia Bistriceanu, 41, whom Mr. DiCaprio said had claimed to be his wife and carrying his baby, The Associated Press reported. According to Mr. DiCaprios complaint, Ms. Bistriceanu tried to meet him at his home and office, acted aggressively and refused to leave. Given this obsessive and harassing behavior, Mr. DiCaprio, 35, said in court papers, I am frightened of Ms. Bistriceanu and feel that my personal safety, and the personal safety of those around me, is in jeopardy. On Thursday another woman, Aretha Wilson, 40, was ordered to stand trial on a charge of slashing Mr. DiCaprios face with a broken bottle at a Hollywood party in 2005.

This much is clear: It began life as a $3.95 paperback and stayed on the New York Times best-seller list for more than a year. Copies were plentiful, yet asking prices for used ones today can easily top $100 and sometimes exceed $1,000. Somebody must think it contains useful information.

Prominent figures on the right accused Bill and Hillary Clinton of everything from drug smuggling to murder. description: The full story of the massacre in Tamaulipas, in northeast Mexico, awaits telling by its one survivor. The early news accounts are horrifying: 72 people, said to be migrants from Central and South America on their way to the United States, are waylaid and imprisoned by drug smugglers on a ranch 100 miles south of Texas. They refuse to pay extortion fees and are executed. The survivor, shot in the neck, hears their screams for mercy as he flees. After a gun battle with the authorities, the killers escape in S.U.V.s. The dead, 58 men and 14 women, are found piled in a room, discarded contraband.

description: Belleville and biennial are two words that are rarely seen together. While the first is the name of a colorful, but mostly run-down neighborhood on the eastern side of Paris, the other evokes international art events that gather the crme de la crme of contemporary art.

description: AXA, the giant French insurer and once the largest shareholder in Goldman Sachs, cut its holdings in the investment bank in half over the last quarter as Goldman was plagued by the threat of a long legal battle with the Securities and Exchange Commission, The Financial Times reported.

description: Swedens Financial Supervisory Authority revoked HQ Banks license to operate and applied for its liquidation, saying the company broke regulations.

title: How Do You React to News of Natural Disasters?
description: This weekend was the fifth anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, but this summer the floods in Pakistan have been front-page news, with nearly 20 million people significantly affected. Meanwhile, in Haiti, hundreds of displaced families from the January earthquake are still living in shanties. When you read or hear news of large-scale suffering and devastation like this, how do you react? Why? Why do you think some disasters get more coverage  and more attention and help from individuals  than others?

title: Cisco Rumored to Make Offer for Skype
description: Cisco has reportedly made an offer to acquire the Internet phone firm Skype before it completes its planned initial public offering, TechCrunch said.

Depressed? This is not like her.

title: Now Stitching | Brooklyn Shirting Gallery
description: Epaulet makes custom shirts, selvage jeans and corduroys in a shade of lime called go-to-hell green. Welcome to D.I.Y.-crazed Brooklyn. The emphasis at this modest Cobble Hill storefront is on fabric and fit: Epaulets button-fly chinos (from $135) have inspired cultish devotion because they fit snugly, like a perfect pair of jeans. We run on the Louis Vuitton model, says Michael Kuhle, who opened the store two years ago with his wife, Adele Berne. We never do markdowns because all our stuff sells out. Their latest offering is an urban safari shirt (above; $245) created with Hamilton, the Houston-based heritage label. It has easy-to-roll-up sleeves, the better to show off a wry tattoo. Go to epauletshop.com.

title: Revel Yelp
description: For those whove never had the opportunity to party like a rock star and felt like they were missing out, Please Take Me Off the Guest List (Akashic Books) may very well smooth over those regrets. A collaboration between the writer (and singer and Beauty Bar Brooklyn bartender) Zachary Lipez, the photographer (and Yeah Yeah Yeahs guitarist) Nick Zinner and the designer (and former design director of Artforum) Stacy Wakefield, the book chronicles the side effects of a hyperactive night life, including rambling cocaine narratives, a job as a disgruntled clerk at the Strand bookstore and the joys of being sent to fetch a straw from the bodega for your girlfriends morning P.B.R. I call dibs on the indefensible, Lipez says. Sobriety may not figure, but when consciousness raises its head, it is acerbic, anarchic and definitely not for the faint of heart.

title: New Uses for an Old Plug
description: Do you know about that data port in your car? Of course you dont. But as of 1996, all cars sold in the United States have had to have an on-board diagnostics port that can give technicians information on the performance of various automotive subsystems. It is usually located under the steering wheel. This is a way for mechanics narrow down what is wrong with a car when the check engine light comes on.

title: Egyptian Culture Minister Talks With Prosecutors in van Gogh Theft
description: Farouk Hosni, Egypts minister of culture, said he had been questioned by prosecutors as an investigation continues into the theft of a valuable van Gogh painting from a museum in Giza this month, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Hosni said he volunteered for the interrogation, which took more than three hours on Sunday night, to counter accusations that his negligence had been responsible for the theft. The van Gogh, known as Poppy Flowers or Vase and Flowers and valued at more than $50 million, was taken on Aug. 21 from the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum, where it hung in a room with only some working cameras and no working alarms. Mr. Hosni said that day that the painting had been recovered at the Cairo airport, then had to retract that statement, saying it was based on faulty information.

title: A Cathedral to the Shrine of Nature
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.  The view from the cathedral-size windows of the $27 million visitor center that opened here last week leads down a paved path toward a gently curved mound of rock. A mist of hissing steam drifts from the mound, but every 90 minutes or so, water starts to spurt fitfully, then more aggressively, until it erupts into a tower as high as 180 feet, whose spray may be spread by the breeze toward the hundreds of viewers gathered to watch the spectacle.

title: Now Booking | Tasmanian Angel
description: With its otherworldly beauty and back-of-beyond remoteness, the Australian island of Tasmania has enjoyed its status at the vanguard of far-flung travel for many years now. That adventurers who make the journey had to be content with a cozy cabin only added to the mystique. So the June opening of Saffire Freycinet, on the eastern end of the islands Freycinet peninsula, puts a certain wrinkle in the places rustic authenticity. But in a good way. Though the property is packed full of features, like hydraulic flat-screen TVs and radiant-heated marble floors, that have come to signify modern luxury, Freycinets design complements the surrounding landscape and respects the islands natural resources.

title: A Closer Look at the Second Quarter G.D.P.
description: On Friday, the Bureau of Economic Analysis  reported a downward revision in the second quarter growth in the gross domestic product to 1.6 percent, from 2.4 percent. While the headline number was bad, the devil is in the details. The downward revision does not signal a new contraction or a double-dip recession. Instead, this revision demonstrates how one component of group that comprises a macro-statistic like the G.D.P. can skew the numbers.

title: Plans for Print-Free Oxford Dictionary Arent Fully Defined
description: The Oxford English Dictionary defines the word clarify as To free from darkness or gloom; to light up, illumine; to brighten (in an appearance of the word dating back to 1398) and To make clear (an obscure subject) (in a coinage from 1823), among other usages. And thats what representatives of the O.E.D. did in a statement released Monday after remarks by its chief executive were interpreted to mean that the venerable reference work would be not be released in a paper format for its coming third edition.

title: Qaddafi Sets Up Camp Again in Rome
description: ROME  Less than a year after his last visit, when he invited 200 aspiring models to convert to Islam, the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has pitched his well-known tent in Rome for a two-day media blitz. This time around, the colonel, who has ruled Libya since 1969, had coffee in downtown Rome after delivering a lecture about Islam to 500 young women chosen by a modeling agency. Islam, he said, should be Europes primary religion. (Italian media outlets reported that three of the women converted on the spot.)
